Bobby Bartels of Astoria, Queens, who has won eleven of his sixteen professional fights, will meet Jackie Matesic of Pittsburgh in the feature bout listed for eight rounds tonight at the St. Nicholas Arena. The St. Nicks card is the only one scheduled in New York this week.

Jerry Tallmer, drama critic of The Village Voice, will receive the George Jean Nathan Award in Drama Criticism for the 1960-61 season. The Village Voice is a weekly newspaper published in Greenwich Village.

HANNOVER, West Germany, April 15 (AP)--West Germany rallied to defeat Spain, 14--6, in rugby today.

STRATFORD-ON-AVON, England, April 17--"Midsummer Night's Dream" opened here tonight to hearty laughter at the Royal Shakespeare Theatre. It was the second of six plays to be presented this season.

A record number of potato futures contracts--6,132 carlots--changed hands yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Prices closed off 9 points (hundredths of a cent a pound) to up 1 point. The May contract was weakest.
The Pennsylvania State Public School Building Authority borrowed $26,430,000 in the bond market yesterday to finance the construction of buildings to be leased to local school districts.

Consumer boycotts organized by Negro groups have attracted a lot of attention of late. The boycotts have been directed against merchants and manufacturers who were allegedly pursuing discriminatory practices.

WHITE PLAINS, April 17-- Automobiles on highways, oil burners in homes, bonfires in back yards and smokestacks of large factories and incinerators came under intensive study in Westchester County today as potential sources of dangerous air pollution.
The Joint Defense Appeal opened its 1962 campaign last night for $6,100,000 to help combat bigotry and prejudice and to promote democratic liberties.
WASHINGTON, April 17-- Members of Congress joined publishers today in denouncing a House-approved increase in magazine and newspaper postal rates.

A PENNY-SAVING practice shoppers might find worth investigating is the purchase of day-old baked products. Breads, rolls, cakes and cookies, not sold on the first day they are offered, may be obtained in some outlets on the second day at prices that have been reduced from 25 to 50 per cent.

LONDON, April 18--Prices again moved indecisively and narrowly on the market here today. On average, the leading equities finished slightly dearer and the Financial Times industrial index rose 0.4, to 298.6.

The short interest on the New York Stock Exchange in the month ended on April 13 increased to 3,205,840 shares from 3,119,209 shares on March 15. This was the highest since Dec. 15, 1961, when the total was 3,406,805 shares.

Sales of the Reynolds Metals Company were a record of $136,813,000 for the first quarter of 1962, Richard S. Reynolds Jr., president, reported at the annual meeting in Richmond, Va., yesterday. This was 25 per cent above the volume of $108,949,000 for the 1961 period.

MASSENA, N.Y., April 18 (AP)--The target date for the opening of the 1962 season of the St. Lawrence Seaway has been advanced to April 24, Seaway officials announced today. The opening was delayed by a long crack in the Eisenhower Lock.

ALTHOUGH the playing career of Red Schoendienst had come to an end and he was formally designated as a coach, he still took batting practice during spring training in St. Pete. KNOXVILLE, Tenn., April 18 --A total of $140,000 in damages was awarded today to Oak Ridge plant workers who were exposed to large dosages of radiation in an accident at the Y-12 plant in Oak Ridge nearly three years ago. They had sought $950,000.
ALBANY, April 18--Lincoln's handwritten draft of his Emancipation Proclamation will go on public display in the state tomorrow for the first time in twelve years.
MOSCOW, April 18 (AP)-- Informed sources reported today that Vasily J. Stalin, son of the late Soviet dictator, died a few days ago in Kazan, capital of the Tatar Autonomous Republic.

New orders received by manufacturers of durable goods declined by 4 per cent in March from the February level, after adjustment for normal seasonal variations, the Commerce Department reported yesterday.

CLARK, N.J., April 21--Mr. and Mrs. Russell G. Schaar have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Barbara J. Schaar, to William B. Simons, son of the Rev. and Mrs. Harvey B. Simons of Shamokin, Pa.

The rights of individuals who appear before legal tribunals are discussed by Edward Bennett Williams, trial lawyer, in his forthcoming book "One Man's Freedom."
Treatment with female sex hormones appears to cut in half the death rate among men who have recovered from heart attacks, a new five-year study disclosed yesterday.

IN front of St. Patrick's Cathedral in this Sunday's Easter parade, brilliantly colored paper daisies will be spotted throughout the crowd. Attached to hats or the back of barrettes, they will distinguish local adherents of an organization known as Women Strike for Peace.

WASHINGTON, April 18 (AP)--Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, a hearing aid concealed in the frames of her glasses, said today that the price of hearing aids "must come down" if the devices are to be of value to a great many people.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, April 18--Hopes for a speedy diplomatic settlement with the Netherlands of the West New Guinea dispute dimmed in Jakarta, today as President Sukarno's top military spokesman announced that Indonesia's armed forces were ready to attack.
An appeal for "harmony and understanding" in the school system was made yesterday by Dr. John J. Theobald, the Superintendent of Schools.

PHILADELPHIA, April 18 (UPI)--Bob Skinner's three-run homer in the fifth and three-hit relief pitching by Earl Francis carried Pittsburgh to a 4-3 victory over the Philadelphia Phillies tonight. The unbeaten Pirates now boast a winning streak of seven.
Record first-quarter sales and earnings were achieved by the R.J. Reynolds Tobacco Company, it was reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 18 (AP)--The General Accounting Office, at the request of a House subcommittee, has started looking into Billie Sol Estes' operations in Texas.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., April 18 (AP)--The rebuilt Wheeler Dam lock on the Tennessee River in North Alabama was opened today to commercial barge traffic, the Tennessee Valley Authority reported.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 18 (UPI)--Aristotle Onassis' yacht Christina, with Sir Winston Churchill aboard, arrived here today for a three-day stay. Mr. Onassis left the ship at Crete to tend to business affairs but will rejoin Sir Winston later.
CHICAGO, April 18--Dr. Sharat Jumar Roy, chief curator at the Chicago Natural History Museum and an expert on meteorites and volcanoes, died yesterday in Billings Hospital. He was 64 years old.
BONN, Germany, April 18-- Dean Heinrich Grueber, an Evangelical churchman from Berlin, asserts it is a "shame" that West Germany still withholds diplomatic recognition from Israel.

WASHINGTON, April 18-- George P. McGovern, director of the Food for Peace program, announced today that he would run for a seat in the United States Senate from South Dakota.

The wholesale commodity price index was unchanged Tuesday from 82.4 Monday. The index, compiled by the Bureau of Labor Statistics, stood at 87.3 on April 12, 1961.

ELIZABETH, N.J., April 18 --The owner of a liquor store and a man tentatively identified as a patron were killed tonight by two men who rifled the cash register of an unknown amount of money and fled.

He said that the Administration recognized steel's need for profits and said that his policies had been aimed at improving "both profits and incentives to invest." The City of New York yesterday opened officially the port's newest waterside terminal--a $1,400,000 combination overwater parking garage, seaplane base and pleasure boat marina. The installation is on the East River at Twenty-third Street.

Production of electric power totaled 15,600,000,000 kilowatthours in the week ended April 14, the Edison Electric Institute reported yesterday. This compared with 15,569,000,000 kilowatt-hours in the preceding week and 14,434,000,000, kilowatt-hours in the comparable week a year ago.

MANILA, April 18 (AP)-- The Philippine Supreme Court voided today President Diosdado Macapagal's order impounding $20,000,000 worth of Virginia tobacco imported from the United States.

CINCINNATI, April 18 (UPI) The Cincinnati Reds backed Jim O'Toole's four-hit pitching with a fifteen-hit attack tonight in walloping the Los Angeles Dodgers, 14--0.

Rose O'Neill, Bert Martin's $10,000 claim, returned to the familiar precincts of the Aqueduct winner's circle yesterday.
Gen. Barksdale Hamlett, Vice Chief of Staff of the Army, said here yesterday that the Army was convinced that a practical defense weapon against intercontinental ballistic missiles was obtainable.

An unusual Portuguese rose wine now is being imported into this country by the Franconia Import Company. Unlike most natural wines from that country, it comes from the mountainous northern region, specifically the Duoro River Valley.
ST. LOUIS, April 18 (AP) --A step toward heart surgery outside the body was reported today by four Stanford University surgeons.

HONG KONG, April 18-- Marshal Chen Yi, Foreign Minister of Communist China, said in Peiping tonight that the Asian and African peoples had been "advancing from victory to victory" since the Bandung Conference but still faced "serious tasks of struggle."

WASHINGTON, April 18-- President Kennedy announced today that the International Airline Pilots' Association and Pan American World Airways, Inc., had agreed to binding arbitration on how jet cockpit crews would be cut from four men to three.

Families gathered around the table in Jewish homes last night for the Seder, the ceremonial meal that opens Passover, the week-long festival that commemorates the liberation of the ancient Israelites from Egyptian slavery.

MOSCOW, April 18 (AP)-- Leading Soviet scientists paid tribute to William Wallace Campbell, the American astronomer, on the centenary of his birth, which fell today.
SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, April 18 (AP)-- The Dominican Republic said last night it had uncovered a plot by four former air force officers to overthrow the Government.
WASHINGTON, April 18-- Two Army Reservists charged with breaches of military discipline were granted clemency today by President Kennedy.

WASHINGTON, April 18 (AP)--Representative Ray J. Madden of Indiana was elected chairman of the new House Democratic Steering Committee today. The twenty-fourmember committee elected as its secretary Rpresntative Leonor K. Sullivan of Missouri.

PULASKI, N.Y., April 18 (AP)--Fire destroyed the fortysix room Randall Hotel early today. Twelve persons were in the building when the fire started, but all escaped without injuries. The fire began in a kitchen area, but the cause was not determined.
BERLIN, April 18 (UPI) --An East German, mortally wounded by Communist gunfire, drove a three-ton dump truck through the Berlin wall today at a speed of 60 miles an hour.

Mr. [Alfred Kazin]'s new compendium of critical essays, "Contemporaries" (Little, Hrown) contains his criticisms of Puerto Ricans. When he was teaching Eng lish at the university in Rio Pieciras, his students refused to visualize the New England landscape or wintery weather. He regards Puerto Ricans as "docile" and "inert." He found life dull in Puerto Rico. After the ice-cream cart with its " and gluey" music passed down the street in the morning, Mr. Kazin observed that "the of the long day takes over." "With Puerto Ricans," he reports, "one finds oneself dis cussing their feelings and sufferings, never their ideas and their hopes." There have been notable ex ceptions to the docility Mr. Kazin found in Puerto Ricans. Charles A. Halleclt does not regard them as docile. Bullet holes in his desk remind him every day of the aggressiveness of a hand ful of Puerto Ricans who sprayed the House of Repre sentatives with gun-fire on March 1, 1cJ54. Last year Puerto Ricans rioted against a troupe of mainland actors and set fire to the lovely Tapia Theatre in the Plaza de Col6n; and the Govern ment had to post a police guard around the house in which Harry Yellen, the New Yorlt producer, was living with his family.

The work brigade operates Cording to a plan. First come: the cleaning, then the repainting and finally the "re-bulbing." During "re-bulbing," a finishing touch that involves more than a million electric light bulbs, old bulbs are tested. If they work, they are washed, polished apd returned to their sockets. New bulbs are wiped before they ate installed. It was but one of several cleaning tips that may give com fort to householders about to embark on their own dreary duels with the dust and dirt. Mrs. Cook is loyal to detergents --"They don't streak the way soaps do"-and systematic work procedures--"Finish one area completely before moving on to the next." "We don't do our own win dows," Mrs. Ceok continued. "Au outside cleaner comes in every four days when the park is open -every day for buildings with glass enclosures."

The Marines have also feat ed that the new command might' tend to tape over the tradi tional functions of the Marine) Corps, particularly the mission assigned to the corps by Con gressional legislation-the de velopment of amphibious tech niques. Tlte D-Iarines maintain a De velopment Center at Ritantico; Va., that studies, tests and evolves and equipment, doctrine and tactics. The Navy develops amphibious craft at the Amphibious Training Com mand at Little Creels, Va. This command would operate and supervise the Combat Develop ment Experimentation Center at Fort Ord, Calif" which has been operating for some years, and outer Army development :s.

WASHINGTON, April 19 (UPI)--Two airliners with a total of sixty-one persons aboard had a brush with death for forty-two minutes recently when they were accidentally assigned to the same "holding" altitude in a thick overcast.
KLM Royal Dutch Airlines reported yesterday that it had a net loss of $21,300,000 in 1961 and therefore would not pay a dividend on the common shares.

RACINE, Wis., April 19 (AP)--Stockholders of the struggling J.I. Case Company gave overwhelming approval today to a drastic proposal of the company's new executive officers that reduced the par value of common stock from $12.50 to $1 a share.
MONTLUCON, France, April 19 (AP)--Jacques Chevalier, Education Minister in the Vichy Government, during World War II, died today in the house where he was born eighty years ago.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, April 19--President Moise Tshombe of Katanga Province was permitted to return to Elisabethville today after the United Nations, which had guaranteed his safety, forced Congolese officials to release his plane.
EDWARDS AIR FORCE BASE, Calif., April 19 (AP)-- Joe Walker flew the X-15 rocket plane 3,920 miles an hour today in a warm-up for an attempt to soar almost fifty miles into space.

TORONTO, April 19 (UPI)-- Sparked by Bob Pulford's three goals, the Toronto Maple Leafs routed the Chicago Black Hawks, 8--4, tonight and took a 3-2 lead in the Stanley Cup play-off finals. The four-of-seven-game series resumes in Chicago Sunday night.
CINCINNATI, April 19 (AP) --The Los Angeles Dodgers halted rallies in the third and eighth innings tonight and scored a 4-3 victory over the Cincinnati Reds.

She has also been the head of and, in recent decades, the peer among equals of a group of countries stretching around the world.

CHICAGO, April 22 (AP)The Kansas City Athletics defeated the Chicago White Sox, 7-1, and 7-5, in a double-header today and stretched their winning streak to four games. It equaled the Athletics' longest victory string of last season.

TABLE linens are one of the main household victims of the machine age, according to many New York homemakers. They complain that commercial laundries often return cloths with frayed, uneven edges, faded colorings and tired, stretched fibers.
In parks, playgrounds, shopping centers and auditoriums, thousands of worshipers attended sunrise Easter services in the metropolitan area.
New York's warmest Easter Sunday on record brought out throngs of Easter paraders and more throngs of peoplewatchers all over the city yesterday.
COCOA BEACH, Fla., April 22--Ranger IV, a 730-pound spacecraft equipped to take television pictures of the moon, is scheduled to be launched from Cape Canaveral tomorrow.
Edward Drozniak, the Polish Ambassador to the United States said yesterday that that Polish Jews had every opportunity to develop their cultural, social and relgious lives.

WASHINGTON, April 22--It was peaceful at the White House on the afternoon of Tuesday, April 10--so peaceful that the President of the United States thought he might have time for a nap or a little relaxed reading.
GENEVA, April 22-With a four-day Easter week-end ahead, the Swiss stocks markets idled during most of last week's four sessions. The markets were closed Friday and will not reopen until Tuesday.
SAN ANTONIO, Tex., April 22 (UPI)-The police booked a 23-year-old Trinity University freshman today on Charges that he killed his stepfather, Count Ivan C. Podgoursky, 61 years old.

Fixed ideas about what American products can or cannot be sold abroad are being profitably exploded by United States trade promotions in London.

PAL BENKO, who fled from Hungary, has garnered many chess titles since he came to this country about five years ago. He and Bobby Fischer will represent the United States at the Candidates Tournament at Curacao, Netherlands West Indies, which begins May 2.
TRENTON, Ga., April 22 (AP) -One hundred persons searched two caves and a mountainside today for three college students who disappeared on a cave expedition.

President Kennedy is at a high point in popular support, according to a consensus of newspaper publishers and executives from around the country who arrived here yesterday for the city's annual Press Week.
SEATTLE, April 22--The president of the New York World's Fair used the newly opened Seattle World's Fair today as a platform for applauding this city's spirit and deploring Eastern "bickering."
The medical training ship Hope will leave from San Francisco the first week in May on a medical mission in Peru.

CHICAGO, April 22 (UPI)Goals by Bob Nevin and Dick Duff in the last ten minutes tonight enabled the Toronto Maple Leafs to beat the Chicago Black Hawks, 2-1, for their first Stanley Cup championship since 1951.
WASHINGTON, April 22-- The Senate is scheduled to touch off a talking match Tuesday over the Administration's major civil rights proposal for this session.
NEW ORLEANS, April 22 (AP)--Leander H. Perez Sr., who was excommunicated by the Roman Catholic Church last Monday for segregationist activities, attended Easter Sunday mass without incident today.
JERUSALEM (Jordanian Sector), April 22--Christians from over the world crowded into the old walled City of Jerusalem today for religious celebrations.

An actor with no desire to play Shakespeare, a comedian who does not try consciously to be funny and a complex man who sees himself as uncomplicated has succeeded in becoming one of the brightest new faces of the entertainment world.
North Vietnam is pushing ahead with an industrialization program this year, the Hanoi radio indicates.
HAVANA, April 22 (AP)-- Christians and Communists observed different holidays in Cuba today. The Christians went to church in large numbers; the Communists paid homage to Lenin.
MOSCOW, April 29--A leading Soviet ideologist defended the Khrushchev regime today against critics of its domestic and foreign policies by asserting: "Our party is acting in the Leninist way."

WASHINGTON, April 22-- The Joint Congressional Committee on Atomic Energy reported today that nearly three years of research had brought "no material progress" toward an effective method of detecting clandestine underground nuclear tests.
Young readers will soon be able to leave the world of Bugs Bunny and Mickey Mouse for the literary kingdom of Marianne Moore, Randall Jarrell and Isak Dinesen.
THE following menu is suggested as a guide to the use of foods that are reasonable in cost. A recipe is given for an economical main dish.

The First Republic Corporation of America, a realty concern, has leased an entire floor with 15,000 square feet in 530 Fifth Avenue at Forty-fourth Street for executive offices. The rentals aggregate about $1,500,000. Matthew J. Stacom, vice president of Cushman Wakefield,...

NEW ORLEANS, April 22 (UPI)--The New Orleans Citizens Council will ask the Louisiana Legislature for $100,000 to finance "freedom trains" to send Negroes to Northern cities, a council spokesman said today.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 22--A powerful nation could bankrupt the United Nations by refusing to contribute to peace-keeping activities of the organization, U Thant, the Acting Secretary General, said today.

MONTREAL, April 22 (Canadian Press) -- The outlook in shipping circles here brightened during the Easter week-end following an announcement that the opening of the St. Lawrence Seaway, delayed for a week by a damaged lock, would take place tomorrow, a day earlier than expected.

PARIS, April 22--With minimum fanfare the largest United States air base in Arabian western Asia was closed at the beginning of this month. This was the installation at Dhahran, Saudi Arabia, now turned over to King Saud's entire control.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 22-Eleven students from the University of Southern California, directed by Fred Zinnemann, have made a movie that may set a pattern for training American film talent.

Solomon Pimsleur, composer and pianist, died yesterday in his home, 500 West 114th Street, after a short illness. His age was 61.

ALGIERS, April 22--Heavy explosions tonight destroyed the two printing presses of L'Echo d'Alger, Algeria's largest newspaper. The newspaper's other mechanical departments were heavily damaged by fire.
Demand continued last week for better dresses, raincoats and sportswear, including wraparound skirts and stretch denim pants, resident buying offices here reported.
Engineering concerns were among tenants signing leases for new offices in deals reported yesterday.
The new $35,000,000 passenger liner now being built for Home Lines will be named the Oceanic when she is launched in Italy this summer, the line announced here yesterday.

Ever since the advent of television, drug commercials have followed a hard-sell pattern. Tablets have tumbled through intestinal tracts, sinuses have drained, sledge-hammers have crashed against skulls and, at the end, there was the usual promise of fast, fast, FAST relief.
Mayor Wagner moved yesterday to stem rising unrest among large groups of city employes dissatisfied with their pay and working conditions.
Three young New Yorkers are planning an expedition to a primitive region of Brazil and Venezuela that is fraught with taboos, superstitions and hostility among its tribes.
LAS VEGAS, Nev., April 22 (AP)-Carlos Ortiz, the new lightweight champion of the world, said today he would fight anyone-"for the right kind of money."

EASTER is the traditional day for something new, and television rose to the occasion yesterday by introducing two contemporary oratorios. Maurice Jacobson's "The Hound of Heaven" was presented on Channel 2 in the morning, and Earl Wild's "Revelation" followed a few hours later on Channel 7.
PALM BEACH, Fla., April 22 (UPI)--President Kennedy spent Easter today with his wife, two children and a few friends who joined him on a brief afternoon yacht cruise.

Robert Montgomery, the actor, who directed Joseph Hayes' "The Desperate Hours," which was put on for 213 performances in 1955, will stage "Calculated Risk," another work by the same playwright. The play will be produced this fall by Mr. Hayes and Howard Erskine, sponsors of "The Desperate Hours."
ALBANY, April 22--Governor Rockefeller announced today that he had signed the bill authorizing New York City to speed the collection of its gross receipts tax on business.
Four new films are scheduled to arrive in local theatres this week. The programs follow:
WASHINGTON, April 22-- Governor Rockefeller said today that the New York City teachers' strike showed that Mayor Wagner was having a "pretty tough time" running the city.
WASHINGTON, April 23 (UPI) A special survey by the Federal Aviation Agency shows most of the nation's airports illequipped for medical emergencies.

HOUSTON, April 23 (AP) Bobby Nichols, after recovering strongly from a bad tee shot, sank an 8-foot putt for an eagle 3 on the nineteenth hole of a scheduled 18-hole play-off today to win $9,000 in top money in the $50,000 Houston Classic golf tournament.

Despite significantly increased investments since Jan. 1 in higher-yielding tax-exempt securities, Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company predicted yesterday its 1962 earn ings would be less than last year's.

WASHINGTON, April 23--The conductor took up his baton, turned back once again to assure quiet from his youthful audience and directed the ninety-six-piece orchestra to begin Handel's overture to the Water Music suite.

WASHINGTON, April 23 (AP) The Kohler Company of Wisconsin appealed to the Supreme Court today from a decision that it had prolonged a strike begun on April 5, 1954, by Local 833 of the United Auto Workers.

WASHINGTON, April 23--Treasury bills rates rose on today's sale of the regular weekly issues. It was the second consecutive weekly increase. The rates have been alternately rising and falling all year for spells of not more than two weeks.
Four universities in upstate New York announced yesterday plans to work with sixteen public school systems in a fouryear experimental program of high school reform.
UDON, Thailand, April 14 A race against time is under way in the primitive, underdeveloped northeast of Thailand.

Capt. Phineas B. Blanchard, board chairman of the National Association of Stevedores and from 1939 to 1941 president of the Maritime Association of the Port of New York, died yesterday at his home, 7802 Ridge Boulevard, Brooklyn. His age was 83.
CHICAGO, April 23--Dr. Karl Barth, Swiss Protestant theologian, began an explanation of his faith today in the first of five lectures.
WASHINGTON, April 23-- The Supreme Court told Michigan's Supreme Court today to take another look at the fairness of that state's legislative districts.
WASHINGTON, April 23 A Labor Department report today showed wide variations from state to state in the family characteristics of the long-term unemployed.

MOSCOW, April 23 (Reuters) Guy Burgess, former British diplomat who defected to the Soviet Union, said today that the British Government obtained a warrant for his arrest last week partly because it was "terrified" of his possible return to England.

Prices, profits and public relations are among the key subjects the directors of the United States Steel Corporation will have on their minds as they gather for their regular meeting this afternoon at 71 Broadway, the New York command post for the nation's largest steel producer.

The Defense Department's new program world readjust force structures and eliminate eight of the thirty-seven existing National Guard and Reserve divisions. It has already encountered strong and justifiable criticism in Congress.

THE beaded curtain, which often is associated with the antics of yesterday's movie sirens, the clutter of the Victorian era and the doorways of small foreign shops, is becoming increasingly popular in contemporary New York interiors.
WASHINGTON, April 23 (AP) The Department of Commerce announced today a major move to improve the data used in calculating the United States balance of payments position.

LONGXUYEN, Vietnam, April 23 Provincial authorities charged today that a band of Cambodian soldiers had destroyed a village on the South Vietnamese border, killing fifty-two inhabitants and wounding twenty-two.

Harry Delmar, who was known in the last Nineteen Twenties and early Thirties for his revues called "Delmar's Reveals," has joined forces with Mickey Alpert to re-create one of them for Broadway next fall. Naturally, it will be called "Harry Delmar's Revels."

AN authority on one of literature's liveliest arts holds stage center throughout "Raymond Chandler Speaking," ad mirably edited by Dorothy Gardiner and Kathrine Sorley Walker. Truth becomes as entertaining as Chandler's fiction.
The recent revelation that a major manufacturer has stopped making separate collars for men' shirts obviously marks the passing of an era.

PAU, France, April 23 Maurice Trintignant of France, a ripe old 45 and Mayor of a town in Provence, easily won the 171-mile Grand Prix of Pau today. It was the third time he had won this race and he set a record doing it. His average speed was 64.5 miles an hour.
PARIS, April 23 (AP) Gen. Count Aldebert de Chambrun, a descendant of the Marquis de Lafayette, died last night at his home. He was 89 years old.
DETROIT, April 25 (AP) The auto industry last week achieved a record one-week production for the year. The usual holiday lull did not occur.
WASHINGTON, April 23 The White House lawn took its annual egg beating today at the hands of thousands of shrieking youngsters and assorted adults.
Potato futures prices closed unchanged to off 6 points (hundredths of a cent a pound) on the New York Mercantile Exchange yesterday.

A dispute between "The Sound of Music" and the owners of the Lunt-Fontanne Theatre, Cy Feuer and Ernest Martin, has been settled out of courtTerms of the settlement were approved by State Supreme Court Justice Samuel M. Gold.
CINCINNATI, April 23 (AP) Billy Pierce, a 35-year-old American League cast-off, held Cincinnati to seven hits tonight in pitching the San Francisco Giants to a 4-1 victory over the Reds.
WASHINGTON, April 23 Five scientists received Ernest O. Lawrence Memorial Awards today for contributions to nuclear science.
Del Benjamin of La Salle Academy set a national schoolboy record for sophomores yesterday when he high-jumped 6 feet 7 inches at the sixth annual All Hallows Games at Van Cortlandt Park, the Bronx.
The expansion of the news service of The Associated Press and plans for further automation of its operations were described yesterday at the annual meeting of the news cooperative.
The lower West Side site of the Washington market may be used for an all-industrial complex in place of the combination of commercial and industrial units that had been originally planned.

IF "Alcestis Comes Back" were as inventive and sus tained as its basic idea is clever, it might be that rare theatrical achievement a lively modern variation on a classic theme.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., April 23 Dr. Eugene Calvelli Sr., believed to have been the first cardiologist to practice in Nassau County, died today at his home after a brief illness. His age was 70. He lived at 82 Country Club Drive.

CHICAGO, April 23 (UPI)--A Federal court today enjoined a conductors' strike against Pullman facilities on the "Nation's railroads, and a Presidential order barred a threatened strike of telegraphers against the Chicago and North Western Railway.
LOS ANGELES, April 23 (UPI) Undefeated Cassius Clay scored a fourth-round knockout over George Logan tonight in the main event on a four-fight boxing card at the Sports Arena.
The tenants at 226 East Third Street have petitioned the Temporary State Housing Rent Commissiton to allow their landlord to charge then the highest rents possible under the law.

PITTSBURGH, April 23 The New York Mets, $2,400,000 worth of assembled hope, won their first major league game tonight. Praise be, and on to Cincinnati....Who can fear pennant-winners at a time like this?
BUENOS AIRES, April 23 President Jose Maria Guido was considering tonight a decree calling for a takeover by the Federal Government of the administration of all Argentina's provincial:

GREENWICH.,Conn., April 23 In St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church here this morning Miss Elizabeth Baldwin, daughter of Mrs. George Willis Baldwin and the late Dr. Baldwin, became the bride of David Walker Jayne 3d, son of Mr. Jayne Jr. of Stamford and Mrs. Lucille Francis Jayne of Old Greenwich.

A 26-year-old painter on the way up and a 38-year-old splicer in a hole, a youngster gasping for air and an old man who had just tasted defeat were among several dozen New Yorkers who paused yesterday to discuss always with kindness and never with scorn the city's champion losers, the Mets.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 23 A widespread rebellion by Kurdish tribesmen against the armed forces of Premier Abdul Karim Kassim is raging in the mountains of northern Iraq.
Prices of United States Government securities and prime corporate bonds moved lower yesterday in a slack trading session.
The forty-fifth year of the Stadium Concerts will begin Tuesday night, June 26. Among the six conductors who will lead most of the scheduled twenty-eight outdoor concerts is Antonio de Almeida.
A 6-year-old girl who hoped to become a pianist lost four fingers last night after she slipped and fell on a subway escalator and caught her hands in the grillwork.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 23 U Thant, Acting Secretary General, said today that the inclusion of a statement by East Germany in an official report to the Unitec Nations Disarmament Commission contained no implication on "the legal status and the international position of East Germany."
A new process for retreading tires, was announced yesterday by the W.J. Voit Rubber Corporation of Los Angeles, tread rubber manufacturing subsidiary of the American Machine and Foundry Company.

The American Maritime Association yesterday asked Attorney General Robert F. Kennedy to begin an immediate anti-trust investigation of a plan by nine major oil companies to build a 1,600-mile pipeline to transport petroleum products from Houston, Tex., to Linden, N.J.
Merry Ruler returned to his stakes-winning form of last year by taking the Toboggan Handicap at Aqueduct yesterday.

ONE of the more venerable of the Casey Stengel stories concerns the time he was managing the hopeless Dodgers a quarter of a century ago. His maladroit Brooks had just kicked away a double-header to the Cincinnati Reds in slightly unbelievable fashion when OP Case dropped into the hotel barber shop.

Ninety executives of overseas advertising agencies arrived here yesterday to exchange ideas with American agency officials and their discussions indicated that, no matter where they work, ad men had basically the same worries.

MIDDLETOWN, Conn., April 23 (AP) Mrs. Amy E. ArcherGilligan, who was convicted in 1917 for the arsenic murder of a patient in her nursing home at Windsor and sentenced to death, died today at the Connec ticut Valley Hospital. She was 89 years old.
CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Tuesday, April 24 A 730pound spacecraft, Ranger IV, was launched yesterday on a course expected to send it crashing into the moon Thursday morning.

ALBANY, April 23 Governor Rockefeller announced today the signing of a bill giving the New York City Transit Authority power to issue up to $93,000,000 in bonds to buy 724 subway cars. The authority plans to use its new power within two or three months.
The lawyer for John Henry Faulk charged yesterday that a self-appointed "vigilante" group had engaged in a conspiracy to link the former television commentator with communism.
F. Eberstadt Co. and associated underwriters are offering 480,000 common shares of Becton, Dickinson and Co. at $25 a share today. It is the first public offering of the stock.
Ricky Ortiz of Puerto Rico used a right-hand punch to advantage last night in outpointing Billy Bello of the Bronx in the main eight-round bout at the St. Nicholas Arena.

A general election is to take place in the Central African Federation on Friday. It was called by the federal Prime Minister, Sir Roy Welensky, who is going to "win" because only his followers in the United Federal party will go to the polls.
Steels dipped yesterday but again failed to pull the market as a whole into noticeably lower ground. Tobaccos and nonferrous metals were strong and most other major groups were mixed.

ANATOLY FYODOROVICH DOBRYNIN, the Soviet Union's new Ambassador in Washington, has been called the "most mixable" of Moscow's diplomats.

The Crowell-Collier Publishing Company is planning to expand into the professional magazine field through the proposed purchase of Grade Teacher, a seventy-nine-year-old magazine for elementary school teachers. The transaction would involve an undisclosed amount of cash, it was stated yesterday.

IN the current issue of Daedalus, which discusses "Sci ence and Technology in Contemporary Society," Walter J. Ong of St. Louis University argues for a new religious orientation. (Daedalus is the journal of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences.)
WASHINGTON, April 23 (UPI) Government officials are attempting to persuade the major construction unions not to make extravagant contract demands.

MANCHESTER, N.H., April 23 (AP) Forty-three trucking companies in New Hampshire and five in Vermont shut down operations today because the Teamsters Union called strikes against six of the companies in the two states.

WASHINGTON, April 23 United States and Soviet scientists have agreed on a proposal to establish a "world weather watch" consisting of a network of regional fore casting centers linked by meteorological satellites.

Revenues and net income of Pan American World Airways, Inc., for 1961 were the highest in the airline's thirty-four-year history, Juan T. Trippe, president, reported to stockholders yesterday in the annual statement.
MOSCOW, April 23 Soviet leaders have shown concern about the extent of corruption in their country.
On two Sundays next autumn, the Titans and the Giants will struggle head to head for New York's professional football patronage.

MARBLEHEAD Mass., April 23 The crewmen who will man the new Boston Yacht Club candidate for the defense of the America's Cup will have a wealth of yachting experience judging from the list of fifteen names released today.

WASHINGTON, April 23 (AP) The Supreme Court refused today to review a case in which evidence was obtained by a Federal alcohol tax agent who connected a midget tape recorder to his telephone earpiece when he talked with a prospective seller of bootleg whisky.
Opposition to the Government's proposal to withhold taxes on dividend income was voiced yesterday by Keith Funston, president of the New York Stock Exchange, in his quarterly report.
LONDON, April 23 Stirling Moss, Britain's leading auto racing driver, was in serious condition tonight after crashing at a speed of 105 miles an hour on the Goodwood race track in Sussex.
CHICAGO, April 23 (AP) Grain futures eased today after a slow, gradual climb from an early weakness on the Board of Trade.
The Indonesian Government has acquired the British liner Gunung Djati of the Blue Funnel Line. She will be the biggest passenger ship to fly Indonesia's flag.
Traffic Commissioner Henry A. Barnes trained his fire yesterday on another pet project of Robert Moses the proposed Mid-Manhattan Elevated Expressway.

WESTBURY, L.I., April 23 At a cost of $15,000 enough to keep a horse in oats for years Leader Pick, an outstanding 3-year-old pacer, was made eligible today to compete in the rich Messenger Stakes at Roosevelt Raceway on May 18.
The men who draw the nation's comic strips complained yesterday that people were losing their sense of humor.
The city's record budget for education was criticized at public hearings yesterday as failing to meet some of the schools' most pressing needs.

Mayor Wagner has asked Governor Rockefeller to veto four bills that would add more than $20,000,000 a year to the city's expenses by giving additional pension benefits to teachers, policemen and firemen.
DETROIT, April 23 The apportionment of the Michigan State Senate practically guar antees control of that body by rural Republicans.

A plot of vacant land 336 by 100 feet on the Boston Post Road, between Taylor's Lane and Greenhaven Road, in Mamaroneck, has been bought by Pleasantville Associates, Inc. a syndicate of investors. It was sold by Mary Concordia through, Peter C. Doern Jr., president of the Mamaroneck realty company bearing his name.

One of the large labor unions may provide a greater test of President Kennedy's mettle than the steel companies did, Merriman Smith, White House reporter for United Press International, said yesterday.

The Ukrainian Dance Company from Kiev will make its American debut tonight at the Metropolitan Opera House. The company of 100 includes seventy-nine dancers, ten instrumentalists, and a musical director.

The twelve-story office building at 52 Broadway, corner of Exchange Place from Broadbought for about $6,500,000 by the 52 Broadway Realty Company, of which the general partners are Louis Monas, Jack Fechter and Belle Bergner.
WASHINGTON, April 23 (AP) Katharyn Duff, assistant editor of the Abilene (Tex.) Reporter-News won the Thomas L. Stokes Award today for articles on conservation.

TRENTON, Ga., April 23 (AP) Three college students were rescued today alive and well from a mountain cave after they spent more than sixty hours huddled on a tiny ledge carved from mud.
WASHINGTON, April 23 Vice President Johnson reported today that nine major defence contractors had taken "corrective action" after complaints of racial discrimination had been filed against them.

Attorney General Robert F. Kennedy called yesterday for more Americans to go abroad to explain the United States' belief in individual freedom and its doctrine that "the state exists for the individual." This would dispel massive misunderstanding abroad, he added.
A Third Avenue saloonkeeper tomorrow night will don a tuxedo, hop into a chauffeurdriven Rolls-Royce, and be escorted to the New York Athletic Club for a testimonial dinner.
A five-alarm fire, officially described as suspicious, destroyed a box factory in Brooklyn last night.

An article in the current issue of Look magazine says that former President Dwight D. Eisenhower expressed misgivings about reconnaissance fights over the Soviet Union long before Francis Gary Powers was shot down on May 1, 1960.
CHICAGO, April 23 The Chicago Association of Commerce and Industry announced today that it had signed up twenty nations, which would be representative of five continents, for its trade fair.

WASHINGTON, April 23 The United States and the Soviet Union agreed today to conduct their formal negotiations on the Berlin dispute in Washington. However, it was unlikely that the talks would open before mid-May.

Narcotics addiction should be approached as if it were epidemic and treated like any other public health problem, according to Dr. Lewis Thomas, chairman of the Department of Medicine of the New York University of Medicine.
A circus tent big enough to accommodate a herd of elephants was pitched yesterday on grounds of the Museum of Modern Art, adjoining the Sculpture Garden.

ALGIERS, April 23 Gen. Michel Fourquet declared today that the French Army now had a sufficient number of troops in Oran to curtail the Secret Army Organization operations in the big Algerian port city.
As the day approaches for the resumption of nuclear testing in the atmosphere there is still the hope that somehow at the last moment some miracle might occur that would spare humanity this ordeal.

The American Bowling Congress' fifty-ninth annual tournament will end its sixty-nine-day run Thursday at Des Moines' Veterans Memorial Auditorium. It will close with a proud record of excellent competition, excellent scoring conditions and record shooting.

WASHINGTON, April 23 (UPI)--Government auditors said today that purchases by the military services of uniforms and cloth that turned out to be off-color or outdated had cost the taxpayers more than half a million dollars.

WASHINGTON, April 23 A National Labor Relations Board trial examiner said today that it was unfair labor practice for New York newspapers to agree to suspend publication when one of them was hit by a work stoppage in a grievance dispute with a craft union.
The Dodge Wire Corporation of Covington, Ga., has acquired some of the assets of United States Wire Cable Corporation of Union, N.J., it was announced yesterday. The terms were not disclosed.

EAST NORTHFIELD, Mass., April 23 Dr. Edmond S. Meany Jr., headmaster of the Northfield School for Girls, and Mrs. Meany have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Margaret Meany, to Stephen Winslow Keene.
A Congregational clergyman last night joined the reform Democratic candidates seeking to end Charles A. Buckley's 28year career as a member of Congress from the Bronx.
WASHINGTON, April 23 (AP)--The Supreme Court agreed today to review an antitrust case involving the White Motor Company and its distribution system.
PORT ARTHUR, Ontario, April 23 (Canadian Press) Despite peketing by the Seafarers International Union, grain started pouring into the holds of the 465-foot carrier Douglas Houghton here today.
Sales of the nation's leading retail store chains increased eight-tenths of 1 per cent in March from the 1961 level, according to a survey completed yesterday by The New York Times.
A week of dry weather and yesterday's high winds caused the spreading of brush and forest fires through much of the metropolitan area and adjoining country regions.
LUSAKA, Northern Rhodesia, April 23 Nine more Africans were reported to have been injured today as a weekend of political fighting spread from the copper belt to provinces in the north.
MOSCOW, April 23 They newly elected Supreme Soviet, the national Parliament, met today and arranged to hear a report on the negotiations in Geneva.

ARTICHOKES, those delectable and increasingly popular members of the thistle family, are available here the year round. Attention is called to them now because of the outstanding quality of current supplies. The leaves, or "bracts" as botanists call them, are plump and unblemished.
Following is the text of the 1962 annual report of the board of directors of The Associated Press, read yesterday at the annual meeting of The Associated Press:
A business man was accused yesterday of perjuring himself before the Temporary State Housing Rent Commission in connection with the alleged falsification of three rent-increase orders.
NEW DELHI, India, April 23 The Government presented a budget to Parliament today that called for increased taxes and greater emphasis on exports.
MONTREAL, April 23 (Canadian Press)--A steady stream of ships moved through the 185-mile St. Lawrence Seaway today as the long inland water system finally opened to traffic.

WASHINGTON, April 23 The Supreme Court's order today in the Michigan legislative apportionment issue preserves for eventual review a case on which the court could broaden the new assumption it made on March 26 of jurisdiction over internal political processes in the states.
BUENOS AIRES, April 23 Latin-American delegates criticized the Alliance for Progress today as the governors of the Inter-American Development Bank began their third annual meeting.

IF a woman were asked to pick the one kind of dress that she finds most useful, day after day, season after season, chances are that she would say it is a knit. For this reason, a shop that specializes in knits of all varieties has an important place on many women's shopping lists.

THE following might be called a neo-naturalis tic drama, or, viewed another way, a tragi-comedy in one act. It is titled "Morning Becomes Issac W. Everyman," or if the reader doesn't care for that, how about "Long Day's Journey into the Great Outdoors Together?"

Schweickart Co., a New York Stock Exchange member firm, faces a suspension from trading on any of the national stock exchanges of up to twelve months as a result of a settlement reached yesterday with the Securities and Exchange Commission.
WASHINGTON, April 23 (AP) The Federal Trade Commission strongly opposed today legislation to set up a system of resale price maintenance.
LONDON, April 23--A two-minute silence tonight before the blank facade of the United States Embassy, dominated by its great, brooding eagle, ended a British mass demonstration against nuclear arms.

Louis Boyd, the unemployed Negro Longshoreman who arrived here penniless from New Orleans Saturday with his wife and eight children, yesterday found a $100-a-week job, good prospects for a home and hundreds of well-wishers.
HAVANA, April 23 (UPI) A total of sixty Cubans in groups of three to five entered the Uruguayan Embassy in Havana today and were granted political asylum, according to reports here.
WASHINGTON, April 23 A group of Midwestern physicists reported today initial success in their program to build an atom smasher producing 1,000 times more particles than any such machine in existence.
The Allied Chemical Corporation expects a 5 to 10 per cent increase in sales this year over those of 1961, stockholders were told yesterday at the annual meeting.

Broadcasting magazine said yesterday the George Foster Peabody radio and television awards should be abolished because of last week's award to Newton N. Minow, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission. The trade publication is considered to reflect and uphold the views and interests of the broadcasting industry.

WILMINGTON, Del., April 23 Christ Protestant Episcopal Church, Christiana Hundred, was the setting this afternoon for the marriage of Miss Sarah MacLellan Sharp, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bayard Sharp of Centerville, to William S. Farish 3d. He is the son of Mrs. Hugo V. Neuhaus of Houston, Tex., and the late Mr. Farish Jr.
PRINCETON, N.J., April 23 Princeton Theological Seminary today began a fourteenmonth observance of the 150th anniversary of its founding on Aug. 12, 1812.

The board of the Hugoton Production Company declared a dividetnd of 40 cents a share on the new stock, payable on June 15 to holders of record of May 31. This would equal 80 cents a share on the old stock prior to a recent two-for-one split. The rate of disbursement on the old shares had been 75 cents.
NEW DELHI, India, April 23 India and Nepal said today that they had a "vital interest in each other's sovereignty, independence and territorial integrity."
Republican housing policies were stressed last night by Governor Rockefeller as he opened a drive to recruit 100,000 additional volunteers for this year's state campaign.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 23 The movie industry both union and management has called upon the Federal Government to pull Hollywood out of its slump.
NAIROBI, Kenya, April 23 (Reuters) A Kenya team driving a Volkswagen won the 3,000mile East African Safari today.
STRATFORD-ON-THEAVON, England, April 23 The Royal Shakespeare Theatre celebrated William Shakespeare's birthday tonight with a gay and robust production of "The Taming of the Shrew."

ISAAC STERN likes to play chamber music. So does Leonard Rose. So does Eugene Istomin. So what more natural than these three American instrumentalists get together and form a trio? They did, last season, and have played several concerts in public.

The Port of New York Authority announced yesterday that May 1 would be the date of sale for $35,000,000 of bonds to help finance construction projects now under way. These projects chiefly involve airports in the metropolitan area.
BUENOS AIRES, Tuesday, April 24 President Jose Maria Guido announced late last night that Argentina would elect a new President before the end of July.
THE exhibition of the works of Pablo Picasso, open ing tomorrow in nine New York City galleries, was heralded last night in an hour-long program seen locally over station WNBCTV.
QUINHON, Vietnam, April 23 An American sergeant wounded in a leg in Communist fire has been denied the Purple Heart.
WASHINGTON, April 23 The Federal Government has $216,000,000 worth of rubber it does not need, but foreign policy is preventing its sale now.

LAUREL, Md., April 24 (AP) --Weatherscope, a 3-year-old campaigning for Mrs. F. Eugene Dixon Jr. of Philadelphia, won on the turf today and paid $36 for $2.
The producton of paperboard in the nation totaled 351,417 tons in the week ended April 21, the National Paperboard Association reported yesterday.
TRENTON, April 24--The long-awaited forms required by New Jersey residents who must file 1961 returns under the state's commuter benefit tax will be ready for distribution no later than next Tuesday.
WASHINGTON, April 24 (AP)--The State Department's attempt to deny a passport to Mrs. Elizabeth Gurley Flynn ran into trouble today when an unidentified major witness failed to appear.

Mrs. Kathleen Finley Wright, the widow of Dr. Fred E. Wright, scientist who was secretary of the National Academy of Sciences, died on Monday in Lexington, Mass. Mrs. Wright, whose home was in Washington, was 85 years old.

United Press International acquired a "significant increase in subscribers" during the last year, it was reported at the news agency's annual meeting yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 24-- Late in 1945 a physicist who had helped develop the atomic bomb was co-author of a chapter in the book "One World or None" that predicted that within five years the Soviet Union would also have the bomb.

Baseball has been described as a pastime owing its popularity to the fact that almost anything can happen on a given pitch, and occasionally does. A case in point was presented in yesterday's game at the Stadium in which the White Sox downed the Yankees, 3--1.

The New York Building Congress, which held its forty-first annual meeting yesterday at the Astor Hotel, elected Charles Haines as president.
The New York Savings Bank, the only savings institution in the state paying 4 per cent for two-year deposits, said yesterday that its savings since April 1 had risen by more than $4,000,000.

VIENTIANE, Laos, April 24 (AP)--The pro-Western Laotian Government said today that attacking Communist forces had captured a key ridge southeast of Nam Tha after forty-eight hours of "fierce fighting" near the northwest provincial capital.
GENEVA, April 24--The Soviet Union accused the United States today of seeking a "onesided" disarmament that would give the Western Powers a military advantage over the "peace-loving states."

In the days when the Soviet people advanced with remarkable unanimity and patriotic uplift toward the elections to the U.S.S.R. Supreme Soviet, the eighteen-nation Disarmament Committee began its work in Geneva.

GEORGE LONDON, bassbaritone, of the Metro politan Opera, is one of the few fine singers around today whose acting is on a par with his singing. Since television is incapable of transmitting some of his most beautiful sounds, this is all to the good.

WASHINGTON, April 24 (AP)--Senator Clifford P. Case, Republican of New Jersey, proposed legislation today to require contractors who lease post office buildings to the Government to pay prevailing construction wages to their employes.
ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L. I., April 24--Former New York State Supreme Court Justice Francis G. Hooley died yesterday in his home at 209 Hempstead Avenue. He was 79 years old.

THE last few days have seen Bach choral music presented in all philosophies. Friday night saw Thomas Dunn lead his Festival Orchestra and Chorus in a performance of the "St. John Passion" with forces that approximated those of Bach's own day.

PALM BEACH, Fla., April 24--Dr. Howard Rusk will arrive here tomorrow to examine Joseph P. Kennedy preparatory to sending the President's father to the Institute of Physical Medicine and Rehabilitation of the New York University-Bellevue Medical Center in New York.

BRONXVILLE, N. Y., April 24--Dr. Doris Aurelia Russell, chairman of the English Department at Vassar College, died of cancer today in Lawrence Hospital here. She was 59 years old and lived at Williams Hall on the Vassar campus at Poughkeepsie.
Francis Skiddy Marden of 12 West Forty-fourth Street, an investment banker who had been the oldest member of the St. Nicholas Society for a number of years, died on Saturday at the age of 94.

HEMPSTEAD, L. I., April 24 --Hofstra College's lacrosse team scored its sixth victory of the season against two losses by defeating the Towson State Teachers, 12--2 today. Bruce Bauer and Spike Orr led the Flying Dutchmen, each scoring three goals.

CHICAGO, April 24 (UPI)-- Egg futures eased today on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange while most poultry futures gained slightly. Shell eggs were unchanged to 30 points down, frozen eggs 5 to 7 down, Tom turkeys unchanged to 3 down.
WASHINGTON, April 24-- United States soldiers wounded in the fighting in Vietnam will receive the Purple Heart.

NEW DELHI, India, April 24 (Reuters)--Sixteen persons were killed and thirty injured yesterday when freight cars that had come loose from a shunting train crashed into a bus at a grade crossing in Dhanbad, the Indian Parliament was told today.

The Eig Seven women's colleges yesterday completed their mailing of a total of 4,620 acceptances to fill approximately 2,800 places for their September freshman classes. Altogether, the colleges had received 9,789 completed applications.

Boyd Neel, English conductor who lives in Toronto, will lead one of the four free concerts given by the Naumburh Orchestra in Central Park this summer. Mr. Neel's last appearance here, six years ago, was also in this series.

CHICAGO, April 24--About 2,000 stockholders of the International Business Machine's Corporation, gathered here for the annual meeting in a harmonious and festive mood, heard repeated assurances today that the company would have a good year in 1962 and in the years thereafter.
The city can undertake longrange financial planning only after the Legislature gives it effective power to manage its own fiscal affairs, Controller Abraham D. Beame said yesterday.
Arthur Bryan has been named managing director of Josiah Wedgwood Sons, Ltd., British china manufacturer.

BIRMINGHAM, England, April 24 (Reuters)--Johnny Prescott, an unbeaten Birmingham heavyweight, tonight outpointed Frankie Daniels of Bakersfield, Calif., in ten rounds. Prescott, 23 years old, started slowly, but he dominated the middle rounds and withstood a late rally by Daniels, 34.

Robert Preston and Ray Bolger will be masters of ceremonies at the distribution of the American Theatre Wing's Tony awards. The presentations will be made Sunday night at a dinner-dance in the WaldorfAstoria Hotel.
BUENOS AIRES, Wednesday, April 25--President Jose Maria Guido announced yesterday that he had canceled the results in the recent provincial elections, which had been won mainly by Peronist parties.

The Lever Brothers Company announced the election yesterday of Hugh R. Conklin as sales vice president. Mr. Conklin, who joined the company in 1957, had been general sales manager of the Lever division, which markets soaps and detergents.
Benjamin M. McKelway was re-elected here yesterday as president of The Associated Press. He is editor of The Washington Star and was named president of the news cooperative by the board of directors.
MOSCOW, April 24--Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko said today that the Soviet-United States talks on Berlin had yielded "some glimpses of hope" that agreement could be attained.

HAVANA, April 24 (UPI)-- Fire attributed to saboteurs raged through the half-built National Bank building here tonight, sending a pillar of flame into the air that could be seen from every part of the city.

TORONTO, Ont., April 24 (Canadian Press)--Scientific teams from Canadian and United States universities are to set off a series of explosions on the bottom of Lake Superior to measure the thickness of the earth's crust in North America.
BUFFALO, April 24 (UPI)-- Two New York nuclear scientists were named today to supervise the installation of the first nuclear reactor in Thailand.

HACKETTSTOWN, N. J., April 24--Frank X. Ryan, former president of the Hackettstown Taxpayers Association, which opposed the school budget, told the Mayor and Council last night that he has been warned anonymously to get out of town or his two young sons would suffer. The boys now have police protection.
John V. Dunne, senior partner of the brokerage firm of John V. Dunne Co., 120 Broadway, died yesterday at Roosevelt Hospital. He was 81 years old and lived at the Beekman Hotel, 575 Fifth Avenue.
A European theatre tour and playwriting seminar will be conducted this summer by Prof. Randolph Goodman of Brooklyn College. The group will leave here on June 23 and return on Aug. 20.

NICOSIA, Cyprus, April 24 (Reuters)--An island-wide police dragnet was out today for gunmen who murdered two leading Turkish Cypriote newsmen last night. Leading Cypriotes condemned the assassinations and declare them politically motivated.
CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., April 24 (AP)--Two military missiles--a Minuteman and a Pershing--were blown up here today in launching failures.
HICKSVILLE, L.I., April 24--The driver of an automobile that struck a pedestrian in Farmingdale last November was awarded $10 in Small Claims Court here today for damages to his car.
WASHINGTON, April 24-- The Administration opened its campaign today for Congressional endorsement of a $500,000,000 program to help cities and towns develop better commuter trains, buses and subways.

ROCHESTER, N. Y., April 24 (AP)--Bruce Anderson, a 20year-old student at Rochester Institute of Technology, bowled a 300 game last night in qualifying for the New York State bowling proprietors' match-play tournament. Anderson rolled a sixteen-game series of 3,325.

BOGOTA, Colombia, April 24 (Reuters)--Bad weather forced the suspension today of a search for a Colombian airliner missing since Sunday on a flight over Colombia carrying forty persons, including two members of the United States Peace Corps.
AMARILLO, Tex., April 24-- Lawyers are at a premium in some towns in the Texas Panhandle.
CINCINNATI, April 24--The new Mets, riding the crest of a one-game winning streak, bumped into the Cincinnati Reds at Crosley Field tonight and became the same old Mets.

A hundred ships and planes and 12,000 men stand ready at Christmas and Johnston Islands to start the new experiments.

Record first-quarter earnings and an increase in the quarterly dividend were announced yesterday by Texaco, Inc. Augustus C. Long, chairman, told the company's annual meeting in Chicago that consolidated net income in the first three months of 1962 was $115,256,652, equal to 93 cents a share.
BOSTON, April 24 (UPI)-- Pete Runnels hit two home runs today to lead the Boston Red Sox to a 4-1 victory over the Washington Senators.

MOSCOW, April 24 (AP)-- The Soviet Union accused British authorities today of trying to take the front page away from them with the recent story of the runaway British diplomats, Guy Burgess and Donald D. Maclean.

The Moore-McCormack Lines, Inc., announced yesterday the retirement of two senior officials, Robert C. Lee, chairman, and George L. Holt, executive vice president. Both men will continue as directors.

BOURNEMOUTH, England, April 24 (UPI)--Ann Haydon of England easily defeated the Scottish champion, Frances MacLennan, 6--1, 6--1, today in the first round of the British hard-court tennis championships.

CINCINNATI, April 24 (AP) --Augustania College, a Lutheran school at Rock Island, Ill., won the eighth annual Robert Mark National International Debating Tournament today.

MINEOLA, L.I., April 24-- It appeared unlikely today that there would be bipartisan endorsements of candidates for seven new state Supreme Court judgeships in Nassau County.

BALTIMORE, April 24--The development of an improved model of a flowmeter capable of measuring simultaneously underwater currents in three dimensions was announced here today by the Westinghouse Electric Corporation ordnance division.
WASHINGTON, April 24-- Scientists at The Johns Hopkins University have devised a way to measure angles ten times more accurately than before.
LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, April 24--Premier Cyrille Adoula called on the United Nations today to draw up a tougher mandate for coping with Katanga Province.

ACCRA, Ghana, April 24-- President Kwame Nkrumah began today to carry out a pledge to purge his party. Government and nation Of corruption. He presented a draft of a bill providing three to fifteen years' imprisonment for certain corrupt practices.

A 4-year-old child, Rita Robbins of 2060 East Twenty Seventh Street, in the Sheepshead Bay section of Brooklyn, was found apparently unharmed yesterday at about 11 A. M. in the room of a maintenance man. She had been missing since Sunday evening.
New York said farewell yesterday to Grover A. Whelan, who welcomed so many prominent figures to the city between 1919 and 1953.

NOUAKCHOTT, Mauritania, April 24--Twenty-four Mauritanians went on trial for their lives here today on charges of treason and murder.

Michael Rennie, British actor, and Mrs. Mary Gardner Preminger, former wife of Otto Preminger, film producer announced their engagement here yesterday. Mr. Rennie flew here from London for the announcement.

President Guido of Argentina has now yielded to the military leaders. He has decreed the annulment of the March 18 elections in which the Peronists won ten provincial Governorships. He has also ordered federal--in this case, military-- control in all twenty-two provinces. Presumably an election for a new President will be held within ninety days.

Bess Myerson, television hostess and former Miss America, and Arnold M. Grant, a Manhattan lawyer, obtained a marriage license here yesterday. They did not specify their wedding plans. Both have been married before.
PINEHURST, N. C., April 24 (AP)--Cobby Ware, the medalist, and Bill Hyndman 3d, the defending champion, won first round matches in the North and South amateur golf tournament today.

WOODRUFF, S. C., April 24 (AP)--Sammy Taylor said today the Chicago Cubs weren't paying him enough to keep a home in Chicago and one here, where his wife prefers to live. He said he would quit baseball if he weren't traded.
ALBANY, April 24--Counsel for the Fifth Avenue Coach Lines charged before the Court of Appeals today that New York City's seizure of the bus lines served no public purpose.
PALM BEACH, Fla., April 24 (AP)--Two university officials were named by President Kennedy today to the board of visitors for the Air Force Academy.

Public ownership in the Ford Motor Company was broadened yesterday with the offering of 2,250,000 common shares valued at $218,250,000. The shares were sold by the Ford Foundation in a continuing move to diversify its holdings.
NEW ORLEANS, April 24-- A proposal to send a "freedom train" up North carrying 1,000 Negroes on a free one-way ride away from segregation in the South drew new cries of outrage and support today.
A powerful dose of fiscal medicine--a 1 per cent income tax--is about to be administered to Detroit to cure the city's deficit financing.
BUENOS AIRES, April 24-- The United States appealed today to Latin-American and European nations to help the United States' position in international payments.
A group of Upper East Side tenement boys and girls had a special order in Central Park yesterday: "Collect for identification anything that does not weigh too much or move too fast."
The Columbia Broadcasting System is shuffling its array of daytime television programs. Seven shows will be affected in June and three next fall.
PITTSBURGH, April 24 (AP)--Alvin McBean, with ninth-inning relief help, pitched the Pittsburgh Pirates to a 7-3 victory over the San Francisco Giants tonight.

Charles E. Kane, a vice president and advertising director of Newsweek magazine, died Monday night after a brief illness in the Manhasset (L. I.) Medical Center. He was 47 years old and lived at 57 Short Drive, Manhasset.
LONDON, April 24 (Reuters) --Sir Winston Churchill returned to London by air today from Athens after a seventeenday Mediterranean cruise on the yacht of Aristotle Onassis, the shipping magnate.

PELHAM MANOR, N. Y., April 24--The marriage of Miss Erin Marie Roach, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David Joseph Roach, to Walter Hildreth Russell, son of Mrs. Frederick A. Russell and the late Captain Russell of the Merchant Marine, took place here at noon today.

Katherine Anne Porter's highly praised novel of Germany in 1931, "Ship of Fools," will be given a large-scale film production next year by Stanley Kramer.

The effects of the recent conflict in the Congo were reflected yesterday in the announcment by Union Miniere du Haut-Katanga that its indicated dividend on 1961 profits would be $16 a share compared with $30 in the preceding year.

WASHINGTON, April 24 (AP)--The American Bar Association told the Senate Finance Committee today the proposed tax withholding system on dividends and interest would produce many errors and also invite frauds.

LONDON, April 24 (Reuters) --The first stage play by Robert Crean, American television playwright, opened here today. Entitled "A Time to Laugh," at deals with the problem of religious faith in terms of satirical comedy.

TOLEDO, Ohio, April 24 --A State Department official disclosed today that the United States would offer a four-point plan next fall designed to improve the United Nations.

A family medical office that will provide comprehensive med ical care for 9,000 hotel workers and their families was dedicated yesterday at the New York Medical College-Flower and Fifth Avenue Hospital.

JERSEY CITY, April 24-- First quarter earnings of the Union Bag-Camp Paper Corporation rose to $4,886,806 from $4,050,507 in the 1961 period, Alexander Calder Jr., president, reported at the annual stockholders meeting here today.
WASHINGTON, April 24-- Dr. Frederick Seitz, a University of Illinois professor and a prominent research physicist, was elected president of the National Academy of Sciences today.

A daughter was born to Mr. and Mrs. Nicholas L. Tilney of 423 East Sixty-ninth Street on March 31 in Lying-In Hospital. Mrs. Tilney is the former Miss Henriette B. Loudon, daughter of Mrs. James H. Stebbins of New York and the late Dr. Alexander Loudon, who was the Netherlands' Ambassador to the United States. The child, the couple's second, has been named Louise Southgate.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 24--U Thant, acting Secretary General of the United Nations, appealed today to "all powers concerned" to refrain from nuclear tests.

MOSCOW, April 24 (Reuters) --Yevgeny Yevtushenko, 29year-old "angry young man" of Soviet poetry, will fly to Britain Friday for a two-week visit. Mr. Yevtushenko caused a storm in Soviet literary circles last year with a poem "Babi Yar," which implied latent Soviet anti-Semitism. He was subsequently bitterly attacked by Soviet critics.
New York City borrowed $108,530,000 in the bond market yesterday at an interest cost of 2.5781 per cent to finance school Construction and other public improvements.
WASHINGTON, April 24-- The United States and Hong Kong have agreed to make virtually no change in this country's ban on imports of Hong Hong's cotton goods.

Present sugar legislation guarantees domestic beet and cane growers more than half the American market. It also authorizes the Government to limit the total supply of sugar available for sale here--by limiting imports--to permit an artificially high price for this high-cost American industry.
Pete Seeger will present a program of folk songs for children on Saturday at 2:30 P.M. at Town Hall, 123 West Fortythird Street. Admission is $1.75 and $2.25. For information, call JUdson 2-2424.

The secrecy that surrounded the building of the Australian America's Cup challenger Gretel w as stripped away at least partially in a motion picture shown before a small gathering at the Quantas Airways Center last night.
An 81-year-old druggist defied an armed bandit yesterday morning because, he explained. "I don't believe in giving money to bums."

"The Life of Man" will be seen tomorrow through Saturday nights in the sanctuary of the Spencer Memorial Church at Remsen and Clinton Streets in Brooklyn. Leonid Andreyev is the author of the symbolical drama, which will be performed by John E. Ericson's repertory troupe.
WASHINGTON, April 24 (AP)--Bess Furman, for many years a Washington newspaperwoman, was named today to head the press information section of the department of Health, Education and Welfare.
MELBOURNE, Australia, April 24--Four Japanese warships, the first to visit Australia since World War II, will arrive in Melbourne July 6, the Government announced in Canberra today.

SEOUL, Korea, April 24-- Gen. Park Chung Hee, the South Korean military ruler, today confirmed the death sentence for Han Pil Kook on charges of smuggling. The execution will take place shortly. Han, who is 37 years old, was sentenced March 5 as the leader of a smuggling ring.
Burt Lancaster walked off Mike Wallace's "P. M." television show yesterday after Mr. Wallace had asked the motionpicture actor about reports of his quick temper.

William L. Pfeiffer of Old Westbury, L.I., treasurer of the New York Republican State Committee, was elected president of the National Republican Club yesterday in balloting at the club, on the eighteenth floor of the Biltmore Hotel.
Ground rules for the space age are urgently needed, speakers told a conference on the law and sociology of space yesterday.

Miss Mary Markley Roberts and the Rev. Peyton Gardner Craighill were married yesterday in the chapel of the Tainan Theological College in Tainan, Taiwan. The Right Rev. Charles P. Gilson, Protestant Episcopal Bishop of Taiwan, performed the ceremony assisted by Rev. Richard Yoh.
Trading volume in cocoa and wool futures was heavy yesterday, the frst day on which notice of delivery against the spot month could be posted. Most other commodity markets in New York were dull.
DHAHRAN, Saudi Arabia, April 23--King Saud told Palestinians "in all parts of the wide earth" last night that Palestine "cannot be liberated except by the blood of Palestinians."

GARDEN CITY, L.I., April 24--Adelphi College has been granted $12,000 by the National Science Foundation in Washington for special physics research. The research will be directed by Henry Brysk, Associate Professor of Physics.
Complaints from the public about underestimates on moving charges have resulted in criticism and warning from the Better Business Bureau.

ROYAL OAK, Mich., April 24 --A daughter was born last Wednesday in the Beaumont Hospital here to Mr. and Mrs. James Franklin Jamison Jr. of Birmingham, formerly of New York. Mrs. Jamison is the former Miss Patricia Anne Daugherty of New York. The child, the couple's second daughter, has been named Dana Anne.
The Undergraduate Journal of Barnard College, containing outstanding writing done by Barnard students in connection with their studies, will be published for the first time this month.
CHICAGO, April 24 (AP) --The American Can Company set a record for sales and earnings in the first 1962 quarter, William C. Stolk, chairman, reported at the annual meeting today.

The Japan Development Bank has registered with the Securities and Exchange Commission $15,000,000 of fifteen-year 6 per cent external loan bonds bearing the unconditional guarantee of the Japanese Government on principal and interest.
SPARKILL, N. Y., April 24-- Yale's varsity golf team scored a 6-1 victory over Columbia at the Rockland Country Club today. Pete Salzberg, a sophomore, was the only victor for the Lions.
WASHINGTON, April 24-- The Defense Department decided today to remove the secrecy from a flashing-light geodetic satellite designed to measure intercontinental distances and the shape of the earth.
LONDON, April 24--The market resumed after the four-day Easter holiday in a fairly cheerful mood although buying was selective and trading generally on a small scale.
THE following menu is suggested as a guide to the use of foods that are reasonable in price. A recipe is given for an easy-to-prepare main dish.

Alternate side of the street parking regulations will be suspended today and tomorrow because they are the concluding days of Passover, Traffic Commissioner Henry A. Barnes said yesterday. All other traffic regulations will remain in effect.
A freight-train derailment on the New York Central and brake trouble on a Long Island Road caused some delays yesterday during the morning rush hours.

WASHINGTON, April 24-- The Public Health Service, under pressure from a Congressional subcommittee, announced today that it had terminated the awarding of research grants to profit-making institutions.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, April 24--The Yugoslav Government is imposing controls on retail and wholesale trade in an effort to halt an inflationary trend that has driven the cost of food in local markets up 25 per cent in the last four months.

ELIZABETH, N. J., April 24 --Robert C. Crane, former editor and publisher of The Daily Journal, an afternoon newspaper here, and a former State Senator, died today of cancer in Elizabeth General Hospital.

PARIS, April 24--France put further pressure today on Monaco to revise her liberal tax laws and institute direct taxation.

PARIS, April 24--Jacques Chaban-Delmas, Speaker of the National Assembly, hinted today at the possibility that France's regime would become a Presidential one. The regime is nominally a parliamentary one.

The election of W. Earl Miller as a vice president of Gimbel Brothers, Inc., was announced yesterday by Bruce A. Gimbel, president. Mr. Miller formerly was president of Ed. Schuster Co., Inc., which recently was acquired by Gimbel Brothers.

WASHINGTON, April 24 (UPI)--An official of a leading hearing aid manufacturer said today its business had dropped by 60 per cent on Oregon after enactment there of a state law requiring dealers to be licensed.

GENEVA, April 24 (Reuters) --The United Nations Economic Commission for Europe began today its yearly survey of the European economy.
