LONDON, April 24--Qualified sources reported tonight that Prime Minister Macmillan would suggest to president Kennedy this week that the Western powers consider some form of continuous consultation with the Soviet Union.

MIAMI BEACH, April 24 (AP)--A Civil Aeronautics Board examiner upheld an order that reduced to co-pilot status Ronald H. Conway, pilot of an Imperial Air Lines plane that crashed and killed seventy-four Army recruits near Richmond. Va., Nov. 8. Examiner S. Thomas Simon announced his decision last night.

WHAT are 15,000,000 dead fish among friends? That, according to the Division of Water Supply, and Pollution Control of the Government's Public Health Service, is the number of fish killed by water pollution last year.
WASHINGTON, April 24 (UPI)--The Labor Department said today it would withdraw its approval from apprentice training programs that barred Negroes.
The new West German cargo ship Cap San Diego will arrive today on her maiden voyage.
WASHINGTON, April 24-- Attorney General Robert F. Kennedy said today that about half of this nation's young people would probably fail a simple physical fitness test.
The credit card division of Averican Express Company has moved out of the red.
SOUTHAMPTON, England, April 24 (Reuters)--The twenty-six-year-old Cunard liner, Queen Mary, arrived here today from New York after making her fastest crossing since she won the Blue Ribbon in 1938.

EAST ORANGE, N.J., Wednesday, April 25--Andrew C. Axtell of Livingston was elected Republican chairman of Essex County early today in one of the closest county committee votes in many years. He defeated William F. Tompkins of Maplewood, 433 to 416.
Jules Munshin, actor and Bonnie Lynn Pohlmann, a dancer, obtained a marriage license here yesterday. It will be the second marriage for both.

The Erie-Lackawanna Railroad reported yesterday that it had reduced its first quarter deficit to $4,952,838 from $10,504,893 a year ago. Operating revenues for the first three months totaled $53,156,033, a 6 per cent increase over the $50,073,885 for the same period last year.

DAMASCUS, Syria, April 24 (Reuters)--Premier Bashir el Azmeh said today that freedom of the press would be restored in Syria within the next few days as a prelude to the restoration of other public freedoms.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 24--Sir Patrick Dean of Britain told the United Nations today that conditions had been established under which all parties in Northern Rhodesia would take part in elections there, probably next fall.
Premier Khrushchev has told an American publisher that he now believes he should not confer with President Kennedy at a summit meeting until diplomats have paved the way with preliminary agreements.

Increasing trends toward 10cent prices for daily newspapers and more use of offset printing were reported yesterday during the American Newspaper Publishers Association convention at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

DESPITE their popularity, long pants on women still present the problem of fit. Most stores carry at least two size ranges--Misses 8 to 16 and Juniors 5 to 15--but many women are not a standard size from the waist down.
The velocity of demand deposits--the rate at which bank customers use their checking accounts--rose by 15 per cent in New York City in March compared with February.
WASHINGTON, April 24-- The Senate civil rights battle got off to a stumbling start today when Southerners forced adjournment because of difficulty in getting a quorum of Senators to the floor.

The 1961-62 appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund brought a record contributions total of $582,563,46. This total, announced yesterday, compares with $572,816 for the 19601961 appeal and $557,701,89 for the 1959-1960 appeal.
National Better Hearing Month, sponsored by the American Hearing Society throughout May, will be marked by tree hearing tests for residents of the metropolitan area.
Alexander H. Cohen has returned from a three-week visit to the London theatres with the American rights to "Signpost to Murder," a thriller by an Australian writer named Monte Doyle.

Many persons entertained at the fifth annual Hearts and Diamonds Ball in the Grand Ballroom of the Plaza last night. Mrs. Cortright Wetherill is the founder and president of the Heart and Lung Foundation, beneficiary of the event.
Record first-quarter sales and earnings were registered by the American Tobacco Company, it was reported yesterday by Paul M. Hahn, president.
THE ambivalent attitude of the highest-ranking bridge players toward their tournament opponents is regularly perceptible in their intimate chats among themselves.

DETROIT, April 24 (AP)-- Meetings are scheduled for tomorrow between Detroit's two daily newspapers and at least two of three unions still at odds with management in a work stoppage that has lasted two weeks.

MADRID, April 24 (Reuters) --The number of miners on strike in the Asturian coalfield in northwest Spain rose 2,000 today, to 20,000. Striking is illegal in this country. The miners are angry at management's delay in granting a claim for a 15 per cent raise.
WIMBLEDON, England, April 24 (UPI)--Doctors at Atkinson Morley Hospital expressed "good hope" today for the recovery of the British auto racing star, Stirling Moss, although he still was unconscious
NEW HAVEN, April 24-- St. John's scored its twelfth straight baseball victory today by beating Southern Connecticut State, 9--8, in ten innings.

The Seaboard Air Line Railroad incrased its first quarter earnings by 26 per cent from a year ago, John W. Smith, president, told the annual meeting yesterday in Richmond, Va. First-quarter net income totaled $3,065,759, or 63 cents a share, compared with $3,295,207, or 50 cents a share, a year ago.
Another Senate filibuster may begin today in connection with the Administration's bill to nullify the use of literacy tests to bar Negroes from registering as voters. After a week or so
WASHINGTON, April 24-- The general level of consumer prices rose to a record in March for the second consecutive month, the Labor Department reported today.
The Transit Authority said yesterday it would seek to renew its lease of city-owned subway and bus facilities for at least fifteen more years beyond its expiration in mid-1963.
The Progress Manufacturing Company, Philadelphia, a leading producer of lighting fixtures and related electrical products, announced yesterday the election of Arthur C. Kaufmann as a director.
L. Charles Wallach completed his 200th crossing of the Atlantic Ocean yesterday, and his enthusiasm confirmed that he felt "like a 21-year-old."

Directors of the WarnerLambert Pharmaceutical Company increased the quarterly dividend on the common stock with the declaration yesterday of 45 cents a share. The payment will be distributed on June 12 to holders of record of May 15. In previous quarters shareholders received 37 cents a share.
The New York Telephone Company reported yesterday a decline in first-quarter net income, although operating revenues rose by 3.5 per cent.

NEW HAVEN, April 24 (AP) Blyden Jackson, a Negro integration leader who was shot and wounded by his wife, pleaded guilty today to a charge of giving false information to the police in connection with the case. Circuit Court Judge George Wise fined him $25.
WASHINGTON, April 24-- The Pennsylvania Railroad threw its support today behind the merger proposals of the Norfolk and Western Railway.
RIVERHEAD, L.I., April 24 --Suffolk Democrats and Republicans seem unwilling to choose party nominees for four new State Supreme Court judgeships.
The International American Federation of Entertainment Unions will hold its annual convention May 8 to 10 in Lima, Peru.

DETROIT, April 24 (AP)-- The Detroit Tigers scored a run in the eighth inning tonight and ruined the starting-pitcher debut of Dan Pfister in a 1-0 victory over the Kansas City Athletics. The loss ended Kansas City's four-game winning streak.
BUFFALO, April 24 (AP)-- Warren Rabb, a quarterback candidate, signed his 1962 contract with the Buffalo Bills of the American Football League today.
VIEQUES, P.R., April 24 (UPI)--About 10,000 United States Marines were on the beaches of this tiny Caribbean island today, simulating an amphibious attack.
AUGUSTA, Ga., April 24 (AP)--A state prosecutor said today he would present charges of murder against seven Negroes for the killing of a white youth in a Negro residential area.
Stocks closed practically unchanged yesterday as investors waited to see whether United States Steel would declare a dividend at its regular rate of 75 cents a quarter.
The Continental Can Company announced the election of Helmer R. Johnson and Ellison L. Hazard as directors at the annual stockholders' meeting yesterday.

Investors Diversified Services, Inc., reported yesterday that it wound up 1961 with new hights in earnings, dividends, aggregate sales, total assets under its management and numbers of persons and institutions served.

Columbia, led by Bob McCool, blanked Notre Dame, 10--0, in an Eastern Rugby Union match at Van Cortlandt Park yesterday. McCool, the Light Blue football captain in 1960, scored two tries as the Lions took a 9-0 half-time lead.

By creating a Bureau of Outdoor Recreation in the Department of the Interior the Kennedy Administration has taken a positive step toward carrying out the recommendations of the Outdoor Recreation Resources Review Commission.
WASHINGTON, April 24-- A team of management experts reported today that the Federal Communications Commission was unable to discharge its public responsibilities and urge its immediate overhaul.
THE woman who wants and buys an orange dress this spring, when the stores are flooded with orange dresses, often is acting just as a long list of experts predicted she would.

KAMPALA, Uganda, April 24 (Reuters)--More than a million voters are expected to go to the polls in Uganda tomorrow to elect a new eighty-two seat National Assembly for a five-year term. Britain will grant Uganda independence Oct. 9.
Left-over vegetables may be turned into palatable dishes by sauteing them gently in a little butter, or tossing them in a French dressing.

AVON, N. Y., April 24 (AP) --The Rural County Democratic Chairman's Association of Western New York reported "enthusiastic encouragement" tonight for Howard J. Samuels of Canandaigua to seek the Democratic nomination for Governor.

The New York City Ballet opened a three-week spring season at the City Center last night with a performance of "A Midsummer Night's Dream," the full-length Balanchine-Mendelssohn ballet that received its premiere in January.
LONDON, April 24--Ship tonnage under construction in Britain at the end of March was the lowest in seventeen years.
Douglas Dillon, the Secretary of the Treasury, said last night that the nation must "continue to guard vigilantly against wage-price inflation," which, he said, could "strike at any time."

CHICAGO, April 24 (AP)-- Sandy Koufax of the Los Angeles Dodgers struck out eighteen batters today and matched the modern major league mark he already shared with Bob Feller. The 26-yearold left-hander accomplished the feat in beating the Chicago Cubs, 10--2.
TUNIS, April 24--Mohammed Ben Bella, Vice Premier of the Algerian nationalist Provisional Government, called to day for French-Algerian cooperation.

Dotted swiss has come out of the nursery and onto the beach. Some of summer's most beguiling playcloths will be made of this airy fabric. Colors will be sophisticated--bright red, clear navy blue and black. Designs include bathing suits, beach shifts, tailored shirts and even the new fad, hipster pants.
Mayor Wagner signed into law last night the controversial measure under which the city will take over rent control here from the state next Tuesday.

The election of Cyril R. Porthouse as president of Dunhill International, Inc., was announced yesterday following the company's annual meeting here.
The election of Walter J. Fried as a director of Bergdorf Goodman was announced yesterday by Andrew Goodman, president of the Fifth Avenue specialty store.
WASHINGTON,--April 24 (UPI)--Benny Goodman will give President Kennedy and Prime Minister Macmillan of Britain a sample Friday night of the jazz show he will take to the Soviet Union next month.

A department director and a supervisory inspector of the state Department of Labor were arrested here yesterday on charges of having extorted money from a contractor on a low-cost housing project in the Bronx.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, April 24 (AP)--Joao Goulart, President of Brazil, has accepted an invitation to visit Czechoslovakia the official Czech press agency C.T.K. reported today.
Cotton futures were unchanged to 40 cents a bale up yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange.

The Tri-Test Transmission Corporation has leased the onestory building at 1935 Flushing Avenue, Maspeth, Queens, from N. Piazza. The corporation will use the property for general offices and repairing, installing and servicing automatic transmissions. The Kalmon Dolgin Company was the broker.

JERUSALEM, (Israeli Sector), April 24--Adolf Eichmann, under - sentence of death for participating in the murder of millions of Jews during World War II, has been talking with a Protestant minister, it was learned today.

WESTBURY, L. I., April 24-- The Women's Division of the Mental Health Association of Nassau County is sponsoring a gala dinner and Night-at-theRaces at the Cloud Casino at the Roosevelt Raceway here on May 9.
The high-grade bond market chalked up another defensive trading session yesterday. Activity was inhibited by the shadow of the Treasury's impending $11,683,000,000 refunding operation.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., April 24--Hofstra College will add about an acre of ground to its academic area this summer through the relocation of its athletic field to the eastern part of the campus in Uniondale.
Mayor Wagner appointed Aaron Brown, a Negro educator, to a full seven-year term on the Board of Education yesterday.
Nonprofessional employes of the French Hospital, 330 West Thirtieth Street, voted 104 to 93 yesterday to be represented by Local 1199, Drug and Hospital Employes Union.
Higher earnings from firstquarter operations and a realignment of top officers were announced yesterday by the Philips Petroleum Company.

DETROIT, April 24--The Rev. Avery Dulles, son of the late Secretary of State John Foster Dulles, said here today that Roman Catholics had cheated themselves in the past through narrowmindedness but were beginning to recognize a fallacy in isolationism.
State Controller Arthur Levitt, a Democrat, opened a campaign yesterday to hold Governor Rockefeller, a Republican, responsible for some local tax increases in the state.
The United States Steel Corporation reported yesterday that it made a profit of $55,808,436 in the first quarter of 1962, a return of 5.7 per cent on sales of $978,219,633.

WORCESTER, Mass., April 24--The College of the Holy Cross, a Jesuit liberal arts college, began a $20,400,000 development-fund program this week. Henry M. Hogan, former vice president and general counsel of the General Motors Company, is chairman.
The wholesale commodity price index remained at 82.4 Monday for the fifth straight day. The index, compiled by the Bureau of Labor Statistics, stood at 87.2 on April 18, 1961.
MOSCOW, April 24--Nikita S. Khrushchev was renamed today as Premier of the Soviet Union by the Supreme Soviet, or national Parliament.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 24 (AP)--The New Haven Railroad wants to turn over the management of its trucking subsidiary to a transportation consultant.
PASADENA, Calif., April 24 --The crippled United States spacecraft Ranger IV was more than halfway to the moon today.

ATHENS, April 24--Cloth and items of clothing form United States Air Force uniforms worth a total of $14,000,000 are being given to Greece to provide uniforms for the Greek militia, it was announced here today.
WASHINGTON, April 24 (UPI)--William H. Brubeck today was named special assistant to Secretary of State Dean Rusk and executive secretary of the State Department.
The Southern Railway Company increased its first quarter earnings this year to $6,083,000, or 80 cents a share, from $4,880,000, or 64 cents a share, a year ago, the road reported yesterday.

ROME, April 24--Despite the "bitter news of the suspension of Parliaments in certain countries the parliamentary system is continually gaining ground," Giuseppe Codacci-Pisanelli, an Italian Deputy, told delegates today to the spring conference of the Interparliamentary Union.
WALNUT, Calif., April 24 (UPI)--Jim Beatty has withdrawn from the mile run at they annual Mount San Antonio Relays Saturday because of a leg condition, it was disclosed today.

SYDNEY, Australia, April 24 (Reuters)--Gretel, the Australian challenger for the America's Cup, finished a quarter-mile ahead of the chartered trial yacht Mim in an official race today over a twelve-mile course off Sydney Heads.
ALGIERS, April 24--The Secret Army Organization intensified its campaign of terror today.
WESTBURY, L. I., April 24-- A scarcity of free-for-all trotters again has forced Roosevelt Raceway to modify its racing program this week.

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, April 24--A funeral service was held today, for Prince Sahle Selassie, who died last night at the age of 31.
A total of 986 persons were hurt in automobile accidents here last week, the Police Safety Bureau reported yesterday. This was forty-one fewer than in the comparable 1961 period.
"Color and Cook With Your Royal Book" is a twenty-page booklet containing recipes using fruit-flavored gelatin and instant puddings.
Eighteen inspectors considered important to the city's Neighborhood Conservation Program are being transferred back to their posts in the Health Department.

TRENTON, April 24--Gov. Richard J. Hughes called for renewed efforts today to solve the problem of teen-age residents who go to New York to drink and later become involved in highway accidents in New Jersey.

Abe Burrows, co-author and director of "How to Succeed in Business Without Really Trying." will receive the Barter Theatre Award "for the most outstanding contribution to the American theatre for 1961-62."
The soft drink business is girding itself for a long, hot summer. But most of the heat will came from the competition rather than the weather.
MIAMI, Fla., April 24 (AP) --A Danish tanker abandoned during the night after an explosion in her engine room was reboarded this morning as salvage operations began, the Coast Guard reported.
CHICAGO, April 24 (UPI)-- A Federal District judge took jurisdiction today in a dispute between two taxicab driver unions.
Ten Pin Lanes, Inc., has leased a recreation center to be constructed on Route 1 in Princeton, N.J., from the Princeton Recreation Center.
Mayor Wagner accepted with "deep regret" yesterday the resignation of Ralph W. Whelan as Commissioner of Youth Services and as executive vice president of the New York City Youth Board.
Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., reported yesterday gains in operating revenues, net income and sales of electricity, gas and steam for the twelve and three months ended on March 31.

CHICAGO, April 24 (AP)-- Grain futures finished mostly steady to firm today but soybeans fell in the final minutes on expanded liquidation and closed with losses running to a cent a bushel.
BOSTON, April 24--Three milk distributing companies and five of their executives were indicted today on charges of conspiracy in pricing and bidding in New England.

A car of advanced design and with special safety features will have its first public showing tomorrow at the International Automobile Show at the Coliseum.
RICHMOND, Va., April 24 --Hanover Presbytery, the oldest of eighty-three in the Presbyterian Church, U.S. (Southern Presbyterian church) elected a Negro today as its moderator for the first time.
HALLANDALE, Fla., April 24 (AP)--Brae Burn Farm's His Legend won the feature at Gulfstream Park with a stretch drive today as Florida's long racing season ended.

In a news analysis article dealing with city wage problems in Monday's editions of The New York Times, it was erroneously stated that Mayor Wagner's executive order No. 49 of 1958 provided for collective bargaining procedure in all city departments. The order specifically excepted the Police Department. It applies to all others.
The board of governors of the American Stock Exchange has amended two rules and adopted one new one affecting specialist capital requirements, functions and activities.
ALBANY, April 24--Governor Rockefeller signed legislation today establishing a new formula for the distribution of state aid for education.
ALBANY, April 24--Governor Rockefeller signed into law today the Gordon-Liebowitz bill expanding the powers of New York State life insurance companies to invest pension funds in common stocks.

The Wollman Memorial skating rink in Central Park will reopen for roller skating on Saturday, and will close June 17, the Department of Parks announced yesterday.

KINGSTON, Jamaica, April 24--Sir Alexander Bustamante, 78-year-old leader of the Labor party, was sworn in today as Premier of the Government that will lead Jamaica to independence Aug. 6. The new Cabinet was sworn in at a later ceremony.
TAYNINH, Vietnam, April 24--"How often do you go into Cambodia?" Brig. Gen. William B. Rosson asked a senior Vietnamese officer today.
Pan American World Airways announced yesterday the placing of an order for two purejet all-cargo airplanes at a total cost of $13,000,000
Miss Wally L. Goldstein and G. Peter Buchband plan to be married in July.

LONDON, April 24--President Sukarno of Indonesia has informed Queen Elizabeth that because of the present state of tension over Netherlands New Guinea he will be unable to pay a state visit to Britain that was scheduled to begin in the second week of May.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., April 24 (UPI)--Marguerite Piazza, former Metropolitan Opera soprano, gave birth today to her sixth child, a daughter. Miss Piazza is the wife of William Condon of Memphis, a snuff company executive. She has three sons and two other daughters.

A subway conductor, a railroad clerk, a transit police sergeant, a porter and a bus driver proved yesterday that it pays to be nice. Each of them was designated "Mr. Courtesy" by the Transit Authority, for which they work, and each was given a railroad watch at a breakfast in their honor at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., April 25 Dr. Louis H. Harris, formerly a senior psychiatrist at Bellevue Hospital, New York, died here today in his home at 249 Paine Avenue. His age was 61.

EVANSTON, Ill., April 25 The names of 1,050 winners of four-year scholarships were announced today by the National Merit Scholarship Corporation. The winners may attend the colleges of their choice.
GUATEMALA, April 25 Guatemala has ordered the civil and military police to block or break up any demonstrations until the country's political crisis has ended.
The board of directors of the Air Reduction Company, Inc., approved yesterday the acquisition of two manufacturers of plastic products with combined sales of about $22,000,000 a year.

SALISBURY, Southern Rhodesia, April 25 Sir Roy Welensky declared tonight that he was prepared to go before the United Nations to answer what he termed the "crocodile tears" of Kenneth Kaunda, African nationalist leader in Northern Rhodesia.

THE fifth annual worldwide bridge tournament conducted by the Department of State-United States Information Agency Recreation Association for Government personnel here and abroad, was won this year by players stationed in Tokyo and Paris.

TRENTON, April 25 For New Jersey and much of the East this is the year of the locust. The New Jersey Bureau of Entomology reported today that May and June should bring the insects out of the ground for the first time since 1945.

WASHINGTON, April 25 (AP) A 2,000-man infantry battle group will be flown to Germany in early May as part of a new exercise designed to test United States ability to reinforce North Atlantic Treaty Organization defenses in Europe.

General Motors Corporation, the world's largest auto maker, had record sales and earnings in the first quarter. The results, according to Frederic G. Donner, chairman, and John F. Gordon, president, reflected a high level of general economic activity and strong customer demand for G.M. products.
WASHINGTON, April 25 Five Supreme Court Justices joined tonight in an unusual tribute to a longtime Government lawyer who is about to become a judge.
SAIGON, Vietnam, April 25 South Vietnam sent a stern protest to neutralist Cambodia today demanding compensation for "material and moral" damage caused in a border raid last Friday.
Mayor Wagner said yesterday that he was opposed not only to Representative Charles A. Buckley's retention as Bronx Democratic leader, but also to Mr. Buckle's renomination for Congress.
Newspaper leaders were shown yesterday how a three-foot space satellite would expand channels for reports from every part of the world. The satellite would serve as a microwave tower in the sky.

LEXINGTON, Ky., April 25 A challenge round for the Kentucky Derby will be contested at Keeneland tomorrow. "The Bob Newhart Show," which completes its first television season on June 13, will not be renewed for next season by its sponsor, Sealtest Foods. Whether the comedian will continue his show next fall under other auspices was uncertain yesterday.

Braulio Baeza, the popular 22-year-old Panamanian rider who makes his home in Queens, rode only one mount in Aqueduct's nine races yesterday but he showed he wasn't short of practice.

If the topic of this analysis is to be the emergence of the Communist system as the world's controlling power, these demonstra

The first-quarter profits reported by the United States Steel Corporation and other major steel producers provide support for both President Kennedy and the companies in their recent battle over steel prices. The company earnings were substantially higher than those in the first quarter of the recession year of 1961, but they fall far short of the record totals forecast by the President.

CHICAGO, April 25 The following is the text of the remarks made by Joseph L. Block, chairman of Inland Steel, at the annual meeting today: "Inland's decision not to follow the general price increase announced by other steel producers was not an easy one to make. We have long been mindful of the fact that steel profits

Charles Boyer will return to Broadway Oct. 31 in "Lord Pengo." He last appeared here in "The Marriage-Go-Round," which closed two years ago after a run of 433 performances. A Shubert house, which has not been selected yet, will receive the offering.

WASHINGTON, April 25 (AP) Secretary of State Dean Rusk said tonight that until the arms race is limited the United States is committed to maintain military might so strong that no nation would rationally attack the free world.
The United States, British and Soviet missions to the United Nations listened politely but unyieldingly yesterday to protests against the resumption of atmospheric nuclear tests.

World sugar futures prices closed unchanged to off 4 to 9 points (hundredths of a cent a pound) yesterday on a volume of 9,900 tons on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. Only the far July contract was steady.

An effort to place the membership list of AWARE, Inc., in the court record was sidetracked temporarily yesterday in the Supreme Court libel suit brought by John Henry Faulk against the corporation and two of its members.
First-quarter earnings of the Babcock Wilcox Company increased 12 per cent to a record of $5,266,000, or 85 cents a share, from $4,720,000, or 76 cents a share, in the 1961 period.

The nation's inventories of gasoline declined seasonally by 2,045,000 barrels last week, the American Petroleum Institute reported yesterday. Supplies on last Friday were 202,016,000 barrels, compared with the revised figure of 204,061,000 for the preceding week and 207,799,000 a year earlier.

"I'D rather cook than play bridge or wield a golf club, perhaps that's why." Mrs. Morton Heineman was explaining to a visitor how she came by her present vocation of teaching cuisine in her home in Purchase, N.Y. Three times a week she holds culinary court before a group of women who watch with rapt attention as she blends and seasons and simmers and bakes.

AMARILLO, Tex., April 25 Not far from the Silver Spur Motel and Pauline's Cafe on U. S. Highway 66 east of Amarillo is a neat, yellow stucco office building sitting modestly behind two young elm trees.
CHICAGO, April 25 (AP.) A late burst of selling virtually wiped out some broad advances in corn futures today on the Board of Trade and left other commodities generally weak.

WASHINGTON, April 25 A network of sampling and testing stations throughout the country will keep Americans posted on whether they are in danger from nuclear fall-out.

THE Civil War centennials are proving to be rather sedate affairs. There probably have been louder rebel yells in committee rooms than on the fields of glory. Even the reliable tide of familiar essays on the war's appeal to posterity seems stuck at the ebb. And, although many new books about the Gray and the Blue appear, few, these days, achieve brucecattonizing appraisal.

WASHINGTON, April 25 The Administration said today that it was sorry it had had to resume nuclear tests in the atmosphere, but said its diplomatic and propaganda defenses were as good as possible under the circumstances.
Robert Moses made a sharp attack yesterday on Traffic Commissioner Henry A. Barnes in reply to the Commissioner's criticism of the proposed MidManhattan Elevated Expressway.

The Colgate-Palmolive Company had mixed news for its stockholders yesterday. George H. Lesch, president, reported that first-quarter consolidated sales of $168,408,000 were the highest for any quarter in the company's history.
CANTHO, Vietnam, April 25 Vietnamese Rangers and the Civil Guard, with help from United States marines, dealt a major blow yesterday to Communist insurgents in the heart of the Mekong Delta country.
The American Independent Tanker Owners Association, Inc., won a series of points yesterday in the United States District Court in an antitrust suit against eight of the nation's major oil companies.
NEW ORLEANS, April 25 (AP) Two buses carrying Negroes who seek to escape segregation in New Orleans may leave for New York this week, an official of the white Citizens Council said today.
LEOPOLDVILLE, The Congo, April 25 Robert K. A. Gardiner, chief of the United Nations Congo operation returned here today after talks with Acting Secretary General U Thant in New York.
WASHINGTON, April 25 The United States resumed nuclear testing in the atmosphere today by setting off an intermediate-size explosion near Christmas Island in the Pacific.

Two putouts separated the Chicago White Sox from success at the Yankee Stadium yesterday. Then one of their field hands erred. The Bombers entered the ninth trailing by 6 3. Before the inning was over, four Yankees had circled the bases and the home side averted a fourth straight defeat, gaining a 7-6 victory.

After three days of public hearings in which his proposed executive budget for 1962-63 was severely and justifiably criticized as inadequate to the city's needs, Mayor Wagner has issued a long statement of explanation and defense. "It is part of the game of city government to blame the Mayor, no matter what goes wrong."

William F. Rickenbacker, 34year-old son of Capt. Edward V. Rickenbacker, chairman of Eastern Airlines, was found guilty yesterday of refusing to answer a special questionnaire sent by the Bureau of the Census to every fourth household.
The possibility of a reduction from 5 to 4 per cent today in the British bank rate put sterling under some pressure yesterday in the New York foreign exchange market.

BONN, Germany, April 25 A leading editor-publisher has called on the West German Government, Parliament and press to prepare the country for possible "risky, grave and unpopular decisions" in any Berlin settlement that might be reached with the Soviet Union.
MOSCOW, April 25 A short story has appeared in the Soviet press that, according to some Russians, explains why harsher days have not befallen the domestic political enemies of Premier Khrushchev.

MUSIC came off second best in the program New York City presented last night at Carnegie Hall as part of its four-year-long observance of the centennial of the Civil War. A late start, half an hour of speeches and an inefficient
WASHINGTON, April 25 The Senate began a major civil rights debate today that could tie it up for weeks or even months. The majority leader, Mike Mansfield of Montana, opened
WASHINGTON, April 25 President Kennedy's handling of the steel price increase has earned an extra dividend: it deeply confused the Soviet contention that monopolies dominated the United States.
ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., April 25 Guy Wiggins, the artist, died here today in the Flagler Hospital at the age of 78. He was a resident of Old Lyme, Conn., and had been vacationing in Florida.

A curious episode took place at City Hall yesterday. It involved E.E. Cummings, the poet and painter; Mayor Wagner and a man who styled himself harold birns, commissioner of buildings. Before it was over Mr. Cummings had slain a Myth, and he had done it with Capital Letters.

As dawn was breaking over the Central Pacific, the United States resumed atmospheric testing of nuclear devices. An Air Force plane dropped a device of less than one megaton in explosive force in the vicinity of Christmas Island. The explosion took place high in the air at 10:45 A.M. (E.S.T.). The Administration emphasized that fall-out from the series of tests would be held to a minimum. [Page 1, Column 8.]

The city made new moves yesterday to prepare for taking over rent control here from the state next Tuesday, May 1. Mrs. Hortense W. Gabel, designated by Mayor Wagner to be city Rent and Rehabilitation Administrator, announced the appointment of Matthew J. Domber and Joseph Goldberg as deputy administrators. A third deputy will be named soon.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, April 25 Francis Hackett, Irish-born author and literary critic, died last night in his home here. His age was 79. Mr. Hackett came to Denmark in 1937 with his Danishborn wife. Signe Toskvig, also

ALBANY, April 25 Twenty-two bills providing for the first major reorganization of the court structure of the state in more than a century were signed by Governor Rockefeller today. The reorganization will become effective Sept. 1.

Triptych, a new type of triple projection, believed to be of marked significance in nontheatrical films, will be demonstrated tonight at the fourth annual American Film Festival, conducted by the Educational Film Association at the Biltmore Hotel.
The administration of Actors Equity scored a sweeping victory in the election of councilors to serve on the union's governing board. The results of the mail vote were announced yesterday.
THE family has decided," said Ken Boyer, trying to look grim but not succeeding, "that as soon as we get that young man back home again we are going to give him a saliva test."

ALBANY, April 25 Governor Rockefeller signed a bill today that increases from $100,000,000 to $200,000,000 the amount of bond anticipation notes New York City may issue for middle-income housing. The notes are issued pending the completion of plans for the sale of bonds.
Newspaper executives complained yesterday that "the obdurate positions adopted by most unions often have prevented the cost-saving efficiency of far-sighted planning by publishers."

BOURNEMOUTH, England, April 25 (UPI)--The Wimbledon champion, Rod Laver, and two of his young Australian colleagues advanced to the quarter-finals of the British hard court tennis championships today.

Fordham remained undefeated in Metropolitan Baseball Conference competition by whipping New York University, 7 3, at Jack Coffey Field in the Bronx yesterday. The victory was the Rams' seventh in the league this season.
Christmas Island, site of the renewed American testing of nuclear weapons in the atmosphere, lies beneath what is perhaps the most perplexing known air current.

A new symphony orchestra, formed under the direction of Leopold Stokowski, will present a series of six concerts in New York during the 1962-63 season. The orchestra, the personnel of which will be drawn from musicians in the New york area, will be known as the American Symphony.
TALL, short, dowdy or fashionable, the women as cended, crushed in a pastelsuited clump. "It's like a department store elevator," one of them remarked.

WILMINGTON, Del., April 25 Mundy I. Peale, president of the Republic Aviation Corporation, said today that reports of projected lay-offs resulting from production cutbacks at the company's Farmingdale, L.I., plant had been exaggerated.

Premier Khrushchev has declared that there are "no reasons for serious disputes" between the United States and the Soviet Union because their interests "do not clash directly anywhere." However, the Soviet Premier said, a visit by President Kennedy to the Soviet Union at the present time would not be wise.

Three high executives of the Port of New York Authority have received raises of $5,000 each, to bring their annual salaries to $45,000. The bi-state agency also gave substantial increases to other executives and authorized better retirement benefits.

The Russian Children's Welfare Society will benefit from a cocktail dansant, to be held in the Crystal Suite of the Savoy Hilton on May 10. Princess Diane Eristavi and Princess Mary Troubetzkoy are co-chairmen for the event. The president of the society is Princess Nicholas Troubetzkoy.

Miss Helen Lee Lawrence and Allen Brush Pierce plan to be married in the summer. Mr. and Mrs. John T. Lawrence of 876 Park Avenue and Southampton, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter to the son of Mrs. William James of Dublin, N.H., and the late Winslow Shelby Pierce.

ROME, April 25 The Roman Catholic Church is willing to make considerable concessions on practical grounds to meet the "separated brethren" half way in achieving Christian unity, Augustin Cardinal Bea said today.

The Ralph M. Chait Galleries, importers of Chinese works of art for more than fifty years, have leased space for a groundfloor shop in the Corning Glass Building, 12 East Fifty-sixth Street, which it will occupy in the fall. The lease was arranged by Joseph A. Grotto, assistant

Directors of Investors Diversified Services, Inc., the nation's biggest investment company group, recommended yesterday a stock reclassification plan that would give equal voting rights to its common and class A shares outstanding.
WASHINGTON, April 25 The Defense Department lifted its ban on Government-paid travel by military dependents today. The action will permit families to join thousands of service men in Europe.

At the Marshall Chess Club a reception and buffet was given recently in honor of Bobby Fischer, the winner of the Interzonal Tournament in Stockholm, and America's favorite to win in the coming Candidates' Tournament in Curacao.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., April 25 Wilburn Sells, a hurdler, broke one Rutgers record and tied another as the Scarlet track team defeated Columbia today, 106 2/3 42 1/3.

The merger-bound Norfolk and Western Railway presently is discussing consolidation with the Delaware and Hudson Railroad, a wholly owned subsidiary of the Delaware and Hudson Company, a holding concern.

CHICAGO, April 25 The Inland Steel Company reported today that profits for the first quarter were more than double those of the 1961 period, and its chairman welcomed limited Government intervention to protect economic stability.
LOS ANGELES, April 25 (UPI) Mass picketing of a closed hearing by a subcommittee of the House Committee on Un-American Activities decreased in size today.

PINEHURST, N.C., April 25 (AP) The defending champion, Bill Hyndman 3d, of Philadelphia, and the medalist, Cobby Ware of Augusta, Ga., were defeated in the North and South amateur golf tournament today.

A program to put more punch behind the daily newspaper industry's advertising sales efforts was announced yesterday at the annual meeting of the Bureau of Advertising of the American Newspaper Publishers Association.
Spring arrived on the Columbia University campus last night to the sounds of police whistles, sirens, firecrackers, bursting paper bags of water and the youthful chant of "let's go to Barnard!"
GENEVA, April 25 The Soviet Union rejected as "utterly unacceptable" today the United States proposals for guaranteeing the peace once the world had completely disarmed.

The Libbey-Owens-Ford Glass Company, flat glass manufacturer with executive offices in Toledo, Ohio, has acquired Bogardus, Wilson, Ltd., of Vancouver. B.C., and its three affiliated distributing companies.

The visit to the United States by Harold Macmillan, British Prime Minister, is made at this time not because of any special world crisis but for the more prosaic reason that Mr. Macmillan had accepted an invitation a long time ago to speak to the American Newspaper Publishers Association, now meeting in New York.

The revelation that Andrei P. Kirilenko, Communist party boss of Sverdlovsk, has been secretly raised to full membership in the party. Presidium is the most interesting piece of internal political information to emerge from this week's Moscow meeting of the Supreme Soviet.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, April 25 Prince Bernhard of the Netherlands announced in the Hague tonight that the Erasmus Prize for 1961-62 would be awarded to Prof. Romano Guardini of the University of Munich.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., April 25 The General Electric Company's seventieth annual meeting here today turned into a running verbal battle between Ralph J. Cor diner, chairman, and Mrs. Wilma Soss, president of the Federation of Women Shareholders in American Business, Inc.

GENEVA, April 25 The United States has warned the neutralist delegations at the disarmament conference here against walking out of the talks because of its resumption of nuclear tests in the atmosphere.

Mayor Wagner declared yesterday that the city must be prepared to impose new special taxes next year to help meet the cost of services that were needed and desired
THE buzz of the mosquito is the imminent bane of fair weather. For believers in urban air, closed windows and air conditioning leave much to be desired and the only solution is screens.
PALM BEACH, Fla., April 25 President Kennedy issued an order today making it possible for United States soldiers wounded in fighting like that in Vietnam to receive the Pur ple Heart.
An Indian shipping official said here yesterday that the growing merchant marine of India would probably reach 1,500,000 gross tons by 1966. Ten years ago fewer than 400,000 tons were in the fleet.
TRENTON, April 25 The State Commissioner of Banking and Insurance granted the New Jersey Blue Cross a 19.9 per cent increase in rates today. The rise would take effect Sept. 1.

Prices on the New York Stock Exchange registered yesterday their bigest one-day loss since Sept. 19, 1960. It was however, an orderly retreat. Volume barely expanded. Pressure from big blocks apparently sold by institutions was absorbed by the specialists on the exchange floor.

The Board of Education and the United Federation of Teachers held their first bargaining session yesterday since the oneday teachers' strike on April 11. The federation, bargaining agent for the city's 40,000 teach

The high-grade bond market marked time yesterday waiting for announcement of the Treasury's decision of the terms for refunding of $11,683,000,000 of debt securities due in May and June. The announcement is expected today. About $9,000,000,000 of the maturing debt is held by private investors.
MOSCOW, April 25 A leading Soviet playwright said in the Supreme Soviet today that Jews were among the principal victims of Nazi death camps. The statement attracted attention among some observers
MOSCOW, April 25 Premier Khrushchev disclosed today that he had established a high Government agency to coordinate the Soviet Union's expanding program of foreign trade and economic aid.

WASHINGTON, April 25 Arthur S. Flemming, Director of Defense Mobilization during President Dwight D. Eisenhower's term, explained today why he had let windfalls in copper go to copper suppliers rather than to the taxpayers.

IT appears as if some out standing fishermen are having a bit of trouble with pictures these days. Ted williams, the lean and eventempered baseball player turned outdoorsman is one example. The Orvis fishing tackle people in Vermont are another.

FLEMINGTON, N.J., April 25 The possibility of a general increase in stainless steel prices in the rest of 1962 is "remote," Joel Hunter, president of the Crucible Steel Company of America, said after the annual meeting here today.
BUENOS AIRES, April 25 President Jos Maria Guido announced tonight that he had nullified recent Congressional elections. Dr. Guido, acceding to the demands of Argentina's military

The First Boston Corporation and Johnston, Lemon Co. and associated underwriters offered yesterday 150,000 cumulative preferred shares, $4.80 series, of the Washington Gas Light Company at a price of $100 a share.

Collies have been among the first ten in American Kennel Club registrations for many years, but never in first place. Mrs. William H. Long Jr. of Oyster Bay. L. I., a leading breeder, exhibitor and judge, is glad. Overpopularity would hurt the breed, she says.
BOSSIER CITY, La., April 25 (AP) Fire damaged the summer cottage of a Shreveport integration leader early today, about fourteen hours after an explosion rocked a new $30,000 Negro Masonic Lodge.
CAMDEN, N.J., April 25 A master plan for city-wide redevelopment that would increase property values from the present $340,000,000 to $680,000,000 by 1980 was released today.
CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., April 25 The nation's lunarflight program received a welcome lift today when an eightengine Saturn was launched successfully for the second time in two attempts.
WORCESTER, Mass., April 26--Don Reidl, a junior right hander, pitched a no-hit game today as the Holy Cross baseball team defeated Dartmouth, 6--1.
WASHINGTON, April 26-- Two principal factors drove President Kennedy to the decision he had hoped he would never have to make--the order to resume atmospheric tests.

WASHINGTON, April 26-- The railroad and trucking industries reported today that freight movements last week were substantially higher than the year-ago levels. Comparisons with over the prior week were mixed.
MOSCOW, April 26--The Soviet Union sought today to muster world opinion against the United States for its resumption of nuclear testing.
The United States Treasury gold stock fell last week for the eighth time in the sixteen weeks of 1962. The Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday

ONE of the most excited and exuberant first-nighters at "Solo," a program of six scenes by Sylvia Leigh and Mark Justin that opened last night at the East End Theatre, proved to be a young woman in red.

ORADELL, N.J., April 26 --Mrs. Philip Cudone of the Forest Hill Field Club won the season's opening tournament of the Garden State Women's Golf Association today over the 6,164-yard, par-73 Hackensack Country Club course.
CHICAGO, April 26 (AP)-- The Los Angeles Dodgers hit four homers today, two of them by Willie Davis, and defeated the Chicago Cubs, 12--5. The Cubs made six errors.
WASHINGTON, April 26-- The executive council of the merged labor federation today gave one of its affiliates permission to try to take some members from another.

POSSIBLY never before in the many thousands of years since man first turned sand into glass have as many glass-making techniques been explored simultaneously as today. Much of the resulting excitement is evident in the two exhibitions that will open here on Tuesday.

THERE are two good shows at Durlacher's, 11 East Fifty-seventh Street. Eliot Hodgkin is showing meticulous still lifes of berries in baskets, onions, mushrooms, artichokes, garlic, apples, and feathers. However indigestible this sounds all together, Mr. Hodgkin's pictures, done in high-fidelity tempera reproduction, are thoroughly digestible one at a time.
Tampa, Fla. borrowed $15,400,000 in the bond market yesterday at an interest cost of 3.4568 per cent to finance sewerage improvements.

WASHINGTON, April 26-- Senators examining the Government's stockpiling operations tried to find out from Dr. Arthur S. Flemming today who might have influenced him to release copper suppliers from Government contracts in 1955.

Stockholders of Trans World Airlines, Inc., at the annual meeting in Kansas City, Mo., yesterday dedicated a memorial to the company's founder, Jack Frye, who was killed in an Arizona automobile accident in 1959.

SUMMER will soon be "icumen in"--which means that people will soon be cooking out. This brings up the problems of how to make that old barbecue sauce seem just a bit different, and what to put in the salad apart from some tired iceberg lettuce and the same French dressing.
A leading spokesman for the port's maritime industry yesterday urged the International Longshoremen's Association to consider forgoing wage increases.
WARSAW, April 26--Wladyslaw Gomulka, Polish Communist leader, has sharply rebuked the Polish press and television industry for deference to Western ways.
Firm prices maintained their sway over the bond market yesterday except in the field of convertible debentures, which were affected adversely by further weakness in common stocks.

WASHINGTON, April 26 (UPI)--Senator Olin D. Johnston, Democrat of South Carolina, today accused supporters of the Administration's civil rights bill of dragging in the race issue as a "smokescreen of emotion to hide the unconstitutionality" of the measure.
The United States Steel Corporation and the Bethlehem Steel Company were indicted here yesterday by a Federal grand jury on charges of violating the antitrust laws.

WASHINGTON, April 26-- The Democratic Governor of New Jersey and the Republican Governor of Massachusetts today joined the ranks of supporters of the Kennedy Administration's $500,000,000 urban mass transportation program.
Messages to keep the buses and subways clean have been issued by the New York Transit Authority in Latin and twenty other real or fancied languages.

Moscow, April 26--The Soviet Union announced today the launching of the fourth instrumented satellite in its current series of space exploration. The latest vehicle, known as Cosmos IV, is circling the earth every ninety and six-tenths ...
ATLANTA, April 26--Legislators failed tonight to agree on changes in Georgia's county unit election system designed to make it acceptable to the Federal courts.

AN exhibition of thirteen miniature chests of drawers will open April 30 at Black Starr Frost. They will be presented by the Gorham Corporation, which until recently had a controlling interest in the store. The miniatures, adapted from antiques, vary in style but not in function. All of them were designed to hold life-sized silver.

ELISABETHVILLE, the Congo April 26 (AP)--Foreign Minister Evariste Kimbe announced today that President Moise Tshombe would leave for Leopoldville May 3 for further talks with Premier Cyrille Adoula on unifying the Congo.
CHICAGO, April 26 (AP)-- New-crop soybean futures rallied well in the final minutes of transactions today on the Board of Trade and finished strong; other months and the grains were genearlly weak.

YONKERS, April 26--William J.F. Duggan, the official auditor of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York, died today in St. Joseph's Hospital here. He was 68 years old and lived at 312 East 241st Street, the Bronx.

A one-day boycott of white merchants sponsored by Negro ministers in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn has led to a pledge by the merchants to help improve economic and social conditions in the community.
A plainclothes squad except for the commanding officer was transferred from the north end of the Bronx yesterday after being accused of loose enforcement of the gambling laws.
KARACHI, Pakistan, April 26--The long-standing Kashmir problem seems to be leading Pakistan and India, into a renewed period of bitterness.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., April 26--Julius Emspak, secretarytreasurer of the United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers of America, died today of a heart attack at Lawrence Hospital. He was 57 years old and lived in Tuckahoe.
WASHINGTON, April 26-- Department store sales in the nation for the week ended Saturday, April 21, were 15 per cent above sales in the corresponding week last year.

CHICAGO, April 26--The nation's railroads served notice today that they wanted President Kennedy's Administration to hold the anti-inflation line on wage and fringe benefit recommendations for 450,000 offtrain employes.
SAN ANTONIO, April 26 (AP)--Bob Shave Jr. and Bill Collins finished with five-underpar 66's today to share the first-round lead in the $30,000 Texas open golf tournament.

ANYONE who wants to be somebody different this summer apparently has only to fling herself into one of the new active sportswear or beach ensembles. There is a long list of characters from which to choose.

The extent to which government in France has become presidential rather than parliamentary was demonstrated yesterday. The new Premier. Georges Pompidou, who made his maiden speech, has never served in Parliament, never been elected to an office, and he spoke for President de Gaulle to a Parliament that has, if possible, become less important than ever.

Record sales of $422,340,000 for the fiscal year ended on Jan. 31 were reported yesterday by Gimbel Brothers, Inc., the department store chain. This was 3.7 per cent above the preceding year's volume of $407,044,682.

The Women's Division of the American Friends of the Hebrew University will open to the public Sunday afternoon "Art Is Forever," its tenth annual spring art festival at University House, 11 East Sixtyninth Street. The show will continue there through May 8.

NEW ORLEANS, April 26-- One hundred Negroes will leave New Orleans in the next few days on "freedom buses" bound for New York, Chicago and California, George L. Singelmann, director of the White Citizens Council of Greater New Orleans, said today.
LEXINGTON, Ky., April 26-- Ridan came within a fifth of a second of the track record in winning the $33,200 Blue Grass Stakes today at Keeneland.

LOS ANGELES, April 26 (AP)--Willie Kirkland drove in two runs with a seventh-inning single today and Sam McDowell scored his first major league victory as the Cleveland Indians defeated the Los Angeles Angels, 6-4.

A block of 89,252 capital shares of Chesebrough-Pond's, Inc., was offered yesterday at $60.25 a share by Lazard Freres Co. and Lehman Brothers. The shares belong to a stockholder and the company will receive none of the proceeds.
LONDON, April 26--The British Government reduced the bank rate by one-half percentage point today to 4 per cent.

Stocks experienced a sizable loss again yesterday. The decline was not as sharp as on Wednesday but it was enough to roll key averages back to a new low and, in fact, to the lowest point since May 2, 1961.
Manhattan Republican leaders said yesterday that the 1962 campaign accent would be on "youth and fight." They announced one Senate and two Assembly candidates, all young lawyers.

WASHINGTON, April 26-- The United States will invite all nations tomorrow to join in the most extensive international project thus far in space -- the use of a flashing-light satellite to determine the shape of the earth.
GENEVA, April 26--The Soviet Union said today that it would continue its efforts at the disarmament conference "to unmask those who work against the peace."
MOSCOW, April 26--A prominent scientist said today that a "do-it-yourself" movement of scientific research was being promoted in the Soviet Union.

The Universal American Corporation paid $35 a share for the 130,000 shares of the Bohn Aluminum and Brass Corporation it recently acquired and has placed three of its officers on the eleven-man Bohn board.

PARIS, April 26--Raoul Salan former chief of the European Secret Army Organization in Algeria, was reported today to have set conditions for his participation in the preliminary phases of his forthcoming trial for insurrectional and terrorist activities.
SARASOTA, Fla., April 26-- Charles Francis Swift, who retired in 1959 as manager of the Men's Faculty Club of Columbia University in New York, died here today in his home. His age was 67.
BUENOS AIRES, April 26-- Delegates of the United States and Latin-American countries closed the third meeting of the governors of the Inter-American Development Bank today.
HAVANA, April 26 (UPI)-- Twenty-four persons were injured today in an explosion and fire that destroyed a Government fertilizer plant at El Cotorro, ten miles east of Havana.
DETROIT, April 26--Roman Catholics have started a drive ...

The Columbia Broadcasting System, which will televise a drama about abortion tomorrow night, announced yesterday that ten of its affiliated stations had refused to carry the program. The list includes stations in Boston, Providence, R.I.; Buffalo, Rochester, N.Y., Binghamton, N.Y., New Orleans and Milwaukee.

STERLING FOREST, N.Y., April 26--Five hundred New York City and suburban high school editors and student council presidents visited this burgeoning new scientific community today.
"X" marked the spot for a quick shift in investor thinking yesterday. This letter is the New York Stock Exchange symbol for the common shares of the United States Steel Cor- poration.
The Transamerica Corporation is planning to acquire the General Acceptance Company, Midwest, of Bartlesville, Okla., it was announced yesterday.
SALISBURY, Southern Rhodesia, April 26--Sir Roy Welensky wound up his re-election campaign tonight convinced that Britain was intent on "trimimng down" the Federation of Rhodesia and Nyasaland.
HEIDELBERG, April 26-- Gen. Bruce C. Clarke today termed the "best news in a long time" the Defense Department's lifting of its ban on government-paid travel by military dependents.
PALM BEACH, Fla., April 26 --President Kennedy will have a working luncheon in Washington, next Thursday with Dr. Alfons Gorbach. Austria, the White House an nounced today.

A Congressional committee conducting an inquiry into the state of the country's merchant marine will soon call industry officials and union officials in its search for answers to industry troubles, it was reported yesterday.
WASHINGTON, April 26--The National Guard Bureau stirred up a dispute with the nation's Governors today by telling them how it planned to spread a cut of 475 Army Guard units among the states.

WASHINGTON, April 26 (AP)--A thirteen-year legal battle ended today when the Government accepted the formula laid down by Federal Judge Walter J. LaBuy for E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., to liquidate its holding of General Motors Corporation stock.
The paper industry needs "some upward price adjustments," William R. Adams, president of the St. Regis Paper Company, said yesterday.
Spring is everywhere in evidence. Tulips bloom on Park Avenue, trees are in their first flush of tender green, and shad, with its incomparable roe, is at the peak of its season.
PINEHURST, N.C., April 26 (AP)--Billy Joe Patton shot three-under-par golf to day in defeating Charlie Smith, 3 and 1, in the quarter-finals of the sixty-second North and South amateur tournament.

"Light in August," one of William Faulkner's major experiments in stream-of-consciousness technique, will be brought to the screen next year by Abby Mann, the Academy Award-winning scenarist of "Judgment at Nuremberg."
DES MOINES, April 26 (AP) --Winners were crowned today in Classic and Regular Division singles, doubles and all-events as the fifty-ninth annual American Bowling Congress tournament ended.
LONDON, April 26--Prices of industrial shares and British Government securities rose on a wide front in the stock market today.
WASHINGTON, April 26-- The United States promised today to make "every possible effort" to achieve at the earliest possible moment a treaty forbidding nuclear tests.

The Soviet delegation proposed to hold a plenary meeting of the eighteen-nation disarmament committee on the question of the cessation of nuclear weapon tests in view of the fact that because of the actions of the United States the committee is now facing a completely new situation.

May potato futures prices fell 18 points (hundredths of a cent a pound) on a strong volume of 2,908 carlots on the New York Mercantile Exchange yesterday. Other months were unchanged to off 2 points on twenty-eight carlots, bringing total activity to 2,936 carlots.
CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., April 26--The first international satellite, a British experiment carried aloft by American rockets, was successfully or bited today.
LONDON, April 26--Pakistan pressed today for changes in the command structure of the Central Treaty Organization at a meeting of its military committee.
BERLIN, April 26--The Soviet Union has approached the United States with a proposal to restore freedom of movement in all parts of Berlin for the United States and Soviet commandants.

Before I take your questions, I should like to make a few comments on nuclear testing. First, I should like to urge all of you to study again carefully the address to the nation made by President Kennedy on March 2 on this subject.

Southerners, and not only Southerners, are making a constitutional argument against the literacy test bill now before the Senate. The argument rests on two propositions: (1) the Constitution gives the states absolute power to fix qualifications for voting, free from any Federal restraint; and (2) the proposed legislation would impinge on the states' rightful exercise of their power. We disagree on both points.
SAIGON, Vietnam, April 26-- Foreign Minister Vu-Van-Mau charged today that the Polish team on the International Control Commission showed consistent bias against South Viet nam.
AS things have turned out, no one really wants to celebrate the centenary of the Civil War.
Bobbie Brooks, Inc., Cleveland maker of women's apparel. acquired yesterday Colebrook, Inc., Colebrook Mills, Inc., and affiliated corporations.
Irwin Maier, president and publisher of The Milwaukee Journal, which is 72 per cent employe-owned, was elected president of the American Newspaper Publishers Association yesterday.
Mayor Wagner is against Representative Charles A. Buckley's return to the House seat he has held since 1935. He is also against Mr. Buckley's retaining the position of Democratic leader of the Bronx.

Bethlehem Steel Corporation has cut 5 to 10 per cent from its earlier estimate of 1962 steel industry production, despite favorable factors in some markets, Arthur B. Homer, chairman of the nation's second largest steel producer, reported yesterday.
GARDEN CITY, L.I., April 26--Governor Rockefeller said tonight he had no idea who would run against him this fall but, whoever it was, he himself would "run scared."

DOVER, Del., April 26-- Stockholders of the General Dynamics Corporation, the nation's largest defense contractor, were told today that the company had turned the corner following its stunning losses in the commercial jet transport field.
Prime Minister Macmillan, in a speech here last night, counseled the West to continue seeking agreements withthe Soviet Union. His advice was "to be firm but patient;
WASHINGTON, April 26-- The United States moved toward new economic aid agreements with the United Arab Republic today.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., April 26--The United States Civil Service Commission undertook at a public hearing today to determine whether political activity by a civil defense director would be a violation of the Hatch Act.

AT long last shad hogs have had it in Massachusetts. A shad hog is one who catches and keeps large quantities of shad when he really needs only a few. A few is all he's going to be able to keep from now on because the state has set a limit.

BOURNEMOUTH, England, April 26 (UPI)--Rod Laver rounding into form for a defense of his Wimbledon title, advanced to the semi-finals of the British hard-courts tennis tournament today by defeating Alan Mills of England, 6-3, 6-2, 5-7, 6-2.
The controversy holding up plans to fly some eighty foreign tennis players here for the United States amateur championships at Forest Hills, Queens, has been settled amicably.
WASHINGTON, April 26-- Nassau County had the healthiest economic record of any county in New York State in 1960, the Bureau of the Census reported today.
WESTBURY, L.I., April 26-- A group of harness-racing fans enjoyed a new experience for a Metropolitan New York track tonight by participating in a pay-off that has become known as a "tax double."
ALGIERS, April 26--In a new attack on the essential air links between Algeria and France, Secret Army Organization terrorists blew up a commercial airliner at the Algiers Airport early today.
MAUBEUGE, France, April 24--A pale, hazy moon hovered over this town this evening, the symbol of what might be called the miracle of Maubeuge.

WASHINGTON, April 26--Now that the Kennedy Administration has decided to go forward with atomic testing, maybe its scientific leaders will have a little more time to deal with the non-military problems of the nation and its economy.

James J. Moran, a former Fire Department official who has spent more than ten years in prison for extortion, perjury and income tax evasion, will receive a Federal parole on June 25, a member of his family said last night.
ALBANY, April 26--The construction of an arterial highway for thirteen miles along the south shore of Staten Island was authorized in a bill signed by Governor Rockefeller today.

The Grand Prix de Puerto Rico, a new automobile race on the international calendar, to be run as the feature of a program scheduled Nov. 4 through 11, was announced here yesterday by the Puerto Rican Government. David Ash of New York, a widely known race driver and automobile sales executive, was named as the race organizer.
WASHINGTON, April 26--The Treasury offered today three new issues of Government securities to investors who hold three issues amounting to almost $11,700,000,000 and maturing in May and June.

PARIS, April 26--France's new Premier, Georges Pompi dou, bid today for the National Assembly's approval with a program emphasizing measures to raise living standards, speed industrial expansion and increase financial stability.
A study published yesterday indicates that Premier Khrushchev's assertion that the Soviet Union will overtake the United States in industrial output by 1970 will prove to be wrong.

The National Foreign Trade Council has asked President Kennedy to "hold the line," as far as the nation's shipping practices are concerned, in his forthcoming discussions with Prime Minister Macmillan.

WASHINGTON, April 26-- Secretary of State Dean Rusk said today the Soviet Union seemed interested in handling the Berlin dispute "responsibly." But he indicated that there had been almost no progress on the central issues.]

THE World Bridge Federation's tournament for mixed teams is scheduled to begin today at Cannes, on the French Riviera, with three United States teams entered and one or more teams from each of eighteen other countries.
This has been a fruitful week in mankind's efforts to probe the space dimension that has been added to human capabilities by the fantastic progress in rocket technology.
Parkinson's disease, or shaking palsy, may be the result of a specific biochemical deficiency in the body, according to a report yesterday to the American Academy of Neurology.

Gentlemen, I deeply appreciate the privilege of addressing this gathering tonight. I recall that President Wilson on one occasion began a speech to the American Bar Association with these words: "I used to be a lawyer, but now I am a reformed character." Similarly, I used to to be a publisher--not, alas, a newspaper publisher before whom the politicians cringe, but just a book publisher who is bullied by the authors.

Reports were confirmed yesterday by Sidney Kingsley that his next play, unnamed as yet is to open at the Brooks Atkinson Theatre on Oct. 22. As is customary with Mr. Kingsley, he will also be the producerdirector.

The Princess Ann Girl Coat Company, one of the country's largest manufacturers of outerwear for young women, has leased a new building containing 34,000 square feet of space in the Fair Ridge Shopping Center on Bergen Boulevard, near Walker Street, in Fairview, N.J.
LONDON, April 26--Sir Harrie Stewart Wilson Massey, general director of the British satellite project, is a man far more interested in pure science than in reaching for the moon.
WHITE PLAINS, April 26-- Building contractors of Westchester and Putnam counties asked President Kennedy and Governor Rockefeller today to curb the "economic anarchy" of labor unions.
The International Division of the Maritime Trades Department has scored a major incursion into the ranks of the International Transport Workers Federation.

THOUGH admittedly stranger things have happened in the art world, a week that offers full-dress celebrations both of Picasso's eightieth birthday and the fiftieth anniversary of Sir Lawrence Alma-Tadema's death testifies to an astonishing range of appreciation.

The Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) announced yesterday that its net income in the first quarter of 1962 rose to $231,000,000, equal to $1.07 a share, from $193,000,000, or 89 cents a share, in the corresponding 1961 period.

The Chemical Bank New York Trust Company has leased the second to fifth floors in the fifty-story office building being erected at 277 Park Avenue. The four floors will have 300,000 square feet of the total of 1,450,000 square feet in the skyscraper, which will occupy the block bounded by Park and Lexington Avenues, Forty-seventh and Forty-eighth Streets.

Track and field's biggest week-end of the year will en gage thousands of athletes in competition today and tomorrow in the Penn Relays at Philadelphia, the Drake Relays at Des Moines, the Mount San Antonio Relays at Walnut, Calif, and the Pilot Relays in Norfolk, Va.
Perhaps the most noticeable feature of the stock market decline of the last four and a half months has been the calm with which the average investor has greeted it.

THE two one-act plays that opened last evening at the Vandam Theatre are the longest short plays to visit Off Broadway in many a balmy April.
The traditional barriers against liquor advertising seem to be toppling one by one.
BUENOS AIRES, April 26-- The Chamber of Deputies recessed tonight until May 22 with the Presidency still apparently under the control of the country's military leaders.
ALBANY, April 26--The state established legal standards today for the construction of group and family fall-out shelters.
The United Federation of Teachers has asked the Board of Education to allocate more than the $41,700,000 projected for increased teachers' pay and improved working conditions.

First-quarter profits of the Shell Oil Company rose to $38,266,921, or 63 cents a share, from $34,709,182, or 57 cents a share, in the corresponding period last year, Monroe E. Spaght, president, reported at the annual meeting here yesterday.
GOLDSTONE, Calif., April 26 --The United States' spacecraft Ranger IV crashed onto the moon today after a flight of just under sixty-four hours.

Five fillies and mares contested the seven-furlong Level Best Handicap at Aqueduct yesterday, with Nicholas A. Martini's 3-2 favorite, Pepper Patch, home first by a nose ahead of Ogden Phipps' Funloving.

GRANADOS' "Goyescas," a cycle of six piano pieces inspired by the paintings and drawings of Goya, was played in its entirety last night by Mario Miranda in a program sponsored by the Spanish Institute in Grace Rainey Rogers Auditorium of the Metropolitan Museum of Art.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 26--The Security Council will meet tomorrow on Pakistan's charge that India is threatening to use violence in their fourteen-year-old dispute over Kashmir.

Earnings of the Pittsburgh Plate Glass Company rose $4,638,579 over those of the initial three months last year, reflecting a 17 per cent increase in first-quarter sales, the report disclosed yesterday.

LISBON, Portugal, April 26 --Dr. Adriano Moreira, the Portuguese Minister for Overseas Provinces, announced today that a new "rural labor code" for Portuguese territories would become effective Oct. 1. It replaces the 1928 Native Workers Code.
SELDOM have college girls bent so studiously over their desks in deep concentration. The desks had mirrors and the girls were studying themselves their makeup and skin care.

The annual Bishops' Fund Appeal for Overseas Relief will be conducted in the 402 parishes of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York, beginning tomorrow and continuing through May 6. Elsewhere in the country the campaign ended on April 1.

The semi-annual game of "Change the Clocks" will be played tonight. In seventeen states, the District of Columbia and parts of nine other states, all timepieces should be turned ahead one hour for Daylight Saving Time, which goes into effect at 2 A.M. tomorrow.

Mrs. James Russell Lowell Jr. and Mrs. William J. Butler, luncheon co-chairmen, have announced that arrangements have been made to hold the second annual Lincoln Center Seat Endowment Campaign Committee luncheon May 7 at the Tavern-on-the-Green.
LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, April 27 United Nations headquarters here announced today that Robert K.A. Gardiner, chief of the United Nations Congo operation, would fly to Elisabethville Monday.

WASHINGTON, April 27 (AP) The Securities and Exchange Commission asked 2,000 corporations today to supply information for the Government's investigation of the securities industry. The corporations were those whose stocks were traded on the over-the-counter market.
Dr. Norris Folger Hall, Professor Emeritus of Chemistry at the University of Wisconsin, died Thursday at his home in Danbury, N.H. His age was 70.

WASHINGTON, April 27 (AP) An order designed to ease the disposal of excess materials from the Government's $7,700,000,000 stockpile was signed today by Edward A. McDermott, director of the Office of Emergency Planning.

CHICAGO, April 27 Prof. Karl Barth, the eminent Protestant theologian, received an honorary Doctor of Divinity Degree from the University of Chicago this afternoon at a special convocation called for him alone.
BOSTON, April 27 Richard Burgin is doffing the hat he has worn for forty-two years as concertmaster of the Boston Symphony Orchestra.
Awards were presented last night at a banquet in the Biltmore Hotel for the year's best nontheatrical entries in the fourth American Film Festival.

Some superior musicianship lightened the humidity in Carnegie Recital Hall last night as Ma Si-Hon, the Chinese-American violinist, and his wife, Tung Kwong-Kwong, pianist, presented a program of sonatas. They played three works, Mozart's F major (K. 377), Brahms' G major, Op. 78 and Bartok's No. 1.
ALBANY, April 27 Opponents of the proposed Huntington Hartford restaurant in Central Park have won a round in their fight to force New York City to abandon the multimilliondollar project.
Despite his high weight of 125 pounds, the 4-year-old Carry Back is the 7 5 overnight favorite among the dozen racers in today's nineteenth running of the Grey Lag Handicap at Aqueduct.
TRENTON, April 27 The State Tax Policy Commission wound up three days of public hearings on state taxes here today.
MADRID, April 27 The Spanish Government is planning an attempt to stimulate foreign investment in industry by guaranteeing the right to repatriate both capital and profits after two years.
CLEVELAND, April 27 (AP) Dick Donovan of the Cleveland Indians limited the Minnesota Twins to six hits tonight in scoring his fourth straight victory, 7 2.
A heavy program of new corporate and municipal debt offerings is scheduled for next week. A total of $220,000,000 worth of fixed-interest securities is expected.
