Federal Judge Archie O. Dawson denied a motion yesterday to dismiss an indictment charging income tax evasion against J. Truman Bidwell, former chairman of the board of governors of the New York Stock Exchange.

DETROIT, April 27 The National Catholic Educational Association elected Coadjutor Archbishop John Cody of New Orleans, as its president-general today. Archbishop Cody is a stanch advocate of integration.
CHICAGO, April 27 The American Association of University Professors opened its annual meeting today split on the issue of church-state separation in Federal aid to education.

DES MOINES, April 27 (AP) Texas Southern's twelve-man squad set two of the day's four meet records as the rain-splattered fifty-third Drake Relays opened today with another disappointing performance by John Uelses, the 16-foot pole vaulter.
WASHINGTON, April 27 Gherman S. Titov, the Soviet astronaut, will be invited to visit Cape Canaveral next week to see the preparations for the United States' next man-inspace flight.
SALISBURY, Southern Rhodesia, Saturday, April 28 Sir Roy Welensky was returned to office as Prime Minister of the Federation of Rhodesia and Nyasaland in yesterday's election.
BALBOA, C.Z., April 27 "All vessels without exception seeking transit through the Panama Canal are subject to admeasurement and security regulations, an official waterway statement said today.

FOR almost forty years women who prefer quality and beauty to fashion extremes have come to designer Bernard Newman. He has dressed them in little black crepes at Bergdorf Goodman and wrapped them in ostrich feathers at movie studios.
On the theory that apartment seekers prefer to see exactly where they will live before signing a contract, a builder in Queens is completing his cooperatives in advance of sales.

Net earnings of the American Motors Corporation for its second fiscal quarter, ended on March 31, amounted to $8,850,200, equal to 48 cents a share, the company reported yesterday. This was four times greater than the $2,208,264, or 12 cents a share, cleared for the year-earlier period.
The directors of the American Maize Products Company proposed yesterday a threefor-one split of the common stock.

The Weyerhaeuser Company plans to expand its activities in the paper industry by acquiring Crocker, Burbank C., Assn., Fitchburg, Mass., paper producer, for more than $28,000,000 in Weyerhaeuser stock.
ALBANY, April 27 The participation of New York City in the financing of a balletoperetta theatre in the Lincoln Center project was authorized in a bill signed by Governor Rockefeller today.

WEST BERLIN, April 27 Lucius Clay, the great proconsul of our Republic, will leave here next month after having helped save West Berlin's freedom for a second time. It is no accident his office in American headquarters here is on a street renamed Clayallee by grateful Berliners.
The high-grade bond market snapped out of a week-long lull yesterday as dealers and investing institutions moved swiftly to make the most of the terms of the Treasury's $11,683,000,000 refunding.
NONE of six cafeterias in museums and parks in this city visited this week was found to merit unqualified approval on all counts.
Sonny Liston of Philadelphia, whose challenge for Floyd Patterson's world heavyweight boxing championsnip has been accepted, was denied a license yesterday to fight in New York State.
A centrally air-conditioned ranch home, priced at $21,490, is on display in a Long Island development.

HIGHLAND MILLS, N.Y., April 27 When it became known today that Sonny Liston was not socially eligible to be invited to fight for the heavyweight championship in New York. Floyd Patterson shook his head and asked, "What's he done?"
Unequal pay for women was assailed yesterday as "intolerable" and "disgraceful" at a Congressional hearing in Federal Courthouse here on equalpay bills now before Congress.

WASHINGTON, April 27 The Air Force announced today the establishment of a special warfare center at Eglin Air Force Base in Florida as part of the Administration's growing effort to develop skills for guerrilla warfare.

WITH the welcome change to warm weather New Yorkers are busy refurbishing terraces, prettying country cottages or just opening wide the windows of year-round homes and injecting into the interior a light, airy look.
WASHINGTON, April 27 Secretary of State Dean Rusk and Anatoly F. Dobrynin, the Soviet Ambassador, held their third and most intensive discussion of the Berlin problem today.

TUNIS, April 27 A crisis appears to be developing within the Algerian nationalist movement that could jeopardize the peace accords signed last month between the French Government and the Algerian Provisional Government.
Mayor Wagner said last night that the Negroes "fellow citizens of ours" arriving from the South in "freedom buses" would be welcome in New York City.

WASHINGTON, April 27 (AP) Southern Senators said today that if literacy tests had been used to keep qualified Negroes from voting, the Justice Department had fallen down on the job of enforcing the law.

RANGOON, Burma, April 21 Being a political pris oner in Burma, under the current military regime, is about as pleasant as confinement can be, according to accounts circulating in the ruling army circles.

Upton Sinclair was in New York last night for the first time in twenty-five years considerably calmer and less vocal than he was in the old muckraking days. But the novelist's thinking was no less incisive.

SOME less obvious pitfalls in menu planning for family or guests can be avoided by following a few principles. The season and the anticipated weather pattern can offer a valuable guide to the choice of dishes, bearing in mind the known tastes and preferences of those to be served.
PHILADELPHIA, April 27 Villanova and Michigan, which together won five of last year's eight major relays, today captured the first two big prizes of the sixty-eighth annual Penn Relays.

For its fifth and final chamber-music concert of the season, given last night at the New School for Social Research, the resuscitated United States section of the International Society for Contemporary Music presented four works fascinatingly diverse in style and content.
PLAINVIEW, Tex., April 26 This town has a population of 18,000 persons, a thirty-mile view of the Texas panhandle and the biggest concentration of Billie Sol Estes's grain storage tanks in Texas.
ATLANTA, April 27 Legislators modified Georgia's county unit election system today, but it was attacked immediately as unconstitutional before a three-judge Federal Court.
WASHINGTON, April 27 A union spokesman said today that railroad industry statements about a report of a Presidential emergency board were "brazen" and "unethical."
The producers of "The Festival of the Performing Arts" are preparing for a series next season although a return engagement is far from guaranteed.
WASHINGTON, April 27 Two New York State Republicans objected today to giving the Kennedy Administration long-range authority to commit Federal funds for urban transit programs.

THE book "Five Weeks to Winning Bridge," by Al fred Sheinwold, has been the biggest-selling bridge book of the last two years, in a 50cent paperback edition published by Pocket Books. Now it has been issued in a hardbound and somewhat expanded version by Simon and Schuster at $4.95.

A living room measuring 20 by 15 feet and a formal dining room are features of a ranch model on display at Town House, a new development on Little Neck Avenue, south of Jerusalem Avenue, in North Bellmore, L.I. The rooms are accessible from a foyer measuring 9 by 10 feet.
NEW ORLEANS, April 27 Plans of the Greater New Orleans White Citizens Council to send a busload of thirty-nine Negroes to New York City were postponed today.

With a $4,000,000 increase in first-quarter profits, the Union Carbide Corporation "is reasonably optimistic about earnings for the balance of the year," Morse G. Dial, chairman and chief executive officer, told shareholders at the annual meeting here yesterday.
The New York State Banking Board in effect turned thumbs down this week on a petition from the state's 127 savings banks for permission to pay a flat 4 per cent interest rate on all deposits.

"Old fashioned economics" without any intervention by the Kennedy Administration should have been given a chance to operate with respect to the attempted increase in steel prices earlier this month, E.J. Hanley, president of the Allegheny Ludlum Steel Corporation, said yesterday.

The rally President Kennedy will attend in Madisbn Square Garden on May 20 is planned as the showpiece of twentyeight simultaneous rallies across the nation in support of his program of medical care for the aged through Social Security.

Several major oil companies issued first-quarter reports of higher sales but lower earnyesterday indicating a patternings than in the first three months of 1961. The declines in profits generally were attributed to lower prices for refined products, particularly gasoline.

Children's rooms, furnished with contemporary, traditional and Danish themes, are now on view in Macy's fourth-floor juvenile furniture department. The three furniture lines were designed by Larry Peabody for Child Craft.
The Alliance for Progress is being frankly discussed and criticized in the United States and Latin America without shaking its essential soundness or dampening the hopes it has aroused.
REDDING, Conn., April 27 Money is pouring into the estate of Mark Twain in a manner it never did during his lifetime.
ALBANY, April 27 The Board of Regents moved today to tighten its procedures in examinations for medical licenses.

KARACHI, Pakistan, April 27 The Pakistani concept of "basic democracy" will be tested tomorrow when 80,000 electors choose a National Assembly. The same electors will name Assemblies for East and West Pakistan, the country's two provinces, on May 6.
PARIS, April 27 Premier Georges Pompidou won today an unimpressive investiture vote 259 to 128 from a National Assembly that is sulking over its lost power and prerogatives.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 27 The United States formally protested today the circulation as an official United Nations document of a letter from the East German Government on nuclear disarmament.
The court-appointed trustees of the Swan-Finch Oil Corporation reported yesterday to Federal Judge Edmund L. Patmieri that the corporation now has a cash balance of more than $1,000,000.
BUENOS AIRES, April 27 Alvaro Co Alsogaray, who conducted Argentina's stabilization and austerity program for nearly two years, returned today to the post of Economics Minister.

AFTER a galvanic quarter of a century or so on the deck of Time magazine, Mr. Matthews went to live quietly in London. Three years ago he came back to tour the enormous country behind Manhattan's towers.

PLAINVIEW, Tex., April 27 The sixteen-county South Plains area of Texas is one of the biggest cotton-growing regions in the country, and for the last five years its inhabitants have been told that consumption is the answer to prosperity.

WASHINGTON, April 27 The Government announced today it had seized more than 5,400 "giant economy size" jars of Maxwell House instant coffee. It explained that the package cost more per ounce than the regular six-ounce jars.
WASHINGTON, April 27 The International Ladies Garment Workers Union will make available $100,000,000 in the next four years to help finance family farms.
LONDON, April 27 Britain was threatened today with a nation-wide strike of longshoremen to begin at midnight May 13.
WASHINGTON, April 27 The merged labor federation's top command approved today an organizing drive aimed at signing up 750,000 new union members in the Los Angeles area.

LONDON, April 27 Prices of most industrial shares continued to rise in the stock market today despite heavy profit taking. The threat of a national dock strike seemed to have little effect on the market.

As the United Nations Security Council resumes consideration of the Kashmir question, this nagging issue between India and Pakistan appears no more susceptible to settlement now than ever before. A solution depends on concessions by India, which has as yet shown no readiness to compromise even if faced with an adverse United Nations vote.

BONN, Germany, April 27--Dr. Heinrich von Brentano, former Foreign Minister of West Germany, will fly to Washington Sunday, admittedly worried that something has happened to the common West German-United States policy he helped create.
WASHINGTON April 27 Maj. Arch E. Roberts was ordered relieved today of his active duty assignment by the Army. He will be returned to reserve status.

SAN ANTONIO, April 27 (AP) Joe Campbell of Pendleton, Ind., shot a three-under-par 68 for a total of 135 today and took a one-stroke lead in the $30,000 Texas open on the 6,616yard Oak Hills Country Club course.

GEORGETOWN, British Guinea, April 27 The Government, defeated last night in a vote on its revised budget, is believed to be planning to introduce the legislation again next week and muster its majority to force the bill through.
BETHEL, Alaska, April 27 (UPI) Two men were found alive in the wreckage of an Army H-21 helicopter that crashed Wednesday killing the eight other persons aboard.
WASHINGTON, April 27 The United States set off two nuclear explosions today one in the atmosphere in the Pacific, the other underground in Nevada.
Broadway showmen have taken action that may lead to recognition of the Society of Stage Directors and Choreographers.

The nation's railroads have asked the White House for help in holding the anti-inflation line on wages and fringe benefits. The rail operators are worried over reports that a Presidential emergency board considering pay adjustments for 450,000 mechanical, maintenance and clerical employes plans to recommend increases in excess of the Administration's formula for gearing ...

RYE, N.Y., April 27 The formation of the Westchester Philharmonic Orchestra, a professional organization that will give ten concerts for adults and four for children next season, was announced here today.

LOS ANGELES, April 27 (AP) Don Drysdale, who had never beaten Pittsburgh in Los Angeles, scored his third victory in four decisions tonight as the Dodgers beat the league-leading Pirates, 7 2, before 40,509 fans.

HONG KONG, April 27 Communist China, condemning United States resumption of nuclear testing, warned today that the Chinese people together with the rest of the world "will eventually settle accounts with the United States."
LONDON, April 27 The Military Committee of the Central Treaty Organization reported "satisfactory progress" tonight on the planning for the defense of the Middle East againat Soviet aggression.
Mrs. Sally Bruce Kinsolving, an author, died yesterday in Laurel (Md.) Sanatorium, after a long illness. Her age was 86.

A mistrial in the libel suit of John Henry Faulk was denied yesterday after David Susskind, the television producer, had testified that 1,500 actors, writers, directors and technicians had been termed "politically undesirable" in a 1954 industrial "blacklist."
BEETHOVEN occupied yesterday afternoon's New York Philharmonic program, and there was one unfamiliar work on it the "Choral Fantasy." This is one of the more weird works in the canon.

CHICAGO, April 27 (AP) The first genuine crop scare of the year was felt in the wheat futures pit today and firmed all contracts on the Board of Trade. Other grains ranged from firm to weak in the most active trading in several days.

WESTBURY, L.I. April 27, A bit of harness racing nostalgia that dips back seven decades will be thrown into focus tomorrow night at Roosevelt Raceway as the Nassau County track makes a bit of history itself.
WASHINGTON, April 27 The Chinese Communists are said to be stepping up their military advisory program in North Vietnam to counter the continuing build-up of United States forces in South Vietnam.
WASHINGTON, April 27 Slumping sluggers such as Roger Maris might take note of the antidote the Yankees' famed home run hitter took today for his ailment.

Queens Borough President John T. Clancy said yesterday he opposed jet operations at La Guardia Airport "until such time as I can be assured that the people in Jackson Heights will not be affected adversely."
A survey of the theatre in India is made by Balwant Gargi, leading Indian playwright and authority on drama in his country. Called "Theatre in India," ...
LOUISVILLE, April 27 (AP) Two of racing's brightest stars, both Kentucky Derby material, make their Blue Grass State debut tomorrow when Churchill Downs opens its eighty-eighth spring meeting.

The Justice Department's Antitrust Division is considering a civil suit against four steel companies that were indicted Thursday on charges of conspiring to fix prices and rig bids in the sale of steel forgings.

WASHINGTON, April 27 An instrument invented for the Sperry Gyroscope Company gives a pilot continuous readings as to whether his aircraft will reach take-off speed at a safe point on the runway. This enables him, if something goes wrong, to abandon the faulty take-off.

It is being called the First International Webern Festival, for there is hope that it will be only the first of many such tributes. One of its events will be the organizational meeting of the International Webern Society, which is likely to be the group to uphold the torch.

Hodges on the legal aspects of the American Export Lines' proposed purchase of fourteen ships and the trade routes of the Isbrandtsen Steamship Company aroused widespread interest in the maritime industry last week. The steel-price controversy two and a half weeks ago provided the first sharp test of President Kennedy's anti-inflation policy for labor and management. The policy calls for "keeping their total increases in wages and profits in step with productivity." Mr. Kennedy, after persuading the steelworkers union to accept a non-inflationary wage settlement, wielded the farranging power of the Presidency to compel the steel companies to rescind an announced price rise.

SPRING is the time to set out tender bulbs for exoticlooking flowers in summer and fall. The earliest recommended planting dates for the New York latitude are May 1 to 15, when the weather is warm and the danger of frost is past. Bulbs, corms, tubers or rhizomes are generally available at garden centers and supermarkets. Nursery-grown started plants will produce flowers up to four weeks sooner.

ROD SERLING'S "Twilight Zone" may not go into total eclipse after all. The expanded version of "Twilight Zone" would go on the air possibly midway of the 1962-63 season or in the fall of 1963.

"Accent," which the Columbia Broadcasting System calls a "kaleidoscope of contemporary culture," will continue on television this summer. Recently there had been indications, the program series might be dropped next month.

Tax withholding on dividend and interest income, the hottest tax issue in nearly two decades, was debated in Congress and from speakers' rostrums with increasing intensity last week as the Senate Finance Committee continued its hearings on the Revenue Act of 1962. MINNEAPOLIS, April 29-- The League of Women Voters will begin tomorrow to shape the program to which it will devote its efforts for the next two years. The likelihood is that it will decide to pick up the cudgels again for the United Nations.

WARSAW, April 29--Stefan Cardinal Wyszynski was charged this week-end with trying to create an atmosphere of "persecution and martyrdom" in Poland to bolster the weakening position of the Roman Catholic Church.

Two engineering concerns have leased space in the Crystal Building, a twenty-two-story office structure being renovated at 801 Second Avenue, southwest corner of Forty-third Street. The building is owned and managed by Harry G. Silverstein Sons.

WASHINGTON, April 29-- A House Republican policy panel issued an analysis of Kennedy Administration spending proprosals today. It summed them up as "a pattern for poverty."

SCARSDALE, N.Y., April 29--Ruby Zemo's Dr. Ed, a son of Blenheim and grandson of Man o' War, kept the Al Low Memorial Trophy by repeating as the working hunter champion of the Boulder Brook horse show tonight.

WALNUT, Calif., April 29 (UPI)--Actually, it should have been no surprise when Lieut. Dave Tork of the Marines set a world pole vault record of 16 feet 2 inches yesterday. Tork had been predicting it for weeks.

FELTONVILLE, Pa., April 29 --Ch. Ah Sid's Dilettante, a red chow chow owned by Joan Wellborn's Ah Sid Kennels of Clinton, Md., claimed his second consecutive best-in-show award in two days today at the nineteenth annual Penn Treaty Kennel Club fixture.
MOSCOW, April 29--The Soviet Union announced tonight the composition of the Union Committee on Agriculture, which will be the highest coordinating agency for the nation's farms.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 29--The chief United States disarmament official commended today the contributions of the eight nonaligned nations to the disarmament conference in Geneva.

IN the enjoyable game of turning up forgotten fig ures of the past, the Bernard Black Gallery at 1062 Madison Avenue near Eightieth Street plays the card of Frank Boggs (1855-1926), an American painter who worked largely abroad.

Reform Democrats will begin balloting tonight in Manhattan's Nineteenth Congressional District for a candidate to oppose Representative Leonard Farbstein for renomination in the Democratic primary Sept. 6.
The Mets soared to previously unknown heights of glory and then toppled back to frustration yesterday in the course of a seven-hour double-header with the Philadelphia Phillies at the Polo Grounds.

SINCE last Monday this country's Protestant the ologians have been having a Biblical field day The reason: on that day Dr. Karl Barth began a series of lectures at the Divinity School of the University of Chicago.
THE favored British team won the mixed teams of four event over the week-end in the World Bridge Federation's olympiad tournament in Cannes, France.

WASHINGTON, April 29-- The rain that fell over the District of Columbia Stadium today merely delayed--it didn't prevent--the Yankees' clean sweep of their four-game series with Washington and the extension of the Senators' losing streak to thirteen in a row.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 29--A few teaspoonfuls of sugar in the world's teacups and rice bowls have added up to momentous gains in consumption of the commodity since prewar days.

The Defense Department's plan for reorganizing the National Guard was attacked yesterday by Maj. Gen. James F. Cantwell, chief of staff of New Jersey and president of the Adjutants General Association of the United States.

143-YEAR-OLD opera by Franz Schubert finally made it to New York on Saturday night. The work is "The Twin Brothers'" ("Die Zwillingsbrueder"), and it was given its local premiere at McMillin Theatre by the assembled musical forces of Columbia University under the direction of Howard Shanet.

The political banquet circuit in New York is rapidly approaching its annual flood season. By the time the ebb sets late in June, party treasuries will have been enriched by $2,000,000 to $3,000,000 and tens of thousands of the party faithful will have sat through hundreds of speeches, most of which...
A three-year study of city land use has found New York to be 118 acres larger than previous surveys had indicated.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., April 29--Columbia, the 12-Meter yacht that successfully defended the America's Cup in 1958, slid down a marine railway on the late-afternoon tide today at they Robert E. Derecktor yard.

WHEN any institution in this city of the pneumatic drill celebrates an eightieth birthday, it is reason to raise a stein on high. And tomorrow Luchow's Restaurant, 110 East Fourteenth Street, will toast the occasion.

IN 1934, when he was an undergraduate at City College and only 19 years old, Alfred Kazin impulsively left the subway at Times Square and rushed into the New York Times Building to call upon John Chamberlain, then the daily book reviewer of this newspaper. A few hours later he departed with an introduction to the editors of The New Republic.
MOSCOW, April 28--Crucifixes and red flags competed today for the devotion of the Russian people.
Jack Small, general manager for the Shubert theatrical organization, died Friday in Gibraltar while on vacation. He was 52 years old.

PRINCETON, N.J., April 29--The Rev. Dr. Karl Barth, world-renowned Swiss Protestant theologian, began a series of six lectures here tonight that are designed to amplify for American audiences what has come to be known as "Barthianism" or "evangelical theology."

LONDON, April 29--The United States is opposed to building up the Central Treaty Organization (CENTO) with American or British troops into a small-scale North Atlantic Treaty Organization, qualified sources said tonight. The United States was said to believe that forces now available to the alliance were adequate at this time.

WASHINGTON, April 29-- Warren W. Wiggins, an associate director of the Peace Corps, has long shared the view of his chief, Sargent Shriver, that more retired Americans should lend their experience and skills to projects of the corps overseas.

LONDON, April 29--Ten months after Prime Minister Macmillan's Government decided to apply for entry into the European Economic Community. Britain approaches the critical phase of her negotiations with Europe.

ST. LOUIS, April, 29 (AP)-- The Cincinnati Reds ended St. Louis' winning streak at four games and dropped the Cardinals out of the National League lead by winning the second game of a double-header, 4--3, today on Eddie Kasko's ninthinning home run. The Cards routed the Reds, 16--3, in the first game.
Lieut. Gov. Malcolm Wilson praised Lieut. Col. John H. Glenn Jr. yesterday for having Said "all the wrong things" according to prevailing attitudes toward religion and patriotism.

WASHINGTON, April 29 (AP)--President Kennedy has invited seven high officials of the American Medical Association to a meeting at the White House on Tuesday that could bear heavily on the fate of the Administration's medical care program.

SAN ANTONIO, April 29 (UPI)--Arnold Palmer made one of his typically dynamic finishes today with a fourunder-par 67 and won the Texas open golf tournament for the third straight year. He posted a 72-hole score of 273 at the Oak Hills Country Club and won by a stroke.
Manufacturers' sales and inventories rose in March, but new orders declined, the Commerce Department reported yesterday.

Dr. Lester David Volk, a former Republican Representative from the Tenth District of Brooklyn, who practiced law and medicine, died yesterday at his home, 1111 Ocean Avenue, Brooklyn. He was 77 years old.

Rubin Carter, who favors a knockout punch because he likes to get home early, headed for Paterson after 2 minutes 3 seconds of the second round of his middleweight ten-rounder at St. Nicholas Arena last night.

While Benny Goodman is putting a band together for his visit to the Soviet Union this month, the spirit of the Swing Era, which Mr. Goodman ignited back in the Thirties, is burning unusually brightly at the Metropole Cafe.

Jim Rathschmidt of Yale and Joe Burk of Pennsylvania expressed their gratification yesterday over winning performances of their crews last Saturday. Yale and Penn will row against Columbia for the Blackwell Cup this week at Philadelphia.
ATLANTA, April 30--The Federal District Court here was asked today to end all forms of racial segregation in the city's public school system.
DEERFIELD, Ill., April 30-- Dr. Herman Hille, who was a partner of the late Dr. Albert C. Barnes in the original manufacture of Argyrol, died in his home here on Saturday. He was 90 Years old.

WASHINGTON, April 30 --A Presidential study committee has found no ground for Congressional complaints that the Government gives too much management control over research projects to nonprofit research groups.
PRINCETON, N. J., April 30 --A genial, 75-year-old Swiss Protestant theologian has captured the hearts and minds of this college community in a little less than twenty-four hours.
Despite their problems on the playing field, the Mets in their first sixteen games have proved themselves to be masters of statistical intrigue.
BERLIN, April 30 (AP)-- Both Communist and Western authorities are taking precautions to prevent trouble along the wall that divides Berlin during two rival May Day celebrations tomorrow.
ALBANY, April 30--Governor Rockefeller signed today a bill that lets New York City ease the impact of its gross business receipts tax on companies with low profit margins.
Cotton futures were 15 cents up to 35 cents a bale off yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange.

PARIS, April 30--Stirling Moss ate porridge and drank orange juice for breakfast this morning in the hospital at Wimbledon, England, where he has lain for eight days since crashing at 100 miles an hour or more during a Grand Prix car race at Goodwood.
Audiences may have their favorite performers at the circus, but performers also have their favorite audiences.
MOSCOW, April 30 (UPI)-- The Soviet Union will celebrate May Day tomorrow with the accent on peace and prosperity but also with the traditional military parade through Moscow's Red Square.

Silas Blake Axtell, an admiralty lawyer who, for more than fifty years, was in the forefront of the battle for seamen's rights, died Sunday in Chevy Chase, Md., after suffering a heart attack. He was 77 years old and lived on Drury Lane, Little Britain, N. Y., and at 3 Helena Road, Dongan Hills. S. I.
New York City is abandoning the soft sell in its antilittering campaign. The hard sell, or hit-'em-where-they-live approach, is back in fashion.

WASHINGTON, April 30-- George W. Ball, Under Secretary of State, warned today that the war against the Communist guerrilla invaders in South Vietnam would be a "long, slow, arduous" struggle of a type that is not "congenial to the American temperament."
Dr. Otto Muller, Emeritus Professor of Romance Languages at City College, died in his sleep yesterday morning at his home in Cambridge, N. Y. His age was 69.

WASHINGTON, April 30--A proposed tax measure, designed to eliminate "tax havens" for American corporations, might cost the Government three times as much in shipping subsidies as it gained in new tax revenue, the Senate Finance Committee was told today.
ATLANTIC CITY, April 30-- A new method for correcting dangerous abnormalities in heart rhythm was reported to a medical research meeting today
COLLO, Algeria, April 13-- Ironies are constant in Algiers in the wake of the French-nationalist peace accord, even in the vast hinterland where there is no longer either much violence or much fear.

Chas. Pfizer Co., Inc., producer of fine chemicals, pharmaceuticals and agricultural and consumer items, is going into the dairy food field with a new weight-control aid in biscuit form,called Limmits.

Appreciation of the work of the late Dag Hammarskjold has been shown all over the world since his death, U Thant, Acting Secretary General of the United Nations, said yesterday.
ATLANTIC CITY, April 30-- Gov. Richard J. Hughes told the National Planning Conference today that city planners and politicians involved in urban renewal were now bound together in a common cause.
FORT LEE, Va., April 30 (AP)--Maj. Arch E. Roberts said today he was asking the Army to reconsider the order that suspended him from active duty.
JAMES TERENCE BRADY has stepped from the anony mity of being a "ghost" designer on Seventh Avenue into the spotlight as the fur designer at Bonwit Teller.
District Attorney Frank D. O'Connor of Queens announced yesterday he would join "with enthusiasm" in meetings being set up across the state for potential Democratic candidates for Governor.

David Mulfinger, whose father, George Mulfinger, is professor of piano at Syracuse University, made his New York debut last night at Carnegie Recital Hall. The young man, who is following in his father's footsteps, is a pianist too.
ROME, April 30--A caucus of the Christian Democratic party designated Antonio Segni today its official candidate for President of the Italian Republic.
The Foundation on Automation and Employment, Inc., announced yesterday the creation of an eleven-member board of directors.

IMITATION, the sincerest form of flattery, may not even be bad for business.

The Lytton Financial Corporation announced yesterday that it had borrowed $16,500,000 privately. The deal, negotiated by Oppenheimer Co., was described as the largest debt transaction ever made by a savings and loan holding company.
The first women's national intercollegiate bowling tournament, staged by the Association of College Unions, was conducted in Phoenix, Ariz., last Sunday.

The wounds left by the battle over steel prices were reflected yesterday in the cool reception the United States Chamber of Commerce accorded President Kennedy's attempts to assure it that his Administration is not anti-business. Clearly it will take more than soothing words to restore the kind of cooperation between Government and industry that is essential for the nation's economic health.
American colleges and universities face a serious decline unless they restore the office of their presidents to a status of academic leadership, according to Dr. Harold W. Dodds.

WASHINGTON, April 30-- The Supreme Court held today that the Federal Power Commission had no right to approve a merger of two natural gas pipeline companies while an antitrust suit challenging the merger was before the courts.
VIENNA, April 30--The Hungarian Communist regime has made public a report on a 1958 tax proposal that Premier Janos Kadar said might have produced a disaster.
WASHINGTON, April 30--A Republican opinion survey indicates Governor Rockefeller's popularity in New York State has declined only slightly since his divorce.
LONDON, April 30--British trade unions were told today they would face many difficulties, like the 'rest of the nation, if Britain joined the European Economic Community.

Howard Hawks, one of the most consistently successful action-directors in American films, will be the subject of a summer "retrospect series" described by the Museum of Modern Art as "the longest and most complete" organized to date.
JERUSALEM, Israeli Sector, April 30--Adolf Eichmann was permitted a brief visit by his wife, Vera, in Ramle Prison last night.
Mayor Wagner was asked yesterday to urge the Federal Government to sell New York City sixty-seven acres of Manhattan Beach property that could accommodate 50,000 bathers a day.
WASHINGTON, April 30--President Kennedy told the nation's largest organization of business men today that his Administration did not want the task of setting prices.
Steel production last week fell below 2,000,000 tons for the first time in 1962, sliding to the lowest level since last August.
A teak-trimmed bookshop that will employ literary editors as salesmen from time to time will be opened at 757 Third Avenue next year by Harcourt, Brace World, Inc.
CHICAGO, April 30--Days off are for baseball players in batting slumps, which is one reason Cletis Boyer of the Yankees was unhappy about today's lay-off.

An issue of $75,000,000 of Sunray DX Oil Company debentures was offered yesterday at a price of 98.75 each, for a yield of 4.33 per cent to maturity. The underwriting group was headed by Eastman Dillon, Union Securities Co.

Buying was brisk and industry forecasts were rosy yesterday as the National Shoe Fair of America completed its second day of showings here.
LISBON, April 30--The illegal Portuguese Communist party is reported to be planning to turn the May Day labor celebrations into a major test of political strength against the Salazar regime.
NEW ORLEANS, April 30 --The White Citizens Council of Greater New Orleans sent thirty-four more Negroes west and north by bus and train today.

SAN SALVADOR, April 30-- Lieut. Col. Julio Adalberto Rivera and his National Conciliation party received a total of 370,000 votes in yesterday's election, party headquarters reported today. Opposition parties boycotted the election.

LOUISVILLE, April 30-- Motivated mainly by the hope of gaining encouragement for their chances in the Kentucky Derby Saturday, eight owners will send their 3-year-old horses into the Derby Trial Stakes tomorrow.
WASHINGTON, April 30-- On the advice of his doctors, Justice Felix Frankfurter will not participate in the work of the Supreme Court during the remainder of the present term.

Profits for the Foster Wheeler Corporation in the first quarter of 1962 were less than half those of the 1961 period, stockholders learned yesterday at the annual meeting in the Gotham Hotel. John E. Kenney, president, reported that net income for the first quarter equaled forty-one cents a share, down from eighty-nine cents a year ago.

PHILADELPHIA, April 30 (AP)--The Philadelphia Phillies beat Warren Spahn for the first time since 1959 tonight as they scored five runs in the third inning for a 6-4 victory over the Milwaukee Braves.

WASHINGTON, April 30 -- Treasury bill rates rose slightly on today's sales of the regular weekly issues. It was the third consecutive weekly increase, but the rates were still smaller than they have been at several intervals earlier in the year.
BUENOS AIRES, April 30-- The Government took elaborate precautions today to insure against disorders on Argentina's traditional May 1 labor holiday tomorrow.

CHICAGO, April 30 (UPI)-- Tornadoes and high winds collapsed the roofs of two schools, unroofed factories and a supermarket, tore through an Air Force Base and carved a broad trail of destruction across the Midwest today.

The Rockefeller Foundation announced yesterday that its grants during the first quarter of 1962 totaled $3,400,302. In the same period, twenty-five fellowships awarded to individuals from seventeen countries became active.

This summer's thaw in the Himalayan uplands will bring no corresponding melting of international tensions along the vast, mountainous frontier between the Indian subcontinent and Chinese-ruled central Asia.

LONDON, April 30--Qualified sources reported tonight that Secretary of State Dean Rusk would canvass French and West German opinion on the status to be accorded East Germany in the event that his negotiations with the Soviet Union approach a settlement of the Berlin issue.
TORONTO, April 30--Unanimous critical acclaim, studded with superlatives, greeted the three latest works of Igor Stravinsky here last night.
WASHINGTON, April 30 (UPI)--Prices farmers received for crops and livestock fell nearly 1 per cent in the month ended April 15, the Department of Agriculture reported today.

WHITE PLAINS, April 30-- Nine high school pupils picketed the Westchester County Office Building this afternoon because the county plans to build a $5,700,000 sewage plant adjoining their recreation field at Harbor Island, Mamaroneck.
ALGIERS, April 30--French officials directing the campaign against the Secret Army Organization in Algiers and Oran are confident they have wrested the initiative from the extremist insurgents.

Maj. Gherman S. Titov, a man of relatively few words, directed some of them yesterday at earthbound diplomats, frenetic stockbrokers on the floor of the Stock Exchange, and New York's traffic problem.
AUGUSTA, Ga., April 30 (AP)--Mickey Wright, the 1961 winner, shot a three-under-par 69 today and defeated Ruth Jessen in a play-off for first place in the women's titleholders golf tournament.

The award of the Lenin Peace Prize to Pablo Picasso, which means the award of the Communist equivalent of the Nobel Prize to the world's most famous living painter, comes, by coincidence, during "Picasso: An American Tribute,"the most elaborate exhibition to date of his works in this country.
The Commonwealth Edison Company, Chicago, reported yesterday that sales of electricity in the first quarter were 12 per cent above the 1961 level.

A fair will be held in the gymnasium and on the athletic field of Trinity School at 139 West Ninety-first Street on the evening of May 11 and all day May 12. Proceeds from the event will increase the scholarship fund of the boys' preparatory school.
TRENTON, April 30--The Assembly voted and sent to Gov. Richard J. Hughes today eight bills designed to revamp the state's child welfare laws. He is expected to sign them.

WASHINGTON, April 30 (AP)--The United States told Japan today that it would stop its Pacific nuclear tests immediately "if the Soviet Union changes its previous position and now concludes a test-ban treaty."

WESTBURY, L.I., April 30-- Officials of the New York State Harness Racing Commission had to dig into the rule book this morning when the second $15,000 supplementary entry for Roosevelt Raceway's' rich Messenger Stakes was made.
Stock prices on the New York Stock Exchange were sharply off in April as the market hit its largest monthly loss since September, 1960. Blue chip or investment grade issues were weakened.

ONE of the highest-ranking French pairs, Pierre Ghestem and Claude Bacherich, led a field of seventyeight pairs going into the second and third qualifying rounds of the World Bridge Federation's Olympiad pair tournament yesterday in Cannes, France.
ALBANY, April 30 (AP)-- A slight increase in welfare spending and a slight decline in the number of persons on relief were recorded by the Newburgh Welfare Department last year.
The State Judicial Conference may shortly take a first step toward eliminating some of the more flagrant political abuses of judicial patronage.

Mrs. Hortense W. Gabel, head of the city's Rent and Rehabilitation Administration, said yesterday that the agency would begin a campaign this week to place under rent control hotels now improperly exempted.

THE Symphony of the Air finished its seven-concert Beethoven cycle last night at Carnegie Hall. Logically enough, the marathon traversal of the composer's symphonic output concluded with the Ninth Symphony.

WASHINGTON, April 30 (AP) -- The Supreme Court decided today that an ailing lawyer who spent two winters in Florida on his physician's advice could not deduct from his taxable income as a medical expense the rent paid for an apartment in Fort Lauderdale.
An 82-year-old recluse who used to accept food from neighbors left a gross estate of $1,150,000.
A motion by Brooklyn Supreme Court Justice J. Vincent Keogh for a trial separate from that of four co-defendants was being studied yesterday by Federal Judge Edward Weinfeld.
Mrs. Siegfried Roebling will give a cocktail party in the Carpenter Suite of the WaldorfAstoria on Thursday in honor of Mrs. Harry C. Mills, Mrs. Gustave Aufricht and Mrs. Sidney Vere-Smith.

NORFOLK, Va., April 30 (AP) -- The Norwegian ship Tarantel, her right side ripped from water line to deck from a Chesapeake Bay collision yesterday, rested aground today while men from two Navy salvage vessels battled to keep her from settling deeper.

KANSAS CITY, ,April 30-- Maj. Gen. Ralph E. Truman, former commander of the Thirtyfifth Division, National Guard, and a first cousin of former President Harry S. Truman, died here this afternoon of a heart attack. He was 81 years old.

About 100 representatives of business, labor, education, religion and other aspects of the city's life attended a clinic on fire prevention yesterday. Then they were designated to serve as a voluntary Citizens Committee for Fire Prevention.

Changes in the top executive posts of the Union Oil Company of California at the board meeting yesterday abolished, in effect, the post of board chairman. Reese H. Taylor, who has been chairman and executive, officer, was elected President.
SCARSDALE, N.Y., April 30 --A century-old carriage house of a former country estate here is the new headquarters of a voluntary library service.

TOKYO, April 30 (UPI) -- The Japanese lightweight champion, Teruo Kosaka, scored an upset split decision tonight over the world junior lightweight champion, Gabriel (Flash) Elorde, to win the Orient lightweight crown.

Dr. Charles Carpenter Tillinghast, retired headmaster of the Horace Mann School, died yesterday at Norwalk (Conn.) Hospital. He was 77 years old and lived on Ridgefield Road in Wilton, Conn.

CHICAGO, April 30 (UPI)--Wheat futures moved sharply upward in active dealings today on the Chicago Board of Trade, but other grain futures slipped back.

WASHINGTON, April 30 (UPI) -- President Kennedy prodded Congress today to raise the pay of top-level Federal administrators, engineers and scientists.
ROME, April 30--the Vatican newspaper, L'Osservatore Romano, protested strongly today against what it termed the "growing anti-religious campaign" in Poland.

Potatoe futures prices closed up 2 points (hundreths of a cent a pound) in the near-by positions and were unchanged in the 1963 months yesterday. Volume on the New York Mercantile Exchange totaled 1,700 carlots of 50,000 pounds each.

ATLANTA, April 30--Georgia will appeal a Federal court's ruling that its county unit election system is unconstitutional. The state will do this before trying to deal with the problems raised by the decision.

LONDON, April 30--Industrial shares advanced strongly and then declined on the stock market today. Most groups had more rises than falls.

MOSCOW, April 30 (AP)--The Soviet Union awarded a Lenin Peace Prize today to Pablo Picasso, most of whose paintings cannot be shown here. Another went to President Kwame Nkrumah of Ghana.

DETROIT, April 30 (AP)-- Over-all car production last week was the highest in more than a year with 152,529 autos rolling from the lines along with 26,296 trucks. By the end of this week, calendar year output will be over 2,500,000 cars.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 30 (AP) -- The San Francisco Giant vaulted over Pittsburgh into first place in the National League today by beating the Pirates, 4--1.

CHICAGO, April 30 (AP)-- A dual track meet between Poland and the United States was scheduled today for June 30 and July 1 at the University of Chicago.

DURHAM, N.C., April 30 (AP)--Harry Golden, the author, said today he would undertake to raise the money so that New Orleans Negroes who accept free one-way bus rides north "can return home after their vacation."
WASHINGTON, April 30-- The Justice Department filed today its first suit to have a Southern voting registrar held in contempt for violating a court order against racial discrimination.

MINNEAPOLIS. Minn., April 30--In a city suffering from a news blackout, and lit briefly by two fiery crosses last night, the League of Women Voters began deliberations today over how it could best serve the nation and its voters for the next
A legal drive designed to bring substantial imports of iron ore through the Port of New York was opened here yesterday.
Mayor Wagner said yesterday that the city must get more money next year "from Albany, from Washington and from local taxes" to expand its day-care centers.
HONG KONG, April 29-- Twenty-two Chinese are believed to have drowned in an attempt to escape from Communist China to Hong Kong.
WASHINGTON, April 30-- The Public Health Service said today it had no plans to comply with a New York request that the Federal Government guarantee adequate supplies of poliomyelitis vaccines.
LOS ANGELES, April 30 (UPI)--Thomas J. Lieb, former Loyola University of Los Angeles head football coach, died today, apparently of a heart attack at the age of 62.
Flotations of new bond and stock issues in April fell below the levels for April, 1961. New stock offerings also were below the March, 1962, total but the bond aggregate was higher.

The American Jewish Congress yesterday repeated its allegations that the Arabian American Oil Company was abetting the anti-Semitic policy of Saudi Arabia by "refusing to hire Jews for employment in its New York office.
WASHINGTON, April 30 (AP) -- The Marine Corps announced today a reserve reorganization geared to the formation of a fourth division and air wing team in emergency of war.
The Kennecott Copper Corporation, the world's largest mine producer of copper, is considering entering the phosphate field.

NEW YORK stores are introducing new little shops within the big one. At Bloomingdale's, the ground-floor Arcade has been invaded by a bounty of novel straw hats and handbags in what the store calls its Straw Market. Many of the
Bill Ward, the head coach of track and field at St. John's University since 1947, will relinquish that post this fall to devote his full time to administrative duties in the athletic department.
Doug Harvey, the playercoach of the New York Rangers, and Andy Bathgate, his star right wing, were selected yesterday for the National Hockey League's 1961-62 all-star team.

WASHINGTON, April 30--The Atomic Energy Commission has become the first Federal unit to establish the principle that its employes and job applicants should have the right to confront accusers in security cases.
City Controller Abraham D. Beame said last night that a proposal to accelerate the flow of revenue from the 3 per cent sales tax into the city's treasury was receiving "serious consideration."
WASHINGTON, April 3O (UPI)--The chief economist of the Truman Administration called President Kennedy's proposed tax program for business a "costly, wasteful bonanza" today.
Stocks moved down sharply yesterday in a decline led by International Business Machines.
OCEANSIDE, L. I., April 30 --The Metropolitan Professional Golfers Association is establishing an employment bureau for golf professionals.

The State Housing Division announced yesterday that applications will be accepted next week from persons who seek to purchase middleincome cooperative apartments with as little as $200 of their own money.
WASHINGTON, April 30-- Building trades union leaders are making new efforts to prevent strikes by their members at missile base construction sites.

BONN, Germany, April 30-- The executive committee of the Volkswagen Automobile Company decided today to maintain its recent price increases despite heavy pressure from Dr. Ludwig Erhard, Economics Minister.

By proclamation of Mayor Wagner and under the sponsorship of citizens who care, this is City Parks Week, beginning today. Parks do not just happen. Those we now enjoy in New York City are both the heritage of the past, handed down through the foresight and sacrifice of other generations, and the product of present-day initiative, building for the future. The battle to have
Floyd Patterson plans to retire from the ring unless he can fight Sonny Liston for the heavyweight championship.
I.D. Robbins, president of the City Club, was eliminated last night as a contender for the Democratic Congressional nomination in Manhattan's Nineteenth Congressional district.
Barbara Harris, a comparative newcomer to local audiences, has been chosen to play the feminine lead in the unnamed Richard Rodgers-Alan Jay Lerner musical.

John Henry Faulk, former radio and television entertainer, testified yesterday that sponsors of his WCBS radio show began leaving the program shortly after a newsletter linked his name to a Communist conspiracy.
I want to congratulate you on your new president, Presiden: (H. Ladd) Plumley-- and it's nice to have a president from Massachusetts, and we're glad to have him here.
THE following dinner menu is given as a guide to the use of foods that are reasonable in cost. A recipe is offered for an easy-to-prepare main dish.

WASHINGTON, May 1-The Administration will ask Congress next week for permission to keep its two senior Soviet specialists and a handful of other diplomats on active duty without requiring them to make special financial sacrifices.
GHARDIMAOU, Tunisia, May 1--Some soldiers of the Algerian Army of Liberation are impatient with the moderation of Premier Benyoussef Ben Khedda's Provisional Government.

ROANOKE, Va., May 1-- Attorney General Robert F. Kennedy suggested today that the Supreme Court moved into the problem of legislative districting because the states would not solve the problem themselves.
CARACAS, Venezuela, May 1 --President Romulo Betancourt is contemplating stringent action against the Communist party and groups allied with it.
Dr. Jerome Weiss, a physiotherapist and orthopedist in practice at 1703 Rutland Road, Brooklyn, died yesterday at Adelphi Hospital, Brooklyn. His age was 64.
Diamond Dan O'Rourke's saloon, one of the last links with the gay life on the Bowery in the old days, is being torn down to make way for a cooperative apartment house.
The Transportation Corporation of America "has agreed to purchase" La Prensa, a 47year-old Spanish language daily published here.
A Loyalty Day demonstration and a May Day observance by Communists and left-wingers were held in Union Square Park yesterday, three hours apart.
BALTIMORE, May 1 (AP)-- James W. Foster, director of the Maryland Historical Society since 1942, died of a heart attack yesterday. His age was 71.

Mrs. Arthur B. Kelly has sold the town house, a fivestory limestone and brick building on a lot 22 by 100 feet, at 52 East Seventy-third Street. The buyer will occupy the residence, which now contains doctor's offices. It was sold through George I. Newell and Sylvia K. French of William B. May Co., brokers.

An issue of $40,000,000 of Southern California Edison Company bonds will be offered at 100 by an underwriting group headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc. The issue was awarded to the group on its bid of 98.32.

Beginning in 1963, the United States pavilions at the great international art festivals in Venice and S o Paulo, Brazil, will be dark unless new sponsorship elects to perpetuate the showings of American art.
The Greater New York Fund opened its 1962 appeal for $11,000,000 at a luncheon in the Waldorf-Astoria yesterday for 1,300 volunteers representing industry, labor and public service.
CHICAGO, May 1 (AP) --There are thirty-five Negro millionaires in the United States, Ebony, a Negro monthly magazine says. Only one of them is an entertainer.

Surprise was the dominant reaction yesterday to the Federal Reserve Board's rejection of two merger proposals involving four New York commercial banks. It was not an unmixed reaction, however. In various places there were strong overtones of delight, amazement and indignation.
HEMPSTEAD, L.I., May 1-- A loan exhibition of nineteen works of art from Governor Rockefeller's collection, including five works by Pablo Picasso, went on display today at Hofstra College.

The Aluminum Company of Canada, Ltd., (Alcan) has sold $100,000,000 promissory notes to institutional investors. The First Boston Corporation and Morgan Stanley Co. negotiated the placement of the 5.1 per cent notes, which are due in 1992 and payable in United States currency.

Had breakfast with Democratic Congressional leaders; received report from his labormanagement advisory committee; signed the educational television bill; met with representatives of the A.M.A.; saw members of the Evangelical (Lutheran) Political Club

Counting the number of points lost on stocks since the year's start has become a compulsive game for investors. Just to make the unpleasant task easier, Harold Clayton, analyst for Hemphill, Noyes Company, has made a tally on the market downs and ups on an I.B.M. machine.
LONDON, May 1--Jean Monnet, one of the architects of the common Market, declared today that he had "no doubt at all" that every one of its six members welcomed the prospect of Britain's accession.

While the Communists misused May Day to flaunt their military power, the Western and Western-oriented nations busied themselves with conferences to review their defenses. Under the leadership of the United States these conferences are producing policies designed to strengthen the West, but without offering any provocation to either Soviet Russia or the neutralists.

"I believe that the art of jazz has suffered artistically because of improper presentatation and exposure," wrote John Handy in a program note for a recital by his quartet last night at Carnegie Recital Hall.

The Interclub Trophy races, conceived by George Rand at Bridgehampton, L.I., several years ago, will return to its original format this week-end at the 2.85-mile course in the dunes. This means that six different groups, including the independent Long Island Sports Car Association, the Scuderia
The Rev. Dr. Karl Barth, the Swiss Protestant theologian, voiced a fervent plea, yesterday for prison reform in this country.
As part of a campaign to preserve the city's parks, 1,500 lapel buttons will be distributed today in the shopping and business districts of Manhattan and Brooklyn.

OTTAWA, May 1--Prime Minister Macmillan concluded two days of talks with Canada's Prime Minister, John Diefenbaker, today. He renewed assurances that Britain was determined to "safeguard the essential interests of Commonwealth countries" in her negotiations for membership in the European Economic Community.

International Business Machines, an outstanding favorite among institutional investors, with 571 of them holding 2,458,000 shares at the most recent count, went through a wild swing yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange.

LOUISVILLE, May 1--The rain rode in on a lightning and wind storm last night to beat down on the parched earth of Kentucky's blue-grass country. It was welcomed by farmers, gardeners and horticulturists.

A SHOTGUN shell has remained basically un changed over the years. It consists of a paper and brass tube with a little over an ounce of lead pellets seeded over wads designed to keep the explosive force of the burning gasses from having adverse effect on the pellets. The propelling force, of course, is provided by incandescent expanding gasses given off by the progressively burning powder.

Cardinal Spellman broke with custom yesterday when he celebrated a solemn requiem mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral for John S. Burke, chairman and former president of B. Altman Co., who died Friday at the age of 72.
PHILADELPHIA, May 1-- A new opera company was formed here today two months after the merger that consolidated Philadelphia's two major operas.
MIAMI, May 1--Sam Griffith of Miami will seek his third consecutive victory in the Miamito-Nassau power-boat race when the 180-mile dash begins at 7 A.M. tomorrow.

Cold, damp weather turned the Polo Grounds into a dubious habitat for baseball last night, but it had a salutary effect on the Cincinnati Reds in general and Joey Jay in particular during a game with the New York Mets.

FEW women today are aware that an Englishman nee dled the French into the establishment of their present-day haute couture. The Lincolnshire lad in question was Charles Frederick Worth, whose designs will be honored with a display of fifty-two original
BOSTON, May 1 (UPI)-- Willie Pastrano brought Tom McNeeley's ring career to an apparent end tonight by taking a unanimous ten-round decision from the former heavyweight title challenger.
Pink, red and white flowers provided the setting in the Sert Room of the Waldorf-Astoria last evening for the seventh annual Heart of America Ball.
Compton Advertising, Inc., and Grey Advertising, Inc., have been assigned by the Procter Gamble Company to handle advertising for several brands previously handled by the Gardner Advertising Company.

Potato futures prices closed up 1 to 8 points (hundredths of a cent a pound) on the New York Mercantile Exchange yesterday. The session was hectic and the volume was 3,423 carlots of 50,000 pounds each.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 1 --Frederic Cavens, fencing master who taught some of Hollywood's greatest movie stars, died yesterday at the Motion Picture Country House in Woodlands Hills. He was 79 years old.

Radio Corporation of America told its stockholders yesterday that the momentum of the first quarter had continued through April to carry the company to the highest sales and earnings "of any first third of a year" in its 43-year history.

BRITISH and French pairs led in the olympiad world championships at Cannes, France, going into the fourth and fifth sessions yesterday, but American pairs were strong contenders in both the open and the women's contests.
ALBANY, May 1 (UPI)-- Governor Rockefeller vetoed a bill today that would have retricted dissemination of results from race tracks.
THEY came in overalls and pinafores to sing work songs and sea chanteys, and ballads about other topics with which they were equally conversant, including prison life and unrequited love.

The second day of the subscription period for the Treasury's $11,683,000,000 refunding passed yesterday with a good demand showing up for the three exchangeable issues. These maturing obligations are exchangeable until midnight tonight for new Treasury securities due in 1963, 1966 and 1971.
NEW ORLEANS, May 1-- The program of the White Citizens Council of Greater New Orleans to give Negroes a free ride north of the MasonDixon Line came to an apparent halt today.

WASHINGTON, May 1--The Senate leadership will move Monday to try to break the Southern civil rights filibuster. Senator Mike Mansfield of Montana, the majority leader, announced today that he would file on Monday a petition to close debate. Under the rules, it, will come to a vote on Wednesday.
Results of further tests of a live-virus measles vaccine that was said to be the "safest, most effective yet developed against the disease" were reported here yesterday.

OLD GREENWICH, Conn., May 1--Clarence M. Pettit, retired vice president of the retail division of the Aeolian Company, piano manufacturers, died yesterday in the Stamford office of Trudel Associates, real estate brokers. He was 64 years old and lived at 3 Wendle Place here.

A new issue of $20,000,000 of bonds of the Kingdom of Denmark will be offered for public subscription here today by a syndicate headed by Kuhn, Loeb Co., Inc.; Smith, Barney Co., Inc.; Harriman Ripley Co., Inc., and Lazard Freres Co.
The number of persons hurt in car accidents in the city last week increased by twenty-two compared with 1,033 in 1961, the Police Safety Bureau reported yesterday.

The Xerox Corporation, a manufacturer of office copying equipment, announced the election yesterday of Charles C. Glavin as a director. Mr. Glavin is senior vice president of the First Boston Corporation, an investment banking concern.

As of this week, the listing of entertainment for children is broadened to include events in the fine arts and performing arts that have been selected by The New York Times critics as being of particular interest to teen-agers.
Bacteria have been brought back to life after 650,000,000 years in a salt deposit deep underground in Siberia, a German physician reported here yesterday.

The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company had a net income in the first quarter this year of $15,841,020, equal to 46 cents a share, or 2.8 per cent better than the $15,404,059, or 44 cents a share, earned in the 1961 period. Sales increased 7.3 per cent to $370,794,554 from $345,653,781.
LONDON, May 1--The United States, Britain and West Germany will finance development of Britain's P-1127, a revolutionary vertical take-off aircraft.

Automobile production gained sharply in April from the level in the 1961 month. Every manufacturer reported increases. Production figures of the Studebaker Corporation were lacking, however, so that a total comparison of the industry with 1961 was not possible.

Last year, C. P. Snow published his account of the controversy between the British scientists Sir Henry Tizard and Lord Cherwell (F. A. Lindemann), under the title "Science and Government." The opinions he expressed were widely criticized.

First-quarter net earnings of the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation amounted to $7,781,000, equal to $1 a share, compared with $4,364,000, or 59 cents a share, earned in the period a year ago. Sales totaled $393,043,000 against $336,291,000 for the same 1961 quarter.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 1 (AP)--The Television Academy announced its fourteenth annual nominations today and did not include the top two stars of the 1961-62 season--Lieut. Col. John H. Glenn Jr. and Mrs. John F. Kennedy.
The city announced yesterday what officials said they hoped were the final plans for the $180,000,000 West Side urban renewal project.

ALBANY, May 1--The 1962 Legislature produced 1,013 new laws. This was the tally as Governor Rockefeller completed action just before last midnight on the last of the bills left behind for the thirty-day signing period when the Legislature adjourned March 31.

Daniel C. Lindsay, an airconditioning engineer who did some of the earliest work in the ventilating and cooling of deep mines in South Africa, died in his sleep of a heart attack on Friday at his home in East Orange, N.J. He was 67 years old.
There Was an air of indignation surrounding the United states Hoffman Machinery Corporation annual meeting yesterday.
BOSTON, May 1--Erich Leinsdorf plans to carry on the traditions of the Boston Symphony Orchestra "in the continuity of the United States Senate."

MINNEAPOLIS, May 1-- Discovery of the smallest known star in the universe was announced today by Dr. William J. Luyten, chairman of the Astronomy Department of the University of Minnesota. It is 60,000 times too faint to be seen by the unaided eye.

WASHINGTON, May 1-- Clarence B. Randall told the United States Chamber of Commerce today that the public had developed a "plague on both your houses" attitude toward labor and management in the steel industry.

IN the notes he has written for "A Pastorale Sym phony," Alan Rawsthorne, the composer, describes the third movement as being a country dance with "sinister elements appearing from time to time, as so frequently happens during rustic pursuits."
MONTREAL, May 1 (Canadian Press)--The Canadian interests of Alvin J. Walker and family have bought back control of Holt, Renfrew Co., Ltd., it was announced after the annual meeting today.
WATERBURY, Conn., May 1 --Basil S.S. Rockey, retired squadron leader of the British Royal Air Force, died on Friday at Waterbury Hospital. He was 72 years old and lived at 52 Newton Terrace here.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, May 1--The Yugoslavs sprang a surprise today in Belgrade's annual May Day parade. In the line of march were twenty new Soviet-made T-54 tanks, the first such weapons the Yugoslav Communists have obtained since their 1948 ouster from the Soviet bloc.
WASHINGTON, May 1-- President Kennedy's Advisory Committee on Labor-Management Policy recommended today greater Government activity, influence and power in the collective bargaining process.

LONDON, May 1--Sir Charles Wheeler, president of the Royal Academy of Arts suggested tonight that Britain did not deserve to keep the valuable sketch of "The Virgin and Child with Ss. John the Baptist and Anne," by Leonardo da Vinci.

Casey Stengel and Madison Avenue, a marriage made in a brewery boardroom, got together yesterday. Casey responded by running a trade (Charley Neal for Willie Mays) up the flagpole to see if any one would salute, as they say in ad agencies.

RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, May 1--President Mohammad Ayub Khan declared today that new countires should be assisted by the United Nations to devise forms of democratic government more suitable to their character than the standard Western forms.
TORONTO, May 1 (Canadian Press)--Power Supermarkets, Ltd., Ontario food store chain, announced today that it would discontinue its trading stamp plan on June 2.
WASHINGTON, May 1 (UPI) --Spokesmen for the nation's two largest coal companies supported today an Administration bill that would aid transportation of coal by pipeline.

WASHINGTON, May 1-- Pierre Salinger, the White House press secretary, will spend several days in Moscow later this month at the invitation of Alexei I. Adzhubei, the editor of Izvestia, who is Premier Khrushchev's son-in-law.

John Henry Faulk denied yesterday, item by item, charges of pro-Communist leanings that he says cost him his job as a radio and television entertainer. Mr. Faulk testified for the fifth day in the Supreme Court trial.
The election of Mrs. Arthur Hays Sulzberger to a seven-year term on the board of trustees of Barnard College was announced yesterday.

A senior at James Madison High School in Brooklyn has become the second student here to make a perfect score this year on the nation-wide examination sponsored by the Mathematics Association of America and the Society of Actuaries.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 1-- Fully a quarter of the fat people who say they cannot reduce no matter how little they eat may really be telling the truth, according to a report today to the Association of American Physicians.
A maritime union complaining about job shortages has been unable to supply enough officers to one line for the last year, an official of the ship company charged yesterday.
Cotton futures were 35 cents a bale up to 10 cents off yesterday.

The Grand Concourse Realty Syndicate has bought the fivestory apartment building at 1197 Grand Concourse, corner of 167th Street, the Bronx, from clients of Manning, Hollinger Shea, lawyers. The building occupies a plot 102 by 150 feet and contains fifty-five apartments, two offices and five stores. It was sold for cash over a mortgage of $214,000 through Leonard, Levites, Schiller, brokers.
Supreme Court Justice William B. Groat of Queens Village, Queens, has been appointed Administrative Judge of the new city-wide Civil Court.
Traffic Commissioner Henry A. Barnes lashed out yesterday at "intolerable harassment by city investigators" that he contended was impeding his efforts to solve traffic problems.

Major Gherman Titov's visit here has given New Yorkers an opportunity to express the traditional American acclaim for all those who perform extraordinary achievement and exhibit great personal courage. The major's comments yesterday about the cordiality with which he has been greeted testify to the strength of this national trait and its ability to override the antagonisms born of the world ideological struggle.

PHILIP EVERGOOD, a leading figure in art, is having a two-gallery exhibition. His earlier work is at the A. C. A. Gallery, 63 East Fifty-seventh Street; his later work is at the Terry Dintenfass Gallery, 18 East Sixty-seventh...

NEW ORLEANS, May 1-- Federal Judge Frank B. Ellis granted a stay today of a broad public-school desegregation plan that had been ordered by his predecessor. He will decide next Tuesday whether to order a new trial in the case.
MOSCOW, May 1--Defense Minister Rodion Y. Malinovsky warned the Communist-bloc nations today to be vigilant against the possibility of a preventive nuclear attack by the United States.

Stockholders of the Kennocott Copper Corporation attending the annual meeting here yesterday took a two-hour hike through a forest of topics, from prices and profit to Chilean taxes and cumulative voting.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 1 --Alex North will compose the music for "Cleopatra" the multimillion dollar historical drama now shooting in Rome.

Prince Philip, the Duke of Edinburgh, will be guest of honor and will share the dais with Prince Bernhard of the Netherlands at a dinner on June 7 that will open the United States campaign to "Save the World's Wildlife." It will be in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria.

PHILADELPHIA, May 1--A new system of hiring longshoremen at a central point was initiated here today amid confusion, grumbling, the honking of auto horns and, finally, a dispute that made idle five ships and 330 men.
The Little Gardens Club of New York will conduct a tour of Greenwich Village gardens on May 10 from 2:30 to 6:30 P.M.
CHICAGO, May 1 (AP)--A rally, which pulled in a good volume of stop-loss buying lifted grain futures into a generally strong range today on the Board of Trade.
PHILADELPHIA, May 1 Capt. Joseph A. Biello, a former medical officer of the Fourth Naval District here, died yesterday in the Philadelphia Naval Hospital at the age of 82.
The president of the United Federation of Teachers warned yesterday that the union might call a new strike or resort to "drastic alternatives" unless the teachers' salary controversy was resolved.
ALBANY, May 1--Federal aid to community mental health services was urged here today by Dr. Jack Ewalt, who directed the nation-wide Joint Commission on Mental Illness and Health Study for Coneress.

PARIS, May 1--Militarily, the real test we are meeting in Southeast Asia is the test of Mao Tse-tung's doctrine. Mao's strategic writings date from 1936 and, although regarded by his adherents as eternally true and, indeed, sacred, they are probably out of date. The task of proving this falls to us.
PECOS, Tex., May 1--Cotton allotments and their possible transfer from one area to anothers have become hot politics in the Texas primaries to be held Saturday.

TELEVISION'S recital realism came into its own last night as Isaac Stern was soloist in Channel 5's fifth event of its "Festival of performing Arts." Not that the format of the program was altered; nor did the violinist play in his shirt sleeves.

NEWARK, May 1--In a May Day gesture against communism, New Jersey Presbyterians sponsored a "Flight in Freedom" from Miami to Newark today for twenty-five Cuban families who had fled the Castro regime.

A, thoroughgoing reorganization of the structure and operation of the New York courts-- for which those dedicated to court reform have worked so valiantly these many years--is now finally assured. Governor Rockefeller has signed the twenty-two bills implementing the constitional amendment the voters approved last November. The prodigious task of carrying them into effect by next September has begun.
RIO DE JANEIRO, May 1-- President Joao Goulart called today on the workers of Brazil to elect a new Congress with powers to end the country's parliamentary system and to adopt basic economic reforms.

Sammy Davis Jr. is to be starred in the proposed musical version of Clifford Odets' "Golden Boy." The announcement was made yesterday by Hillard Elkins, who promises to bring the show to Broadway in the fall of 1963.
WASHINGTON, May 1--Don't tell Roger Blough, but the construction workers of America are nibbling President Kennedy's wage-price line to shreds.

Maj. Gherman S. Titov, the Soviet astronaut, declared yesterday that "the question of questions is disarmament." Major Titov was the guest of honor at a luncheon at the Overseas Press Club, 54 West Fortieth Street. He spoke briefly and then, through an interpreter, answered questions put to him in writing.
The Port of New York Authority borrowed $35,000,000 in the bond market yesterday to finance construction projects at the Metropolitan Area airports and other improvements.
WASHINGTON, May 1--The airline industry set traffic and revenue records last year, but showed a financial loss.
Robert Moses yesterday attacked Traffic Commissioner Henry A. Barnes' design plan for the controversial Mid-Manhattan Expressway.
WASHINGTON, May 1--Dr. James E. Allen Jr., Commissioner of Education for New York State, proposed today the establishment of a national board of education.
ALBANY, May 1--Governor Rockefeller announced today that he, had signed a bill to move up the tax payment dates for the state's corporation and bank taxes.
WASHINGTON, May 1-- Thurgood Marshall, who has been sitting as a Federal judge since last Oct. 24, finally got a Senate hearing today on his confirmation.

George D. Widener's Seven Thirty, sharing high weight of 121 pounds with Bert. W. Martin's Rose O'Neill, is the overnight betting choice at 3-1 in the field of fourteen older fillies and mares in today's $29,850 Bed o' Roses Handicap at Aqueduct.

President Kennedy, putting his signature to the bill that turned Alexander Hamilton's last home, the Grange, into a national monument, did more than enhance the memory of the eminent statesman, a founder of this nation. He also preserved one of the all too few examples of an exquisite style of American architecture, the "Federal," so light, so decorative and yet so noble.

WASHINGTON, May 1 (UPI)--Eric Johnston, head of the Motion Picture Association of America, said today he agreed with a proposed tax limtation that would strike at United States actors living and working abroad.
The Government's civil antitrust suit against the Singer Manufacturing Company, manufacturer of sewing machines, was dismissed yesterday by Chief Federal Judge Sylvester J. Ryan.
BERLIN, May 1--East Berlin's May Day parade was marked by a display of groundto-air rockets said to be of the type that the Russians contend downed Francis Gary Powers, the U-2 pilot, two years ago.

Students who use some of the 5,000 pianos in the public schools may have to go on hitting clinkers for a while. A Civil Service examination for piano tuning in the schools, scheduled for today, has been postponed.

WITH its concentrated week of "Midsummer Night's Dream" safely behind it, the New York City Ballet returned to its familiar policy of repertory at the City Center last night and undoubtedly made many people happy. It should have made them happy, also, to find George Balanchine's "La Valse" back in the works once more after an absence of half-a-dozen years.

The Copenhagen Telephone Company, Inc., of Denmark is seeking a loan from United States investors. The company has registered with the Securities and Exchange Commission $15,000,000 of sinking fund de- ...

The City Gardens Club is sponsoring a tour of six Manhattan gardens on Tuesday from 2:30 to 6 P.M. to finance scholarships for public school teachers at the summer camps of the Audubon Society in Maine and Connecticut.
LISBON, Portugal, May 1-- One man was killed and more than fifty persons were injured tonight here and in Oporto in clashes between the police and participants in forbidden May Day demonstrations.

WASHINGTON, May 1--The Atomic Energy Commission awarded a $114,000,000 contract to Stanford University today to build one of the largest machines ever constructed for basic scientific research--a two-mile-long atom smasher.
A DAPPER former cognac salesman was exactly in character yesterday when he suggested that the six members of the European Common Market would be delighted to welcome Britain as the seventh.
WASHINGTON, May 1 -- President Kennedy and seven leaders of the American Medical Association discussed for nearly an hour today how to finance medical care for the aged.

Directors of the American Bakeries Company reduced the quarterly dividend yesterday with the declaration of 45 cents a share on the common stock. It is payable on June 1 to holders of record of May 16. Shareholders received 60 cents a share in previous quarters.
The City Council passed a bill yesterday to increase the $900,000 annual revenue from the commercial occupancy tax.

The American Newspaper publishers Association Research Institute has announced the selection of officers of its board of directors and the election of four new directors. Three others were re-elected.
ST. LOUIS, May 1 (UPI)-- The St. Louis Cardinals scored five runs in the first inning, checked a Houston rally in the seventh and beat the Colt .45s, 6--4, tonight.
HASTINGS-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., May 1--The Orphan Asylum Society in the City of New York re-elected Mrs. Samuel Randolph Walker president tonight at a meeting in the Graham School here.
SAIGON, Vietnam, May 1-- Two United States Army sergeants captured by the Communist guerrillas more than three weeks ago were freed today by their captors.
