--The Senate confirmed by voice vote today President Kennedy's nomination of Nicholas deB. Katzenbach to be Deputy Attorney General. He succeeds Byron R. White, now a member of the Supreme Court.
Stocks rallied sharply yesterday after four consecutive sessions of sharp declines. The turnabout was immediately hailed in some Wall Street circles as marking the end of a "selling climax."

BONN, April 30--A prominent German talent agent today labeled as "grotesque" recent charges by Joey Adams, the comedian, that a "dictatorial reign" was preventing American entertainers from appearing in United States service clubs in West Germany.

The Women's Metropolitan Golf Association opened its season with interclub team matches yesterday. More than 600 women, playing over 71 district courses of Westchester, Long Island and New Jersey, completed their matches despite the rain.
AUGUSTA, Ga., May 1--Nine Negroes were indicted today for murder in the gunshot killing two weeks ago of a 16-year-old white youth.
Law Day, marking the importance of the rule of law in society, was celebrated here yesterday by observances and displays in courts and law schools.

LONDON, May 1 (UPI)-- Gardnar Mulloy, the 48-yearold campaigner from Coral Gables, Fla., today rallied to defeat David Olney of England, 0--6, 6--2, 6--4, in a second-round match of the London hard-court lawn tennis championships.

PARIS, May 1--Jean Cocteau's secular oratorio "Patmos" in which flying saucers have been substituted for angels and the word God is not permitted to appear, will have its world premiere Thursday at Versailles.
ABILENE, Kan., May 1-- Former President Dwight D. Eisenhower said today that American concepts of beauty, morality and decency were declining.
WASHINGTON, May 1 (AP) --Two magazine publishers protested strongly to the Senate Post Office Committee today over increases affecting them in President Kennedy's postal rate bill.
Mike Wallace announced yesterday that he would quit "P.M." on June 22, one year after its advent on television.
WASHINGTON, May 1 (AP) --The Oregon State University rifle team has won its second national title in three years with a score of 1,170 points of a possible total of 1,200.
Rutgers registered its sixth straight baseball victory yesterday by defeating Columbia, 8--7, at Baker Field. Lee Curley's ninth-inning relief pitching stopped the Lions with the winning run on base.
LONDON, May 1 (Reuters)-- United States plans to explode three "rainbow" bombs 500 miles over the Pacific set off complaints from world scientists today.
KEW, England, May 1 AP)-- Sir Sydney Cockerell, an associate of famous literary figures, died today at the age of 94.
Permission to raise rates by $778,500 a year was given to the Jamaica Water Supply Company yesterday by the Public Service Commission. The amount is $133,100 less than had been requested.
Thank you very much. Mr. Vice President, Governor and Mrs. Anderson, members of my family and my very dear friends:
WASHINGTON, May 1--A leader in the Soviet space program indicated today that more Russians would fly into space this year, but gave no numbers on planned satellite launchings.

A Ford Foundation grant of $1,750,000 has been made to New York University's Courant Institute of Mathematical Sciences to expand a doctoral program for the training of specialists in applied mathematics.

ABOUT ten minutes from Manhattan, by way of the Hudson Tubes, stands one of the East Coast's most colorful restaurants. It is the Clam Broth House, at 30-38 Newark Street, Hoboken, N.J., and it opened its doors in 1899. It is said that the Clam Broth House
WASHINGTON, May 1-- Mayor Wagner went to the White House tonight with a selection of Democratic state candidates to place before President Kennedy.
LONDON, May 1--The conference to set a date for British Guiana's independence, scheduled to be held this month in London, has been postponed indefinitely.
WASHINGTON, May 1 (AP) --Pete Burnside pitched a fourhitter tonight and snapped the Washington Senators' thirteengame losing streak by beating the Red Sox, 2--1.

Two entirely separate developments have called attention to Spain. One is the strike of the Asturian miners and the other the persistent reports that Generalissimo Franco has not been recovering satisfactorily from the hunting accident he had on Christmas Eve when his left hand was severely injured.

WASHINGTON, May 1-- Control of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad by the Chesapeake and Ohio Railway today met with the approval of an Interstate Commerce Commission examiner. His recommendation now goes to the full commission for final approval.
WASHINGTON, May 1--Following are excerpts from the report to the President by the Advisory Committee on Labor Management Policy on "Free and Responsible Collective Bargaining and Industrial Peace:
MINEOLA, L.I, May 1--Milton Lipson, a lawyer and former Secret Service agent, was appointed Commissioner of Accounts for Nassau County today by County Executive Eugene H. Nickerson.

Governor Rockefeller yesterday criticized the King-Anderson Bill for medical care for the aged under Social Security. He said that it had three flaws that "not only reduce its effectiveness but are hurting its chances of enactment."

LOUISVILE, May 1--Roman Line won the $16,050 Derby Trial by six lengths today at Churchill Downs. Alie Grissom's colt the even-money favorite of the crowd of 12,890, beat a halt-dozen rivals in the one-mile test.
CHICAGO, May 1--"There goes the no-hitter," a voice at Comiskey Park boomed tonight when Nellie Fox of the White Sox crashed his bat against a Yankee pitch in the ninth inning.
WASHINGTON, May 1-Although no one has seen Venus because of its cloud cover, analysis of radar echoes suggests that it resembles the...
MINNEAPOLIS, May 1--A strong opinion that the League of Women Voters should pay closer attention to domestic issues has developed among delegates to the national convention here.

MOSCOW, May 1--The Soviet Union announced today the completion of the Kara-Kum Canal in the desert of Central Asia. Press reports described the 500-mile waterway as one of the largest irrigation systems in the world.
LONDON, May 1--Industrial shares as a group showed no trend after heavy trading in the stock market today.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., May 1 --Former Gov. Sidney S. McMath announced his candidacy for the Democratic nomination for Governor tonight. He delivered a slashing attack on the administration of Gov. Orval E. Faubus.
Suburban school districts balloted spiritedly last night in annual elections for board memberships, budgets and school programs.

A champagne preview of paintings by Harry T. Fisk, marine artist, representing the his tory of the frigate Constellation at the Salmagundi Club next Wednesday and Thursday, will benefit the Catan-Rose Institute of Art in Jamaica, Queens.

Five demonstration projects designed to improve commuter rail services were proposed yesterday by the Tri State Transportation Committee. The projects are part of a concerted attack on the mass transportation problems that plague New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

ALBANY, May 1--Governor Rockefeller, acting at Mayor Wagner's request, has vetoed three measures that would have added $15,500,000 a year to city pension costs by giving additional benefits to teachers, firemen and policemen.

WASHINGTON, May 1-- President Kennedy signed today a bill authorizing $32,000,000 to expand educational television facilities throughout the country. The appropriation would be distributed on a matching basis over a five-year period to educational institutions and agencies and nonprofit groups.
Meeting, Council for Women's Activities, Visiting Nurse Service of New York, 107 East Seventieth Street, 2:15 P.M. Speaker: Margaret Arnstein.
WASHINGTON, May 2 (AP) --The two top leaders of the International Union of Electrical Workers reportedly had a physical clash today, in full view of the union's thirtyone-member executive board.
Unless $90,000 can be raised within the next ten days, there will be no Empire State Music Festival this summer.
Potato, copper and wool futures were active yesterday on the New York commodity markets in an otherwise dull day.
SAIGON, Vietnam, May 2-- Two American sergeants denied today they ever begged for clemency during twenty-two days of captivity among the Communist guerrillas.

PARIS, May 2--In all its long history as custodian of great treasures of the world, the Louvre has never been so well guarded as it was tonight, before a month-long showing of ing of a collection of French jewelry. The showing opens tomorrow.
PHILADELPHIA, May 2--A wildcat strike by 1,300 longshoremen halted all dry-cargo handling here today.

Having withdrawn himself as a candidate for other office this year, Mayor Wagner quickly carried another message to the White House with the names of some men he had in mind as possibilities for Governor and United States Senator. There were some men of distinction among them, and there were some obvious omissions also in this, the early summer book. Perhaps more entries will be made later.
LONDON, May 2 (AP)--Lady Ward, daughter of the late Whitelaw Reid, United States diplomat, died here yesterday at the age of 78.

WASHINGTON, May 2--Despite the substantially higher hourly wages paid by steel companies in this country, their average profitability is comparable to that of their foreign competitors, according to a report prepared for an interna tional conference of steelworkers' unions.

UNITED NATIONS, May 2-- Increased production and a sustained high volume of world trade in wheat are indicated for the rest of 1962, according to the latest commodity review by the Food and Agriculture Organization.
Suburban residents generally approved new budgets in the annual school district elections held Tuesday night and last night.

Hawaii borrowed $10,000,000 in the bond market yesterday to finance public improvements. The money was raised by the sale of serial Bonds due from 1965 to 1989 to Wells Fargo Bank American Trust Company at an interest cost of 2.714 per cent. An account managed by Bank of America National Trust and Savings Association bid a cost of 2.7956 per cent.

NASSAU, Bahamas, May 2-- John Bakos, a marathon-racing expert from St. Cloud, Fla., drove a twenty-five-foot Bertram Moppie to a record-shattering victory today in the sixth annual Miami-to-Nassau powerboat race.
John Guy Moyston, former foreign correspondent for The Associated Press, died yesterday in his apartment at 345 West Fifty-eighth Street. He was 78 years old.
LONDON, May 2--The reserves of gold and convertible currency held by Britain as celltral banker for the sterling area rose last month by 7,000,000 ($19,600,000).

The nation's inventories of gasoline declined 2,653,000 barrels in the week ended last Friday according to the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end, total supplies were 199,855,000 barrels, compared with 202,508,000 a week earlier and 205,346,000 a year ago.
The city announced yesterday that it was expanding the basis under which landlords must relocate tenants whom they want to evict.
ATHENS, May 2--Secretary of State Dean Rusk warned the Atlantic alliance today not to expect too much too soon from the East-West talks on Berlin.
Planes were behind schedule at Idlewild yesterday because of fog. At near-by Aqueduct, however, George D. Widener's Seven Thirty came home right on time.

MANCHESTER, Vt., May 2 --The trout-fishing season in Vermont, one of the best trout states, has been open for a few days, and the weather is raw, cold, drizzly and generally gloomy. That means that everything is more or less normal for the opening of the season here.
WASHINGTON, May 2--A new committee of the Organization of American States warned today that most Latin-American nations were being too casual in their efforts to combat Communist subversion.

WASHINGTON, May 2-- Senator James O. Eastland, Democrat of Mississippi, said today that Chief Justice Earl Warren "decides for the Communists" whenever there is a clear-cut Supreme Court decision between them and the security of the United States.
GREENPORT, L. I., May 2-- Taxpayers in this waterfront village last night defied a State Supreme Court order and voted a controversial ferryboat school transportation item out of the budget.
Allis-Chalmers Prices in the capital goods field show a tendency toward stability but are still depressed, R. S. Stevenson, president of Allis-Chalmers Manufacturing Company, said yesterday at the...
NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., May 2--Instant traffic warnings were produced here today and sent by radio to neon signs along the 131-mile. New Jersey Turnpike.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., May 2--George Romney, Republican candidate for Governor of Michigan, gave the League of Women Voters some words of criticism here today. He advised the group to be less leisurely and less feminine.
WASHINGTON, May 2--Secretary of the Army Elvis J. Stahr Jr. has resigned, effective June 30, to become president of Indiana University.
LOS ANGELES, May 2-- Irving Bibo, composer and music publisher, died today at his home in West Los Angeles. He was 72 years old.

A vast majority of the issues closed higher yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange, but the market averages were mixed. Standard Poor's 500stock index was higher but both the Dow-Jones industrial average and The New York Times combined average were down.

Guests at the luncheon and fashion show next Wednesday at the Sheraton-East are expected to bring rummage to be sold May 14 at the second spring boutique of the Kips Bay Boys Club. Proceeds of the sale in the clubhouse auditorium at 301 East Fifty-second Street will help support the club.

The Pepsi-Cola Company set records for earnings and for unit and dollar sales in the first quarter of this year. This was disclosed by Herbert L. Barnet, president at the annual meeting in Wilmington, Del, yesterday.
WASHINGTON, May 2 (AP) --Representative Emanuel Celler urged the Maritime Administration today to approve loan guarantee application from the American-Hawaiian Steamship Company of New York city.

WASHINGTON, May 2-- The Federal Reserve Board reported today that the condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in leading cities showed the following principal changes for the week ended, April 25:

GARDEN CITY, L.I., May 2 --The Republic Aviation Corporation made today what it termed its "final offer" to settle a thirty-one-day strike by machinists of Lodge 1987, International Association of Machinists.
TWO searipg experiences have marked the life of the Austrian Chancellor who arrived in the United States yesterday.
The head of a union of city sanitation workers hinted yesterday that its members might strike because Governor Rockefeller vetoed a pension bill backed by Mayor Wagner.
LONDON, May 2--Equity prices drifted lower in a quiet session on, the stock market today.
A major part of the ice cream industry in the metropolitan area was closed yesterday by a combination strike and suspension of operations.

Interpublic, Inc., the parent company of McCann-Erickson and McCann-Marschalk, seems to have developed an insatiable appetite for food accounts. The organization yesterday picked up its seventh major new account in the food field in the last year.

The Western world moves steadily toward economic and political fusion, but the vast problems involved are now being brought home to Washington. President Kennedy has just conferred with Prime Minister Macmillan on Britain's projected entry into the European Economic Community, involving the fate of the Commonwealth. Today the President confers with Chancellor Gorbach of Austria on even wider European integration involving the fate of the European neutrals.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 2--A United Nations investigating commission reported today that it had been unable to discover the cause of the plane crash in which Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold was killed last Sept. 17.

ELEVEN women whose homes stretch from coast to coast are currently furthering, their checkered careers in this city. At the Manhattan Chess Club, the Marshall Chess Club and the London Terrace Chess Club, the foremost women chess players of America are engaged in a tournament to determine the women's chess champion of the United States.

LOUISVILLE, May 2--It was gray and clammy in the early-morning hours at Churchill Downs today and the sun had not yet won its struggle to puncture the overcast. But it was business as usual in the barn area along the backstretch, particularly in the far row of stables where the more pampered pets are awaiting Saturday's eighty-eighth running' of the Kentucky Derby.
SAN FRANCISCO, May 2 (UPI)--Enrique Jorda, conductor of the San Francisco Symphony Orchestra for the last eight years, resigned his post
KANSAS CITY, Mo., May 2 (AP)-- Representative Tom Steed, Democrat of Oklahoma, says opponents of a strict formula to control oil imports are either too ignorant or too greedy.
WASHINGTON, May 2--President Kennedy's free-trade proposals spurred heated debate and an attempt to shift policy at the United States Chamber of Commerce convention today.
WASHINGTON, May 2 (UPI)--Secretary of the Interior Stewart L. Udall said today that development of a technique to carry coal by pipeline would strengthen the nation's security.

The partnership of influential citizens with the Fire Department in fire prevention activities is something new that deserves generous support. Appointed jointly by Mayor Wagner, Deputy Mayor Cavanagh and Fire Commissioner Thompson, the new Citizens Committee for Fire Prevention includes some hundred leaders representing organizations in every field of activities
Six unmarried Negro men, jobless and destitute by by no means humorless, arrived here yesterday morning after a fortyfour-hour bus ride from New Orleans.

CLIFTON, N.J., May 2--The New Jersey Highway Authority announced plans today for three improvements to its Garden State Parkway to meet demands of growing Bergen and Passaic Counties. The total cost to the authority will be $8,038,000.
BILOXI, Miss., May 2 (UPI) --A. Federal judge threw out nine Mississippi segregation statutes as unconstitutional today in upholding the right of three Negroes to unsegregated transportation service.

WASHINGTON, May 2-- Maj. Gherman S. Titoy, the Soviet astronaut, flew here today to chat with President Kennedy, talk about space "fireflies" with Lieut. Col. John H. Glenn Jr., his American counterpart, and to spread pleas for general disarmament.
Frank Braden, press agent for the Clyde Beatty-Cole Brothers Circus, died early today of pneumonia at Rhode Island Hospital in Providence. He was 76 years old.
An English secretary offered this bit of advice yesterday to her American counterparts: "Aim at perfection, even on the most trivial job."
WASHINGTON, May 2-- President Kennedy has intervened to halt a struggle for control of his $1,500,000,000-ayear Food for Peace program. The fight had split his immediate staff.
Discrimination against Jewish engineers, researchers and economists in major American industries "has largely disappeared," the American Jewish Committee reported yesterday.

British postponement of the conference that was to be held at the end of May to set a date for the independence of British Guiana was doubtless unavoidable. That steaming, tropical jungle country is not going to be ready for statehood this year.
LOS ANGELES, May 2--Leo E. Sievert, chief executive officer on the West Coast for the Santa Fe Railway, has died in Karachi, Pakistan, it was learned here today. He was 64 years old.
DETROIT, May 2 (AP) -- The Ford Motor Company said today that it cleard $2.32 a share for the first three months of 1962 on record sales of almost $2,000,000,000.
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., May 2 (AP)--State Senator Ryan DeGraffenried seemed almost certain tonight of a run-off in the Governorship race with front-running George C. Wallace.

EVEN if you did not know that the town is burgeoning with celebrations of Stravinsky's forthcoming eightieth birthday, you might have suspected something of the sort from last night's performance of his "Agon" by the New York City Ballet at the City Center.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 2 --The prop man, that unsung star of many a Hollywood "super-colossal," is moving with the flow of science.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., May 2 --Gov. Orval E. Faubus said today he would file his candidacy for the Democratic nomination and seek a fifth two-year term.

CHICAGO, May 2--The president of the American Medical Association charged here today that the Kennedy Administration was "trying to create a bandwagon" to win support for its medical-care plan for the aged.

WASHINGTON, May 2-- Democratic farm leaders found themselves still shy one vote today to clear the Administration's farm bill in the House Agriculture Committee. The trouble is still in their own party.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., May 2 (UPI)----Gov. Buford Ellington today ordered a special session to deal with Tennessee's legislative apportionment situation --the case that inspired the recent historic United States Supreme Court ruling.

WASHINGTON, May 2 (UPI)--Congressional invesgators said today the Air Force had "goofed" in ordering 156 men from Guard and Reserve units to active duty as individual fillers during the Berlin crisis.

RABAT, Morocco, May 2-- Allal el Fassi, a Moroccan nationalist leader, declared today that a "general rebellion" had broken out in the Republic of Mauritania and had been kept secret by authorities there.

Chancellor Alfons Gorbach of Austria said yesterday he was confident that President Kennedy would take a "sympathetic attitude" to Austria's desire to join the European Common Market as an associate member.

BRIARCLIFF MANOR, N.Y. May 2--Arthur J. Jones, headmaster from 1920 to 1947 of the Browning School, a college preparatory school for boys at 52 East Sixty-second Street, New York, died yesterday in the Brandywine Convalescent Home here. He was 83 years old and a resident of the home.
The State Workmen's Compensation Board ranks the New York City government last among nine major self-insurers in the state in terms of services to injured workers.
Mayor Wagner's suggestion that Dr. Ralph J. Bunche be considered a possible candidate for United States Senator produced a generally favorable reaction among state Democrats yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 2--Dr. James A. Van Allen, discoverer of the earth-circling radiation belts that bear his name, today termed the planned hydrogenbomb explosion high over the Pacific Ocean a "magnificent experiment."
ALBANY, May 2--Governor Rockefeller announced today that a Rochester Negro and a New Yorker of Puerto Rican descent had been appointed to the newly expanded State Commission on Human Rights.

LOS ANGELES, May 2 (AP) Al Demaree, former major league baseball pitcher, died here Monday. He was 75 years old. Mr. Demaree, whose full name was Albert Wentworth Demaree, worked as a syndicated sports cartoonist after he left baseball.

WASHINGTON, May 2--The startling view that the top of the earth's atmosphere is primarily heated not by sunlight but by magnetic waves rolling in from space was voiced today by scientists of three nations.

WASHINGTON, May 2-- Two Presidential emercency boards threw their weight today behind earlier recommendations for settling the question of how jet airliner cockpit crews are to be cut from four men to three.
ALBANY, May 2--The State Department of Health is embarking on experiments to ascertain the amount of strontium 90 that has been absorbed in the human body as a result of fallout from bomb testing.
SEOUL, Korea, May 2--Gen. Chung Hee Park, South Korean military ruler, ordered today the release from prison of Lieut. Gen. Chang Do Young, former head of the junta, and seven others.

Joseph Schmitz Fairchild of 5 Laurel Street, Longmeadow, Mass., president of the United States Envelope Company, Springfield, Mass., died yesterday of a heart attack in London, where he had stopped en route to the European Machinery. Show at Duesseldorf, Germany. His age was 59.
CHICAGO, May 2 (AP)-- Wheat futures had a short-lived burst of strength on the Board of Trade today but finished steady. Other commodities were mixed in slow dealings.

MANAGUA, Nicaragua, May 1--President Luis A. Somoza Debayle has announced labor reforms he said his Administration would submit to Congress. The reforms were announced at a May Day rally of the General Confederation of Workers.
COIN-OPERATED dry-clean ing machines, which are said to save up to 75 per cent on dry-cleaning bills, may soon become familiar to many New Yorkers.
WASHINGTON, May 2--The House of Representatives approved and sent to the Senate today a bill providing for a requirement that new television sets be capable of receiving all eighty-two channels.
Broadway's Hindu astrologer, Sant Ram Mandal, who said he could foresee most of the world's problems, died Monday at the age of 68.
A director of the ExportImport Bank of Washington described as "pathetic" yesterday the reluctance of many American business men to take advantage of foreign trade opportunities.

PARIS, May 2--Former Gen. Raoul Salan, captured chief of the Secret Army Organization, will go on trial May 15, both for his part in the military uprising of April last year in Algeria and for his subversive activities that followed.

Earnings have been on the rise in recent months, but the question remains whether the rise is vigorous as the Administration has hoped. One answer of "no" came yesterday from the First National City Bank.
KATMANDU, Nepal, May 2 --A ban on four Nepalese daily newspapers will be lifted immediately, an official spokesman said last night.
Price irregularity was visible in United States Government securities yesterday on the final subscription day for the Treasury's $11,683,000,000 refunding operation.
ALGIERS, May 2--At least ninety-one Moslems and six Europeans were killed here today by terrorists belonging to the Secret Army Organization. About 130 Moslems were wounded in the attacks.
WASHINGTON, May 2 (UPI) --The Federal Aviation Agency is preparing a corps of specially trained flight inspectors to help prevent any recurrence of last summer's "skyjacking" incidents.

WASHINGTON, May 2 (AP) --Business witnesses told the Senate Finance Committee to. day that the foreign earnings provisions of President Kennedy's tax bill would seriously harm United States concerns operating abroad.

The Longacre has been reserved for "Harold," in which Anthony Perkins will be starred, Nov. 29 is the opening date for Herman Raucher's comedy. Saint Subber, in association with Ben Edwards and Wigwam Productions, will sponsor the offering, to be directed by Larry Blyden.

WASHINGTON, May 2--The House Rules Committee, after a three-mouth delay, agreed today to let Senate and House conferees try to devise a compromise between the college-aid bill approved by the House and that passed by the Senate.
AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, May 2 (Reuters)-- Benfica of Lisbon rallied in the second half tonight and beat Real Madrid, 5--3, to retain the European Soccer cup.
CHICAGO, May 2 (AP)-- Mayor William D. Ryan of Newburgh, N.Y., said tonight that many needy persons were afraid to apply for relief in his city.
Governor Rockefeller opposed last night any "arbitrary" reduction in the strength of the National Guard. A major cut, he said, would "drastically affect the Guard's readiness posture."
ROME, May 2--Foreign Minister Antonio Segni, a pro Western former Premier, was leading today at the end of the first day's voting for Presiden of the Italian Republic.

THIRTEEN wives of African diplomats, who were given a bird's-eye view of the garment industry yesterday, indicated that they did not know the difference between French, Italian and American fashion-- and cared less.

Additional details of the battle of words between Traffic Commissioner Henry A. Barnes and Investigation Commissioner Louis I. Kaplan came to light yesterday, but both principals insisted the truce they had reached Tuesday was still in force.

SOUTH FALLSBURG, N.Y., May 2--A broad-shouldered, 225-pound man who hopes to become the world heavyweight boxing champion before the year runs out, came to The Pines Hotel here today to set up his training camp.

Dr. Samuel B. Gould, president of the Educational Broadcasting Corporation, proposed yesterday that New York's cultural resources, including orchestras, theatre companies and performing artists, be made available for programing on station WNDT (Channel 13). The station, the first noncommercial outlet for New York, will begin its programs on Sept. 16.

WASHINGTON, May 2-- Secretary of State Dean Rusk said in Congressional testimony published today that persons who talk about a "no-win policy" seem to want either a thermonuclear war or American withdrawal from the world stage.

Vincent W. Hartnett, author of a bulletin that imputed Communist sympathies to John Henry Faulk, the entertainer, made no such accusations either in "Red Channels" or during appearances before Congressional committees, it was stated yesterday in State Supreme Court.
HARRISON, N. Y., May 2-- Miss Ann Lee Morgan and David Anderson Fabianic plan to be married in August.
AUSTIN, Tex., May 2--A jerry-built but vigorous liberal Democratic coalition has emerged in Texas to challenge the state's established political order and Vice President Johnson.
Duquesne Light Company and subsidiaries reported yesterday "substantially higher" sales and earnings for the first quarter.

In the summer of 1813, a three-man commission from the young United States met with representatives of Great Britgin in St. Petersburg, Russia, to negotiate the end of a war between their two countries.
ALTHOUGH he is primarily the twentieth century's most influential composer, Igor Stravinsky has been vitally associated with many arts other than music, principally opera and ballet.
The City Planning Commission approved yesterday the controversial Cadman Plaza redevelopment project in Brooklyn.

NEW DELHI, India, May 2--India has accused Communist China of creating conflict and tension among Asian nations. In a note to Peiping made public today, India bluntly rejected the Chinese Communists' contention that they wanted to live in friendship with other Asian nations.

NEWMARKET, England, May 2 (UPI)--Privy Councillor led most of the way to beat the American-owned Romulus by three lengths today in the Two Thousand Guineas. The stakes is the first of Britain's five spring racing classics. It had its first running in 1809.

LAUREL, Md., May 2 (AP) --Charles E. Reithmeyer's Double Heritage scored a twolength victory over Carolyn K. Stable's Nip o'Brandy in the fifth running of the $16,650added Maryland Derby at Laurel today.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 2--Pakistan demanded today that India allow a plebiscite to find out whether the people of Kashmir wished to join India or Pakistan.
WASHINGTON, May 2--The President's Committee on Equal Employment Opportunity announced today that Comet Rice Mills, Inc., was again eligible to receive Government contracts.

The students of the North and South Senior High Schools of Great Neck, L.I., will sponsor two Carnegie Hall concerts next month for the benefit of Lincoln Center. The concerts will take place in the afternoon and evening of June 3.

GENEVA, May 3--Britain challenged the Soviet Union today to prove its desire to end the arms race by making constructive proposals for advancing the negotiations on a treaty on general and complete disarmament.

BOSTON, May 2--Philip Ray Allen, former president of F.W. Bird Son, paper manufacturers of East Walpole, died this morning in the Massachusetts General Hospital. He was 88 years old. His son, Philip Kirkham Allen, is president of the Massachusetts Republican State Committee.

CHICAGO, May 2--Elston Howard's two-run homer in the ninth turned an apparent 3-2 defeat at the hands of the White Sox into a 4-3 victory for the streaking and frontrunning Yankees tonight at Comiskey Park.
IN Weston, Conn., two 14-yearold vandals recently were apprehended for defacing a thirty foot bridge. For punishment they had to repaint the bridge railings.
WASHINGTON, May 2 (UPI) --The Securities and Exchange Commission today revoked the licenses of two New York securities brokers.
WESTBURY, L.I., May 2-- Four harness horses from Australia and New Zealand will command a share of the interest in a pair of stakes events at Roosevelt Raceway on Saturday night.
TOKYO, May 2 (UPI)-- Three Americans broke Japanese records today in the national indoor swimming championships.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 2-- The property condemnation powers exercised by municipal governments in most urban renewal programs were attacked today on the ground that they were uprooting minority groups struggling to gain a foothold.
Cotton futures were unchanged to 15 cents a bale off yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange.

With the holding of elections for a National Assembly, Pakistan's new system of limited democracy under a new Constitution has passed its first test. But, as President Ayub Khan has said, more difficult trials lie ahead.

WASHINGTON, May 2--The United States has requested the right to stage a two-year national exhibition in Moscow and Leningrad in exchange for Soviet participation in the 19641965 New York World's Fair.

BONN, Germany, May 2-- Qualified sources reported today that Foreign Minister Gerhard Schroeder would make reservations about United States proposals for a Berlin settlement when he meets Secretary of Satte Dean Rusk this week.
A late Easter pushed sales last month of the major department stores in the metropolitan area 14 per cent ahead of figures for April, 1961, a survey by The New York Times disclosed yesterday.

Springtime's annual outdoor flower show in city parks and gardens had strong competition yesterday from the Gramercy Park Association. Exhibits of floral arrangements filled the gallery of the National Arts Club at 15 Gramercy Park South.

MANY novels lull us into what you might call a false sense of peril. We think that something pretty terrific is going to happen. Then nothing apocalyp tic happens at all. Nothing, that is, beyond the banalities of violence that hardly change from one book, one scene, to another.
A Madison Avenue jeweler who died last month left an estate of about $250,000 "to the Treasurer of the United States of America."

Another depressing miasma hovered over Coogan's Bluff and the Polo Grounds yesterday. This one could not be laid to the derelictions of the Mets, but rather to the weather. It was cold and wet, forcing the postponement of a game with the Cincinnati Reds.

An independent union of deck-scow captains, most of whose members are currently unemployed, warned yesterday of a costly strike against member companies of the Harbor Carriers of the Port of New York.

Operations of the Anaconda Company for the first quarter of this year resulted in an increase in consolidated net income to $13,900,000 from $11,700,000 for the 1961 period. Profits equaled $1.30 a share, compared with $1.09 a share.

OTTAWA, May 2 (Canadian Press)--Donald M. Fleming, minister of Finance, announced tonight that the international exchage rate of the Canadian dollar was being stabilized at 92 , cents in terms of United States Currency. The new rate takes effect immediately.

The Canal-Randolph Corporation, a real estate holding concern, has reacquired part of the 20 per cent interest in its own stock that had been held by the Kratter Corporation, a real estate investment company.

GEORGETOWN, British Guiana, May 2--Spokesmen for the Government party and an opposition party criticized today Britain's decision to delay talks on British Guiana's independence. The delay, announced yesterday, will permit an investigation into origins of the Feb. 6 rioting in which six persons were killed and much damage was caused by arson and looting.

Events today: New York Philharmonic preview concert, Leonard Bernstein, conductor, Seiji Ozawa and Maurice Peress, assistant conductors, Carnegie Hall, 8:30 P.M.; Concert Singers of Inter-American ...

The forty-two-story office building at 515 Madison Avenue, northeast corner of Fiftythird Street, has been purchased by Aaron Rabinowitz for family investment. Mr. Rabinowitz is chairman of the boardnof the Fred F. French Management Company.

THE program that Paul Boepple and his Dessoff Choirs presented last night in Carnegie Hall was rather strange. For some reason he decided to preface the Mozart Requiem with the first New York performance of Louis Calabro's Symphony No. 2 for String Orchestra.
A call for safeguards against a rising volume of imported knitgoods made of wool and synthetic fibers was issued here yesterday by a spokesman for the domestic knitted outerwear industry.

A Roman Catholic educational film group has produced a documentary feature giving its interpretation of the controversial San Francisco riots during the 1960 Communist investigations by the House Committee on Un-American Activities.
The National Basketball Association will be asked today to approve the sale and transfer of the Philadelphia Warriors' franchise to San Francisco interests headed by Bernard Solomon.
WORCESTER, England, May 2 (Reuters)--The Pakistani cricket team made an indifferent start in opening its tour today, finishing 78 runs behind Worcestershire with six first-innings wickets down.

A revision in the method of arriving at best-of-breed winners at dog shows has been offeted by J. M. O'Connor of New York, who owns the Norcrest Kennels. He would have the winner emerge from a single open class, with the winners, dogs; winners, bitches; best of winners and special classes eliminated.

COLOGNE, Germany, May 2 (AP)--West Germany's exports, despite the gloomy predictions of Ludwig Erhard, Minister of Economics, Jumped to a record 12,600,000,000 marks ($3,150,000,000) in the first quarter of 1962, according to figures made available today.

New Yorkers were asked yesterday to help protect the city's parks against litter and vandalism. The personal appeal was made by eight young women who distributed lapel buttons and balloons to persons along Fifth Avenue and in the financial district.
ANCHORAGE, Alaska, May 2--Thirteen candidates for Governor and Senator crouched at the starting line today on Alaska's thawing political track.
PRINCETON, N.J., May 2-- The Rev. Dr. Karl Barth said today he hoped Israel would be "wise enough" not to execute Adolf Eichmann.
William Gargan demonstrated yesterday that an actor who loses his voice may still play a useful and communicative role.
THE final round of the World Bridge Federation's olympiad pair tournament at Cannes, France, began last night with thirtysix pairs surviving out of the starting field of seventy-eight pairs.
BRUSSELS, Belgium, May 2 --Norway applied today for membership in the European Economic Community.

LOUISVILLE, May 2--For a race that promises to be a duel between Christopher Chenery's Sir Gaylord and Mrs. Moody Jolley's Ridan, the Kentucky Derby may have more than fifteen horses shooting for part of the $125,000 added money on Saturday.
Fairbanks Whitney Corporation management at the annual meeting here yesterday reported a nominal gain in first quarter earnings, over the year ago period.

The Yanks are go ing. In Britain, many of their installations are closing down, mainly because of a shift in major weapons. G. I.'s will be around for a long time yet, but the strain imposed on the British by the vast, trampling herd of other years has been easing.
CALL it a merger of Tokyo and Naples with fine cheeses and spices and herbs thrown in for good measure. That is the one-block area on East Fiftyninth Street between Second and Third Avenues.

A group of investors headed by the Millard William Shroder Company has bought the property at the northeast corner of Columbus Avenue and Sixty-seventh Street. The site will be used in the near future for an office or apartment building.
ANKARA, Turkey, May 2-- The coalition government of Premier Ismet Inonu is overcoming its latest crisis.
WASHINGTON, May 2--The United States set off today its first explosion in the megaton range in the atmospheric nuclear tests in the central Pacific.

The recommendations of President Kennedy's Advisory Committee on Labor-Management Policy for a more assertive Federal role in collective bargaining indicate the necessity for redefining the boundary lines in the relations of Government, industry and labor.

The Official Catholic Directory for 1962, published here today by P.J. Kenedy Sons, lists the total number of Roman Catholics in the United States at 42,876,665. This represents an increase of 771,765 over last year, or about 1.8 per cent.
After quite a lapse in interest, investors turned once again to gold shares yesterday, and all because of the weakness in the Canadian dollar.
ROME, May 3 The Senate and Chamber of Deputies, meeting with ten regional representatives, were unable for a second day to elect a President of the Italian Republic.

The Federal Maritime Commission told eight British shipping lines yesterday to disregard an oorder issued recently by Britain's Minister of Transport, Ernest Marples. It advised them instead to comply with an order issued by one of the regulatory agency's examiners.
SINCE S.J. Perelman is a humorous writer, he needs a sober place in which to work.

ESPIONAGE, it is generally conceded, is a dirty business. Many of the people involved in it are more interested in private gain than in patriotic service. The risks are always frightful and the rewards meager. Few spies, we may safely assume, lead the glamorous life of Ian Fleming's redoubtable James Bond.

Towers Marts International, Inc., which operates twenty-five discount department stores on the East Coast and in Canada, filed suit yesterdqy to end its contracts with two companies that operate leased departments in its stores.

ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L.I., May 3 Miss Rosalyn Gross, daughter of Mrs. Sigmund Gross and the late Mr. Gross, was married here at noon today to Dr. Leonard Coleman Harber, son of Mr. and Mrs. Morris Harber of Long Beach.
WHITE PLAINS, ay 3 Ogden R. Reid chose world peace today as his main discussion point in his campaign for nomination as the Republican candidate for Representative from the Twenty-sixth District.
LOUISVILLE, May 3 It was a lazy spring morning. An atmosphere of bucolic peace and contentment hung over the barn area at Churchill Downs as a benign sun blazed down from cloudless blue skies.
Charles Frederic Chapman is No. 1 man in the large fraternity of pleasure boating. Statisticians of the Coast Guard and other agencies reveal there are about 40,000,000 devotees of boating.
CHICAGO, May 3 (AP) The grain market was unusually active today with the feed grains strong and other commodities about steady to weak on the Board of Trade.
A thousand ground employes of Pan American World Airways staged two unauthorized walkouts at New York International Airport yesterday but returned to their jobs in late afternoon under union orders.
The City Planning Commission approved yesterday the acquisition of property needed for the construction of the proposed $100,000,000 Lower Manhattan Expressway.
MOSCOW, May 3 The Soviet Union accused the United States today of withdrawing from a flexible policy on Berlin to an intransigent position that endangered world peace.
The shutdown of twelve ice cream manufacturing plants in the metropolitan area will not cause a serious shortage, a Teamster Union official said yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Friday, May 4 (AP) The Embassy of the United Arab Republic said early today reports that President Gamal Abdel Nasser had been shot and wounded by an assassin were "absolutely baseless."

MILLEDGEVILLE, Ga., May 3 Mrs. Helen Dortch Longstreet, widow of James Longstreet, the controversial Confederate General, died at Milledgeville State Hospital this morning of a heart attack. She was 99 years old and had been a patient at the institution since 1957.
TOKYO, May 3 (AP) American swimmers captured five of the six events they entered in the Japan national indoor swimming championships today and bettered one Japanese record in the process.
Six men and women received the Sidney Hillman Foundation annual awards yesterday for achievements in the fields of writing and television in 1961.

WASHINGTON, May 3 (AP) Representative Wayne Hays has charged that American taxpayers are bearing the cost of Congo officials' paying themselves $3,000 a month, or more than one and a half times the salary of a United States Congressman. A Congressman gets $22,500 a year.

The Governors of New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, in setting up the Tri-State Transportation Committee on Aug. 30, 1961, asked for an "action-oriented" program. The committee's second interim report has met this request squarely.

STAMFORD, Conn., May 3 Henry D. Mercer's 12-meter yacht Weatherly, one of four candidates to become the defender of the America's Cup, entered Lonh Island Sound water from the Luders Marine Construction Company yard today.
WASHINGTON, May 3 Saul Wallen long ago lost count of the arbitration decisions he has written in labor-management disputes, but the total is close to 5,000.

PARIS, May 3 A former colonel, considered by experts here to be one of the most dangerous members of the French Right-wing subversive movement, is understood to have toured French Army garrisons in West Germany recently.
School and teacher representatives will meet today in another attempt to resolve the salary dispute that led to last month's one-day strike by the city's teachers.

WASHINGTON, May,3 (AP) Senate Democrats and Republicans sharply rebutted today charges by Senator James O. Eastland that the Supreme Court had upheld Communist party views in forty-six of seventy recent decisions.
State and municipal long term financing reported in April totaled $839,834,502, com pared with $709,954,735 in April, 1961, and the revised total of $620,648,054 for last March.
Daily average borrowings by member banks of the Federal Reserve System fell $22,000,000 in the week ended Wednesday to $63,000,000, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.
SYRACUSE, May 3 After the race on Onondaga Lake last Saturday, Pete Gardner, the Dartmouth rowing coach, told Loren Schoel, his Syracuse counterpart, "you've got a flying machine."

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., May 3 Gene Borek, a rookje head professional, tied Herman Barron and Gus Salerno for the Westchester Professional Golfers Association championship today. Each scored 144 at the Ridgeway Country Club. An 18hole play-off is scheduled Sunday to decide the title.
WASHINGTON, May 3 The first transmission of television pictures by way of an orbiting satellite was announced today by the Air Force.
DACCA, Pakistan, May 3 Commmist China and Pakistan have agreed to negotiate on the demarcation of the border between Sinkiang Province and the segment of Kashmir controlled by the Pakistanis.

MINNEAPOLIS, May 3 Americans will have to live with the "hard but necessary fact of the nuclear arms race" until the Communist regimes agree to effective international inspection and control of nuclear weapons, an Administration leader told the League of Women Voters tonight.
HARRIMAN, N.Y., May 3 Automation marks the end of any "rational resort" to isolationism and protectionism, the president of the American Assembly said today.

BATON ROUGE, La., May 3 (UPI) A New Orleans Citizens Council official said today that Little Rock (Ark.) segregationists would ship two Negro families to Boston Tuesday and telegraph Edward M. Kennedy to meet them there.

The Museum of Modern Art has announced that it can no longer sponsor the United States sections in the world's two major international art exhibitions, the Venice and Sao Paulo biennials. The question of our participation following the museum's final commitment to Venice this summer is thus left to the Federal Government.
Irving Melsher of 309 West 100th Street, composer of popular songs, band leader and music teacher, died yesterday at Mount Sinai Hospital, His age was 56.
WASHINGTON, May 3 A Presidential emergency board recommended today what it said were noninflationary wage increases for 500,000 nonoperating employes on the nation's railroads.
BAYONNE, N.J., May 3 A break in a thirty-inch water main cut off the entire water supply for this city of 74,000 persons for more than six hours today. It was repaired shortly after 8 P.M.

Following is the transcript of the news conference held by Lieut. Col. John H. Glenn and Maj. Gherman S. Titov in Washington yesterday, as recorded by The New York Times. Major Titov's remarks were translated from the Russian.

The $6,000,000,000 increase in commercial banks' time and savings deposits during, the first quarter of 1962 was not at the expense of competing thrift institutions. This was reported yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York at its weekly press briefing.

It was like the Madhattan Room of the old Pennsylvania Hotel in 1938. Benny Goodman and the band were driving "King Porter Stomp" and the boys and girls were dancing. Admittedly, there were differences: it was twenty-four years later, Benny Goodman was gray, and the boys and girls were Russian.

A "widespread movement" among European Roman Catholic and Protestant church leaders to combat anti-Jewish prejudice "rooted in religious texts and materials" was reported here yesterday by the director of the European office of the American Jewish Committee.

CHICAGO, May 3 Gov. Luis Munoz-Marin of Puerto Rico said tonight that there was only one group in Latin America, or at least one group above all others, that could make the administration's Alliance for Progress work.
Several conflicting trends are reflected in the results of this week's suburban school district elections and referendums.
WASHINGTON, May 3 President Kennedy has directed the military to cut back its orders for nuclear warheads by several thousands, Pentagon sources disclosed today.
Heard V.K. Khrishna Menon of India in Indian-Pakistani debate over Kashmir.
LONDON, May 3 (AP) The statement of account of the Bank of England for the week ended yesterday follows (in thousands of pounds):
WASHINGTON, May 3 A 65-year-old Texas woman said today that she had been dropped as a Peace Corps trainee because she could not run a mile before breakfast, do push-ups and swim with her feet tied.

THE horror-ridden world of Franz Kafka moves from the printed page to the stage with stubborn reluctance. Bunker Jenkins has made a direct, honest effort to dramatize "In the Penal Colony," but he has not gone much beyond providing a reading.
A 40 per cent Increase in automobile deaths here in the first four months of this year was reported yesterday by Police Commissioner Michael J. Murphy.
ATHENS, May 3 Britain will propose to the North Atlantic alliance that all its members discuss when and how tactical nuclear weapons are to be employed in the event of a Soviet attack.
TOKYO, Friday, May 4 Two commuter trains and a freight train piled up in a wreck yesterday at the end of a mild spring holiday, taking a toll of 147 dead.
Production of lumber in the nation totaled 230,592,000 board feet in the week ended April 28, according to reports received from regional associations.
WASHINGTON, May 3 President Kennedy congratulated the Matson Navigation Company today on its eightieth anniversary of service to Hawaii.

The city has asked the United States Public Health Service to withdraw four New York medical investigators from a training course in Atlanta because of discrimination against a Negro member of the team.
SOCTRANG, Vietnam, May 3 Four hundred United States Marines are operating a "dryland aircraft carrier" here to support the South Vietnamese Army's campaign against Communist guerrillas.

MINEOLA, L.I., May 3 Maurice Weingold of Cedarhurst, L.I., an estate tax appraiser of the New York State Tax Commission, was named the first Public Administrator of Nassau County today by Nassau Surrogate John D. Bennett.
A commissioner of the Securities and Exchange Commission urged last night that the mutual funds industry examine itself seriously.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 3 India rejected today the idea of any intervention or good offices by the United Nations or anyone else in her dispute with Pakistan over Kashmir.
The parking-meter controversy that erupted here this week can be traced back almost a decade.
Trading halted on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange about 10:30 yesterday morning as the great gong sounded the knell of the member firm of Schirmer, Atherton Co. of Boston.
Three hundred New York University students rallied near Washington Square yesterday to protest the resumption of nuclear testing by the United States.

WASHINGTON, May 3 (UPI) The Senate Judiciary Committee voted today to tighten an anti-subversive law because of a Supreme Court decision in 1957 that reversed the conviction of fourteen known Communists on charges of advocating the overthrow of the Government.
WASHINGTON, May 3 Senator Prescott Bush said today that the Kennedy Administration had failed to face up to the seriousness of the nation's international economic position.

Secretary of Defense McNamara in testimony before the House Merchant Marine Committee has raised a question of Federal policy that has long needed review and overhauling construction and operating subsidies for shipping. During the committee's inquiry into the state of the merchant marine he said flatly that military needs no longer justified Federal financial aid in the construction of passenger liners. Airlift has taken over.
CANNES, France, May 3 (UPI) Francois Andre, the legendary "Mr. Casino" to prince and pauper alike, died last night in his hotel apartment on the Riviera. He was 83 years old.

SAIGON, Vietnam, May 3 United States Army and Marine helicopters carried South Vietnamese troops yesterday to the edge of the Plaine des Jones, a weird, marshy jungle of sixfoot reeds in the Mekong River delta.
WASHINGTON, May 3 President Kennedy intervened today to reassure critics of the controversial Pentagon plan for reorganization and reduction of the National Guard and the Army Reserve.

NORWALK, Conn., May 3 The Bureau of Research, Statistics and Finance of the State Board of Education has recommended the establishment of regional school districts to include a minimum enrollment of 2,000 pupils.
Bank clearings in the twentysix leading cities of the nation came to $33,733,639,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, Dun Bradstreet, Inc., reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May, 3 President Kennedy, like President Roosevelt in 1934, is coming up to his first mid-term election, and again like Roosevelt in 1934, he is in the middle of his first tiff with the business community.

EVERY spring the Allison Gallery at 32 East Fifty seventh Street puts together an exhibition of landscape and figure paintings by George Bellows, keeping alive the memory and the achievement of one of the most immediately attractive twentieth-century American artists.
WASHINGTON, May 3 Two retired war heroes have turned down the opportunity for special $100-a-month pensions that Congress voted last year for winners of the Medal of Honor.
HARRODSBURG, Ky. MANY horse racing fans, visiting Kentucky for the first time to see the famous race tomorrow, are quickly discovering that this week is party week as well as Derby week.

The Bank of Tokyo Trust Company has leased the corner store and mezzanine in the Brause Building at 320 Fifth Avenue, northwest corner of Thirty-second Street, from Jack Krause, realty investor and owner of the building. The aggregate rental will exceed $750,000.
WASHINGTON, May 3 President Kennedy called today for redoubled efforts to eliminate racial segregation in the public schools.

James Joyce's "Portrait of the Artist as a Young Man," regarded as one of the finest novels of the century, has been adapted into a long, one-act play and will open off Broadway at the Martinique Theatre on May 28.
A new "concept" has been introduced to the foreign aid program by a large group of industrial and banking firms who plan to set up production plants and operations in South Korea.
The Federal Aviation Agency has announced agreement with thirteen airlines on user charges at Dulles International Airport, which is scheduled to open in October.

CHICAGO, May 3 John William Buzhardt, a 25-year-old right-hander from Prosperity, S.C., brought prosperity to the Chicago White Sox tonight. With the help of a fourth-inning homer by Jim Landis, the youthful sinker-ball pitcher hurled a 1-0 victory over the Yankees before 30,481 fans at Comiskey Park.
The stock market rally, which began with a flourish on Tuesday and then eased on Wednesday, got a second wind yesterday. Stocks scored good gains in moderate trading on the New York Stock Exchange.
A group of American ranch mink pelts raised by a Utah mink-breeder were sold here yesterday for $150 apiece, the highest price ever paid for dark mink skins of this type.

PRINCETON, N.J. May 3 Dr. Walter P. Hall of 1 Elm Road, a member of the Princeton University faculty for thirty-nine years before his retirement in 1952, died this morning of a heart attack in Austin, Tex. He had been visiting his son, Michael, a teacher at the University of Texas. He would have been 78 years old on Saturday.
ALGIERS, May 3 Algerian nationalists here threatened today for the first time to take the fight against European terrorists into their own hands.

Eighteen writers, artists and composers were named the winners yesterday of $2,000 grants by the National Institute of Arts and Letters. Malcolm Cowley, president of the honor society, made the announcement.
DEATH is a part of life that should not be concealed from a child, and yet some parents find discussing death more difficult than explaining sex.
LONDON, May 3 Industrial shares continued to drift in the stock market today. There was a sprinkling of gains in most groups, but the general movement was down.
The head of the New York Board of Rabbis appealed to leaders of major faiths last night to put aside their differences and dissensions and create a "powerful moral force" in the national interest.
The Appellate Division, First Department, unanimously rejected Michael H. Prendergast's appeal for reinstatement as Democratic state chairman in a ruling yesterday.
After three days of rain, fog and chill, the sunshine returned to Aqueduct yesterday, bringing back the gulls to the infield lakes and 26,140 customers to the pari-mutuel machines.

The Marine Engineers Beneficial Association yesterday resumed its strike against Isbrandtsen Company, Inc.

IF the regular cook is taking the day off this Sunday, less experienced family chefs will be glad to hear that steaks are offered at reduced rates at some stores this week-end. In fact most cuts of beef are reduced, with chuck roast and chuck steak leading the field.
PRINCETON, N.J., May 3 Martin P. Catherwood called today upon the Federal Government and the states to take more effective steps to reduce unemployment.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 3 Walter P. Reuther said today his union would seek not only annual productivity wage increases in the air-space industries, but also "catch-up raises" to put rates in line with other major industries.

Robert Morse, whose boyish smile is proving almost as disarming to Broadway audiences as to competing executives in "How to Succeed in Business Without Really Trying," has been signed to a four-pictur contract by Otto Preminger.
LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congon, May 3 The United Nations announced here today that President Moise Tshombe of Katanga Province would not return to Leopoldville "for one or two days."
The State of West Virginia borrowed $3,000,000 in the bond market yesterday to finance road construction. The money was raised on serial bonds due from 1963 to 1987 and secured by general taxation.

ELEVEN table settings for "The Poor Girl" go on view at Tiffany's today. They are imaginative, witty and above all sensibly priced. Most of the place settings, exclusive of silverware, cost under $15.
John Henry Faulk testified yesterday that he has had to seek work as an encyclopedia salesman afer accusations of pro-communism had cost him his job as a radio and television entertainer.
SAN FRANCISCO, May 3 Of his resignation as director of the San Francisco Symphony, Enrique Jorda, said today: "This was entirely my own decision. There was no pressure brought upon me."
City Labor Commissioner Harold A. Felix cautioned the head of a union of city sanitation workers yesterday that a strike, threatened by the union, could have serious consequences for it.

Finlandia Center, Inc., has announced it has purchased the property at the southwest corner of Madison Avenue and Fifty-fifth Street. The site will be used for a new Finnish center to take the place of the one that was at 41 East Fiftieth Street until a few years ago.
The wholesale commodity price index rose to 82.2 Wednesday from 81.8 Tuesday. The index, compiled by the Bureau of Labor Statistics, stood at 87.2 on April 27, 1961.

ARLINGTON, Vt., May 3 Another long stretch of the Battenkill River, one of the better trout streams in New England, has been posted. The signs are fresh and new, and if any sportsman feels his temper rise at the sight of them he might consider how they came to be there.
Flight tests to discover whether helicopters can safely navigate in and around a big city using regular aviation radio and radar will begin here today.

WASHINGTON, May 3 Communist propagandists grealy increased their broadcasts in the last year, especially to Africa and Latin America, but they had some difficulty coping with a number of major world issues, according to an analysis of Communist propaganda by the United States Information Agency.
MOSCOW, May 3 (AP) Susan Starr, Philadelphia pianist, was enthusiastically received tonight in the final round of the second International Tchaikovsky Music Competition.

WHITING, Ind., May 3 (UPI) Net earnings of the Standard Oil Company (Indiana) dropped to $37,600,000, or $1.05 a share, for the first quarter of 1962 from $43,800,000, or $1.23 a share for the 1961 period, John E. Swearingen, president, reported today.

STAMFORD, Conn., May 3 This city has sidestepped a school redistricting problem stemming from charges of "racial, economic and ethnic inbalance," by making both of its high schools two-year institutions.
OTTAWA, May 3 Last night's stabilization of the Canadian dollar by the Canadian Government for the first time in eleven years was welcomed by many and deplored by others. Exporters saw it.

David Picket, president of Gotham Construction Corporation, 501 Fifth Avenue, one of New York's leading building concerns, died yesterday of a heart attack in his home at 910 Park Avenue. His age was 55.

Business men in general seem thoroughly convinced of advertising's ability to sell goods, but they harbor strong reservations about its over-all quality and its social repercussions. In fact, the vast majority believes advertising persuades people to buy things they shouldn't buy and that this is a bad thing for the nation.
THE leading pairs remained unchanged in order but drew closer together after the first session of the finals in the World Bridge Federation's olympiad open pair tournament in Cannes, France.

Increased sales and earnings in 1962 were forecast for the Brooklyn Union Gas Company yesterday by John E. Heyke, president. Nearly eighty stockholders attended the annual meeting, held in the concern's new general office building at 195 Montague Street, Brooklyn.

NEW HAVEN, May 3 A late Fifteenth Century map showing the geographical concepts of Christopher Columbus immediately before his discovery of America has been found and given to the Yale Library. This was announced today by James T. Babb, university librarian.
WASHINGTON, May 3-Department store sales in the nation for the week ended Saturday, April 28, were 5 per cent above the level of a year earlier.

JAMESTOWN, N.Y., May 3 Governor Rockefeller advised the milk industry today to counter a New York City Health Department pamphlet that, he said, urged adults not to drink milk.
Before a full house of stockholders yesterday, Jerome A. Straka, president of Chesebrough-Pond's Inc., disclosed a handful of aces.

NEW DELHI, India, May 3 Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru told Parliament today that Indian troops would hold two military posts in the Ladakh section of Kashmir that appeared to be directly threatened by Chinese Communist "frontier guards."
ROCHESTER, May 3 Dr. Howard Hanson announced last night that he would retire as director of the Eastman School of Music on his fortieth anniversary with the school in July, 1964.
Abraham A. Ribicoff expressed confidence yesterday that the Kennedy Administration's medical care plan for the aged would win Congressional approval this year.

ABOUT two weeks ago the trio consisting of Isaac Stern (violin), Leonard Rose ('cello) and Eugene Istomin (piano) made its New York debut in Beethoven's Triple Concerto. Last night these three musicians appeared on their own, giving the first of three chamber music concerts at Grace Rainey Rogers Auditorium.

Dr. Frank Stanton, president of the Columbia Broadcasting System, expressed disagreement yesterday with critics who have charged that the United States image is being damaged by American television shows sent abroad.
Cotton futures were 15 to 50 cents a bale up yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange.
Many persons entertained last evening at the fifth annual dinner dance for the benefit of the Lenox Hill Hospital. For the occasion, the Sert Room of the Waldorf-Astoria had a pink decor.
PHILADELPHIA, May 3 (UPI) Clay Dalrymple singled Johnny Callison home with the winning run in the ninth inning tonight to give the Philadelphia Phillies a 9-8 victory over the Milwaukee Braves.
GENEVA, May 3 The Soviet Union ruled out today all possibility of progress on a treaty to ban nuclear testing unless the West abandoned its demands for international controls and inspection.
LONDON, May 3 Three bronze sculptures of Queen Elizabeth by Sir Charles Wheeler, president of the Royal Academy of Arts, are the featured works this year of the academy's 194th summer exhibition.
LAS VEGAS, Nev., May 3 (AP) Four top professionals, led by Arnold Palmer, were tied after the first round of the $50,000 Tournament of Champions today with 3-under-par 69's.

WASHINGTON, May 3 The railroad and trucking industries reported yesterday higher loadings of freight last week. Loadings were substantially higher than seasonal factors normally indicate, it was noted.
The board of directors of the M.H. Fishman Company, Inc. reduced the quarterly cash dividend yesterday to 7 cents a share. A 3 per cent stock dividend also was voted.

A rarely performed work and two brand new ones all of them engagingly lyrical made up the first half of the BeauxArts String Quartet's program in Carnegie Recital Hall last night. Arriaga's Quartet No. 3
FRANKLIN, Tex., May 3 This town is the scene of one of the most perplexing mysteries in the Billie Sol Estes case.
WILLEMSTAD, Curacao, May 3 Two games were drawn and two were adjourned yesterday in first-round results of the Candidates' Chess Tournament here.

Pan American World Airways and Trans World Airlines, the nation's two major international flag carriers, confirmed reports yesterday that they had discussed a possible merger.
The appointment of several merchandise and operating executives, along with the managers of four branch stores, as vice presidents of Macy's New York was announced yesterday.

LOUISVILE, May 3 More than a little apprehension was generated at Churchill Downs today when the draw for the eighty-eighth running of the Kentucky Derby placed Townsend B. Martin's Sunrise County in post position 2, near the rail.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 3 (UPI) Willie Mays greeted the relief appearance of ElRoy Face with a double to spark a fourrun rally in the eighth inning for the Giants' ninth straight victory, an 8-4 triumph over the Pittsburgh Pirates today.

WASHINGTON, May 3 Astronauts of the United States and the Soviet Union shared a platform today to tell an international gathering of scientists their experiences in orbiting in space. Out of the meeting of Lieut. Col. John H. Glenn Jr. and Maj. Gherman S. Titov came some new details about the twenty-fivehour flight of the Soviet Air Force major last Aug. 6.

DURHAM, N.C., May 3 Announcement has been made by Mrs. Thomas Walker Page 3d of the engagement of her daughter, Miss Celeste Page of New York, to Robert Foster Loughridge Jr. He is the son of Mr. Loughridge of Fort Worth, Tex., and the late Mrs. Elizabeth Hamlett Loughridge.

WASHINGTON, May 3 The Securities Exchange Commission disclosed today the names of the men and organizations invited to testify at the first public hearings of the Government's broad investigation of the stock markets.

WASHINGTON, May 3 President Kennedy displayed a sympathetic attitude today in talks with Chancellor Alfons Gorbach toward Austria's desire for association with the European Economic Community or Common Market.

The September world sugar futures contract fell 6 points (hundredths of a cent a pound) in the final twenty minutes of trading on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. The other positions closed unchanged to up 1 point to off 5 points on a total volume of 13,950 tons. The October contract fell 5 points on 8,700 tons.
The Sheraton-East was the setting yesterday for a tea dance, one of a series of events marking the seventieth anniversary of the Society of Colonial Wars in the State of New York.
What dealers described as a "good tone" prevailed in most parts of the high-grade bond market yesterday. But price fluctuations were narrow and the business was light.
RIO DE JANEIRO, May 3 A large and diversified Soviet exposition of industry, science and culture opened here today.

RAJSHAHI, Pakistan, May 3 Accounts of horror and death related by Moslem refugees here today indicated that recent communal disturbances in the adjacent Indian state of West Bengal amounted to a religious massacre.

Higher copper prices enabled the Phelps Dodge Corporation to raise its consolidated net income for the first quarter of this year to $10,833,000 from $9,128,000 for the 1961 period, Robert G. Page, president, reported yesterday.
KANSAS CITY, May 3 (UPI) A rookie relief pitcher, Diego Segui, stopped the Detroit Tigers today and picked up his second major league victory when the Kansas City Athletics rallied for a 6-4 triumph.
ATHENS, May 3 The United States won the support of its chief allies tonight in pursuing a more positive line on negotiations with the Soviet Union over Berlin.
PHILADELPHIA, May 3 The wildcat strike of Philadelphia's 2,800 longshoremen which has made fifteen freight ers idle since noon yesterday will end tomorrow.

The proposal made in testimony at Washington by Dr. James E. Allen Jr., New York State Commissioner of Education, for the establishment of a national committee of education deserves immediate attention. Important observers of the educational scene, including presidentelect John H. Fischer of Teachers College, Columbia University, have long been pointing to the need for such an advisory body at the Federal level.

Poise never seems to desert Bill Stafford of the Yankees, whether he is pitching against dangerous American League batsmen or lying flat on his stomach. He was discovered in the latter position at the Stadium yesterday, baking pulled muscles in his back and left hip.
WESTBURY, L.I., May 3 Duke Rodney, the rugged, rangy son of the famour sire Rodney, will go after his richest prize of the 1962 season at Roosevelt Raceway tomorrow night.

GENEVA, May 5--The Soviet Union is pressing for a two-month recess in the disarmament conference, starting early in June. It would also like to have the talks resume in New York instead of Geneva.

CHICAGO, May 6 (AP) The grain futures market withstood some profit-selling in late sessions last week and still finished with moderate gains in most commodities on the Board of Trade.

Canadian dollar firm in the early part of the week turned erratic on hectic dealings on Thursday following the announcement establishing a fixed rate for the dollar at 92.50 cents. British pound sterling improved on active trading.
MOSCOW, Monday, May 7 John Ogdon, 25-year-old English pianist, and Vladimir Ashkenazi of the Soviet Union shared first-prize honors early today in the International Tchaikovsky competition.

The House should write a stronger charter for wilderness preservation than the bill passed last year by the Senate. TRENTON, May 6 (AP) A bill is expected to be introduced in the New Jersey Legislature tomorrow to forbid doctors to refuse to treat patients under a proposed Federal medical care plan for the aged.

Bamberger's New Jersey has announced the appointment of Justin Bijur as a vice president. He is manager of the store's branch in Paramus, N.J.

A Florida editor has accused the Defense Department of "censorship by intimidation" through its investigation of Overseas Weekly, a privately published newspaper circulated mainly among United States servicemen overseas.
LOS ANGELES, May 6 (UPI) The Los Angeles Angels unleashed a nineteen-hit attack led by Lee Thomas today to score a 15-7 victory over the Baltimore Orioles. Thomas made five hits in six times at bat.

ROME, May 6 Martin de Porres, the illegitimate son of a sixteenth-century Spanish knight and a freed Negro slave girl, was proclaimed a saint today by Pope John XXIII in solemn rites in St. Peter's Basilica.
