KNOW what they found on the way to the forum? Burlesque, vaudeville and a cornucopia of mad, comic hokum.
LOS ANGELES, May 8-- Richard M. Nixon and his family put their new $150,000 hilltop home on display last night.
CAMDEN, N.J., May 8 (AP) --Ed'a Scholar and Mt. Hood combined for a $1,279 daily double at Garden State race track today. Ed's Scholar won the six-furlong first race and returned $95 for $2.
Archbishop Molloy took the lead yesterday in the tenth annual Mount St. Michael track and field meet at Downing Stadium, Randalls, Island.
A determined campaign to save Greenwich Village pushcarts made major progress yesterday when it won the complete support of Manhattan Borough President Edward R. Dudley.

One of the busiest visitors from Hollywood on the local scene is Robert Arthur. Having completed two new major films for Universal, "The Spiral Road" with Rock Hudson and Burl Ives and "That Touch of Mink," co-starring Cary Grant and Doris Day, the producer is readying two additional properties for the West Coast cameras.
The Transit Authority yesterday cleared up a long-standing mystery to subway riders: why apparently good electric bulbs are discarded and replaced in subway stations. The answer was "economy."
NAIROBI, Kenya, May 8 (UPI)--The Assistant Secretary of State for African Affairs, G. Mermen Williams, invited the former Mau Mau terrorist leader Jomo Kenyatta today to visit the United States.
LONDON, May 8--Home Secretary R.A. Butler forecast today a new effort by the British Government to reconstitute the Federation of Rhodesia and Nyasaland.
Sixty Bronx families found out yesterday that not only could they fight City Hall, but they coutd give it advice--and maybe have it followed.

WASHINGTON, May 8 (AP) The Hughes Tool Company (Toolco) received conditional approval today to acquire control of Northeast Airlines, Inc. The decision, following more than a year of negotiation, was made by Merritt Ruhlen, a Civil Aeronautics Board examiner. Under new C.A.B. rules, this decision becomes a final order automatically unless the full board or one of the parties involved asks for a review within thirty days.
The Washington Suburban Sanitary District, Md., borrowed $15,000,000 in the bond market yesterday at an interest cost of 3.018 per cent.
Assemblyman Bentley Kassal, the reform Democrat named to oppose Representative Leonard Farbstein in the primary, was rebuffed yesterday in his demand for an immediate start on a round of debates.

SAIGON, Vietnam, May 8-- The United States is pressing South Vietnam for early action on a comprehensive pacification plan for the Mekong River delta. Called Operation Delta, the plan would involve the relocation of thousands of families now living in areas dominated by Communist guerrillas. The main objective is to deny the Communists the support of the rural population in the richest region of South Vietnam.
LISBON, Portugal, Wednesday, May 9--Demonstrators attacked steal-helmeted policemen in downtown Lisbon last night, but were swiftly dispersed by tear-gas grenades and warning shots.
LONDON, May 8--Prime Minister Macmillan defended today the United States' projected high-altitude nuclear test on the basis of its "great importance" to the defense of the West.
Members of the Louis Mendelssohn family of Detroit, large holders of General Motors Corporation stock, yesterday

SEATTLE, Wash., May 8--A Swedish savings banker told United States savings bankers here today that rising competition from commercial banks should spur them to seek a wider range of banking services as a base for growth.

Unethical, fraudulent and criminal activitiees in stock market translations are discussed in "Wall Street's Shady Side," which Public Affairs Press of Washington will issue June 4. The author is Frank J. Cormier, a financial reporter for The Associated Press since 1957. His book will have an introduction by Ferdinand Pecora, former counsel of the Senate investigations that led to Federal controls under the Securities and Exchange Commission.
SEATTLE, Wash., May 8-- A new indirect bid to the Soviet Union to join the United States in space exploration was made today by President Kennedy.
ATLANTIC CITY, May 8-- President Kennedy called on labor today to exercise restraint and responsibility in its bargaining demands.

BERLIN, May 8--The Western Allies have agreed on a basic change in the tactics to be pursued for a Berlin agreement with the Soviet Union, qualified non-German sources said today. As a result, the United States package proposal for a settlement will not be presented when Secretary of State Dean Rusk and Anatoly F. Dobrynin, the Soviet Ambassador in Washington, resume their talks, possibly next week.

THE consensus among salt water fishermen and tackle shop operators is that the best season in a long time may be at hand. Their optimism is based on the currently excellent fishing conditions along the bays and in the surf of Long Island. A check around the island failed to turn up a single gloomy note.
Heavy activity in potato and cocoa futures were the highlights of trading on the commodity markets here yesterday.

TIJUANA, Mexico, May 8 (UPI)--Archie Moore last night stopped Howard King in 1:15 of the first round of their nontitle bout. Weighing 199 pounds, Moore knocked out King with a right to the jaw after setting up the knockout with a left hook to cut short a scheduled ten-rounder. King weighed 200.

The Rent and Rehabilitation Administration announced yesterday that it had hired as its relocation expert a man who had been dismissed by Mayor Wagner in January from a similar post in the Department of Real Estate.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., May 8 --Former President Harry S. Truman, jovial and talkative, observed his seventy-eighth birthday anniversary here today.
WASHINGTON, May 8--The Justice Department asked the courts today to outlaw racial segregation in hospitals built with Federal aid.
WESTBURY, L.I., May 8-- Lehigh Hanover, one of the favorites for the $169,430 Messenger Stakes on May 18, escaped serious injury this morning at Roosevelt Raceway after falling during a workout.
WASHINGTON, May 8--The Army said today it was considering recommending an increase in the six-month active duty training period for reservists.

The program of the New York City Ballet last night at the City Center was an all-Stravinsky one, which, though especially fitting at this time as part of the composer's current birthday celebrations, is a regular seasonal practice of this particularly Stravinskian company
A major survey of college curriculums has concluded that isolationism remains a stronger force in American education than in United States foreign policy.
Four scientists of the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center received the first Alfred P. Sloan Awards in Cancer Research yesterday.
WASHINGTON, May 8--A major threat to the Administration's trade expansion program arose today as the House Ways and Means Committee began voting on the enabling bill.
A $20,000,000 issue of Wisconsin Telephone Company debentures was oftered yesterday at a price to yield 4.27 per cent, and was oversubscribed.

THERE is more to bringing home the bacon than simply going to market and buying it. The shopper must know which brand has the flavor and the proportion of lean to fat that she wants. Her task is not easy, for few foods vary as widely in cost and quality as bacon.
TORONTO, May 8--A swatch test that may predict marital adjustment was reported here today to the American Psychiatric Association.
GROTON, Conn., May 8-- The world's largest submarine, the U.S.S. Lafayette, slipped smoothly into the Thames River here today, christened in both French and...
ALGIERS, May 8--Two thousand auxiliary policemen recruited among members of the Algerian National Liberation Army will soon join the fight against the European terrorists in Algiers and Oran.
WASHINGTON, May 8--The $23,000,000,000 mutual fund industry came under close scrutiny today as the Securities and Exchange Commission continued public hearings into the securities market.
GENEVA, May 8--The United States said today that it expected to remain committed to aid any of its allies against attack "until general and complete disarmament is achieved in a peaceful world."

The Rev. Dr. Stuart Hamilton Merriam declared yesterday that his removal as minister of the Broadway Presbyterian Church might have serious consequences for the Presbyterian Church in the United States. He denounced particularly the methods used by the New York Presbytery in ousting him.

ROME, May 8 (AP)--Jon Douglas of Santa Monica, Calif., a member of the United States Davis Cup squad made his debut in the Rome tennis tournament today by defeating Cliff Drysdale of South Africa in a four-hour match.
President Kennedy predicted yesterday that Congress would approve his program for medical care for the aged before the end of the year.

GUYS with salaries of $128 a month don't ordinarily purchase complete boxes in millionaires' row at the Ken tucky Derby. But Paul Hornung is no ordinary guy. Although the Army pays him a painfully modest salary, the handsome blond has a more profitable sideline. He plays halfback for the Green Bay Packers in his spare time.

WASHINGTON, May 8--The Port of New York Authority urged today that $2,967,400 be appropriated for seven New York Harbor channel projects. The proposal was made in testimony to the House Appropriations subcommittee on public works.

Many persons have already reserved tables for the "Salute to Summer" party, to be held in the Ballroom of the Pierre on Monday under the sponsorship of the Society of Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center.
Representative Hugh J. Addonizio was elected Mayor of Newark yesterday, defeating Mayor Leo P. Carlin by a margin of nearly 2 to 1. The vote was 62,338 to 38,155.

The twenty-first American Assembly brought together seventy citizens, many of them distinguished and of differing political and economic views, to consider the challenge and the promise of automation and technological change. Inevitably their opinions often varied sharply, but there was one point on which all found an enthusiastic rallying point: Education is both the root of technological change and the basis for successful adaptation to the problems it presents.
DALLAS, May 8--Architects were told today that their traditional functions were being chipped at by urban planners, Government agencies, entrepreneurs and engineers.
WASHINGTON, May 8 --Civil rights forces in the Senate suffered a damaging blow today when they lost the vote of Senator John Sherman Cooper, Republic of Kentucky.
PARIS, May 7--Although this city's role as the fashion capital of the world is quite secure, two other European countries have been challenging each other to win the runnerup title.
LOS ANGELES, May 8--The increasing power of nationwide mass communications is obviously working to the political advantage of the Kennedys.

ALBANY, May 8--The Department of Social Welfare reported today that 5.5 per cent of the relief applicants in New York City in the last half of 1961 were suspected of having entered the state primarily to obtain public aid.
A study made for the Board of Education has recommended that the city school system spend $75,000,000 over the next five years to meet the current backlog of school repair needs.
The engagement of Miss Jane Trowbridge Gillespie to Henry Marshall Schwarz has been announced.

Dr. Charles E. Walker, executive vice president of the American Bankers Association, praised yesterday the efforts of the Kennedy Administration to spur business investment in plant and equipment through changes in the tax laws.
Fringe ballplayers tiptoe past the general manager's office these days. The reason is the imminence of the cutdown day.
CHICAGO, May 8--The New York Mets climbed out of the National League coal bin for the first time today on the fourhit pitching of Jay Hook and the incompetence of the Chicago Cub outfield.

The Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company raised first-quarter sales and earnings 15 per cent above the 1961 level, setting records for the period, H.P. Buetow, president, told shareholders at the annual meeting in St. Paul, Minn., yesterday.
The American Maritime Association renewed its pressure on the Federal Government yesterday for a quota system that would reserve certain oil cargoes for American-flag tankers.

WASHINGTON, May 8 (AP) --The Department of Agriculture's final estimates today put the 1961 cotton crop at 14,318,000 bales of 500 pounds gross weight each and cottonseed production at 5,978,000 tons.

The United States has gained new ascendancy in free world leadership by its vast nuclear power, first fully disclosed at the NATO meeting in Athens, and by its new efforts at accommodation on Berlin. But the comparative harmony of the Athens meeting on immediate procedures and ultimate goals is being followed by reemergence of basic interallied differences due to individual national interests and varying estimates of Soviet purposes.

The Police Department blocked off Fifty-sixth Street between Seventh Avenue and the Avenue of the Americas yesterday, so that about 3,200 students could hear the New York Philharmonic at Carnegie Hall.

Thirty-three young American singers have been granted Ford Foundation awards to help them in their operatic careers. Each singer will receive $2,500, to be used for coaching, learning new roles, or other purposes that will lead to contracts with opera companies in this country.

Finding time on his hands, what with rain washing out the game against the Boston Red Sox at the Stadium, Manager Ralph Houk last night busied himself paring his Yankee roster to twenty-five players. This is the limit that goes into effect at midnight tonight.
THE day of the instant wardrobe is virtually here, thanks to Manhattan stores that have built up imaginative, well-staffed and quick-acting shopping services.
"The Play of the Week," which once gained a new lease on life because of a campaign on the part of its comparatively small but devoted audience, will return to New York next month.
August Heckscher, President Kennedy's cultural consultant, conferred for the first time yesterday with a group of leaders of the Dramatists Guild at a private luncheon at the St Regis Hotel.
HOUSTON, May 8 (UPI)-- The Los Angeles Dodgers pounded five shaky Houston pitchers for fitten hits tonight but took ten innings to gain a 9-6 victory over the Colt .45s.
Piping Rock Club took the lead in the Long Island division of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association's interclub team matches yesterday.
PRETORIA, South Africa, May 8--South Africa may suggest the partitioning of SouthWest Africa as a possible solution to the long dispute over the mandated territory.

ST. LOUIS, May 8 (AP)-- The San Francisco Giants broke Larry Jackson's jinx at eight games tonight by beating the St. Louis Cardinals, 4--3. The victory enabled the Giants to stretch their lead over the second-place Cardinals to four games.
BLOOMINGTON, Minn., May 8 (AP)--Dick Donovan of Cleveland, a right-handed pitcher, racked up his fifth victory without a loss tonight as the Indians beat the Minnesota Twins, 6--3.
MOSCOW, May 8--The United States and Britain called on the Soviet Union today to restrain the pro-Communist forces in Laos from violating the cease-fire in the divided kingdom.
CAMDEN, N.J., May 8-- Frank T. Lloyd Jr., who was a judge of the New Jersey Superior Court from 1948 to 1956, died yesterday at Cooper Hospital. He was 66 years old.
COLUMBUS, Ohio--May 8 (AP)--Senator Frank J. Lausche won Democratic renomination easily tonight as Gov. Michael V. DiSalle built a growing lead for renomination over Attorney General Mark McElroy.

NEW ORLEANS, May 8--A Federal court deferred a decision today on whether New Orleans public schools must be desegregated through the sixth grade this fall. A temporary stay deferring an order to desegregate was continued.
A demand that New York State's minimum drinking age be raised from 18 to 21 years was made yesterday by the 182d convention of the New York Episcopal Diocese.

MOSCOW, May 8--The Soviet Minister of Railways said today that the nation's rail lines were a highly profitable branch of the national economy that was steadily increasing its contributions to the Government's budget.
THE audience was not too large, but it was very distinguished, and it turned out last night in Carnegie Hall primarily to hear Virgil Thomson's "Missa Pro Defunctis."
Following is the speech yesterday by President Kennedy at the United Auto Workers convention in Atlantic City, as furnished by radio station WABC here and recorded by The New York Times:
Mayor Wagner lectured yesterday on the "obligations" of citizens' groups. He said they "must refrain from inaccurate criticism for the sake of selfsatisfaction or for headlines."
ATLANTIC CITY, May 8-- The United Automobile Workers called today for a vigorous political action drive to bring the election of Congressmen who would support President Kennedy's programs.

The Ferrari Berlinetta in which Phil Hill of Santa Monica, Calif., the world champion, and Olivier Gendebien of Belgium won the Grand Touring class and placed second over all in the Sebring (Fla.) twelvehour race in March, has been purchased by Bob Grossman of Nyack, N.Y., for the Le Mans...

Like Shakespeare's Octavius, President Romulo Betancourt of Venezuela is "bayed about with many enemies." No Latin-American leader has had such a fierce, unrelenting, desperate struggle to stay in office.

INWOOD, L.I., May 8--The St. John's team won the Metropolitan Golf Association's intercollegiate championship today with a score of 326. One of its members, Len Santoro, captured the individual title.
Coach Bill Bowerman will send Oregon's crack distancerunners after the world record in the four-mile relay at the Fresno Relays in Fresno, Calif., on Saturday.

ALBANY, May 8--A proposal to merge the New York Central and the Pennsylvania railroads into the world's largest transportation company was approved here today by stockholders of the New York Central Railroad.

The annual meeting of the Warner-Lambert Pharmaceutical Company was thrown into a minor uproar yesterday as stockholders scrambled to obtain a special dividend--a gift assortment of such company products as Listerine, Bromo Seltzer and an 89-cent toothbrush.
Reflecting record revenues, first-quarter net income of the United Carbon Company and subsidiaries increased 25 per cent to $2,061,560 from $1,645,744 in the corresponding three months last year.
ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L.I., May 8--Mother M. Rose Gertrude, a founder aad academic dean of Molloy Catholic College for Women here, died today at Mercy Hospital after a short illness. Her age was 70.

ALVIN ROTH, who has as many bridge brilliancies to his credit as any other player, proffered today's deal in the course of a late-hour bull session at the Cavendish Club. He had it neatly written out on the back of a sheet from a score pad.
PHILADELPHIA, May 8-- The 112,968 shareholders of the Pennsylvania Railroad voted overwhelmingly today in favor of a merger with the New York Central Railroad.
WARSAW, May 8--Emil Zatopek, Czechoslovakia's retired marathon champion, holds that amateurism in major sports is "a comedy" that should be abollished.
CARACAS, Venezuela, May 8 --The week-end uprising by a marine battalion in the east coast town of Carupano illustrates the strengths and weaknesses of the Government of President Romulo Betancourt.

Two brownstone houses at 119 and 121 East Ninety-first Street have been sold by the estate of Fanny G. Ely. The house at No. 119, which has a roof garden, was bought by Robert A. Bicks, the tenant. The other house, which has a top-floor studio, was acquired by Sheldon A. Vogel. The sales were arranged by Horace S. Ely Co. and Talman, Bigelow, Whittemore, Ltd., co-brokers.
After a week-long journey of 11,263 miles, two pacers from Down Under arrived early last might at Yonkers Raceway, where they are scheduled to compete in three events worth a total of $190,000.
WASHINGTON, May 8-- President Kennedy asked Congress today for stand-by authority to make temporary cuts in income taxes to combat future recessions.

Nobody well acquainted with the United Nations would maintain that it is perfectly organized or perfectly administered. The late Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold must often have felt himself harassed beyond endurance. The present Acting Secretary, U Thant, needs his oriental philosophy.
CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., May 8 (AP)--A Centaur space rocket exploded today at nearly 30,000 feet in its first test flight.
WASHINGTON, May 8 (AP)--James J.P. McShane, a product of New York's Police Department, was named the chief today of 600 United States marshals and deputies.

The reputation of Charlie Chaplin, the "Little Tramp," as one of the world's truly great comic actors was so firmly established decades ago that no degree of controversy over Charles Spencer Chaplin, the man, has ever tarnished it. And there certainly has been controversy.
Botticelli's painting "Primavera" was the inspiration for the spring d cor in the Sert Room of the Waldorf-Astoria last night for the Botticelli Ball, a benefit for Orphans of Italy, Inc.

WASHINGTON, May 8--The Federal Government has on hand a twenty-five-year supply of quartz crystals and it once had a stockpile objective equal to fifty-six years' consumption at present rates. Quartz is used in electronic communications equipment.
ALBANY, May 8--Republican legislative leaders expressed accord today with Governor Rockefeller's prediction that there would be no need to raise state taxes in the next four years.
LONDON, May 8--Stirling Moss, Britain's top racing driver who was injured two weeks ago, many never fully recover the functions of his left arm and leg, physicians reported today.

WASHINGTON, May 8 --The United States said today it intended to continue the "exploratory talks" with the Soviet Union on the problems of Germany and Berlin, despite mounting objections from West Germany.

PARIS, May 8--Next month's meeting between Prime Minister Macmillan and President de Gaulle may prove of massive importance. Their two-day conversation could decide Europe's future political shape if either a decision is taken to grant French support for British admission to the Common Market...
WASHINGTON, May 8--The Soviet Union has refused to allow the United States to display Lieut. Col. John H. Glenn Jr's space capsule at a medical exhibition in Leningrad next month.

WASHINGTON, May 8--Senator Jacob K. Javits has managed to involve himself through the vagaries of polities in a letter-writing campaign in support of the man who may be his Democratic opponent in next fall's election.

PHILADELPHIA, May 9 (UPI) Harold Johnson, the National Boxing Association light-heavyweight champion, today threatened to withdraw from his scheduled defense against Doug Jones of New York here Saturday night if his purse is held back by court order.
BERLIN, May 9--More than 1,000 Soviet soldiers and ranking officials crossed into West Berlin today for a wreath-laying ceremony at the Soviet war memorial in the Tiergarten.

Plans for a performing arts center to add to the summer attractions of Saratoga Springs, N.Y., were announced yesterday. The center, to be financed by the state and by public contributions, would be incorporated into the expansion program now under way on the 1,200-acre Saratoga Springs Reservation.
MADRID, May 8 Strikes and political unrest in Spain and Portugal have raised the question whether the dictatorial regimes in either country will introduce vital reforms before rising pressures erupt.
WITH the passing of the Stuyvesant Chess Club on Fourteenth Street a short time ago the last chapter of an era in American chess closed.
A FASHION-CONSCIOUS New York woman recently remarked: "American women are lucky to be living in the time of Jackie Kennedy and Sydney Gittler."
The Georgia State Building Authority borrowed $26,600,000 in the bond market yesterday on lease revenue bonds to financ the constructioon of school buildings.
A former convict was arrested yesterday by the Federal Bureau of Investigation in a $112,800 swindle of Miss Elisabeth Achelis, former president of the World Calendar Association.

World sugar futures gained strength in active trading yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. Prices were unchanged to up 9 points (hundredths of a cent a pound) on a volume of 9,350 tons.
WASHINGTON, May 9--President Kennedy said today that Vice President Johnson would be on the Democratic ticket again in 1964 "if he chooses to run."
TEL AVIV, Israel, May 9 Israel showed part of her military strength in a parade here today to mark the fourteenth anniversary of her existence as an independent state.
The president of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation urged United States investors yesterday "not to retire from Latin America or other foreign areas in...

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 9 Classification of movies, a form of censorship that is strongly opposed by the American movie industry, was extolled today by Lord Morrison of Lambeth, president of the British Board of Film Censors.

FLEMINGTON, N.J., May 9 Republic Steel Corporation "still needs a price increase" and must be able to adjust prices "as soon as competitive factors permit," T.F. Patton, president, told shareholders of the nation's third largest steel producer behind United States Steel Corporation and the Bethlehem Steel Corporation at the annual meeting here today.

WASHINGTON, May 9 President Kennedy said today that a rejection of his proposal for withholding taxes on dividends and interest would be a victory for tax-evaders. In a strongly worded statement at his news conference, the accused savings and loan associations of "misinforming many millions of people" in a campaign against the proposal. [Opening statement, page 20.]

The United Arab Republic has leased space in 655 Madison Avenue at Sixtieth Street for the office of its Consul General. John Samuelson of Pease Elliman, Inc., was the broker. The lessee will retain the building at 900 Park Avenue, which houses its permanent delegation to the United Nations.

BERLIN, May 9 Chancellor Adenauer voiced his opposition to full membership for Britain in the European Economic Community better known as the Common Market during private talks, with political associates in Berlin this week.
LONDON, May 9 The suggestion that an international authority supervise access to West Berlin has already been made to the Soviet Union, qualified sources said today.
CHICAGO, May 9 Mary Throneberry, a first baseman, was purchased today by the New York Mets from the Baltimore Orioles.
Leaders of the New York women's coat and suit industry had some resounding words of cheer yesterday for its members and for the retailers selling their garments.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., May 9 Leonard W. Hall of Oyster Bay, former Republican National Chairman and former party leader in the Town of Oyster Bay, re-emerged as a political force in Nassau County today when he blocked the party's choice for County Court judge.

HARTSDALE, N.Y., May 9 Vice Admiral Edmund W. Burrough, U.S.N., retired, who had been deputy commander of the Eastern Sea Frontier, died of a heart attack yesterday while riding at North Pelham in a car driven by his wife. He was 71 years old and lived here at 31 Rockledge Road.

Felix Houphouet-Boigny, President of the Ivory Coast and a strong African supporter of the West, arrived in New York yesterday for a state visit that will include a threeday stay in Washington at the invitation of President Kennedy.

WASHINGTON, May 9 (AP) An Artzona sheriff said today that the best way to deal with the narcotics problem on the Mexican border would be destruction of the poppy fields in the States of Sinaloa, Durango, Chihuahua and Sonora.
Two former "whiz kids" of the Big Board soon will be directing the American Stock Exchange.

MELBOURNE, Australia, May 9 Australia announced today, that she was prepared to give token Military and civilian aid to embattled South Vietnam. The announcement followed an appeal by Secretary of State Dearn Rusk for a "helping hand" in Vietnam from other nations of the non-Communist world.
Part of Fifth Avenue became a nostalgic extension of Broadway for a few hours last night as the city marked its Salute to Spring amid the strains of "Porgy and Bess" and other George Gershwin tunes.
LOS ANGELES, May 9 (UPI) Plans for the forthcoming West Coast operations of The New York Times were outlined today by Andrew Fisher, assistant general manager of The Times.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 9 Death sentences for 313 persons for an attempt to overthrow the Lebanese Government last New Year's Eve were asked today in an indictment presented to a military tribunal here.
Park West Village, an apartment development on Central Park West, dramatized its welcome to tenants with dogs last week-end by holding a dog show in its playground.

EVERY year the Parents' League of New York spon sors a series of bridge lessons for the teen-age children of its members, with William Root as the instructor, and every year the culmination of the series is a parentand-child tournament, which serves much as did once the annual recital of the piano teacher's pupils.
Mayor Wagner has recommended a capital budget allocation of $1,000,000 to renovate Sea View Hospital on Staten Island as a nursing home for 800 patients.

The Senate took two votes yesterday on the Administration's bill that would require states using literacy tests for voters to accept a sixthgrade education as the equivalent of literacy. The first move was to decide, 53 to 43, not to close debate. This may enable opponents of the bill...
ATLANTIC CITY, May 9 A Negro was elected today to the International Executive Board of the United Automobile Workers for the first time.
SEATTLE, Wash., May 9 A warning against substituting glamour for science in guiding space policy was injected today into the second national conference on the peaceful uses of space.
Neuwirth Wagner
An aproach to the teaching of elementary school subjects that provides each child with his own desk-top "laboratory" was demonstrated here yesterday.
ALGIERS, May 9 The French security, forces in Algiers received substantial reinforcements today as part of a stepped-up campaign against the terrorists of the Secret Army Organization.

United States Government securities and other high-grade bonds extended price rises yesterday in a trading session of broadening kind in the Government's list and "moderately active" elsewhere in the market.

WASHINGTON, May 9 The national unemployment rate, adjusted against seasonal influences, continued unchanged in April, according to Labor Department figures issued today. It was the second consecutive month in which there had been virtually no improvement.
WASHINGTON, May 9 An international panel of scientists was established today to pre vent "potentially harmful" experiments from being conducted in space.
The election of Representative Hugh J. Addonizio as Mayor of Newark on Tuesday could cause a major split in Essex County's Democratic ranks.
AUSTIN, May 9 Texas will file an antitrust suit against Billie Sol Estes within a few days.
WASHINGTON, May 9 The Administration and civil rights forces supporting its literacy bill went down to humiliating defeat in the Senate today.

Lawyers for Alger Hiss have found an official statement that they regard as indicating that Government investigators "located" the typewriter that Attorney General Robert F. Kennedy has asserted the Federal Bureau of Investigation never "possessed."
WASHINGTON, May 9 Penalties totaling $554,162.71 were levied by the Department of Agriculture today against Billie Sol Estes for violating Federal cotton planting allotments in 1961.

LONDON, May 9 The Government disclosed today it had made "certain preliminary arrangements" for the maintenance of essential supplies and services if the nation-wide longshoremen's strike takes place as threatened at midnight Sunday.
TORONTO, May 9 A couple of pre-Mothers Day messages were delivered unintentionally today in scientific papers at the American Psychiatric Association.

Robert Moses, "reflecting a highway builder's view," asserted yesterday that "we are becoming hysterical and prodigal about aid to ailing commuter railroads and tend to exaggerate the advantages of mass transportation."
WEST ORANGE, N.J., May 9 John J. Turteltaub, a real estate man in New York and New Jersey, died yesterday after suffering a heart attack at his home, 23 Beaumont Terrace. He was 68 years old.
A kind of "What's My Line?" television program for policemen only was broadcast yesterday, with prisoners as the guests.

CHICAGO, May 8 Dr. F.J. L. Blasingame, the American Medical Association's executive vice president, demanded an investigation today of Abraham A. Ribicoff, Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, to determine if he had committed "a criminal act."
ROME, May 9 (UPI) Darlene Hard of Montebello, Calif., and Donna Floyd of Arlington, Va., America's first and tenth ranked players, advanced today to the third round of the Rome tennis tournament.
Reception Here Tomorrow

PHILADELPHIA, May 9 Dr. Karl William Henry Scholz, author and Emeritus Professor of Economics at the University of Pennsylvania, died today of a heart attack in his home at Rose Tree Road in Media. He was 75 years old.

A number of major advertising agencies in recent years have studied the possibility of selling stock to the public. Despite considerable debate and conjecture, however, no agency has taken any action.

SAIGON, Vietnam, May 9 The United States Secretary of Defense, Robert S. McNamara, said today that there was still no plan to send American combat forces to South Vietnam despite Communist gains in neighboring Laos.

The United States Gypsum Company, a leading building materials producer, expects sales and earnings in the second quarter to increase about 10 per cent over the similar period last year, C.H. Shaver, chairman, declared yesterday.
SEATTLE, May 9 Considerable eyebrow-raising among visitors to the Century 21 Exposition has been caused by a surprisingly "down-beat" motion picture that is a feature in the French display area.
Comdr. M. Scott Carpenter will perform experiments in space devised to help in developing rendezvous-in-orbit techniques, a Project Mercury official said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 9 The pro-Communist Pathet Lao movement was condemned today by President Kennedy for having broken the fragile peace in Laos. At the same time, the Royal Laotian Government was implicitly criticized by Mr. Kennedy for stalling in negotiations on a neutral government of national union.
RABAT, Morocco, May 9 King Hassan II will meet soon with President de Gaulle, highly placed Moroccan sources disclosed today.
Tennessee Ernie Ford, who runs a down-to-earth pea pickin' type of television show, will be seen on Monday playing host to Maj. Gherman S. Titov, the Soviet astronaut.

IF the word vintage pertained to vegetables as well as to wines, this year's celery crop might be hailed with such a label. The word from the Florida fields is that there has rarely been a larger harvest of sweeter stalks, so firm and fully packed.

WASHINGTON, May 9 President Kennedy denied today that he had made a sharply critical remark about "all" business men. He told his news conference that he had had some unkind thoughts about some leaders of Big Steel during the recent price controversy but added: "That is all past. Now we are working together, I hope."

WESTBURY, L.I., May 9--Another effort to stage a major free-for-all trot at Roosevelt Raceway failed this morning, when a $25,000 event scheduled for Saturday night did not fill. Only three top-flight trotters, Duke Rodney, Silver Song and Air Record, entered so John Cashman Jr., the racing secretary, canceled the race and substituted a $10,000 junior free-for-all.
Ship masters do not have to win popularity contests among their crews to keep their jobs, according to an industry arbitrator's decision made public yesterday.
PARIS, May 9 The French Government acknowledged today that the situation in Algiers and Oran, Algeria's two largest cities, was "serious and preoccupying."
An American, a Frenchman and a Hungarian have been selected as New York Philharmonic assistant conductors for next season. They are Yuri Krasnopolsky, Serge Fournier, and Zoltan Rozsnyai.

WALTHAM, Mass., May 9 In the Berlin Chapel of Brandeis University here this morning, Miss Ruth Schachter was married to Henry Morgenthau 3d. Rabbi Charles Weinberg, assisted by Rabbi Manfred Vogel and Cantor Abraham Feldman, performed the ceremony, which was followed by a small reception in Cambridge.

WASHINGTON, May 9 (AP)--The details of a not-very-successful nation-wide publicity campaign financed by a New York Stock Exchange brokerage house to promote mutual fund sales were told today at a Federal inquiry into securities selling.

SAN ANTONIO, May 9 (AP) A United States Naval Reserve officer, Robert Beck, of Philadelphia, won the international pentathlon competition today despite finishing thirteenth in the 4,000-meter crosscountry run.

The first two volumes of "The Papers of James Madison" will be issued May 22 under the joint sponsorship of the University of Chicago and the University of Virginia, Volume 1, covering the period from March 16, 1761, to Dec. 16, 1779, begins with...
Politicians have found another use for a commodity often considered impractical: art. The Lexington Democratic Club and the Village Independent Democrats have planned two fundraising art functions.

TRAVELERS to the Red Sox training base in Arizona returned with awed tales of the collection of oversized young pheenoms who are Boston's investment in the future. At long last, it seems, the Fenway Millionaires are on a program designed to restore them to the top.
MALVERNE, L.I., May 9--Malverne School District pupils are seeking a better understanding of children in foreign lands through an art exchange program with schools in six foreign countries.
WASHINGTON, May 9 The Peace Corps plans to branch out into educational television in under-developed countries in Asia, Africa, and Latin America.

WASHINGTON, May 9 The Agency for International Development said today that it would continue to provide Food-forPeace supplies to needy Chinese families on Taiwan despite the withdrawal of Church World Service from the program.
Stocks fell sharply yesterday. In a kind of snowballing movement centered on the standard investment quality issues, every major group on the New York Stock Exchange rolled downhill.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, May 4 To combat a growing wave of hooliganism in cities, the Yugoslavs are reviving an old law permitting courts to exile persistent offenders to the countryside.

TUNIS, May 9 The Algerian nationalist Premier called on the people of his country tonight to observe scrupulously the cease-fire and self-determination agreements signed with the French Government at Evian-les-Bains March 18.
The first of six large steel tanks originally filled with 400 tons sulphuric acid was hoisted to the surface of Red Hook Flats Anchorage off Brooklyn yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 9 An Army spokesman confirmed before a House Armed Services subcommittee today that there had been many instances of wrong assignments and poor utilization of reservists in the Berlin crisis mobilization last year.
Football buffs of various sizes, shapes and loyalties turned out yesterday for the Ivy League's version of spring practice in the grand ballroom of the Hotel Biltmore.

A decline of 1,988,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks in the week ended last Friday was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end, supplies were 197,867,000 barrels, compared with 199,855,000 a week earlier and 262,160,000 a year ago.
IF one has to shout to be heard when a high fidelity system is playing, there is something wrong not with one's senses, but with the sound set-up.
THE time: April 25, 1962. The place: The Church of Christ in Pecos, Tex. Indicted financier Billie Sol Estes was confessing.

MOSCOW, May 9 Reports of a rift between President Kennedy and Chancellor Adenauer have raised doubts here about the authority of the United States to negotiate on behalf of the Western alliance.

WASHINGTON, May 9 (UPI) The Justice Department said today "initial review of the contents of the booklet suggested that the provisions of Section 1913 of Title 18 of the United States Code have not been violated."

NEW DELHI, India, May 9--The United States was understood today to have protested to the Indian Government over its reported intention to buy two squadrons of the latest type of MIG jet fighters from the Soviet Union.

Word is expected from Robert Ryan, Hollywood star, on whether his film commitments will permit him to depict the title role in "Mr. President." The central character in the Irving Berlin-Howard LindsayRussel Crouse musical is a President of the United States at the end of his second term and after his return to private life.

When the basic five-hour day in the electrical construction industry begins in July 1, employers will have to hire 1,700 extra workers for the summer and 1,280 after that, Theodore W. Kheel estimated yesterday.
Just before his Red Sox took the field yesterday, Manager Mike Higgins said: "Stopping these Yankees is tough. There's no telling when somebody in the line-up busts loose and lets you have it."
An issue of 400,000 common shares of the American Hospital Supply Corporation was placed on the market yesterday and oversubscribed at the initial price of $24.75.

MAX POLLIKOFF brought his "Music in Our Time" to a close last night at the Young Men's and Young Women's Hebrew Association with an interesting and wellplanned program of new and not-so-new contemporary music.

Carlton Fredericks, a radio commentator who discusses questions of nutrition, told a Carnegie Hall lecture audience of 1,200 last night that Federal regulatory agencies were trying to force him off the air by the "dangerous device of publicity."
Following is the transcript of President Kennedy's news conference yesterday in Washington, as recorded by The New York Times:

Orders for non-electrical machinery have shown unexpected strength, according to McGrawHill Publishing Company's lat est survey, It shows that the machinery makers expect as 11 per cent increase in orders this year over 1961.
E. Barry Ryan's 3-year-old Princequillo filly, Firm Policy, made her first start of the year an impressive one at Aqueduct yesterday.
Record first-quarter sales and earnings for Columbia Broadcasting System, Inc. were announced yesterday by William S. Paley, chairman, and Frank Stanton, president.
RIO DE JANEIRO, May 9 (AP) A Brazilian airliner with twenty-seven persons aboard crashed and exploded while making a landing approach at Vitoria tonight.
CAMDEN, N.J., May 9 (AP) It was worth $1,279, minus taxes, to Mrs. Irene De Carlo of Collingswood to prove she was Mrs. Irene De Carlo of Collingswood. She couldn't do it.
Erasmus Hall High School in Brooklyn, the second oldest high school in the country, is observing its 175th anniversary this week.
Lawyers for the ousted leaders of the Broadway Presbyterian Church drafted a complaint yesterday to the New York Synod, the state-wide Presbyterian body.
CHICAGO, May 9 The State Department and its management of United States foreign policy were defended tonight by Under Secretary of State George W. Ball.
LONDON, May 8 Nearly every important section of the Stock market declined today despite a late demand that raised prices above the day's lows.
The fourteenth anniversary of Israel's establishment as a nation was observed here yesterday with colorful ceremonies.

Representatives of a dozen civic groups are drawing up amendments to the new City Charter in an effort to remove the Board of Estimate from the budget-making process. They would also restore powers that had been taken away from the City Planning Commission, among other things.

WASHINGTON, May 9 (UPI) The Army has denied that two United States soldiers recently released by Communist guerrillas in South Vietnam made statements that they had been "duped" by United States officials.
WASHINGTON, May 9 Secretary of Labor Arthur J. Goldberg approved today the hundredth job retraining program for unemployed workers in depressed areas.

THE IRISH the Ireland Irish, that is have re cently been making a large public relations to-do about the grand and glorious fishing to be had there. This is, of course, something of a mystery, since people who have good fishing and the Irish do have it, what with salmon and sea-run trout often keep it to themselves.

WINSTON-SALEM, N.C., May 9 Mrs. Anne Reynolds Tate and Dr. Harry Francis Forsyth Jr. were married here this afternoon. The Rev. Dr. Richard O. Flinn of the Presbyterian Church of Carrollton, Ga., performed the ceremony at the home of Dr. and Mrs. Coy Cornelius Carpenter, friends of the couple.
WASHINGTON, May 9 The Government cannot go from city to city and settle all labor disputes, President Kennedy reiterated today.
The Fifth Avenue Coach Lines made a new court protest yesterday against the city's seizure of its buses and routes.
WASHINGTON, May 9 President Kennedy chided the West Germans today for quarreling publicly about the Allied negotiating position on the Berlin issue.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, May 9 Prof. Albert S. Geyser said today that his conviction on a charge of heresy by the Dutch Reform Church would not make him leave South Africa.
WASHINGTON, May 9 (AP) Incumbents won the day in yesterday's primaries in five states, just as they had in earlier nominating contests in five other states.
To decorate one's home by oneself or to hire a pro fessional decorator. That is the question that arises once or more in a lifetime.

William H. McKeon, the new Democratic state chairman, asked county chairmen throughout the state yesterday to tell him whom the Democrats in their areas would like to see nominated for Governor and Senator.

WASHINGTON, May 9 With his speech yesterday to the convention of the United Auto Workers, President Kennedy completed the oral presentation of his professed policy to require of organized labor the same "responsibility for non-inflationary and peaceful settlements"...

PRINCETON, N.J., May 9 Former President Dwight D. Eisenhower, Secretary of State Dean Rusk and Arthur H. Dean, United States delegate to the Geneva disarmament conference, will speak here Tuesday at the dedication of the John Foster Dulles Library of Diplomatic History at Princeton University.

The structural steel frame for the fifty-nine-story Pan Am Building was topped out yesterday. The building's 2,400,000 square feet of office space will make it the world's largest commercial office building though not the tallest. It is rising just behind Grand Central Terminal.
WASHINGTON, May 9 (AP) Inflight telephone service for air travelers moved a step closer today.

The International Paper Company had a net income of $16,471,805, equal to 39 cents a common share, in the first three months of 1962, Richard C. Doane, chairman and chief executive officer, reported at the annual meeting here yesterday.
DALLAS, May 9 A Southern California architect waved his fist angrily and shouted:
GENEVA, May 9 The Soviet Union said today that it would never sign a treaty to ban nuclear testing unless France signed also.
Representatives of more than seventy nations found unity of purpose yesterday at the New York Coliseum.

William L. Slayton, Commissioner of the Federal Urban Renewal Administration, said yesterday that final approval for the city's long-delayed West Side urban renewal project would be granted next week.
FORT WORTH, May 10 (UPI) Arnold Palmer, despite trouble with his 8-iron, scored a three-under-par 32, 35 67 to take the lead today in the first round of the Colonial Invitation golf tournament.

Youth and experience were added to the New York Giants' stable of quarterbacks yesterday with the acquisition of Ralph Guglielmi from the St. Louis Cards. The 28-year-old Notre Dame alumnus had acquitted himself with distinction in four National Football League campaigns, three with the Washington Redskins.
LISBON, Portugal, Friday, May 11 (AP) The police in a dawn swoop today arrested an estimated 1,000 students and members of their families in a crackdown on university demonstrators.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 10 Walter P. Reuther said today there was sufficient "elbow room" in President Kennedy's price and wage policy to permit an adjustment of wage inequities in the air and space industries.
ALBANY, May 10 (AP) State authorities investigating possible tampering with examination grades for medical licensing have widened their inquiry to include about 150 physicians.
Mayor Wagner directed the Welfare Department yesterday to assume the responsibility for "Operation Bowery."

STUDENTS at Central Commercial High School wrote themselves a new slogan and then invited Macy's to interpret it for them. The students were agreed that "The Wise Centralite Dresses Right," but they wanted an exact definition of what is "right." Macy's was only too happy to oblige.

Seeing no reason why there could not be a happy blending of art and banking on Wall Street, a new art association composed of employes and officials of Wall Street firms has been formed. It will hold its first art exhibition in October, it was announced yesterday by Victor Roudin, its president.

The sixth annual United States World Trade Fair opens in the Coliseum today. If the past is a guide, this fair will prove another major spur to expansion of this city's and this nation's foreign trade.

Theodore Charnas, coordinafor of the Self-Regulating Program for Proprietary Nursing Homes, charged yesterday that the Department of Hospitals had refused to acknowledge the agency's "responsible" program.

WASHINGTON, May 10 The Air Force has submitted a new proposal to expand the program to develop and build 2,000-mile-an-hour, high-altitude RS-70 reconnaissance strike bombers. The proposal was prepared at the request of Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara, who promised Congress that he would restudy his earlier objections to expanding the present RS-70 super-bomber program.
GENEVA, May 10 The Soviet Union dropped toddy its campaign to have the disarmament conference recess for two months and reconvene in New York.

CHICAGO, May 10 Montgomery Ward Co. shareholders were greeted at their annual meeting today by reports of increases of 8.4 per cent in sales and 21 per cent in net earnings for the first quarter of this year.

WASHINGTON, May 10 President Kennedy sent a message to President Macapagal of the Philippines today, expressing the hope that he would not be dissuaded from visiting the United States by the defeat in the House of the Philippines war-claims bill.

The Federal Maritime Commission has been assigned the highly unpopular job "of acting as a referee" in an international tournament in which few holds are barred, Thomas E. Stakem, chairman of the Federal agency, said here yesterday.
MADRID, May 10 (UPI) About 1,500 Madrid University students massed on their campus today to demand concessions from the police and the release of schoolmates arrested in earlier demonstrations.

WASHINGTON, May 10 Premier Einar Gerhardsen of Norway expressed hope here today that the European Economic Community would admit his country along with Britain and Denmark and make special arrangements to help protect Norway's agriculture.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 10 (AP) Mrs. Frank D. Fiore of Longport, N.J., and Fred P. Meagher, a suburban Philadelphia contractor, were elected to the board of directors of the Atlantic City Racing Association today.

To add flavor and appeal to fish fillets that are to be broiled or baked, first brush them with an herb butter. Make it by blending together one cup (two sticks) butter, two teaspoons grated onion, one teaspoon each of lemon juice, crushed rosemary, crushed tarragon and chopped parsley.

WASHINGTON, May 10 The stinging setback inflicted yesterday on the Kennedy Administration's first civil rights bill reflected a series of miscalculations by the Administration, its Senate leaders and the supporting civil rights groups.
The emphasis was on youth yesterday during the International Soccer League's kick-off luncheon at Leone's. The league season gets under way a week from Sunday.
PARIS, May 10 King Has san II of Morocco unexpectedly arrived here early today on a private visit to discuss North African problems with President de Gaulle.

WASHINGTON, May 10 The House Science and Astronautics Committee gave unanimous endorsement to the President's accelerated space program today. It did so by approving most of the greatly expanded budget for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration.
The Agriculture Department has approved a plan whereby Lloyd's of London would insure the grain storage operations of the indicted financier, Billie Sol Estes, for $10,000,000.

WASHINGTON, May 10 A leading embryologist asserted tonight that stricter Government and industry controls were needed to prevent some of the new "wonder drugs" from causing congenital defects in unborn babies.
WASHINGTON, May 10 Freight carloadings last week were substantially higher than volumes recorded for the 1961 week, the railroad and trucking industries reported today.
An offering of $8,000,000 of Western Massachusetts Electric company first-mortgage bonds was marketed yesterday at a price to yield 4.23 per cent.
DALLAS, Texas, May 10 There are times when it may pay an architect not to get paid.

The chemicals of W.R. Grace Co. are adding vigor to its operations, J. Peter Grace Jr., president, told shareholders at the annual meeting in the Hotel Biltmore here yesterday. Chemical sales in 1961 exceeded $250,000,000 and represented more than two-thirds of the company's profits.

WASHINGTON, Mad 10 The rejection by the trustees of Columbia University of "Citizen Hearst," by W.A. Swanberg, for a Pulitzer Award in the field of biography is, as reported, the first instance of the kind.

WASHINGTON, May 10 The Administration, apparently sensitive to criticism that it has overlooked women for important jobs, has offered Representative Edith Green of Oregon the post of Ambassador to Canada.
LONDON, May 10 Prices continued to fall on the stock market today. Selling was not heavy but the possibility of a national dock strike and the weakness of Wall Street kept buyers away.

Supporters of the Rev. Dr. Stuart Hamilton Merriam, ousted minister of the Broadway Presbyterian Church, at 114th Street, charged yesterday that the New York Presbytery had, in effect, tried to bribe him to remain quiescent.
TOLEDO, Ohio, May 10 (UPI) The International Stereotypers and Electrotypers Union Local 39 struck at the Toledo Blade tonight.
WASHINGTON, May 10 The Administration suggested modifications in its tax bill today.

IF Maurice Podoloff ever had suspected what was in the offing, he hardly would have postponed until the end of next season his retirement as president of the National Basketball Association. He would have run, not walked, to the nearest exit. Now he is trapped. As if the harassed little boss of the dribble addicts didn't have enough troubles, he has just acquired a new gadfly, Frank Lane.
Daily average borrowings by member banks of the Federal Reserve System tell $7,000,000 in the week ended Wednesday to $46,000,000, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.
THE deal shown today is the counterpiece to an other deal that was famous in bridge long ago. By poetic justice, the player who profited from the ancient one was on the wrong side of this one.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., May 10 Dr. John W. Beardslee Jr., president of the New Brunswick Theological Seminary from 1935 to 1947, died this morning in St. Peter's Hospital, six weeks after he had suffered head injuries in a fall. He was 82 years old.
House defeat of a bill to authorize payment of the remaining Philippines war damage claims was a foolish and indefensible act.
THE social, moral and legal implications of birth control were discussed forthrightly but quietly on last night's installment of "C.B.S. Reports."
LONDON, Friday, May 11--The Conservative party suffered a severe defeat in local elections held throughout England and Wales yesterday.

The plan of Markets Commissioner Albert S. Pacetta to abolish three outdoor pushcart markets collapsed yesterday as suddenly and completely as a pyramid of oranges from which a small boy has pulled out a bottom one.
Anuak tribesmen in the Sudan will soon have a translation of the New Testament in what is believed to be the first book ever printed in their language.
The first phase of a new Super Aquarium at Coney Island was completed yesterday.
WASHINGTON, May 10 (UPI) The House Education and Labor Committee approved today a bill that could cut off aid to Federal land-grant colleges in two or three Southern states.
A two-year-old study charging inequities in New York's legislative apportionment was made public yesterday for the first time.
THE composers were teachers, and the music ranged from moderately out to far out. On last night's Composers' Showcase, at the Museum of Modern Art, were Bulent Arel from Yale.
The United States monetary gold stock declined $30,000,000 in the week ended Wednesday to $16,465,000,000. This figure was the lowest level since August 16, 1939, when it was $16, 335,000,000.

MOSCOW, May 10 (AP) Premier Khrushchev told a group of transport workers today that despite the claims of American scientists no United States rocket had hit the moon. He said tauntingly that the Soviet marker on the moon was getting lonesome waiting for and American companion.
A tiny, gray haired woman with a large block of stock enlivened the annual meeting of the Hotel Corporation of America yesterday.
WASHINGTON, May 10 President Kennedy was urged today to help, end a Senate procedural wrangle that is blocking action on important refugee legislation.

The decision, by Papert, Koenig, Lois, Inc., to sell stock to the public has triggered a major debate in the advertising industry. Some advertising officials questioned the efficacy of the move; others praised it enthusiastically.

TOLEDO, Ohio, May 10 (AP) Seven persons died today in an explosion and fire that wrecked a chemical plant near downtown Toledo. Three other plant emgloyes were unaccounted for more than eight hours after the blasts.
City College's baseball team ended its thirteen-game losing streak yesterday with a 5-4 victory over New York University in a Metropolitan Conference game at Babe Ruth Field in the Bronx.

SHOPPERS will note that price tags on many vegetables are considerably higher than they were a week ago. Snap bean prices jumped 6 cents, bringing that vegetable to a peak of 35 cents a pound. Green peppers are even more expensive; they are up 4 cents to 39 cents a pound.

MILWAUKEE, May 10 (UPI) Frank Bolting, a second baseman, hit a homer off Elroy Face at the start of the ninth inning today to give the Milwaukee Braves a 4-3 victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates before the smallest crowd in the history of County Stadium.
LONDON, May 10 The British Government considers it "over-insurance" to build deep shelters on a nationwide scale against attack by nuclear weapons.
WHITE PLAINS, May 10 Ogden R. Reid of Purchase, formet president of the New York Herald Tribune and former Ambassador to Israel, carried his campaign for Representative to the people here today.

The Columbia Broadcasting System, which has a contract with Arthur Godirey, has expressed disapproval of his plan to appear for a week as host of "Tonight" on the National Broadcasting Company television network.

When Susan Starr got back to New York on Wednesday night, as co-winner of second prize in the piano division of the International Tchaikovsky Competition in Moscow, her most immediate desire was for a good American shampoo.
BEING both professional and unprejudiced, Nor ris Houghton of the Phoenix Theatre has written the best book by an American on the Moscow theatre.

NEWBURGH, N.Y., May 10 (UPI) An attorney for Thomas H. Weygant, whose appearance on a network television program sparked new controversy over this city's welfare policies, said today he was considering suing the city of Newburgh for intimidation and coercion.

WASHINGTON, May 10 Two twin-engined airplanes, apparently purchased as military surplus, were seized in Chicago and Newark tonight because they were reported bound overseas without export licenses, a State Department spokesman said.

The victory President Kennedy thought he had wan for his wage restraint policy in appearing before the United Automobile Workers seems to have slipped away even before its first test at the bargaining table.
GLEN COVE, L. I. May 10--Dr. James E. Burns, first Mayor of the city of Glen Cove, died this morning in Palm Island, Fla., where he was on a visit. He was 88 years old.
SAIGON, Vietnam, May 10 Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara and United States military leaders conferred with President Ngo Dinh Diem tonight in the Vietnamese summer capital of Dalat.
Joseph Curran, head of the National Maritime Union, denounced yesterday the recommendations by President Kennedy's Advisory Committee on Labor-Management Policy.
The Pan-American Society of the United States elected James H. Stebbins president yesterday. He succeeds H. Harold Whitman, who had served three years.

ST. LOUIS, May 10 (AP) Unbeaten Billy O'Dell, pitching in gusts of wind over forty miles an hour, set down the St. Louis Cardinals on four hits tonight, 6 0, and restored the San Francisco Giants' first-place lead to four games.

A spectacular fire at a Brooklyn gasoline dump yesterday exploded two huge storage tanks, spilled flames across the waters of Mill Basin, set a city fireboat aflame and came close to engulfing a former Navy vessel.
"And where are you from?" asked the friendly passenger on the jetliner. "England, We're on our way to Texas," the British couple said.

A BRIGHT galaxy of European royalty has arrived here for a five-day celebration that will culminate Monday in the wedding of Princess Sophia of Greece and Prince Juan Carlos, son of the pretender to the Spanish throne.

WASHINGTON, May 10 A proposal to merge American Airlines, Inc., and Eastern Air Lines, Inc., into the world's largest airline ran into strong opposition here today as hearings on the proposal opened before the Civil Aeronautics Board.
LONDON, May 10 A Philadelphia family left for the United States tonight after deciding against emigrating to the Soviet Union.

EIGHTY years ago, in the spring of 1882, Alfred Ludwig Heinrich Karl, Count von Waldersee, and his American-born wife journeyed from Hanover to Berlin and moved into a large and handsome apartment overlooking the Spree in the headquarters building of the German General Staff.

Dr. Charles Windwer, a physician for forty-three years, died of a heart attack Wednesday night in a barber shop at Flatbush and Eighth Avenues in Brooklyn, He was 70 years old and lived at 100 Eighth Avenue there.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., May 10 Francis W. Kervick, a retired architect and Professor Emeritus of Architecture at the University of Notre Dame here, died on Tuesday in his home. He was 78 years old and had headed the university's Department of Architecture from 1914 until his retirement in 1950.
Tomorrow is the day when children in Greenwich, Conn., make merry at the annual spring fair at the Round Hill Community House.

If the old boy tries to do something about the Berlin problem, the Germans get after him, and if he doesn't, he's in trouble with the Russians or the British. When the Indians and the Pakistanis, the Dutch and the Indonesians, the French and the British get into a scrap, somehow Old Whiskers winds up in the middle.
HANOVER, N.H., May 10 , Thomas J. Dent. former Dartmouth College soccer and lacrosse coach, died today of a heart attack in his home in Fairlee, Vt. He was 67 years old.
WASHINGTON, May 10 (AP) The Department of Agriculture estimated today that this year's winter wheat crop would be 891,498,000 bushels.
WASHINGTON, May 10 Former President Dwight D. Eisenhower accused the Kennedy Administration today of striving for a dangerous concentration of power over Congress and the country.

The European terrorists of the O.A.S., the Algerians of the Provisional Government and the French authorities are engaged in a race against time. If the de Gaulle Government loses this race, the 1,200,000 Europeans now in Algeria will be doomed.
CHICAGO, May 10 A leader of the American Council for Judaism urged tonight that American Jews who are not Zionists stop playing a "parlor game" with the Zionist movement.

WASHINGTON, May 10 (AP)--An American who spent almost twelve years in a Czechoslovak Communist prison was freed today and transferred to the custody of the United States Embassy in Prague, the Czechoslovak Embassay here said.

Instead of owning both a compact sports auto and a power boat, why not save money with a combination of both? A New York lawyer, Hyman Kirmar, 660 Madison Avenue, has taken over the United States partnership of a West German creation, Amphicar, with factories in West Berlin and Lu beck.

WASHINGTON, May 10 (AP) J. Edgar Hoover finished his thirty-eighth year as Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation today, adding to what President Kennedy called "one of the most unusual and distinguished records in the history of government service."

Beau Purple and Eurasia waged an exciting duel in the stretch at Aqueduct yesterday, before Beau Purple won by a length and a half. The victory of Jack Dreyfus' 5-year-old colt was not unexpected by the crowd of 26,412. Ire was the solid favorite and returned $3.80 for $2.

The Pittsburgh Steel Company is predicting steel industry output in 1962 at 105,000,000 to 108,000,000 tons and assumes production will average 110,000,000 tons over the next three years, Allison R. Maxwell Jr., president, said here yesterday. Production in 1961 was 88,000,000 tons.

TRENTON, May 10 Gov. Richard J. Hughes was assured today that the State Senate would vote on Monday for permanent retention of part of the cigarette tax that was to be repealed June 30. The Assembly has already approved it.
David Merrick has bought the stage rights to Sigmund Miller's forthcoming novel, "That's the Way the Money Goes," and hopes to present it as a musical on Broadway "perhaps in the Spring of 1963."
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 10 Samuel Goldwyn declared today that studio executives and producers who blame actors for seeking too much money are themselves at fault.

WASHINGTON, May 10 The director of the Food for Peace program in Taiwan warned today that hunger and resentment would be widespread as a result of the withdrawal of family food relief there by the Church World Service.
CAIRO, May 10 Saudi Arabia dealt a new blow to Egyptian pride yesterday by rejecting the annual offering of a holy carpet for the Mecca shrine.
Austin, Tex., borrowed $14,000,000 in the bond market yesterday to finance expansion of electric light and power, sewerage, and water supply facilities.

A report to the National Council of Churches has declared that parochial school courses in mathematics, science and foreign languages are permeated with religious indoctrination, and that therefore the schools should not get Federal assistance of any kind.

RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, May 10 (UPI) President Mohammad Ayub Khan warned today that the present trend of United States relations with India might force some of India's neighbors to "look for protection elsewhere."

Irving Maidman, realty investor and builder, who is assembling a plot on the east side of Ninth Avenue between Fortysecond and Forty-third Streets for future improvement, has added three parcels to the site.

Under the momentum left over from the sliding markets of Monday, Tuesday and Wednesday, stocks fell for four hours yesterday, then recovered their balance and climbed back. Measured by The New York Times averages, they had hit a low since early January, 1961.
CHICAGO, May 10 "Now I want all you fellas to get nice and clean," barked, Casey Stengel in the Mets' clubhouse in Wrigley, Field today, "because we're going home in ninth place."
BLOOMINGTON, Minn., May 10 (AP) Ty Cline batted in four runs with a pair of clutch singles today to pace Cleveland to a 9-4 victory over the Minnesota Twins that kept the Indians in second place.
Mayor Wagner and Dr. Ralph J. Bunche have had a personal talk within the last few days about Dr. Bunche's availability for this year's Democratic nomination for "United States Senator.
The proposed user tax on the operations of inland waterway carriers presents a serious threat to the existence of the industry, a spokesman declared here yesterday.

NORWAY'S toughest politician is a slim, soft six-footer with the big, powerful hands of the road laborer he once was. The politician, Einar Henry Gerhardsen, heads the Norwegian Government as Premier and the ruling Labor party as chairman.
An offer to buy Ellis Island for $2,100,000 with a view to building a Frank Lloyd Wright "dream city" on it was made yesterday to the General Services Administration.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 10 Last night, for the first time, man illuminated another celestial body.
WASHINGTON, May 10 (AP) Early Wynn lost a shutout in the ninth inning today, but the Chicago White Sox fight-hander gained the 294th victory of his career by beating the Washington Senators, 3 1.

With versatile Bill Urban contributing more than half of its points, New York University took a narrow lead over St. John's and Manhattan yesterday in the first three events of the Metropolitan Intercollegiate track and field championships.
HAMPDEN-SYDNEY, Va., May 10 (AP) Dr. Edgar Graham Gammon, President Emeritus of Hampden-Sydney College and a prominent Presbyterian clergyman, died at his home here yesterday. He was 77 years old.

WASHINGTON, May 14 The Flight Engineers' International Association refused today to participate in an arbitration to decide how Pan American World Airways bet cockpit crews would be cut from four men to three.
QUIETLY, without fanfare, a fine artist has opened a good show in Manhattan. She has no axe to grind, no prefabricated mystique to sell, no blows to strike in the petty wars of the world of art.
WASHINGTON, May 10 District Attorney Frank S. Hogan of New York said today that many big-time criminals were walking the streets because wiretap evidence could not be used against them.

Guests at the White Elephant Tea that Mrs. Laurance S. Rockefeller will give at her home, 834 Fifth Avenue, Tuesday have been asked to donate, "white elephants" to be sold at the annual Brick Presbyterian, Church Fair in the autumn.

Kennedy and Andre Malraux, French Minister of State for Cultural Affairs.

Dana Hodgdon, president of Hodgdon Co., said employes also used directories of other Federal agencies in making unsolicited phone calls seeking customers.

Pan American World Airways, Inc., reduced its net loss by 27 per cent to $4,651,000 from $6,352,000 in the initial three months this year.
The community of long-term investing institutions ended their resistance yesterday to the rich prices designated by investment banking syndicates for new issues of corporate bonds of top grade.
Aplan to operate its buses for airport passengers across midtown Manhattan between the East and West Side Airline Terminals was proposed to the city yesterday by Carey Transportation, Inc.
A civil liberties group is challenging what it believes to be the first criminal charges brought by the Government against a native-born citizen of re-enterine the country.

A bill to double the city occupancy tax on commercial tenants was approved by the Board of Estimate yesterday. It has been passed by the Council and now goes to Mayor Wagner for his signature.

Why did people buy I.B.M.? That question was posed yesterday to some analysts. Because of its past spectacular rises in price, people nicknamed the stock "I Buy Money," according to Eldon Grimm, vice president of Walston Co.

WASHINGTON, May 10 (AP) President Kennedy was re ported to have discussed the worsening situation in Laos with his diplomatic and military advisers today. They considered possible action the United States might take if the cease-fire there could not be quickly restored.
CARACAS, Venezuela, May 10 The Venezuelan Government prohibited all activities of the Communist party and the Marxist Movement of the Revolutionary Left tonight.

BERLIN, May 10 Two questions were being posed by diplomats and observers in West Germany today in the aftermath of the row stirred up by Chancellor Adenauer's remarks here earlier in the week on the Berlin situation.

JUST across the Hudson River there is a new plant that can turn out more than 1,000,000 frozen doughnuts daily. The results of this activity in Secaucus, N.J., already can be seen in local grocery markets, freezer division. They are frozen Chock Full O' Nuts dougtnuts.
ALBANY, May 10 The state's highest court held today that a person who goes to the defense of a third party in a struggle does so at his own peril.
ALGIERS, May 10 Terrorists belonging to the Secret Army Organization killed almost a score of Moslem women in the streets of Algiers and Oran today.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., May 10 (UPI) The Capital Citizens Council began today its longpromised shipment of dissatisfied Negroes from Little Rock to Hyannis Port, Mass., where President Kennedy has a summer home.

WASHINGTON, May 10 Farm lobbyists won a fight today for provision of the Administration's foreign trade bill to provide a lever for removal of restrictions on imports of United States farm products by the European Economic Community.

IN a busy shopping district in Queens, wedged between a pizza place and a trimming shop, a narrow door, topped with a chiropodist's sign, leads down a hall to the Knit-Wood Shade and Screen Company. It is a door that opens, in effect, on the Canary Islands and the Orient.
Guidelines for the development of vaccines against colds and other respiratory virus infections are set down in an article in The Journal of the American Medical Association, out tomorrow.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark, May 10 Paul O. Canaday, president of Arkansas Power and Light Company, died today of a cerebral hemorrhage. He was 57 years old.

A troupe of country musiccians presented a program of folk, country, Western and Bluegrass music last night at Carnegie Hall. Although the star, Johnny Cash, was suffering from a throat ailment, which made it difficult to judge his performance, the evening afforded several diverting moments.
A Columbia University study made public yesterday charges that much money is being spent here on unnecessary or incompetent medical and hospital treatment and care.

THE New York Premiere of Federico Garcia Lorca's elusive tragedy, "If Five Years Pass," was presented last evening by a new off-Broadway company that calls itself Stage 73. More tableau than drama, this little-known work by Spain's celebrated lyric poet comes only flutteringly to life on the stage.
WASHINGTON, May 10 The Democrats, who control all the investigative bodies of the Government, have not done much about the Billie Sol Estes case, former President Dwight D. Eisenhower said today.
In the fourth heaviest trading session of the year, world sugar futures climbed 3 to 7 points (hundredths of a cent a pound) on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. The volume was 14,650 tons.
Four Queens residents moved yesterday in Federal Court, Brooklyn, to void the New York State reapportionment lines in the new Queens Sixth Congressional District.

ALBANY, May 10--The Court of Appeals upheld today the constitutionality of the freeze imposed on rent increases in New York City, until rent administration could be shifted from the state to the city.

A forecast of $100,000,000 a year in sales "within the next four or five years, and perhaps even sooner," was made here yesterday by Carl Rosen, president of the Puritan Fashions Corporation.

MARTINGSBURG, W. Va. May 14--West Virginia's bid to attract touring fishermen is being bolstered by measures designed to insure fish for every fishing line.

BONN, Germany, May 14-- The Government announced a compromise with the Volkswagen company today in their dispute over an increase in prices by the company on domestic models. Volkswagen promptly denied that any compromise had been reached.

The Waldorf-Astoria Hotel was reported yesterday to have dismissed eight union shop leaders in the wake of Sunday's walkout of waiters in a dispute over tipping.
CHICAGO, May 14 (AP)--A $350,000 libel suit brought by Police Capt. Frank Pape against Time Inc. was dismissed in United States District Court today.

BUENOS AIRES, May 14-- Economic Minister Alvaro C. Alsogaray said today that he expected to travel to the United States in the near future, but only after progress had been made in putting Argentina's economy in order.
BRIGHTON, England, May 14 (AP)--Hethersett, owned by Maj. Lionel Holliday, won the Brighton Derby Trial Stakes today and immediately became a 7-1 favorite for the Epsom Derby.

TOKYO, May 14 (AP)-- About 200 Leftist students clashed today with 300 policemen and a few Rightists in Hiroshima. The students tried to break up a Government hearing discussing revision of the American-inspired Constitution, which renounces war. The police arrested thirteen persons.

Groggy but game, the stock market got up off its back yesterday morning and made the most impressive rally since last Dec. 27.

Chief Elton Greene, the 72year-old sachem of the Tuscarora Indians--the tribe that fought for two years to keep the New York State Power Authority from turning 588 acres of its land into a power reservoirmade peace yesterday with the authority's chairman, Robert Moses.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, May 17 --Belgian and Dutch resistance to the French proposal for a European political treaty hardened today in reaction to President de Gaulle's insistence that it should produce a confederation of independent countries rather than an integrated union.
LONDAN, May 17--A deal between Britain and the Common Market countries for a substantial two-way cut in tariffs within the framework of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade was announced today.

HOT SPRINGS, Ark., May 17 (UPI)--Bill Collins of Miami birdied six of the last seven holes today for a seven-underpar 34, 31--65 and took the first-round lead in the $20,000 Hot Springs open golf tournament.
WILLEMSTAD, Curacao, May 17--Paul Keres and Mikhail Tal, both of the Soviet Union, drew their ninth-round game in the Curacao Candidates Chess Tournament.
TOLBUKHIN, Bulgaria, May 17--Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko of the Soviet Union said today that the landing of United States troops in Thailand was "very bad."

BALTIMORE, May 17 (UPI) --Jaipur took over as the favorite for Saturday's running of the $188,300 Preakness Stakes as eleven horses were entered today for the triple crown race.
Mayor Wagner told 1,500 Brooklyn Democrats last night that Governor Rockefeller was "on the run" rnd would be defeated this fall.
