Business men in general are "too sensitive" to Administration utterances on business, Secretary of Labor Arthur J. Goldberg declared at a dinner here last night.
MINEOLA, L. I., May 17-- The Nassau County Planning Commission today recommended that the county establish an airport on 320-acre Seaman's Island in East Bay, off Seaford.
CALDWELL, N. J., May 17 --Dr. Lloyd W. Johnson, headmaster emeritus of Adelphi Academy, a private school in Brooklyn, died yesterday of a stroke in Muhlenberg Medical Center in Bethlehem, Pa.

JERSEY CITY, May 17--A Hudson County jury today acquitted one doctor and was unable to reach a verdict on another and a 65-year-old woman, all charged with conspiracy in an alleged baby-selling racket.

NEW DELHI, India, May 17 --The United States will provide 180,000 bales of long staple cotton to India under an agreement signed today. The cotton, worth $28,200,000, will help meet a critical shortage in Indian textile mills.
LONDON, May 17 (UPI)-- Queen Elizabeth has "a temperature and a sore throat and is confined to her room in Buckingham Palace," a palace communique announced tonight.
TUNIS, May 17--The Information Minister of the Algerian Provisional Government said today that the Moslems in Algeria should take measures in self-defense against European terrorist attacks.

WASHINGTON, May 17-- The Association of American Railroads, in their weekly survey, reported today that for the week ended May 12 there were 583,925 cars loaded. This was 5.9 per cent above the level of 1961, but six-tenths of 1 per cent below the preceding week's level.
SAN FRANCISCO, May 17 (AP)--St. Louis scored an unearned run off Billy O'Dell in the ninth inning today and beat San Francisco, 1--0, behind the six-hit pitching of Bob Gibson.
WASHINGTON, May 17-- Senate stockpile investigators are questioning whether the Government is usings its critical material reserves and surpluses for objectives not explicitly authorized by law.
ASBURY PARK, N. J., May 17--In a new move to speed improvement of highways to the shore from the Hightstown intersection of the New Jersey Turnpike and Trenton, Asbury Park officials...

WASHINGTON, May 18-- Secretary of Labor Arthur J. Goldberg called on railroad union and management officials today to meet with him here Wednesday in an effort to settle their contract dispute.

MANILA, May 18 (UPI)-- President Diosdado Macapagal indicated today that he would reconsider the postponment of his visit to the United States if the House of Representatives passed a $37,000,000 bill to pay war damages to Filipinos.
WASHINGTON, May 18 (UPI) --Capt. George Peteler of National Airlines took his 2 year-old son flying, and he is not likely to do it again.

DEEP-SEA divers or anyone who is interested in under water life might head for Richards Sporting Goods, Inc., a shop marked by a blinking red arrow at 233 West Forty-second Street (between Broadway and Eighth Avenue).
ROME, May 18--Secretary of the Treasury Douglas Dillon urged prosperous Western Europe today to "mobilize its own capital resources" rather than rely on the New York money market.
Ottawa, May 18 (Canadian Press)--The increased air fares out of Canada, originally announced for June 1, will not take effect at that time, a spokesman for the Air Transport Board said today.

AYNOR, S.C., May 18--What does a small farming community such as this one do when allotment cutbacks curb its one cash crop, tobacco? Aynor decided a garment factory would keep the town busy, and the inhabitants-- all 687 of them--went to work on it.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 18--Indonesia's delegate said here today that Indonesian paratrooper landings in Netherlands New Guinea were only the beginning of a "liberation" movement that would not halt unless there was a "peaceful solution" on Indonesia's terms.

WASHINGTON, May 18 (UPI)--Mrs. Robert S. McNamara, wife of the Secretary of Defense, presented President Kennedy's donation today to an 8-year-old girl to open the American Legion Auxiliary's poppy drive.
The housing development that President Kennedy will dedicate today is the second massive cooperative in the city sponsored by the International Ladies Garment Workers Union ...
BERLIN, May 18--An 81year-old man disclosed here today how he led a group of twelve East Germans on a successful underground escape to West Berlin.

TOKYO, May 18--The United States Ambassador, Edwin O. Reischauer, was called to the Foreign Ministry today and told that the deployment of Japan-based American troops to Southeast Asia without prior notice had politically embarrassed the Japanese Government.
HENDERSONVILLE, N.C., May 18 (AP)--Herbert A. Frink, 58 years old, former Mayor of Miami Beach, Fla., was found shot to death in his summer home near here today.

Eighty players and coaches from Dundee of Scotland, Reutlingen of West Germany, Palermo of Italy and Hajduk of Yugoslavia arrived in New York yesterday for the first half of the International Soccer League season.
CACUTTA, India, May 18 (Reuters)--A procession including a Communist member of Parliament marched to the United States consulate here today shouting "Hands off Asia."
LAWRENCEVILLE, N.J., May 18--A son was born on May 5 to Mr. and Mrs. Graham M. Brush Jr. of this community and Warren, Conn., at the Lying-In Hospital in New York.
INDIVIDUAL taste for abstract - expressionist paint ing favors it either more abstract than expressionistic or vice versa. Both tastes will be satisfied in two current exhibitions.

MOSCOW, May 18 (AP)-- The job of getting news from Moscow to the rest of the world was eased today with the opening of teleprinter lines connecting the Moscow offices of United States and French news agencies to their news networks abroad.
The Board of Education has dropped a plan to give extra payment to teachers in difficult schools.
ELEVEN years ago Arthur B. Krim, then only 41 years old, led a team of young executives in saving the United Artists Corporation from financial ruin.

John A. McCone, vigorous new director of the Central Intelligence Agency, has been demonstrating as head of C.I.A. the strong leadership and quick comprehension which all those who knew him had anticipated.
BALTIMORE, May 18--With George D. Widener's Jaipur the likely favorite, the eighty-sixth running of the Preakness Stakes will take place at the Pimlico Race Course tomorrow.

ALGIERS, May 18 (AP)-- French authorities denied charges by the Algerian Provisional Government today that French forces bombarded a unit of the Algerian National Liberation Army near the Tunisian frontier yesterday.
WASHINGTON, May 18 (UPI)--Bob Schmidt hit a home run leading off the sixth ining tonight to break a 2-2 tie and give the Washington Senators a 3-2 victory over the Kansas City Athletics.
The trading bell of the American Stock Exchange tolled at 11 o'clock yesterday morning, signaling two more disciplinary actions by the board of governors.

NEW ORLEANS, May 18 (AP)--In a 2-to-1 ruling, the Fifth Circuit United States Court of Appeals has overturned the decision of a lower court in a case involving the use of two formerly city-owned golf courses in Jacksonville, Fla., and their availability to Negroes.

RECIFF, Brazil, May 17-- Miguel Arraes de Alencar, the Leftist Mayor of Recife, said today that President Kennedy would be "well received" if he visited this under-developed northeast region on his trip to Brazil.

SOME foods are ideal for stuffing--and the avocado is one of them. The indentation left by the pit seems to invite a filling. And the blandness and smoothness of tie flesh of the avocado makes an excellent foil for flavors as extreme as caviar and curry.
WASHINGTON, May 18-- The Office of Civil Defense received a patent this week for its "little black box," which it calls potentially the most valuable electric appliance ever plugged into an outlet.
More than 150 youngsters in New York are in a program designed to help them learn to read English by being taught to read French.
MOSCOW, May 18 (AP)-- Moscow newspaper announced today the death of Admiral Arseni Grigorevich Golovka, first deputy commander in chief of the Soviet Navy. He was 55 years old.
SAIGON, Vietnam, May 18 --A home-made grenade was thrown at Americans seated at sidewalk tables outside a Saigon restaurant last night.

On a sunny Saturday afternoon in Philadelphia, fifty years ago yesterday, a tall, slim, 20year-old lad named Aloysius Stanislaus (Steve) Travers made his major league debut as a pitcher for the Detroit Tigers.

BANGKOK, Thailand, May 18 (AP)--Gen. Paul D. Harkins warned today that a threat still existed from pro-Communist forces in Laos, whose drive from the north brought United States soldiers and marines here to protect Thailand's border.

WIMBLEDON, England, May 18 (UPI)--Stirling Moss, the star British auto racing driver who was seriously injured in a crash in the Goodwood 100-mile race April 23, has regained full consciousness and also has more power in his left arm and leg.
DENVER, May 18--More than 80,000 Presbyterians in the New York area, affiliated with three presbyteries, or local governing bodies, soon may be regrouped in two presbyteries.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, May 18--The wife of Milovan Djilas hired a lawyer today to open a fight against her husband's conviction earlier this week on a charge of divulging official secrets.

The second major local concert of the season was given last night by Joan Baez, at Carnegie Hall.

WASHINGTON, May 18-- Operations of a stock selling enterprise that bore many similarities to the "boiler room" of an earlier generation were unfolded today before the Securities and Exchange Commission panel studying sales practices in the securities market.

HAMDEN, Conn., May 18 (AP)--Mrs. Betty Jones Crowley, who stood by her husband when he was tried in Japan for the death of her brother, died here yesterday after a brief illness. She was 51 years old.

SEOUL, Korea, Saturday, May 19 (AP)--A South Korean general court-martial sentenced to death today three officers and three enlisted men who were convicted of having embezzled army funds.

New issues of fixed-interest securities valued at more than $250,000,000 are expected next week in the bond market.
AS Leonard Bernstein said, it was an afternoon of recognitions and ceremony. Mr. Bernstein made a speech prior to the opening of yesterday afternoon's concert by the New York Philharmonic.
GARDEN CITY, L.I., May 18 --A 2-year-old black miniature poodle finished his championship today in the process of going to best of breed in the thirtieth specialty show of the Poodle Club of America.
CARLISLE, Pa., May 18-- Lafayette College won the Middle Atlantic Conference tennis championship and completed its first undefeated season by halting Dickinson, 6--3, today.

ROME, May 18 (UPI)--Pope John XXIII discussed the forthcoming ecumenical council today with a leader of the Greek Orthodox Church.

Over the protests of spokesmen for meat dealers, Mayor Wagner signed a measure yesterday that will require butchers to place their meat grinders in full view of customers who ask that their meat be specially ground.
TALLINN, Estonia, May 16 --Only five hours by ex press train separate Tallinn, capital of Soviet Estonia, from Leningrad, generally considered the most sophisticated of the Russian cities.
LONDON, May 18 (AP)-- Two masked men slugged two payroll mesengers outside a bank on Oxford Street today and fled with the cash bags. The bags were empty.
The Protestant Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest was the setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Miss Christina Audrey Gillespie to Peter Leigh Griffith.

LEXINGTON, S.C., May 16 --The joint hustings campaign has all but vanished from the American scene. But it still holds a strong attraction for South Carolinians, who will even brave a thunderstorm, as they did tonight, to hear the traveling candidates.
WESTBURY, L.I., May 18-- Thor Hanover, a 71-1 shot given a million-dollar drive by Johnny Simpson, accounted for the year's most shocking upset in harness racing tonight at Roosevelt Raceway.

SOUTHAMPTON, England, May 18 (Reuters)--A five-day strike by 500 dock workers continued today. The liner Athlone Castle had to anchor outside the port and send her 685 passengers ashore by tender. The wildcat strikers are crane operators, electricians and cargo checkers.

WASHINGTON, May 17 (AP) --The Bureau of Mines reported today that stocks of domestic and foreign crude petroleum totaled 254,282,000 barrels on May 12, a net increase of 1,939,000 barrels for the week. Domestic crude increased by 1,325,000 barrels and foreign crude increased by 614,000.

WASHINGTON, May 18-- The President's Committee on Equal Employment Opportunity announced today that Danly Machine Specialties, Inc., of Cicero, Ill., was again eligible to receive Government contracts.

WASHINGTON, May 18 (AP)--President Kennedy named two new United States envoys today. They are Mrs. Eugenie Moore Anderson to be Minister to Bulgaria and Admiral Alan G. Kirk to be Ambassador to Nationalist China.
Zdenko Formanek, Minister to Spain of the pre-Communist Republic of Czechoslovakia, died Thursday in Madrid after a long illness. He was 72 years old.

CHICAGO, May 18 (AP)-- Trade in the grain market was light and cautious today as speculators evened-up positions in the May contracts and found little inducement to expand positions in other deliveries.

WASHINGTON, May 18 (AP) --The abandonment of its entire 106-mile line by the Chicago, North Shore and Milwaukee Railway was authorized today by the Interstate Commerce Commission.

WASHINGTON, May 18 (AP)--In three states--New York, Hawaii and Alaska-- there are more renters than home owners, the Census Bureau reported today.

LONDON, May 18--Bertrand Russell, one of the greatest living philosophers and now the stormy petrel of Britain's foes of nuclear armament, was 90 years old today.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., May 20 --A group of young girls, some so small that they had to halfstand to reach the foot pedals, gave a harp recital here today.

The Commerce and Industry Association of New York said yesterday that the nation's workers, their employers and the self-employed could expect to be taxed to the hilt for any legislation placing medical care for the aged under the Social Security system.

The glory of last-reel heroics was evenly distributed yesterday at Yankee Stadium. New York and Minneapolis split a double-header before 27,146 fans who expended at least one-third of their lung-power cheering for the Mets' scores as they were listed on the scoreboard.
MILWAUKEE, May 20 (AP)--The Milwaukee Braves acquired an outfielder, Gus Bell, from the New York Mets tonight, completing a deal that sent Frank Thomas to the Mets during the winter.
The nation's 50,000 merchant mariners on United States-flag ships read about 500,000 hardcover and paperback books a year.

A leader of the American Jewish Congress charged yesterday that President Kennedy's "failure to give active leadership" in the fight for anti-discrimination legislation had resulted in increasing apathy and discouragement among civil rights supporters.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 20--A weird collection of episodes has been uncovered in the log of Metro-GoldwynMayer's remake of "Mutiny on the Bounty," the movie starring Marlon Brando that was to have been completed some fifteen months ago for about $8,500,000 but that has already cost about $20,000,000.
MILWAUKEE, May 20--Unmindful of the indulgent smiles and snickers that have greeted their recent pretentious moves, Casey Stengel and his Mets rose today to their finest hour.
PARIS, May 20--Our present troubles with Europe derive from the very success of United States policy which wisely sought to restore this Continent's vigor and self-confidence. This has been achieved.
BANGKOK, Thailand, May 20 (Reuters)--American troops camping on Thailand's Central Plateau have found elephants taking showers with the troops' specially filtered water supply.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., May 20 --Mrs. Henry C. Eidenbach has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Elizabeth Mary Eidenbach, to Joachim F. Wirth. He is the son of Mrs. Alexander Otto Wirth of Closter, N.J., and the late Mr. Wirth. The wedding is planned for late September.
ENGLEWOOD, N.J., May 20--Thirty citizens picketed City Hall at 2 P.M. today and then marched a mile and a half uphill in the heat to stand in front of the home of Mayor Austin N. Volk.
The Board of Education disclosed yesterday that it planned a $2,770,000 yearly increase for day-to-day substitute teachers.
More than 200 Cubans from throughout the East gathered here yesterday to commemo rate the sixtieth anniversary of the First Republican of Cuba.

HOLLANDIA, Netherlands New Guinea, May 20-- The Indonesians dropped more paratroopers on Netherlands New Guinea yesterday and Dutch troops immediately attacked them, killing two and wounding three, the Dutch announced today.
President Kennedy attended a private mass yesterday morning at Horizon House, where his father is convalescing at New York University Medical Center.
CANNES, France, May 20-- The Cannes Film Festival audience responded warmly tonight to the official American entry, "Long Day's Journey Into Night."

Dr. Leonard Finlan, and asso ciate professor in the Speech Department of Brooklyn College, died Saturday in St. Vincent's Hospital, after a month's illness. He was 50 years old and lived at 59 West Twelfth Street.
WASHINGTON, May 20 (UPI)--The Federal Aviation Agency decided today that jets are here to stay.
TUNIS, May 20 (UPI)--A United Nations official said today that force of arms might be the only way to end the secession of the Katanga province in the Congo.
The Rev. Dr. Harold Bosley of Christ Church Methodist, Park Avenue and Sixtieth Street, yesterday scored the increase in alcoholism and problem drinking.
American and other nonEuropean insurers are eyeing with interest the European Common Market, which represents an annual insurance premium income of about $5,000,000.000.

The temperature was in the upper eighties at the Weather Bureau's station in Central Park yesterday, and seemed considerably hotter outside the Carlyle Hotel, 35 East Seventy-sixth Street, where half a hundred policemen were sweltering on guard during President Kennedy's visit.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., May 20--Harold M. Scott Jr.'s Dawnell, one of the smallest of the eighty-seven boats that sailed in the Larchmont Yacht Club's Six-Mile Reef race over the week-end, won the Edlu Trophy as the 130-nautical-mile event ended today.
PHILADELPHIA, May 20 (AP)--The free-swinging Chicago Cubs swept both ends of a double-header from the Philadelphia Phillies today, 6--4 and 11--2.
A thirty-seven-page annual report from commissioner Michael J. Murphy published yesterday showed that 1961 was a busy year for the police force.
The city's policy on the pur chase and maintenance of park ing meters may be settled this week following the submission today of the last of three...
The congregation at morning worship in Broadway Presbyterian Church yesterday was divided between a regular service in the sanctuary and a prayer meeting in the basement.

"Research means work and bread," an official of one of West Germany's leading industrial complexes said recently.
LONDON, May 20--Dr. Mer vyn George Haigh, who was Bishop of Coventry when its cathedral was razed by Ger man bombers in 1940, died to day at his home in Dolgelly, Wales.

WASHINGTON, May 20-- --Fearing widespread tribal violence in Ruanda and Urundi after the territories become independent in July, the United States will propose that the United Nations establish protective machinery in the two new African states.
KATMANDU, Nepal, May 20 --Village council elections have been completed all over Nepal as the first stage of King Mahendra's democratization plan, it was announced here today.
WASHINGTON, May 20-- Gen. Lucius D. Clay said tonight he thought it possible that "some settlement" could be reached with the Soviet Union over Berlin.
WASHINGTON, May 20-- The Army is studying whether to permit the establishment of stock brokerage offices in its overseas installations, Pentagon officials said today.
HONG KONG, May 20 (Reuters)--British troops joined Hong Kong policemen and Indian Gurkha troops today in rounding up new refugees from Communist China.
LONDON, May 20--The stock market began last week with considerable activity and an upward swing in prices but the week closed with business slow and prices sagging.

WASHINGTON, May 20 (AP)--While President Kennedy was appealing today for public support of his plan for health care for the elderly, three Republican members of Congress were accusing him of trying to fool the people.
BANGKOK, Thailand, May 20--The build-up of United States troops in Thailand neared completion today with about 4,800 soldiers, marines and airmen deployed in camps scattered throughout the country.
BALTIMORE, May 20 (AP) --Francis V. du Pont, son of a former president of E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co. in Wil mington, died today of lung cancer at University Hospital. He was 67 years old.
OYSTER BAY, L.I., May 20 --The Seawanhaka-Corinthian Yacht Club's opening races in the three-race series for the Philip J. Roosevelt and Elihu Root Jr. Trophies were held today on Long Island Sound.

As chairman of the Washington National Cultural Center's board of trustees, Roger L. Stevens has the immediate task of raising $30,000,000. Meanwhile, a steady stream of scripts flows his way. Friends and business associates make certain that he does not overlook anything worth while.

AT the beginning of Iris Murdoch's new novel, "An Unofficial Rose,"* Hugh Peronett, a dim and fatuous man of 67, is standing in the rain at his wife's grave. At the end, only a few months later, Hugh is sitting in the bar of a ship bound for India, relaxed, delighted with his freedom and entirely unaware that he is about to be trapped by a designing female.

The Huntington Hartford collection of French posters will be on view Wednesday from 8 P.M. to 1 A.M. at the Carnaval de Paris which will take place on Washington Mews between Fifth Avenue and University Place.
A downtown business education center to house the Bernard M. Baruch School of Business and Public Administration and a new community college was proposed in a report made public yesterday.
WASHINGTON, May 20-- "A deal of mortals in the world," says a character in one of Galsworthy's novels, "and not enough imagination to go round."

PORTLAND, Ore., May 20 (AP)--Federal control of education in this country is inevitable if the states and local communities do not make much greater efforts to upgrade their schools," Mrs. Clifford N. Jenkins, president of the National Congress of Parents and Teachers, said today.
The British Home Secretary, R.A. Butler, is now in Salisbury, Southern Rhodesia, on a trip to study that most complex and delicate of problems: what to do about the Central African Federation.
CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., May 20--Lieut. Comdr. M. Scott Carpenter is to be the first American to eat solid food in space, according to present plans for his orbital flight.

Time was when scientists normally became exasperated with those who called computers "electronic brains."
Bathing suits, Jamaica shorts and knit pants were emphasized in heavy orders for summer sportswear last week, resident buying offices here reported.

CHICAGO, May 20 (AP)-- The Chicago White Sox snapped a three-game losing streak today with a double-header sweep of the Baltimore Orioles behind the splendid pitching of John Buzhardt and Ray Herbert. The score of each game was 8--3.

The marriage of Miss Brenda Ward Fuerst, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jack A. Fuerst of 40 East Eighty-eighth Street, to Stuart Monroe Gustin took place yesterday afternoon. The ceremony was performed in the Cottage of the Hampshire House by Rabbi William F. Rosenblum.

SALISBURY, Southern Rhodesia, May 20--When R.A. Butler, Britain's Minister for Central African Affairs, resumes his fact-finding tour of the Federation of Rhodesia and Nyasaland tomorrow, he is expected to be faced with demands by African nationalists in Northern Rhodesia to secede from the federation.

NEW HYDE PARK, L. I., May 20--The marriage of Miss Roberta Arline Benjamin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Benjamin, to Dr. Baruch J. Davis took place here this afternoon. Rabbi Daniel L. Davis, father of the bridegroom, performed the ceremony at the Benjamin home.
President Kennedy slipped twice on a statistic yesterday while telling a Madison Square Garden rally how a worker would pay for the medical care program he is advocating.
Two patrolmen breaking up a street fight in the South Bronx last night were injured slightly by objects thrown from a roof.
The Glee Club of St. Francis de Sales, a girls' boarding high school in Powhatan, Va., was heard in a concert at Town Hall yesterday afternoon.
A letter to the editor in an English-language newspaper in Buenos Aires three weeks ago has brought on a deluge of correspondence for a "retired" New Yorker of world-wide renown.
PITTSBURGH, May 20-- The steel market had a few bright spots last week but the general trend still was not encouraging.

IRVINGTON-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., May 20--The engagement of Miss Harriet Hall Blanton, to Peter Christiaan Schroeder, of New York has been announced by the future bride's mother, Mrs. Alexander John Blanton of this community and Quonochontaug, R.I. A June wedding is planned.
New Yorkers in the hundreds of thousands fled the spring heat yesterday.

MANILA, May 20--President Diosdado Macapagal expressed confidence today that the close friendship between the United States and the Philippines would recover from the damage done by the adverse vote in Congress on a $73,000,000 war damages claim by the Manila Government.

DOBBS FERRY, N.Y., May 20--Governor Rockefeller participated today in the dedication of the $7,000,000 educational building complex of Mount Mercy-on-the-Hudson. The buildings are on the eighty-sixacre former Edwin Gould estate overlooking the Hudson River.
PECOS, Tex., May 19--Billie Sol Estes may have been trying to make a deal with James R. Hoffa's International Brotherhood of Teamsters shortly before the collapse of his agricultural empire in March.
WASHINGTON, May 20-- A New England senator proposed today the acquisition, modernization and operation of railroad passenger facilities from Boston to Washington by a multi-state public authority.

Premier Khrushchev appears to have been playing a double game in the tour of Bulgaria he wound up yesterday. Plainly, the motivation for his visit was to press the Bulgarians to improve their attitude toward Yugoslavia and to soften or abandon the significant remnants of Stalinism in their nation's life.
The most prized status symbol among patrons of the arts is an invitation that "admits two" to a preview of an art show.
WASHINGTON, May 20-- On Aug. 23, 1960, just before a crucial late afternoon vote, Senator John F. Kennedy of Massachusetts addressed the Senate in prophetic tones.
DURANGO, Colo., May 20 (AP)--Three United States Air Force men were found dead today in the wreckage of a twinengine training plane that disappeared Feb. 25.

WASHINGTON, May 20-- One of the oldest and most successful voluntary agencies for settling labor-management disputes will resume its activity tomorrow, facing the heaviest case load in its forty-two-year history.
LONDON, May 20 (AP)--Nicola Pietrangeli and Fausto Gardini completed Italy's sweep over the Soviet Union today in the second round of the Davis Cup European Zone tennis at Florence, Italy.

ZANDVOORT, The Netherlands, May 20--In a race enlivened by six crashes; Graham Hill of Britain easily won the Grand Prix of Holland today. Hill drove his rear-engined V-8 BRM into the lead in the early minutes of the eighty-lap, 208mile race and held it to the end.

Twenty heel-and-toe athletes, including five members of the 1960 United States Olympic team, started yesterday's fiftykilometer national walking championship. Only nine survived the heat, humidity, exhaust fumes and traffic hazards.
COCOA BEACH, Fla., May 20 --The soundless voice of the turtle is attracting more attention along the shores near Cape Canaveral than the roar of rockets.
Though President Kennedy's week-end here was a political one, he might as well have been in Hyannis Port as far as local politicians were concerned. He dropped no hints and patted no heads.

KARACHI, Pakistan, May 20 (Reuters)--Angami Zapu Phizo, president of the Naga National Council, arrived here by air today from London.
MOSCOW, May 20--The Soviet Union warned the United States today that it would be dangerous to allow Chancellor Adenauer to delay an agreement on Berlin and Germany.
CHICAGO, May 20 (AP)-- Weather became the dominant factor in grain futures trade last week and prices advanced or retreated generally on reports of rain or the absence of it.

TEANECK, N. J., May 20-- Miss Gail Louise Ridley, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth Ridley, was married here this afternoon to Herbert Otto Schuffenhauer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert E. Schuffenhauer of Haworth. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Theodore W. Beiderwieden.

The Janet Building Associates has taken title to the Jaret Building, a two-story office and store structure at 1601-21 Kings Highway, corner of East Sixteenth Street, Brooklyn, which they bought recently. The plot is 175 by 102 feet. The David Janet Corporation, represented by Michael Reich and Ray Katoff, was the broker in the sale for $1,042,170.

WANTAGH, L.I., May 20 --Conservationists made an inspection tour of a developing new 500-acre wildlife sanctuary here today on the site of an old private hunting preserve next to Jones Beach. They were delighted with what they saw.

TOKYO, May 20 (AP)--A Japanese newspaper announced today it was temporarily eliminating the American comic strip "Pogo" because the Soviet embassy had pointed out that a "Russian" talking pig in the strip's current episode bore a striking resemblance to Premier Khrushchev.
CLEVELAND, May 20 (AP) --Al Kaline slammed two home runs to lead Detroit to an 8-6 victory over Cleveland after the Indians won 7-6, in the opener of a double-header today.
The newly organized Caribbean Federation for Mental Health of New York will hold a benefit spring dance Saturday at the St. Nicholas Sports Arena, 53 West Sixty-sixth Street.
A truck driver who was almost too shy to take credit for having rescued a teenager from drowning was named National Driver of the Year yesterday by the American Trucking Associations.
The Most Rev. Joost de Blank, Archbishop of Capetown and Metropolitan of South Africa, called Africa "the cross-bearing conscience of the world" in a sermon yesterday.

The New York Philharmonic, which has been playing at Carnegie Hall since 1891, gave its farewell concert there yesterday afternoon. The audience showed it was reluctant to let the orchestra go, giving a final ovation that lasted more than ten minutes.
WILTON, Conn. FOUNTAINS and pools, heretofore associated with Versailles, Paris and Rome, may soon be as indigenous to the American garden as the petunia.

The Christian church, in allowing segregation and discrimination to corrupt its own life and to flourish in the community, "has been false to itself and to Christ," the Rev. Dr. John M. Krumm, chaplain of Columbia University, said yesterday.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, May 20 (Reuters)--The Very Rev. Patrick H.F. Barron, Anglican Dean of Johannesburg, warned today against a new Government bill calling for the death penalty for a wide range of offenses under the heading of "sabotage."

Miss Mary Ellen Newman was married yesterday afternoon to James Richard Kaufman in the home of her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Lloyd Newman of 125 East Seventy-second Street. The bridegroom is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert E. Kaufman of Miami, Fla. The Rev. Dr. Nathan A. Perilman of Temple Emanu-El performed the ceremony.
TOKYO, May 20 (AP)--The Moscow radio charged today that Japan had become "a catspaw of American generals," in view of the deployment to Thailand of United States forces based in Japan.

PORT CHESTER, N.Y., May 20--Mrs. Alice Sweeney Mergenthaler, wife of Herman C. Mergenthaler, the son of Ottmar Mergenthaler, inventor of the linotype machine, died today in United Hospital. She was 75 years old.
The decorative arts collection of Cooper Union has been for more than half a century a prime source for students and professionals of interior design.
The Norwegians, a people used to the cool fjords of the North, matched in their woolens here yesterday in weather that was strictly Mediterranean.

FOR the better part of five years, the Chicago Cubs muddled along in the hinterlands without ever subjecting themselves to the critical gaze of New York observers. Considering the way they played ball, this was not deemed too unendurable a loss. Other National League clubs were seen in spring training, in world series or during excursions to Philadelphia. But the Cubs weren't worth even a trip to Philadelphia.
RANGOON, Burma, May 20 --Prince Souvanna Phouma, the Laotian neutralist leader, said on his arrival here today: "I hope you will soon hear good news regarding my country."

SANDS POINT, L.I., May 20 --At her parents' home here this afternoon Miss Leslie Koeppel, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Koeppel, became the bride of Bernard Liflander. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. E. Phillip Liflander. Rabbi Kenneth Stein performed the ceremony.

A number of African students will get on-the-job training this summer in fifteen basic American industries, all similar to the ones being set up in their native lands. The program is a joint project of the Africa Service Institute, 480 Lexington Avenue, and the Business and Industry Development Company of Washington, D.C.
President Kennedy announced yesterday that Grand Duchess Charlotte of Luxembourg had accepted his invitation to make an official visit to the United States next fall.
LONDON, May 20 (AP)-- An apology went out from Scotland today for the use of Mrs. John F. Kennedy's signed photograph in a pamphlet publicizing Scottish tweed.

ROME, May 20--The foreign tourists who crowd Rome found an added sight-seeing lure today in the outdoor political rallies throughout the city. More than 100 meetings today, all full of sound and some with fury, opened the campaign for the June 10 municipal elections.

WASHINGTON, May 20-- Twenty years ago in New York three young men were convicted of murder during a robbery and sentenced to Life imprisonment. The only evidence against them were the confessions that each had given the police.

Goldman Builders, Inc., of Union, N.J., has bought a tract of land with 100,000 square feet on North Middletown Road in Pearl River, Rockland County. The land was sold by Hugh Fraser through Milton Goldsmith, broker, of Hackensack, N.J.
WARREN RUBIN, economist, and Richard Artschwager, bacteriological chemist, met in New York a half dozen years ago. The result was a store that sells modern furniture.
LONDON, May 20--A dozen British mothers and two children staged a two-hour sitdown in front of the United States Embassy in Grosvenor Square today to protest nuclear testing.
ALGIERS, May 20--French authorities established an emergency airlift today to evacuate Europeans from this terror-ridden city.
CAIRO, May 20--President Gamal Abdel Nasser convenes a National Congress of Popular Forces here tomorrow to make his "Arab socialism" the official will of the Egyptian people.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 20 --Pseudolus, the Roman slave, took a deliberate detour on "the way to the forum" today to titillate an audience at Harvard University.
WASHINGTON, May 20 (UPI)--Senate investigators have quietly arranged to examine the income tax files of Billy Sol Estes, informed sources said today.
CLIFTON, N.J., May 21 (AP The Rizzuto-Berra bowling alley in the Styretown Shopping Center has been sold to Lence, Inc., of New York.
HOUSTON, May 21 The New York Met's gay dash through the West ran out of gas tonight as the Houston Colts brought down Casey Stengel's hopefuls, 3 2, in the opener of a two-game series before 16,317.

This is Mailbox Improvement Week, one of the few designated weeks which will find Manhattan residents sitting on... Mailbox which will find Manhat tan residents sitting on the sidelines, watching it go by. Manhattan has no mailboxes that need improvement, for the simple reason that it has no roadside boxes, which are those under discussion.

BERLIN, May 21 West Berlin's industrial production rose by 9 per cent last year despite the closing of the border by the Communists and the loss of East German workers, the Chamber for Industry and Commerce said in its annual report today.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, May 21 (AP)--Six Americans have reached the finals of Belgium's International Singing Contest. They will compete with six singers from other countries Wednesday, Thursday and Friday at the Brussels Opera House.
RAWALPINDI, Pakistan May 21 (UPI) A daughter of President Mohammed Ayub Khan was married yesterday to the son of the Wali of Swat.
TRENTON, May 21 The State Supreme Court upheld today, for the second time in two years, the constitutionality of the state law barring discrimination in the sale of publicly financed housing.
The Clark State Bank of Clark, N.J., declared an initial dividend of 10 cents on the common yesterday, payable June 4 to holders of record of May 28.
LENINGRAD, May 21 (AP) The world record-holder in the high jump, Valeri Brumel, was defeated today for the first time since the 1960 Olympics when 23-year-old Viktor Bolshov jumped 6 feet 9 inches.

Several thousand persons attended the "$howcase of Stars" at the City, Center of Music and Drama last night. They saw Mrs. Ruth Houghton Axe receive the Joey Award as Woman of the Year of the Children's Asthma Research Institute and Hospital in Denver, beneficiary of the event.

Gustave G. Rosenberg, chairman of the Board of Higher Education, predicted last night that the City University would have to double its capacity for full-time undergraduate students in the next fifteen years.
WASHINGTON, May 21 President Kennedy asked 250 business, labor and academic leaders today to forget their preconceptions and to talk about economic issues as they really are.
LAGOS, Nigeria, May 21 Samuel L. Akintola, Premier of Western Nigeria, has been dismissed from office.

ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L.I., May 21--Mrs. Thomas Kielty has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Mary Jane Kielty, to William Merrell Stott. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. William G. Stott of Scarsdale, N.Y.

WILLEMSTAD, Curacao, May 21 A blunder in a winning position in the twelfth round against Bobby Fischer of the United States yesterday cost Victor Korchnoi of the Soviet Union the lead in the Candidates' Chess Tournament. With a pawn ahead in a King's Indian Defense lasting fortyfour moves, Korchnoi overlooked a piece and lost the game.

CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., May 21 (AP)--Thursday's scheduled orbital flight of Lieut. Comdr. M. Scott Carpenter, delayed for days by technical problems, may run afoul of a more natural menace--swamp forest fires.
LONDON, May 21 South African gold mining shares rose sharply again on the stock market on speculation that the dollar price of gold would be raised. In the other sections business was small.
PHILADELPHIA, May 21--President Felix Houphouet Boigny of the Republic of Ivory Coast, received an honorary degree of doctor of laws at the University of Pennsylvania's 206th commencement today.
FRANKLIN, Tex., May 21 (AP) A state judge ordered today that the body of Henry Marshall be disinterred to determine whether his death by shooting had been murder or suicide.

THERE seemed to be an extraordinary rapport be tween performer and audience last night at the Stage 73, where Sheila Barrett, who once earned the sobriquet of the "acidulous impressionist," returned to the stage after an absence of many years.
WASHINGTON, May 21 (UPI)--The Supreme Court reversed the contempt conviction today of a Toledo lawyer who was punished for advising his client to disobey a state judge's order.
Johnny Rotz, who rode Greek Money to a nose victory over Ridan in last Saturday's Preakness, probably will not appear at a hearing on Wednesday in Maryland in connection with the race.

BONN, Germany, May 21 President Kennedy has renewed his assurances to Chancellor Adenauer that West Germany's interests will be safeguarded in the talks between the United States and the Soviet Union on the Berlin and German problems.
ATLANTA, May 21 A threejudge Federal court was told today that Georgia's urban areas were powerless to obtain fair representation in the state legislature without the court's help.
FORT HOOD, Tex., May 21 (UPI) An M-48 tank on maneuvers plunged off a thirtyfoot cliff today, landed upside down and burned for more than an hour. Five men were trapped inside and died.

PARIS, May 21--The defense sought to establish today that former Premier Michel Debre had tried to block the trial of six men accused of an attempt in 1957 against the life of Raoul Salan, then the commanding general in Algeria.
GETTYSBURG, Pa., May 21--Former President Dwight D. Eisenhower underscored today his opposition to President Kennedy's medical care plan.
WASHINGTON, May 21 The Senate Foreign Relations Committee rejected today a planned $90,000,000 increase in new foreign-aid funds for India.
THE following dinner menu is given as a guide to the use of foods that are reasonable in cost. A recipe is offered for an easy-to-prepare main dish.

This is no time to cut the basic forty-hour work week. But despite President Kennedy's sound arguments to this effect, union pressure for shorter hours is likely to continue until the unemployment rolls shrink appreciably. The recent action of such a responsible union as the Amalgamated Clothing Workers in ignoring the White House and demanding a thirty-five-hour schedule is evidence of widespread worry over job security.
JACKSON, Miss., May 21 (UPI) Fifteen Episcopal ministers, including a son-in-law of Governor Rockefeller of New York, were cleared today of breach-of-peace charges.

Traffic Commissioner Henry A. Barnes said yesterday that if the Police Department were to enforce parking regulations rigidly, "there'd be a tremendous howl" from merchants, apartment house dwellers and others.
President Kennedy praised Representative Charles A. Buckley of the Bronx last night for "firm and consistent" support of national Administration programs.
The New York Life Insurance company yesterday announced the appointment of R. Manning Brown Jr., Raymond C. Johnson and Charles W.V. Meares as executive vice presidents.
The eight waiters whose discharge touched off a two-day wildcat strike at the WaldorfAstoria Hotel last week were reinstated yesterday.
Cardinal Spellman dedicated a new residence for nurses, internes and resident doctors of St. Vincent's Hospital yesterday afternoon.
Rogers Hammond Bacon, a member of the law firm of Saxe, Bacon O'Shea here, died yesterday in St. Luke's Hospital after a brief illness. He was 88 years old and a resident of the University Club.

Gross revenues of Northwest Airlines, Inc., are expected to increase 10 per cent this year over the $123,361,479 volume of 1960, Donald W. Nyrop, president, reported to shareholders yesterday at the annual meeting in Minneapolis.

Addressed economic conference sponsored by Labor Department; met with American Bar Association officers and board of governors; met twenty-five Japanese prefectural governors; saw Maurice M. Bernbaum, Ambassador to Ecuador; asked Congress for $210,800,000 more for A.E.C.; nominated John T. McNaughton as general counsel of Defense Department.

First-quarter net income of the Household Finance Corporation amounted to $7,160,973. Including $220,783 income from its non-consolidated merchandising subsidiary, Coast-toCoast Stores, Inc., the total net income for the 1962 quarter was $7,381,756 equal to 74 cents a common share.
Recognition for many contributions to merchant marine welfare will be given today to Senator Warren G. Magnuson in a ceremony at the White House.
Rubin Carter, the explosive middleweight from Paterson, scored a technical knockout over Sugar Boy Nando last night in the third round of a scheduled ten-round fight at St. Nicholas Arena.
The first brownstone to be rehabilitated by the city for lowrent public housing was dedicated yesterday, two years after the rehabilitation program was started.

"Advise and Consent," the drama produced and directed by Otto Preminger from the Pulitzer Prize novel by Allen Drury, will have a preview benefit showing on Tuesday night, June 5, at the Criterion Theatre. Proceeds of the screening will go to the National Association for Mental Health and the National Multiple Sclerosis Society.
WASHINGTON, May 21 A Department of Agriculture employe who has charged that Billie Sol Estes received favored treatment on Federal cotton allotments told his story to Senate investigators today.
Muriel Strickland, soprano, appeared in a debut concert at Carnegie Recital Hall last night. Her program included songs and arias by Handel, Mozart, Cadman, La Forge and F. Flaxington Harker.

YONKERS, May 21 A crowd of 24,585 harness racing fans turned out tonight for the opening of the sixty-two-night spring meeting at Yonkers Raceway. The fact that no big-name horses were on the opening card was hardly a deterrent.
NEW DELHI, India, May 20 "I have dreamed of meeting the King of Kings of India," said the Sikh in the blue turban to the philosopher in the white turban. "Now my dream is fulfilled."
Mayor Wagner signed three local laws yesterday dealing with meat-grinding and tax revenues.

The Realty Equities Corporation, a real estate company, has subleased part of a floor in the Time Life Building, Avenue of the Americas (Sixth Avenue) and Fiftieth Street, from the American Cyanamid Corporation. Realty Equities will move from 666 Fifth Avenue on July 1. The sublease was negotiated by Sumner Baum of Collins, Tuttle Co., broker. J. Jacques Junker of Cushman Wakefield, Inc., represented American Cyanamid.

CHICAGO, May 21 (UPI) Five brotherhoods of railroad operating employes asked the National Mediation Board today to enter the dispute between the unions and the nation's railroads over proposed changes in work rules.
CAIRO, May 21 President Gamal Abdel Nasser called tonight for a new constitution guaranteeing "social justice" in the United Arab Republic.

Mr. and Mrs. J.L. Daniels of Hornchurch, Essex, England, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Valerie Daniels, to William Kroehle Dabney, son of Mrs. Lewis Stuyvesant Chanler of Rhinebeck, N.Y., and John Carpenter Dabney of Delray Beach, Fla., formerly of New York.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 21 (AP) The New Haven Railroad won Federal Court permission today to sell 300 boxcars that it says it doesn't need.

Four unemployed men arrived here early yesterday morning on bus tickets paid by the Montgomery, Ala., Citizens Council. None of the social agencies pledged to assist such persons was aware of the men's arrival. Their whereabouts was unknown last night.

Good reports on the progress that Mickey Mantle is making in recuperating from a torn thigh muscle were tempered yesterday by the announcement that the Yankees had placed Luis Arroyo, their omnipotent left-handed relief pitcher, on the disabled list.

CAMDEN, N.J., May 21 Msgr. Arthur D. Hassett, pastor of St. John's Roman Catholic Church in Collingswood for thirty years before his retirement in 1960, died today in Our Lady of Lourdes Hospital. He was 85 years old.
For the first time, landlords rewiring rent-controlled apartments will have to put electrical outlets in each rooom to qualify for rent increases.

TOKYO, May 21 (UPI) President Sukarno of Indonesia ordered United Press International today to suspend its operations in Indonesia temporarily. No official reason was given for the suspension order against the news agency.
A NEW book by Fred Karpin of Washington, "How to Play (and Misplay) Slam Contracts," previously forecast here, was published last week by Harper Bros.
ANNOUNCER The views expressed on the following program are those of the sponsor, the American Medical Association.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., May 21 Harry R. Patten of Mount Dora, Fla., who was formerly active in the civic affairs of Westchester County, died today in New Rochelle Hospital after a long illness. His age was 89. He maintained a summer home at 31 Oak Avenue, Larchmont.

PHILADELPHIA, May 21 George W. Blabon 3d, clubman and heir to a Philadelphia linoleum fortune, died Saturday in Palm Beach, Fla., at the age of 62. He had homes in suburban Bryn Mawr and in Palm Beach.
WASHINGTON, May 21 (UPI) The Supreme Court agreed today to examine the Government's contention that the merger of two large banks in Philadelphia would violate Federal antitrust laws.
ROME, May 21 Gen. Alessandro Pirzio Piroli, former military commander of Montenegro, died yesterday at Celio Military Hospital in Rome. He was 84 years old.
A nitrous oxide explosion at a bottled-gas plant in Brooklyn injured six men yesterday morning, none seriously.
WASHINGTON, May 21 (UPI) Camilo Pascual pitched and batted his way to his sixth victory of the season tonight as the Minnesota Twins beat the Washington Senators, 5 3.
Four New Yorkers and three New Jersey residents have been named winners of three-year scholarships at the New York University School of Law.

CLEVELAND, May 21 (UPI) John Romano's three-run homer with two out in the ninth inning gave the Cleveland Indians a 10-7 victory over the Baltimore Orioles tonight. It also enabled the Tribe to take sole possession of first place in the American League.

The discounts at which the pound sterling are sold for forward delivery narrowed further yestreday on the New York foreign exchange market, giving rise to the belief that the expected new reduction in the British bank rate might be forthcoming this week.

WASHINGTON, May 21 In his passionate advocacy of the intact King-Anderson bill for a compulsory system of Government health insurance for citizens over 65 years of age President Kennedy complained that much of the opposition to this measure was created by "misinformation." But to his elderly audience in Madison Square Garden yesterday the President contributed to the misinformation he was attacking.

TOKYO, May 21 (AP) Prince Souphanouvong welcomed today negotiations for a coalition government for Laos. However, the pro-Communist leader took a tough stand toward the pro-Western Government in Vientiane.

LOS ANGELES, May 21 (AP) Sandy Koufax scored his fifth victory with a five-hitter and Tom Davis drove in three runs with a homer and double tonight as the Los Angeles Dodgers defeated the leagueleading San Francisco Giants, 8-1. A crowd of 45,192 watched the game.

Pauley Petroleum, Inc., Los Angeles, Calif., has announced the sale to the Continental Oil Company of one-half of its Mexican oil and gas interests. The consideration was reported at about $15,000,000, but the exact amount will not be fixed until after an audit of the properties and equipment.
BALTIMORE, May 21 (UPI)--A Federal judge ruled today that the National Football League did not have a monopoly in professional football.

THE Miami physician chosen by the American Medical Association to reply last night to President Kennedy on the issue of medical care for the aged decided when he was not quite 6 years old to become a doctor.
WASHINGTON, May 21 Treasury bill rates rose on today's sale of the regular weekly issues from the 1962 lows to which they had fallen last week.
WASHINGTON, May 21 The Supreme Court set aside today the contempt convictions of six men who refused to answer questions of Congressional committees relating to communism.
PARIS, May 21 To judge by the fairly typical examples of two Frenchmen, there is far more good than bad about American export prospects in the European Common Market.

In whatever country, and in whatever language, the loss of an only son is one of the saddest of bereavements. U Thant as Acting Secretary General of the United Nations has his exacting day-by-day problems when he deals with the affairs of 104 nations. Yesterday news came to him that Tin Maung, 21 years old, planning to leave Rangoon University to come back to New York, had lost his life in a bus accident.

Supporters of the New York Diabetes Association have arranged a theatre party at next Monday's performance of "Bravo Giovanni" at the Broadhurst Theatre. Proceeds will go to the association's Camp Nyda at Burlingham, N.Y.
GENEVA, May 21 The assembly of the United Nations World Health Organization ap proved today a working budget of $29,956,000 for 1963, an increase of $4,463,370 over 1962.
NAKHON RATCHASIMA, Thailand, May 21 (AP) Lieut. Gen. James L. Richardson Jr., commander of the growing United States force in Thailand, plans to set up his headquarters under canvas here tomorrow.
WASHINGTON, May 21 Flight engineers employed on Pan American World Airways jets would, under an arbitration board finding handed down today, have to acquire some pilot qualifications.

A young and pretty out-oftown visitor shared the spotlight yesterday with highranking Navy, Coast Guard and Army officers when the American Merchant Marine Library Association opened its eighteenth annual spring book drive at Rockefeller Center.
PARIS, May 21 A plot to assassinate President de Gaulle was reported today to have been foiled by the police.
COTILLION ROOM, Pierre Hotel, Fifth Avenue and Sixty-first Street. Patricia Bright, comedienne; Ruth Harrison and Alex Fisher, dance satirists.
A 26-year-old Brooklyn hoodlum accused of killing two police detectives here last Friday was arrested without a struggle yesterday afternoon in a motel near Chicago.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 21 Stanislavsky has become the patron saint of Japan's stage actors, according to Eiji Okada, best known to Americans for his starring role in "Hiroshima, Mon Amour."

YONKERS, May 21 Traffic outside the Yonkers Raceway moved much slower than the trotters inside at times tonight because of a strike by twentysix policeman who want more money for directing the vehicles of track fans.
Chambishi Mines, Ltd., will begin this year to develop the Chambishi copper property in Northern Rhodesia, some twenty miles from Mufulira, in a $21,000,000, program, it was disclosed here yesterday.

HONG KONG, May 21 The colony's efforts to stem the flow of refugees took on new urgency today with the announcement that Hong Kong had less than a one-month supply of water, as a result of prolonged drought.

A suggestion that a Federal Court of Appeals judge may have been approached by someone interested in a case before him was made yesterday in Federal Court. It came during the trial of State Supreme Court Justice J. Vincent Keogh and two others on a charge of conspiracy to obstruct justice.

GARRISON, N.Y., May 21 Mrs. Joseph F. Haskell of Garrison and Mr. Haskell of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter Miss Janet Haskell, to Pvt. Edward John Manning of the Army. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Sherman Brown Manning of White River Junction Vt.
WASHINGTON, May 21 (AP) Democratic women gathered today to criticize the Republi cans, hail the Administration and predict victories next fall.

The American Medical Association fired a television salvo last night against President Kennedy's program for medical care for the elderly through Social Security. It urged the defeat of the plan in Congress as "a cruel hoax and a delusion."
Dr. Arthur Dickson, Emeritus Professor of English at City College, was found dead yesterday, apparently of a heart attack, in his home at 301 West 108th Street. He was 72 years old.

EAST ORANGE, N.J., May 21 Dr. Charles Frederick Rathgeber, a physician here for fiftythree years, died today at Presbyterian Hospital in Newark, after a long illness. He was 77 years old. His home and office were at 18 William Street.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange were 25 cents a bale up to 5 cents off yesterday.

Successive dead heats for place marked the first two races. The winners were Dicky Dean ($25.60) in the first and Hoot Colby ($10.60), who accounted for a daily double return of $81.20 on program numbers 2-1.
Three thoroughbreds eligible for the $100,000 added Metropolitan Handicap on Memorial Day ran yesterday in the featured $10,000 Herodian Purse at Aqueduct.
The Kings Highway Chapter of Cancer Care will give its annual donor luncheon Saturday at the St. Regis Roof.
Daniel Lawrence Lyons, chief turf editor of The Morning Telegraph and The Daily Racing Form since 1944, died yesterday of a heart attack at French Hospital. He was 74 years old.

The National Broadcasting Company said yesterday it still planned to televise "The Inferno," a documentary about a small slum in Palermo, Sicily. There had been reports that the program was withdrawn for various reasons, including the alleged protests from official Italian sources.

BEING an extroverted young man who prefers the bizarre to the commonplace, Robert (Bo) Belinsky discov ered himself last winter in Venezuela, of all places. He is now convinced that this was the most important thing to happen to South America since Simon Bolivar.

Stocks were pounded yesterday in a decidedly inactive session of the New York Stock Exchange. Most groups showed some resistance, with motors, tires and oils displaying the greatest strength, but steels, tobaccos and electronics gave way rather easily.
TARTU, Estonia, May 15 The rector of Tartu University in Soviet Estonia smiled when asked about "Russification" of the student body and curriculum.
CHARLESTON, S.C., May 21 (AP) At least two merchants have hired Negroes since the start of picketing and calls for a boycott against downtown stores eight weeks ago.

WASHINGTON, May 21 (AP) Senators Kenneth B. Keating and Winston L. Prouty, both Republicans, introduced bills today to end what they said was discrimination against private school teachers in the National Defense Education Act.
WASHINGTON, May 21 Dr. E. Franklin Frazier, a sociologist who concerned himself with Negro problems, died here Thursday after a long illness. He was 67 years old.
DETROIT, May 21 (AP) Although auto sales figures continue to flirt with the records set in 1955, production in the first half of this year apparently is destined to be only third best.

THE first two terms of President Franklin D. Roosevelt were the subject of a program entitled "F.D.R.: "The Voice of Change," seen last night over Channel 9. There was undeniable interest in the selection of newsreel clippings of the past, and the presentation left no doubt that Mr. Roosevelt would have been a superb TV campaigner.

Ruby Goldstein, the referee, testified here yesterday as to his actions and thoughts during the world welterweight title fight in Madison Square Garden on March 24 in which Benny (Kid) Paret of Cuba was fatally hurt. Paret, knocked out in the twelfth round by Emile Griffith of New York, died on April 3 without having regained consciousness.

TRENTON, May 21 The State Assembly voted and sent to Gov. Richard J. Hughes today a bill that would substitute a paid director for the five-man nonsalaried state commission on legalized games of chance.

WASHINGTON, May 21 The Republican national chairman today denounced Sunday's Administration-sponsored demonstrations for the medical care bill as "downright deceptive" of the nation's 17,000,000 citizens over 65 years of age.

LONDON, May 21 A Foreign Office spokesman said today that the Chinese Commu nist Ministry of Foreign Affairs had indicated an "awareness" of the problem created by the thousands of Chinese refugees now flooding into Hong Kong.
The seven-day-old strike of about 750 deck scow captains against the Harbor Carriers of the Port of New York ended yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 21 (AP) The Supreme Court was asked today to affirm immediately a decision handed down on April 28 by a lower Federal court that said that Georgia's county unit election system violated the Federal Constitution.
George P. Connor, an antiques dealer and appraiser, died yesterday at Lawrence Hospital, Bronxville, N.Y. He was 51 years old and lived at 24 Day Street, Clifton, N.J.

The Soviet Union is sending an eight-oared crew to row in the Independence Day regatta at Philadelphia. But the two fastest varsity sprint crews in the East--Yale and Pennsylvania--may both go to Henley, England, in preference to racing the Russians.
TRENTON, May 21 The state Supreme Court ruled today that the producer of the rocket engine for the 4,000-milean-hour X-15 aircraft was liable for property damage caused in testing the engine.
BOSTON, May 21 (UPI) Home runs by the pitcher, Jerry Walker, and the catcher, Jose Azeue, led the eighth-place Kansas City Athletics to a 10-5 victory over the ninth-place Boston Red Sox tonight.
NORTH BALDWIN, L.I., May 21 Miss Carol Anne Armbruster and Rudolph L. Griebel plan to be married.
PECOS, Tex., May 20 "Nothing Derogatory About Estes Grain Storage Found in All Probing." "Political Hacks Keep Up Struggle for Headlines."

WASHINGTON, May 21 Senator Paul H. Douglas said today that the proposed withholding of income taxes on dividends could recover 80 per cent of $1,100,000,000 now lost annually by the Treasury through non-payment. And, he said, it could do so "simply and without undue hardship."
MONTICELLO, N.Y., May 21--Governor Rockefeller pledged tonight his continuing support of measures needed by the police to combat crime.

The B.F. Goodrich Company has announced plans for the construction of two major distribution centers in Mariners Harbor, S.I. Construction will begin within 30 days and completion is expected early in 1963.

AKRON, Ohio, May 21 (AP) Edward O. Lamb of Toledo today successfully completed a six-year fight to take over control of the Seiberling Rubber Company. He gained a majority on the board of directors at the annual shareholders' meeting.
Business men seem to be growing increasingly fretful about the rising cost of advertising.
WASHINGTON, May 21 Rex L. Nicholson, the controversial special assistant to Fowler Hamilton, foreign aid administrator, has resigned.
A dispute between Fire Commissioner Edward Thompson and his deputy, Ralph G. Ortiz, was resolved in a two-and-ahalf-hour City Hall conference that ended shortly before 1 A.M. today.

City Magistrate Walter J. Bayer yesterday found three defendants guilty of disorderly conduct in connection with a demonstration in Times Square on March 3 against the resumption of nuclear testing by the United States.

A motion picture projector has been delivered as a gift to a high school in India after a three-year effort by a Brooklyn group. The projector was finally presented on April, 16, it was learned, here yesterday.

JERSEY CITY, May 21 Charles C. Colgan, formerly deputy register of Hudson County and a member of the New Jersey Assembly, died yesterday in St. Francis Hospital. He was 69 years old and lived at 337 York Street.
The marriage of Miss Rona Wolch, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Isadore Wolch of Winnipeg Man., to Ralph I. Brown, son of Mr. and Mrs. David H. Brown of Forest Hills, Queens, took place here last evening.

A man died of a heart attack after being thrown against a stone wall yesterday by three thugs who robbed him of $22 on Central Park West at Seventy-seventh Street. All three were arrested, the police said, and admitted the attack.

PARIS, May 21 The first serious business in the French tennis championships started today. Almost forty matches were scheduled at Roland Garros Stadium. However, the tournament actually started last week with an elimination round made necessary by nearly 300 entrants.
TEL AVIV, Israel, May 21 The assignment of a United States Foreign Service official here was cut short today after the missing head of a Roman statue had been found in his possession.

Today, National Maritime Day, is customarily accepted in the various allied maritime industries as an opportunity to weigh woes against achievements and future prospects. Many leaders in the industries are already complaining that...
WASHINGTON, May 21 (UPI) An objection by Representative John V. Lindsay blocked House passage today of a bill to tighten security rules on industrial handling of defense secrets.
EAST ORANGE, N.J., May 21 John S. Clarke, a retired executive of the Walworth Company of New York, manufacturers of valves, died today at his home, 91 Prospect Street, after a brief illness.

PITTSBURGH, May 21 (UPI) Dick Groat and Bill Virdon made four hits apiece tonight and paced the Pittsburgh Pirates to an 8-4 victory over the Chicago Cubs. Tom Sturdivant's scoreless relief pitching also played an important part in the triumph.

WASHINGTON, May 21 (AP) Joseph A. Ewing, who on May 1 was appointed director of the field operations division of the Department of Agriculture's statistical reporting service, died Saturday night of a heart attack. He was 59 years old.
The wholesale commodity price index fell to 82.1 Friday from 82.2 Thursday. The index, compiled by the Bureau of Labor Statistics, stood at 86.9 on May 15, 1961.

HOUSTON, Tex., May 21--The leaders of maritime unions were told tonight to come up with some answers to the shipping industry's labor problems "before they strangle the goose that lays the golden egg."

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. George A. Stern of 117 East Seventy-second Street and Stamford, Conn., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Faith Jane Stern, to Lawrence A. Levine. He is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis E. Levine of 60 Sutton Place South.
TAIPEI, Taiwan, May 21 Nationalist China offered today to help solve the refugee problem in the British colony of Hong Kong, saying it was ready to accept all refugees...
RIO DE JANEIRO, May 21 The Brazilian Government adopted monetary measures today to end some of the inflationary pressure from loose money and credit.

WASHINGTON, May 21 (AP) The Supreme Court decided today that Federal regulations on United States Savings bonds purchased in co-ownership form give a survivor the right to ownership, regardless of state community-property laws.

CHICAGO, May 21 (AP) Wheat futures maintained a firm range in active dealings today on the Board of Trade although most interest in commodities was toward eveningup positions in the expiring May contracts.

PARIS, May 21 George W. Ball, Under Secretary of State, conferred today with the French Foreign Minister, Maurice Couve de Murville, primarily on the application of Britain to join the European Economic Community, or the Common Market.
ALGIERS, May 21 The European exodus from Algiers continued today with about 2,000 departures, most of them by ship.

The Little Orchestra Society will give no subscription series at Town Hall next season for the first time in fifteen years. The society's conductor, Thomas Scherman, has other chores with the society, and as musical director of the newly formed Concert Opera Association.

FOR many years a tray of bread sticks has been as much a fixture as salt and pepper shakers on tables of Italian restaurants here. In the past it was necessary to go to a bakery that specialized in Italian products to find them for home use. Now, however, those long crisp sticks that Italians call grissini are offered in virtually every food store.

HONG KONG, May 21 (Reuters) Communist China has lodged a "serious protest" with India, against a "grave violation" of Chinese territory by Indian troops, Hsinhua, the Chinese Communist press agency, said today.
HYANNIS, Mass., May 21 (AP) A Cape Cod spokesman today accused Southern segregationists of "duping" with "an indecent lie" a new group of Negroes being sent here.
Steel production last week slid below 60 per cent of capacity for the first time in more than a year.

Frank Budd of Villanova will be "fit and ready" for the defense of his 100 and 220 yard dash crowns Saturday in the Intercollegiate Association of Amateur Athletes of America outdoor track and field championships at Villanova.

President Kennedy opened the White House Conference on National Economic Issues yesterday with an appeal to management and labor to forget partisan slogans and come forward with creative ideas for cooperation to advance the national welfare. The initial responses offer little encouragement that much of real use will emerge from the two-day session.
Park Commissioner Newbold Morris disclosed yesterday that he was abandoning temporarily a major land-acquisition program on the Bronx waterfront because of public pressure.
WASHINGTON, May 21 John K. Carlock of the Treasury Department received today the Tom C. Clark award given annually to an outstanding career Government lawyer.

Probably no one has campaigned harder for share ownership by the small investor than the New York Stock Exchange. Its theme has been "own your share in American business," but more than that it has stressed the importance to democracy of small shareholders.
WASHINGTON, May 21 (UPI) Officials of the State of Washington and Texas complained today that the National Association of Securities Dealers refused to help them.
PHILADELPHIA, May 21 (UPI) James R. Hoffa charged today the Kennedy Administration was waging a "vendetta" against him to cover up the Estes case, unemployment and the Laos crisis.
THE HAGUE, May 21 (Reuters) The Government has called on U Thant, United Nations Acting Secretary General, to urge Indonesia to stop "all aggressive action against Netharlands New Guinea."
ROME, May 21 A nationwide school strike and a wave of other labor conflicts are causing embarrassment for the Center Left Government of Premier Amintore Fanfani.

The Chinese Nationalist Government's announcement that it will accept any of the refugees from Communist China now pouring into Hong Kong who want to go to Taiwan is certain to have far-reaching repercussions. It may, for one thing, mean such a propaganda loss of face for Peiping that the Chinese Communists will take drastic steps to stem the flow.
WASHINGTON, May 21 (AP) The Securities and Exchange Commission today blocked the proposed sale of stock by three companies.
BUENOS AIRES, May 21 The President of Argentina's Chamber of Deputies, Olegario Becerra, denounced today the Government decree that has recessed Congress.
GENEVA, May 21 The United States said today that a disarmed world was unattainable without stronger international arrangements to settle disputes peacefully.
HONG KONG, May 21 (AP) Angry Chinese villagers thrust their children into the path of a truck convoy today to try to halt the forced repatriation of refugees to Communist China.

RANGOON, Burma, May 21 Tin Maung Thant, the only son of U Thant, Acting Secretary General of the United Nations, died here today of brain injuries after he fell from a moving bus. He was 21 years old.

ANTITRUST LAW Agreed to review a Phila delphia District Court's decision that the merger of two banks into one having about a third of the area's banking business did not violate Section 1 of the Sherman Act or Section 7 of the Clayton Act (No. 799, U.S. v. Philadelphia National Bank).
HONOLULU, May 21 (AP) A flight of fifty-two jet fighterbombers, tankers and turbo-prop cargo planes left Hickham Air Force Base here today for Clark Field in the Philippines, the Air Force reported.

DAR-ES-SALAAM, Tanganyika, May 21 (UPI) The Government has announced it will start negotiations with the Italian state-owned oil company, Ente Nazionale Idrocarburi (E.N.I.) on construction of an $11,200,000 oil refinery designed to have the capacity to supply the entire Tanganyika market.
The man lay rigid and unconscious on the stretcher, legs stiffly extended, jaws tightly shut, fists clenched, one eye pupil dilated abronmally, chest heaving with labored breathing.
EAST HAMPTON, L.I., May 21 Four airmen were killed here early today when their car Struck a tree. All were stationed at the Suffolk County Air Force Base in Westhampton Beach.

Stockholders of the Associated Dry Goods Corporation at their annual meeting yesterday in Richmond, Va., approved a two-for-one split of the common stock. The record and distribution dates are expected to be announced soon.

LONDON, May 21 (AP) Dr. John Seale, 34 years old, said tonight that he assumed he was the man President Kennedy meant when he said yesterday that an English physician was going to speak out against the President's plans on medical care for the aged.
WASHINGTON, May 21 (AP) President Kennedy asked Congress today to appropriate additional money to help cover the costs of nuclear weapons tests and to produce nuclear weapons.
PRINK HILL. TO be outdoors this month is to be at the center of great expectations. Everything in the natural world begins the fresh and tidy season by assuming complete success.

GLYNDEBOURNE, England, May 21 (Reuters) The Glyndebourne Festival Opera paid homake to Claude Debussy tonight when it opened its 1962 season with a new production of "Pelleas et Melisande," by Carl Ebert, to mark the centenary of the French composer's birth.
LONDON, May 21 Bishop Eric Knightley Chetwode Hamilton, Dean of Windsor and Domestic Chaplain to Queen Elizabeth II, died today of a heart attack at Windsor. His age was 71.
A strike by the Seafarers International Union against Moore-McCormack Lines may inconvenience 363 cruise passengers tomorrow.

Events tonight: Music from Marlboro, presented by the Marlboro School of Music, Carnegie Hall, 8:30; Chase Manhattan Bank Choral Club, Ken Thompson, conductor, Town Hall, 8:15; Concert of contemporary chamber music, Carnegie Recital Hall, 8:30.

The Board of Education, holding its first capital budget hearings since its appointment last fall, received advice yesterday on how to improve the school building program from some veterans of such proceedings.
WASHINGTON, May 21 (AP) John T. McNaughton of Cambridge, Mass., was nominated by President Kennedy today to be general counsel of the Defense Department.

HOLLANDIA, Netherlands New Guinea, May 21 (AP)--The Dutch sent reinforcements today to the western tip of Netherlands New Guinea in an attempt to bottle up 120 Indonesians who were dropped by parachute last week-end.

THE HAGUE, the Netherland, May 21 The Soviet Union and the United States presented arguments before the International Court of Justice concerning the obligation of United Nation members to pay for the peace-keeping operations in the Congo and the Middle East.
Benjamin D. Chamberlin, headmaster emeritus of the McBurney School, died in St. Vincent's Hospital yesterday after a long illness. He was 59 years old.

Dr. Kurt Kersten, a staff member of Aufbau, Germanlanguage weekly, and author of several German and Russian histories, died Friday after a long illness in St. Luke's Hospital. He was 71 years old and lived at 1050 Amsterdam Avenue.

SAIGON, Vietnam, May 21 (AP) A Communist guerrilla village near the mouth of the Mekong River delta fell today to an attack by two South Vietnamese companies supported by United States Army helicopters. The bulk of the guerrillas escaped.
MOST little girls have been taught by their parents to take the tangles out of their hair, but as they grow up they are putting the tangles right back, in the process known as teasing.

Two landscapes by Francesco Guardi will go on display at the Metropolitan Museum of Art today. They belong to a series of three "Fantastic Landscapes" by the eighteenth-century Italian painter, The third has been in the museum for twenty years.
CHICAGO, May 21 (UPI) The Detroit Tigers thwarted Early Wynn's attempt for his 295th pitching victory with five runs in the first inning tonight and beat the Chicago White Sox, 7 3.
NEW YORK, May 21 Strong activity in cocoa fu tures marked trading on the New York markets yesterday. Other commodities were generally lower.
WASHINGTON, May 21 Senator Stuart Symington proposed some shortcuts today in disposing of stockpile surpluses.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 21 Aches, pains and illness have bothered Joe Joseph and Billy Golembiewski considerably in recent weeks. Nevertheless, those two took the top awards in bowling in the past four weeks, including $24,500 in prize money during the last four days.
The stockholders and management of Technicolor, Inc., staged a feature-length production at the company's annual meeting here yesterday.
June Havoc said yesterday that she had decided not to go ahead with plans for a production of her play with music, "Marathon '33," on Broadway next season.
Reactions to the latest proposal to aid the ailing Eastern railroads ranged yesterday from "nonsense" to "it rings a bell."

WASHINGTON, May 21 A 15-year-old violinist, James Oliver Buswell 4th, tonight won the $2,000 first prize of the National Symphony Orchestra's Merriweather Post Contest. The seventh annual event, given in conjunction with the Music for Young America concerts, was held at the Department of Commerce Auditorium.
WASHINGTON, May 21 (AP) The Supreme Court declined today to review a decision upholding the constitutionality of New York State's Emergency Housing Rent Control Law.

WASHINGTON May 21 Congressional Republicans are planning to urge the Administration to help clear the way for another series of national televised political debates in the election campaign this year.

Reform Democrats served notice last night that they would continue their fight to unseat Representative Charles A. Buckley although the 71-yearold Bronx leader received fresh support from President Kennedy and other top party officials.
AT the Maurice Rentner showing yesterday, celebrities and buyers drank champagne while Bill Blass, the designer, served them a fabric souffle.
A large-scale expansion of the Town Country discount-store division of Lane Bryant, Inc., was outlined yesterday by Raphael Malsin, president of the retail store concern.

ALGIERS, May 21, (AP) Troops searching houses in an Algiers suburb found the bodies of eight Europeans in an abandoned farmhouse tonight. Soldiers said the structure, fitted out with three built-in cells, appeared to be a Moslem torture chamber.

RANGOON, Burma, May 21 (UPI)--Prince Souvanna Phouma unexpectedly delayed his return to Loas today. Informed sources said the neutralist leader had delayed his return because he had asked the Rightwing leaders of Laos to meet him here.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 21 Paul G. Hoffman, managing director of the General Assembly's Special Fund for stimulating investment in underdeveloped countries, said today that the agency must receive a minimum of $100,000,000 a year if it is to meet the needs of the developing nations.
WASHINGTON, May 21 Administration officials believe United States forces may have to be kept in Thailand for years because of the Communist threat in Southeast Asia.
SUMMIT, N.J., May 21 James Dillon of 29 Blackburn Place, senior vice president and a director of the National Starch and Chemical Corporation, died today after a long illness. His age was 44.
LOS ANGELES, May 21 There are some 17,000,000 persons in the United States over 65 years old.
THE high hopes here for an exceptional summer of salt-water fishing are also found to the south, particularly along the Outer Banks of North Carolina.

KIAMESHA LAKE, N. Y., May 21--The head of the Rabbinical Assembly, the international association of Conservative rabbis, appealed tonight to the Soviet Union to allow its Jewish religious community to conduct a "religious dialogue" with American Jewish spiritual leaders.
