WASHINGTON, May 21 Defense Secretary Robert S. McNamara telegraphed a sharp rebuke to the National Guard Association today for its opposition to his proposals for reorganizing the Army's Guard and Reserve components.
WASHINGTON, May 21--The House Ways and Means Committee gave all-but-final approval today to President Kennedy's trade proposals.
The history of short-haul air transportation in the United States over the last fifteen years was characterized yesterday as one of "profitless growth."

COME summer and nobody seems to have much use for 16 and 17 year olds. Too old to be summer campers and too young to be counselors, they are often unable to obtain summer jobs. Work camps, hosteling and commercial tours have become increasingly popular with this age group, but lack appeal for many youngsters, who end up simply loafing.
HANOVER, N.H., May 21 Mr. and Mrs. John C. Manchester have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Martha Manchester, to Jackson W. Wright Jr., son of Dr. and Mrs. Wright.
Stockholders of Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., seem to care little about holes in their streets but are quite concerned over the lack of stock splits or dividend increases.

An issue fo $17,000,000 in Gulf States Utilities Company bonds was offered yesterday at a price to yield 4.285 per cent. which carry a 4.375 per cent coupon, mature in 1992. They were offered at 101 by an underwriting syndicate headed by Salomon Brothers Hutzler and Eastman Dillon Union Securities Co. The group had won the issue on its bid of 100.78.

One more step toward a military dictatorship in Argentina has now been taken. Congress has been given a forced recess until next year, all political parties have been suspended and President Guido is going to govern by decree.

MACON, France, May 21 A country fair is a country fair, whether it is held in the United States Middle West or in a little town in central France. There are chickens, ducks and prizewinning rabbits and even hot dogs.
BANGKOK, May 21 (UPI) Pote Sarasin, Secretary General of the Southeast Asia Treaty Organization, said today that "if there is aggression against Thailand, all members will observe their obligations."

The New York Presbytery voted its approval yesterday of amended minutes of the May 7 meeting at which the Rev. Dr. Stuart Hamilton Merriam was ousted from his post as pastorelect of the Broadway Presbyterian Church.
The Purchasing Agents Association of New York has announced the election of Charles B. Adams as its president for 1962-63. He is manager of purchasing services for the General Electric Company.
A pint of rare blood was flown from Milwaukee to New York yesterday for a 32-yearold woman about to give birth at Metropolitan Hospital.

COLORADO SPRINGS, Colo., May 21 (AP) The International Typographical Union said today unofficial figures showed that Elmer Brown of New York was leading Fred Hunt of Chicago for the union presidency. Mr. Brown is the incumbent.

Coraloc Industries, Inc., a subsidiary of E.L. Bruce Company, has acquired Sunset Pools, Inc., Los Angeles, and four affiliated corporations, it was announced yesterday. Edward M. Gilbert, president of Bruce, the parent concern, said that the combined sales of residential and commercial swimming pools by Coraloc and Sunset this year are expected to approach $5,000,000. The purchase involved an exchange of stock, with no cash involved.

A stretch of Park Avenue South, formerly called Fourth Avenue, took on a garden aspect yesterday in keeping with its change of name. A center mall reaching from Seventeenth to Thirty-second Street is planned with pink and white azaleas, ivy and hawthorne trees.
A note of amity was sounded yesterday between two rivals engaged in rebuilding the city's 650-mile waterfront.
Trading in Government, municipal and corporate bonds was generally dull yesterday, with all groups showing small price declines.
WASHINGTON, May 21 (AP) The top United States diplo mats in Haiti have been temporarily recalled to Washington in an apparent move to prod the Haitian regime toward more democratic methods.
SACRAMENTO, Calif., May 21 (AP)--A California legislator was convicted today of falsely reproting a bomb on an airplane--a violation of a law he helped enact.
The Henry Street Settlement will benefit from "Moonlight Orbit," a dinner dance with outer space as its theme, to be held in the Gold Room of the Savoy Hilton on Friday.

LONDON, May 21 The Deputy Prime Minister of New Zealand declared today that Britain had failed so far to win adequate protection for the Commonwealth's vital interests in her negotiations to join the European Economic Community.
It was a jaded group of Mets who arrived at 8 A.M. after putting in a sleepless night coming down from Milwaukee.
WASHINGTON, May 21 (AP) Officials here pondered today what course to take on the refugees fleeing Communist China.
MINEOLA, L.I., May 21 Nassau County's plan to establish an airport on Seaman's Island in East Bay, off Seaford, was opposed today by Robert Moses, president of the Long Island State Park Commission.

Measuring how much a ball bearing wears is no easy task, since it's essentially an antifriction device. The small amount that wears cannot be weighed, and yet the wear is there even if conventional techniques cannot measure it.
In the old days when New York was young and stretched from the Battery to Wall Street,...

ALBANY, May 21 (AP) A sampling of the disposition of 500 parking tickets issued in the village of Spring Valley, Rockland County, showed that 40 per cent were unaccounted for, the state Controller's office reported today.

The resignation of Roy W. Howard as president of The New York World-Telegram and The Sun was announced yesterday by Jack R. Howard, president of Scripps-Howard Newspapers. He also announced the appointment of Richard D. Peters as editor of The World-Telegram.

There was a time when an American infantryman received only his clothing, his rations and $13 a month. He could sleep in barracks if there were any barracks, and if not, a small space of turf, rock or sand was usually available.
LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo May 21 Congolese authorities and a delegation of Katangese officials conferred this morning on steps for ending Katanga's secession.
Illinois borrowed $95,000,000 in the bond market yesterday to finance construction. The state agreed to pay 2.9574 per cent for the loan.
WASHINGTON, May 21 A White House aide said today that Sardar, the gift horse from Pakistan, had not got preferential quarantine treatment just because he belonged to Mrs. John F. Kennedy.
ROOSEVELT, N.J., May 21 A community amphitheatre in memory of Franklin D. Roosevelt will be dedicated here June 2 at 1 P.M.
A tentative and promising step toward the revitalization of jazz as dance music was taken last week-end by a group called Jazz Entertainment, Inc.
SEATTLE, May 21 William J. Fronk, a former partner in Haskins Sells, certified public accountants, died here yesterday at the age of 63.
A series of executive changes on The New York Post was announced yesterday by Dorothy Schiff, publisher. She will now become editor in chief, a newly created title, as well as publisher.

Spurred by heavy Easter buying, April sales of the nation's leading retail chain stores and mail order companies were 14.2 per cent higher than in April of 1961, according to a survey completed yesterday by The New York Times.

THE Eastern States Championships, the larg est regional tournament played on this side of the United States, will begin Friday. (A typographical error caused the starting date to be given in last Sunday's editions of The New York Times as May 26, not May 25.)
COLORADO SPRINGS, Colo., May 22 (AP)--Elmer Brown of New York widened his lead today in his bid to retain the presidency of the International Typographical Union.
LOS ANGELES, May 22 (UPI)--Tommy Davis again provided the power tonight with another two-run homer as the Los Angeles Dodgers downed San Francisco, 5--1, to sweep a two-game series from the Giants.

MINEOLA, L. I., May 22-- The Nassau County Planning Commission stood firm today on its recommendation for a county airport off Seaford, despite objections yesterday from Robert Moses, president of the Long Island State Park Commission.
WASHINGTON, May 22--A complex puzzle is posed for the United States by the refugees flowing from Communist China into Hong Kong.

LOS ANGELES, May 22 (UPI)--Former Vice President Richard M. Nixon has committed himself to face a prospective opponent on a national television panel in his fight for the California governorship, he said today.
MADRID, May 22--The clandestine Spanish Communist party called today for "all forms of mass struggle" against the regime of Generalissimo Francisco Franco.
Sir Edmund Hillary, conqueror of Mount Everest and hunter of the Abominable Snowman, emerged here yesterday in a new role: sponsor of education for the Sherpas of Nepal.
WASHINGTON, May 22 (AP)--A unit to operate the Navy's navigation satellite system has been set up with headquarters at Point Mugu, Calif., the Navy said today.

While testifying under oath yesterday before the committee investigating boxing in New York State, Emile Griffith said he thought it would be a good idea for somebody to set up a pension plan for prizefighters. Startling? Scarcely.

The New York City Housing Authority raised $31,845,000 yesterday through the sale of temporary loan notes. The money will be used to continue short-term financing on houses in Manhattan, the Bronx and Queens.
Cotton futures were 10 cents up to 20 cents a bale off yesterday.
WASHINGTON, May 22 (AP)--Attorney General Robert F. Kennedy is one of four Cabinet officers who will not be available for political speeches in the Congressional elections campaign.
HARTFORD, May 22--Abraham A. Ribicoff, Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, held on to his commanding lead for the Democratic nomination for the United States Senate in today's primary.
LONDON, May 22--Sixty-five Labor and Independent Labor party members of Parliament have signed a letter to Premier Khrushchev asking him not to resume nuclear tests.

The General Foods Corporation increased its earnings for the tenth successive year in the fiscal year ended March 31, Charles G. Mortimer, chairman, reported in the pre liminary annual statement issued yesterday.
BOSTON, May 22--The Massachusetts Medical Society rejected a proposal today to make membership in the American Medical Association compulsory.

Mrs. Carolyn Waring MacLeod of 450 East Sixty-third Street and James Butler of Locust Valley, L. I., were married here yesterday. Supreme Court Justice Harry B. Frank performed the ceremony in his chambers.
"Victoria Regina," and its star, Julie Harris, received television's highest awards last night.
CENTERVILLE, Iowa, Wednesday, May 23--A Continental Airlines jetliner with forty-five persons aboard crashed late last night near this farming community in southeastern Iowa.
WASHINGTON, May 22-- Francis M. Goodwin Sr., a lawyer and former Assistant Secretary of the Interior, died on Sunday in his home at 2126 Connecticut Avenue. He was 90 years old.
HOBOKEN, N.J., May 22-- A three-alarm fire that destroyed four one-story buildings here early today killed 100 racing pigeons.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., May 22 (UPI)--Emile Griffith, the world welterweight champion, will meet Ralph Dupas here on July 13 in his first title defense since the March 24 bout in which Benny (Kid) Paret was fatally injured.
Production of paperboard in the nation totaled 358,809 tons in the week ended May 19, the National Paperboard Association reported yesterday.
WASHINGTON, May 22 (AP)--Two sets of the first two volumes of the papers of James Madison were presented to President Kennedy today.
WASHINGTON, May 22 (UPI)--United Air Lines, in a full-page advertisement, said today that the sale of liquor on coach flights was objectionable to both passengers and stewardesses.
The twelfth annual Columbia Journalism Alumni awards for distinguished service to journalism will be presented tomorrow night to Hal Borland, Woody Klein and M. Lincoln Schuster.

BILL RIGNEY is an intense man who concentrates that intensity on his job of managing the Los Angeles Angels, a heavenly surprise this season in the American League pennant race. But every once in a while he catches himself casting furtive glances in the direction of his first love, the San Francisco Giants.
Two state units moved yesterday against an agency that has been bringing women from South America to work as maids in Westchester homes.

CAIRO, May 22--President Gamal Abdel Nasser's new plan for a Socialist United Arab Republic struck diplomatic observers in Cairo today as a far more moderate revolutionary program than had generally been expected.
The Board of Education, like the "old woman who lived in a shoe," was faced with the problem of so many children yesterday that it was hard put to know what to do.
The city's night clubs and cabarets have been warned against trying to make streets near them "private parking preserves" for their customers.

Mrs. Katharine Wilmerding Burch, widow of Lowell R. Burch, former chairman of the executive committee of the New York Air Brake Company, died on Monday in her home at 1 East Sixty-sixth Street. She was 66 years old. Her husband died March 8.

Commonwealth Edison Company of Chicago announced yesterday a 5-cent-a-share increase in the quarterly dividend. This meant that the regular quarterly dividend to be paid Aug. 1 to holders of record of June 22 would be at the new rate of 30 cents a share.
MADRID, May 22 (AP)-- More than 250 industrial and financial leaders from thirty nations gathered today for a two-day business session of the Council of the International Chamber of Commerce.

CIUDAD JUAREZ, Mexico, May 22--At the same time that the indicted financier, Billy Sol Estes, was advocating higher wages for Mexican migrant labor, he was trying to bring in cheap labor for his own benefit and circumvent a new amendment in the Mexican migrant law.
BANGKOK, Thailand, May 22 (Reuters)--United States and Thai troops staged joint exercises today as Thailand announced that a contingent of Australian forces would be dispatched here.

PARIS, May 22 (AP)--Jon Douglas, a United States Davis Cup player from Santa Monica, Calif., produced his best form of the season today in winning his opening match of the French international tennis championships.

LONDON, May 22--Prime Minister Macmillan rejected today a proposal that he seek a special meeting with President de Gaulle and Chancellor Adenauer to discuss their opposition to Britain's entry into the European Economic Community.

LYNN, Mass., May 22--Mr. and Mrs. Charles G. Chambers have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sheila Jane Chambers, to Alejandro Smith y de Herrera. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Alejandro Smith of Mexico City, formerly of New York and Greenwich, Conn.
LEONIA, N. J., May 22--Mrs. Mathilde Gylsen Kiehl, widow of John Kiehl and a former teacher in New York City, died here today at the home of her daughter, Mrs. Dudley Martin. She was 85 years old.
PARIS, May 22--When Jean-Louis Tixier-Vignancour rises to his feet in the treason trial of former Gen. Raoul Salan, he gives the appearance of a hardened, hell-for-leather paratroop officer.
A local law that would remove from the City Charter a stipulation on the qualifications of Building Department inspectors was passed yesterday by the City Council. The vote was 19 to 3.
CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., May 22--If the sky is clear enough, television viewers may get an eyewitness look at some events taking place in space as Lieut. Comdr. M. Scott Carpenter goes into ...

Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz was hailed last night as "a lawyer's lawyer" at a dinner at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel in honor of his election as president of the National Association of Attorneys General. He is the first person in the state to hold the office.

BONN, Germany, May 22-- The Foreign Ministry delivered today to Walter C. Dowling, the United States Ambassador, a lengthy memorandum outlining West Germany's views on American proposals for a Berlin settlement.

STOCKBRIDGE, Mass, May 22--The Rev. Dr. and Mrs. Reinhold Niebuhr of Stockbridge and New York have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elisabeth Niebuhr, to Charles Proctor Sifton. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul F. Sifton of Washington.

Many years ago when "Abie's Irish Rose," by Anne Nichols, had belatedly become a popular success, a reviewer wrote a magazine article entitled "The Play That May Make a Million Dollars." Another interviewer with whom Miss Nichols talked the other day, a generation later, mentioned that the play had actually made about $15,000,000.
One hundred and seventy blind persons were safely evacuated from a Queens building yesterday after a fire on the fifth floor had set off the automatic sprinkler system.

SHAKER HEIGHTS, Ohio, May 22--Mr. and Mrs. Robert D. Beatty Jr. have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Bonnie Beatty, to Alan Crosby Mathews. He is the son of Mrs. Harry Wentworth Hollmeyer of Rio de Janeiro, formerly of New York, and Roger Mathews of Marion, Mass.

LONDON, May 22--Radar, Moon Rocket, President Kennedy, Princess Grace and Dr. Adenauer nodded their lovely heads today on the grounds of the Royal Hospital. They were some of the varieties of roses and tulips with names reflecting the day's news exhibited at the annual Chelsea Flower Show.
BONN, Germany, May 22-- A United States Navy aircraft crashed near Munich at noon today, and all twenty-six of its occupants were reported killed.

The Silver Cross Day Nursery at 451 East 120th Street will benefit from the informal Seven to Eleven dinner dance in the Grand Ballroom of the Plaza tomorrow night. The fete will be preceded by a cocktail party.

A FINE, husky trout in a stretch of the Beaverkill maybe carrying around a Dark Hendricks on nymph these days, and it is hoped that is stings a little and annoys the life out of him. Although he'll lose it soon, he should have to suffer some sort of retribution for making life unhappy for an angler.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, May 22 (UPI)--The United States told the International Court of Justice today that the refusal of France and the Soviet Union to pay special United Nations assessments for peace-keeping missions was a threat to all such international operations in the future.
WASHINGTON, May 22 (AP) --Peru, Guatemala, Costa Rica and the British Crown colony of Mauritius appealed to Congress today for fixed marketing quotas in sales of sugar to the United States.
Dr. Charles M. Reid of 175-33 Linden Boulevard, St. Albans, Queens, a general practitioner, died on Monday at Jamaica (Queens) Hospital. His age was 80.
WASHINGTON, May 22-- The nation's top labor leader challenged a spokesman for industry today to show how more jobs would be created if profits were increased.
WASHINGTON, May 22 (UPI)--Spokesmen for manufacturers and lawyers today attacked a controversial Administration-backed proposal to give the Federal Trade Commission a powerful new enforcement tool.
ATLANTA, May 22--The first breach in the policy of segregation by this city's white hotels was disclosed today.

HYANNIS, Mass., May 22 (UPI)--A Negro mother and her eleven children, cut off from welfare assistance in Little Rock, Ark., arrived in this Cape Cod resort today. They traveled here on one-way tickets provided by the Capital Citizens Council of Little Rock.

LONDON, May 22--Equities declined sharply on the stock market today in the wake of some disappointing company news. No important section escaped the trend, and losses of as much as 1s 6d (21 cents) were common.

Robert E. Bedingfield of The New York Times and Richard Austin Smith of Fortune magazine have been selected as winners of the fifth annual University of Connecticut Loeb Awards for business and financial journalism.

FORTY-SEVEN musicians who have become fired by the "Marlboro idea" last night gave a concert at Carnegie Hall that was both of and for the summer music school in Vermont that they have helped to make famous.

A turnout of 26,176 at Aqueduct yesterday saw an exceptionally brisk mile run in 1:34 4/5 by the Wheatley Stable's 3year-old bay colt Rebellious, part of a James E. Fitzsimmonstrained entry with Ogden Phipps' Comic.

McGeorge Bundy, special assistant to President Kennedy for national security affairs, repeated yesterday the Administration's position that the responsibility for nuclear defense of the West falls upon the United States.

Jack Brause, realty investor, has bought the fourteen-story and penthouse office building at 250 Hudson Street, near the entrance to the Holland Tunnel. The building contains 320,000 square feet of space and has among its tenants the Federal Social Security office.

President Nasser has at last put forward a draft constitution for his "Arab socialism." It was presented to a National Congress of Popular Forces in Cairo--1,750 delegates recently chosen from all walks of life to give a permanent, legal form to the social revolution that Mr. Nasser has in mind.

"Spy in the U.S." by Pawel Monat with John Dills, which had been scheduled for publication last year but was withheld for security reasons, is planned for September issue by Harper. It is an account of a Polish officer, trained by the Communists, who carried out espionage activities here with "the eager, if unwitting, cooperation of loyal Americans." Pawel Monat is a pseudonym.
His old friends used up all the superlatives at the Waldorf dinner honoring Boss Charles A. Buckley of the Bronx night before last.

The Seafarers International Union lifted its picket line yesterday against one of seven ships of the Moore McCormack Line. The freighter Mormacwren was permitted to sail at the request of the State Department and the Department of Labor.
An issue of $22,000,000 of Utah Power and Light Company bonds was marketed yesterday at a price to yield 4.35 per cent, and 480,000 of the company's preferred shares are to be offered today.

The House Ways and Means Committee has put together for final approval the President's "trade or fade" bill, authorizing him to cut or eliminate tariffs for reciprocal bargaining purposes in order to expand our own and free world trade in an Atlantic partnership with the European Economic Community. And the Senate Foreign Relations Committee has authorized $4,662,000,000 for foreign aid during the new fiscal year, a bearable $216.5 million below the President's request.
FRANKLIN, Tex., May 22--A medical examiner strongly indicated today that he believed an Agriculture Department figure in the Billie Sol Estes case had been murdered.

National Football League officials met at the Plaza Hotel yesterday and spent most of the day listening to two doctors discuss player injuries. Then the officials voted to compile a game-by-game record of all injuries by type and manner in which they occurred. The move was the first step in a program to reduce injuries.
KANSAS CITY, May 22 (AP)--Bryce B. Smith, Mayor of Kansas City from 1930 to 1940, died today at the age of 82 in St. Joseph Hospital.

MANASQUAN, N.J., May 22 --Dr. Martin A. Joyce of 137 Main Street, a physician on the staff of St. Francis Hospital in Trenton and Point Pleasant Hospital in Point Pleasant, died Sunday at Point Pleasant Hospital at the age of 38.

Millions of disposable plastic cups and containers soon will be pouring out of a new plant in Wilmington, Mass. The unit is being opened today by the Sweetheart Plastics division of the Maryland Cup Corporation.
PATERSON, N.J., May 22-- Two Guys From Harrison, a discount chain, was enjoined today by Superior Court Judge Morris Pashman from exchanging its trading stamps for stamps issued by competitors.

A collection of custom-designed, hand-painted screens goes on display today and marks the opening of a new concern called Gene Moore, Inc., at 43 West Fifty-sixth Street. Mr. Moore for many years designed the award-winning display windows for Bonwit Teller, and is currently responsible for the windows of Tiffany Co.

HOUSTON, May 22--Casey Stengel, who earlier today had mentioned he would gladly part with half his kingdom for a pitcher who could go all the way, saw Jay Hook toss a seven-hitter for eight innings tonight.
Dr. Harvey Gollance, general medical superintendent of the Department of Hospitals, described last night a medical emergency control plan he has devised for use in disaster situations.

A CHICKEN in a bag that need never to be put in a pot is now available to new Yorkers. This succulent new product from Lipman of Augusta, Me., is a chicken cooked in its heat-resistant, clear plastic container. This method is said to achieve a form of pasteurization, which increases the refrigerator life of the product by as much as three weeks.
Five new films will open today at local theatres.
ALBANY, May 22--The state Lottery Control Commission reported today that bingo players got back about $2.06 for every $3 paid for games in the six months ended March 31.

Mayor Wagner declared last night that it would be a "fracture of faith" with the voters to undertake premature changes in the city's new Charter, adopted last November. The Charter takes effect next Jan. 1.
WASHINGTON, May 22 (AP) President Kennedy told 2,000 cheering Democratic women today that their help was vitally needed because the party could not afford to lose a single seat in Congress.

Mayor Wagner has served notice that any renewed outbreak of the feud between Fire Commissioner Edward Thompson and Deputy Commissioner Ralph G. Ortiz could result in the ouster of one or both of them.
President Kennedy's news conference, scheduled for 4 P.M. today in Washington, will be carried on radio and television.
NEWARK, May 22--A lack of rain and the hot and humid weather are threatening the water reserves and some crops in a number of New Jersey areas.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 22-- The International Ladies Garment Workers Union will open its thirty-first convention here tomorrow, confronted with these problems--slow growth, unemployment, lagging wages and internal questions.

Pablo Casals will conduct in New York for the first time in a concert to be given at Carnegie Hall on Friday, June 22. The 85-year-old cellist, conductor and composer will direct the first local performance of his oratorio, "El Pessebre."
Subway-riding is increasing almost four times as fast as the Transit Authority had expected.

WASHINGTON, May 22 (AP)--A Senate investigator testified today that Boeing Company profits on Government contracts had ranged from a high of 108.6 per cent to a low of 36 per cent, as measured against the company's net investment.
WASHINGTON, May 22 (UPI)--Individuals, companies and Government at all levels ran up $53,000,000,000 of debts in 1961, pushing their total debt to a new high of $937,000,000,000.
Investors about to sign up for a plan variously called equity funding, secured funding or life funding should take a second and more serious look ...
CHICAGO, May 22 (AP)-- Grains futures drifted into stoploss selling in late dealings today on the Board of Trade and closed under rather heavy pressure.

A second Government witness testified yesterday that Representative Eugene J. Keogh, Democrat of Brooklyn, had been involved in an attempt to influence a Federal court decision in a Brooklyn bankruptcy case last year that concerned a $35,000 bribe attempt.
The second of three hold-up men suspected of taking part in the killing of two Brooklyn detectives last Friday was arrested yesterday in Norwich, Conn., and returned to Brooklyn.

The Pioneer Container Corporation, of 330 West Thirtyeighth Street, charged in Federal Court yesterday that the Corrugated Box Jobbers Association, Inc., of 555 West Twenty-third Street, and some of its members were acting in restraint of trade.

Three of New York's noblest toilers in the cause of new music--Howard Lebow, pianist; Matthew Raimondi, violinist, and Arthur Bloom, clarinetist --got together in Carnegie Recital Hall last night and played music by four composers: Erich Itor Kahn, Rene Leibowitz, Erich Schmid and Mathyas Seiber.

Miss Sheila Gloria Kawer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Abe I. Kawer of the Bronx, was married yesterday afternoon to Jay J. Pack of New York. Rabbi Jacob Sodden performed the ceremony at his study, 3822 Sedgwick Avenue, the Bronx.

The Borg-Warner Corporation has announced that it has begun marketing two new thermoelectric appliances. Executives of the company, in making the announcement, added that thermoelectricity, a method of cooling without moving parts, is no longer in "the world of tomorrow."
Divergent views on the future of the American merchant marine were presented here yesterday as the city and the nation observed the thirtieth celebration of National Maritime Day.

Sale of the Americana Hotel in Bal Harbour, Fla., to a "leading Wall Street investment banking firm" was disclosed last night by Marvin Kratter, president of the Kratter Corporation, at the annual meeting at the Biltmore Hotel.
Stan Mosel of the Essex Fells (N.J.) Country Club, set the pace yesterday for the metropolitan area in the local qualifying for the United States Open golf championship.
WASHINGTON, May 22-- Senators were told today that a copper company had gained a windfall of more than $6,000,000, apparently with the help of influence at high Government levels.
GENEVA, May 22 (UPI)-- The United States and the Soviet Union joined today to present a $100,000,000 plan for studying world weather through the use of earth satellites.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 22--As his only son is buried in Rangoon, Burma, Friday, U Thant will carry on his duties as Acting Secretary General of the United Nations by making an address at a Canadian university, according to United Nations sources.

Curious contradictions mark the arguments the American Medical Association and the Republican Congressional leadership have put forward against the Administration's program of medical care for the aged through Social Security. The White House bill is criticized for covering too many elderly persons and for covering too few. The part of total health bills it will pay is derided as inconsequential; its potential costs are called too heavy to be borne.

WASHINGTON, May 22-- By jumping the gun on subscribers to their own market letter, families of several partners in Stearns Co., a member of the New York Stock Exchange, made a small killing in a new stock recommended by the letter, testimony before a study panel of the Securities and Exchange Commission disclosed today.
A full-time investigator was appointed for the first time yesterday by the Board of Education to assure that its policies are being properly carried out.

WASHINGTON, May 22--The House Rules Committee approved today floor reconsideration of the payment of $73,000,00 in war claims to the Philippines. The House rejected on May 9 the authorization in the form in which it was presented and political and diplomatic repercussions resulted.
John Rudometkin, who holds most University of Southern California basketball scoring and rebounding records, signed yesterday with the New York Knickerbockers of the National Basketball Association.
BROOKLINE, Mass., May 22 --A tune-up for the Griscom Cup team matches tomorrow among women golfers from Boston, Philadelphia and New York was played today at The Country Club of Brookline.

Bernard M. Baruch, perhaps the most famous graduate of City College, visited the student center of the college's Baruch School of Business and Public Administration yesterday at 137 East Twenty-second Street in connection with a gift presentation ceremony.

TODAY the Museum of Modern Art opens its potentially most important exhibition of the year. "Recent Painting U.S. A: The Figure" is neither big nor spectacular, and it leaves an impression of tentativeness. But it is the museum's first exhibition devoted specifically to the theme of the figure since ...

Robert G. Grey, an investment banker, and president, treasurer and a founder of the Bruckner Society of America, died yesterday at his home, 697 West End Avenue, after an illness of three months. His age was 67.
Heavy long-liquidation and stop loss orders hit cocoa futures yesterday in one of the most active sessions of the year on the New York Cocoa Exchange.
Syracuse, N.Y., May 22 (UPI)--A poliomyelitis immunization program took on mass proportions today in Onondaga Madison and Oneida counties.

MONTREAL, May 22 (Canadian Press)--A shotgun blast spattered the side of the car of Michael Sheehan, president of the Canadian Maritime Union, today as he stepped out of his home in the Point St. Charles district. Mr. Sheehan was not touched.

JERSEY CITY, May 22-- A corporation was formed here today to promote the joining of Liberty Island with the Jersey City mainland by a 2,500-foot causeway. The establishment of a state or Federal park at the Jersey City end of the causeway is also sought.

PARIS, May 22--The Independent party, which represents a large segment of conservative opinion in France, declared open war on President de Gaulle tonight. It demanded the resignation of its four ministers in the Government.

MINEOLA, L.I., May 22-- Nassau County Executive Eugene H. Nickerson announced today that a Citizens Watchdog Fund had been formed to raise money to help the Commissioner of Accounts to perform his duties.
WASHINGTON, May 22-- The sponsors of the medical care rallies Sunday admitted today that they had "had a few flops," but they insisted total attendance had reached 100,000.
WASHINGTON, May 22 (UPI)--President Kennedy told Congress today that the United States received last year $55,028,419, including interest, on lend-lease debts of World War II Allies.
DAMASCUS, Syria, May 22 (AP)--The Government nationalized all foreign banks in Syria again today and became a share holder in Syrian and Arabowned banks.
PARIS, May 22--The French police searched today for Henri Slebodia, accused of being a member of a Secret Army Organization killer group that plotted to assassinate President de Gaulle.

YONKERS, May 22--There were only six policemen handling the flow of traffic to and from Yonkers Raceway again tonight as the Yorkers Police Benevolent Association continued its demands for an increase in pay for the off-duty work usually handled by twenty-seven or twenty-eight patrolmen.
DAMASCUS, Syria, May 22 --Akram Hourani, a leading Syrian Socialist, denounced today President Nasser's plans for the United Arab Republic as "just words."

WASHINGTON, May 22-- The United States joined today with a number of other countries in a quiet but pointed diplomatic boycott of Haitian President Francois Duvalier's celebration of the anniversary of his "re-election" last year.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 22--Acting Secretary General U Thant has replied to the latest Dutch appeal over Indonesian attacks on Netherlands New Guinea, it was announced here today.
Carol Channing is switching from the musical field to that of drama. After an affiliation with five consecutive musicals here, she has been signed to star in Anita Loos' comedy, "The King's Mare."
Detroit Edison Company and subsidiaries reported yesterday total revenues of $292,821,424 for the year ended April 30. This compared with $278,383,526 in the like 1961 period.

THE intimate and witty two-man revue of Michael Flanders and Donald Swann lent an engaging change of pace last night to "Festival of Performing Arts" on Channel 5. Their farrago of song and commentary still would be seem somewhat better suited to the living stage, but on the home screen "At the Drop of a Hat" often was tremendously amusing.

LONDON, May 22--Reginald Maudling, British Colonial Secretary, told the House of Commons today there was little evidence that the Chinese refugees attempting to enter Hong Kong were suffering malnutrition.
Hokan Bjornstrom Steffanson, a financier, died Monday night at Doctors Hospital after a long illness. His age was 78 and he lived at 56 East Fiftyseventh Street.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, May 22--There were widespread rumors in Belgrade today of an impending reshuffle of some of the more important figures in the Tito Government as a result of the nation's economic difficulties.
Life without Mickey Mantle continues to be strenuous for Manager Ralph Houk and the Yankees.

CANANDAIGUA, N.Y., May 22--A $5,500,000 gamble known as the Finger Lakes Race Track, will open here tomorrow. A group of transplanted New Yorkers are risking that sum to back their judgment that enough racing fans will find a horse park in these rolling, pastoral hills to support a profit-making corporation.

LONDON, May 22 (AP)-- A British physician chided by President Kennedy for telling Americans about alleged shortcomings in Britain's staterun medical program says that he intended no criticism of the President's medical-care bill.
MIAMI BEACH, May 22-- The American Thoracic Society, medical arm of the National Tuberculosis Association, today chose Dr. William Harris as its new president.

When the Oldtimers Club, made up of drivers who ran the 500-mile race more than twenty years ago, holds its annual meeting at Indianapolis next week, one of the prominent East Coast members will be absent because of a previous com- ...

Mayor Wagner indicated last night he would continue striving to unseat Representative Charles A. Buckley as Bronx Democratic leader even though Mr. Buckley had a new endorsement from President Kennedy.

The strong taste of overnight movie fame has yet to alter or subdue Rita Tushingham, a buoyant, 20-year-old lass from Liverpool who has drawn rave notices as the heroine of the British film, "A Taste of Honey."

Pressure against stocks with high price-earnings multipliers communicated itself yesterday to nearly the entire New York Stock Exchange list. Only golds and tobaccos held their ground or pushed forward.
The advertising industry's efforts at self-policing came in for some sharp criticism yesterday at the annual meeting of the Association of Better Business Bureaus.
Sterling came under selling pressure from abroad yesterday, depressing the spot price to $2.8119 offered from $2.8129 Monday. The market opened on a weak note, steadied, then eased.

Miss Alice Jean Cracknell of Delhi, Ont., will be married on June 30 to Terence Edward Finlay. He is the son of the Rev. Dr. Terence John Finlay, rector of St. Bartholomew's Protestant Episcopal Church here, and Mrs. Finlay of New York, formerly of Ottawa.

State Senator George R. Metcalf, Republican of Auburn and chairman of the Senate Committee on Public Health, received the Distinguished Service Medal of the New York State ... Society for Medical Research, Inc., yesterday.

HONG KONG, May 22--The Hong Kong Government is not prepared to reverse its policy of returning refugees to Communist China merely on the basis of the Nationalist Chinese Government's promise to accept those who want to go to Taiwan, a highly placed source said today.
KIAMESHA LAKE, N.Y., May 22--A group of Jewish educators agreed today that teaching of religious values if Jewish education is to have any impact on the "character and quality of human existence."
COCOA BEACH, Fla., May 22 --After four postponements, al most everything looks ready for an attempt to launch Lieut. Comdr. M. Scott Carpenter Thusday on his three-orbit space journey.
DETROIT, May 22 (AP)-- Cus D'Amato, the manager of Floyd Patterson, world heavyweight champion told the Michigan Boxing Commissioner today that a proposed title fight in Detroit appeared unlikely.

The Rev. Charles J. Gallagher died yesterday at St. Vincent's Hospital after a long illness. Father Gallagher, who was 57 years old, was assigned to the Roman Catholic Church of St. Ignatius Loyola, Park Avenue and Eighty-third Street.
MONTCLAIR, N.J., May 22 --Bert S. Fuller, a retired insurance executive, died yesterday at his home at 416 Ridgewood Avenue, Glen Ridge, N.J. He was 85 years old.
RIO DE JANEIRO, May 22 --Gov. Leonel Brizola said today that Brazil was the victim of a "process of occupation and exploitation" by the United States.
LONDON, May 22 (Reuters) --The Pakistan cricket tourists adopted "safety first" tactics to steer their way to a draw in their match against the Marylebone Cricket Club, which ended at Lord's today.
LONDON, May 22 (AP)-- Terry Downes of Britain gained a narrow decision over Don Fullmer of West Jordan, Utah, in a ten-round fight tonight. Downes weighed 159 pounds, Fullmer 158.
GLEN COVE, L.I., May 22-- The City Council approved unanimously tonight a 5 per cent amusement tax, effective June 1.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., May 22 --The marriage of Miss Penelope Schott, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Elihu Schott of Chappaqua, N.Y., to Ernest Kramer took place here this afternoon. The bridegroom is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Simon Kramer of Los Angeles. Rabbi Sherwin Wine performed the ceremony at the Hillel Foundation of the University of Michigan.

FASHION--not washing machines and toasters--will be in the forefront when E.J. Korvette throws open the doors of its Fifth Avenue store tomorrow. The nation's largest discount chain is the first to set up housekeeping on Fifth Avenue. Its new quarters are in the building formerly occupied by W Sloane.

Stephen Stockton of Riverdale and Michael Lebhar of Trinity yesterday gained the semi-finals of the thirtieth annual Eastern Private Schools tennis tournament. The event is being staged by St. John's University at the College Courts in Brooklyn.
NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., May 22 (UPI)--Technical difficulties have postponed the completion of the non-Communist world's largest hydroelectric plant, the $720,000,000 Niagara Power Project.
LEAVENWORTH, Kan., May 22 (AP)--Sgt. George D. Groom said today he and another United States soldier were still baffled over why Communist guerrillas released them after twenty-three days' captivity.
The favorable first-quarter business of the Hertz Corporation continued into April. Revenues rose 15 per cent from April, 1961, and a similar gain is expected in the second quarter.

TWENTY-THREE years ago when I first moved to the rural delights of Fairfield County (no longer, alas, very rural) there was a mule pasture only 300 yards from my house. Sometimes when taking the children for walks we would stop and admire the mules from a respectful distance. But the demands of the book reviewing business were so heavy that I never did find time to become well acquainted with them.
ROME, May 22--The sighing of the wind through the celebrated pines of Rome is becoming a harsh crackle and the city fathers are desperately trying to find out why.
LEWISBURG, Pa., May 22 (AP)--Former Gov. John S. Fine took the witness stand today to deny that he had concealed income on his Federal income tax returns.
Thomas Hopper Beardsley, former counsel and head of the law department of the Consolidated Edison Company, died on Saturday in Escondio, Calif. He was 80 years old.
The latest round in the battle of the trading stamps is being fought with cash on the line.
An Iranian scholar yesterday came to the defense of Dr. Stuart Hamilton Merriam, ousted minister of the Broadway Presbyterian Church, who had interceded in his behalf with the State Department.
A public image of real estate as a "boom-or-bust" industry was said yesterday to have resulted from misunderstanding of the trend in recent years toward broad-based ownership of real property.

ELIZABETH, N.J., May 22 --Stephen K. Urner Sr. of 21 De Witt Road, manager of the Poultry and Egg National Board's New York office, died of a heart attack yesterday at his summer home in Bay Head. His age was 52.

ST. LOUIS, May 22 (AP)-- Bob Gibson hurled a four-hitter and struck out nine in pitching the St. Louis Cardinals to their sixth straight victory tonight, a 6--2 triumph over the Philadelphia Phillies.
Mayor Wagner assailed television and the other mass media yesterday for stressing false values detrimental to youth.

MANHASSET, L.I., May 22 --Mr. and Mrs. Mayson Hatch Tucker have announced the engagement of Mr. Tucker's daughter. Miss Patricia Warren Tucker, to Ensign John Howard King, U.S.N.R. His parents are Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Montgomery King of Tuxedo Park, N.Y., and Coral Gables, Fla.
The National Maritime Union was accused yesterday of not playing according to the ground rules in the "house of labor."
RICHMOND, May 22 (AP)-- The defending champion, Polly Riley of Fort Worth, led the favorites through the opening round of the Southern women's amateur golf tournament today.
The police yesterday were investigating the reported loss of thirty pieces of jewelry valued at $50,000 from the suite of Rosalind Russell in the Pierre Hotel, Fifth Avenue and Sixtyfirst Street.

WASHINGTON, May 22 (UPI)--Attorney General Robert F. Kennedy indicated today a willingness to broaden the Administration's wiretapping bill so that state officials, if the bill passed, could use wiretaps against gamblers operating in cities.

Pier Luigi Nervi, the Italian explorer of new worlds in reinforced concrete, yesterday inspected his work nearing completion in this city--the Port of New York Authority bus terminal rising above the Manhattan end of the George Washington Bridge.

Directors of Pan American World Airways, Inc., have selected a committee to study possible mergers with other carriers and discussions already have been held with several lines, Juan T. Trippe, president, reported at the annual meeting here yesterday.
WASHINGTON, May 22-- The Government has notified Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. of an alleged $38,736 deficiency in his 1958 income tax, Tax Court records show.
A tour of homes in Greenwich Village tomorrow will benefit the Friendly Visitors of the House of Detention for Women.

The large aluminum lighting tower that has offended the esthetic senses of residents near Central Park was transferred yesterday from its original location, but still remained an integral, if not conspicuous, part of the new Shakespeare theatre.

PARIS, May 22--The European Economic Community has found at least two products on which it might raise tariffs in retaliation against the recent United States increases in tariffs on carpets and glass.
Frank (Machine Gun) Campbell, a waterfront hoodlum, was indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury as head of a $100,000-a-year extortion gang that preyed on meat truck drivers.

Mr. and. Mrs. Tyler Bainbridge Kiener of Chester, Va., have announced here the engagement of their daughter, Miss Nancy Kyle Kiener, to Dr. John Nicholas Schullinger. He is the son of Dr. and Mrs. Rudolph N. Schullinger of 1175 Park Avenue. The wedding is planned for next month.
WASHINGTON, May 22--The most serious problem in Washington today--because it affects all other problems--is the gap between present political realities and past political assumptions.
The market for United States Treasury bonds advanced yesterday, ending more than a week of price erosion.
A $500,000 "Shakespeare Student Center" will be built at the American Shakespeare Festival Theatre and Academy in Stratford Conn.

PARIS, May 22--Our disagreement with France derives originally from a contradiction in United States policy. When we held a nuclear monopoly we embarked on an Allied relationship not unlike the "directorate" General de Gaulle now wants.
WASHINGTON, May 22-- The 250 participants in the White House Conference on National Economic Issues, which ended today, followed President Kennedy's advice in their off-the-record sessions.

The North German All-Stars wound up a successful sixgame tour by defeating the German-American Soccer League All-Stars, 3-1, under the lights at Eintracht Oval in Astoria last night. It was their fifth straight victory. They were tied by the same GermanAmerican team, 1-1 in their opening game May 6.

Richard Tucker, Metropolitan Opera tenor, was admitted to the Long Island Jewish Hospital at New Hyde Park yesterday. The diagnosis of his physician, Dr. Irving Wecksell, was "physical exhaustion." Because of his illness, the singer has canceled all public appearances through mid-July.

Eleven scientists, including two former presidents of the American Association for the Advancement of Science, have written President Kennedy asking postponement of the projected hydrogen device explosions in space.
A 23-year-old smiling, candychewing defendant, acting as his Own lawyer, was cited twenty times yesterday for contempt of court for failure to answer questions during crossexamination.

Many local school districts in this state are being grossly overcharged by lawyers who handle their bond issues, a school official declared yesterday. He said that in some cases, where the predominant method of percentage fees is used, the charges amounted to "gouging."
PHILADELPHIA, May 22-- Charles Feinberg, founder of the Feinberg Textile Corporation here, died last night at the home of his son, Myron, who had died a few hours earlier.

WASHINGTON, May 22 (AP)--Sen. John L. McClellan, Democrat of Arkansas, proposed today that Congress use its power to arrest and imprison contemptuous witnesses because, he said, it "cannot rely upon the courts."
GENEVA, May 22--The United States urged the Soviet Union today to permit the immediate discussion of measures designed to reduce the risks of accidental war and surprise attacks.
The fur industry had "a pretty good year" in 1961, the American Fur Merchants Association, Inc., was told at its annual meeting last evening in the Statler-Hilton Hotel.
Mrs. Therese Obermeier Kamins and Stuart H. Steinbrink plan to be married June 24.
Holders of the 5 per cent preferred stock of New York, Susquehanna Western Railroad are being asked if they want to sell their shares by A.W. Benker Co., Inc., a brokerage house.
DENVER, May 22--The General Assembly of the $3,000,000member United Presbyterian Church voted today to provide "responsible" sex education for members of the church.
WASHINGTON, May 22-- The American Ballet Theatre, once warmly received by Premier Khrushchev in the Soviet Union, played the White House tonight.
WASHINGTON, May 22 (AP)--The Federal Aviation Agency said today that it has awarded six contracts totaling $2,660,000 for development work on a commercial supersonic transport.

Wayne County, Mich., borrowed $18,270,000 yesterday to finance sewer improvements at an interest cost of 3.66 per cent. The money was raised through the sale of serial bonds maturing from 1963 to 2002.
HELSINKI, Finland, May 23 --The Government announced plans today for an increase in corporate taxes, excise levies and state loans.

CLEVELAND, May 22 (AP) --Jim Gentile's eleventh and twelfth home runs and a tworun homer by the pitcher, Milt Pappas, accounted for Baltimore's scroing tonight as the Orioles beat the Cleveland Indians, 4--1.

DENVER, May 22--The General Assembly of the United Presbyterian Church tonight reversed a recent decision of the Synod of New Jersey that barred a Princeton Theological Seminary professor from membership in the Presbytery of New Brunswick, N.J., because he refused to affirm or deny belief in the Virgin Birth.
Physicians made an exchange tranfusion of a rare type of blood yesterday for a sevenpound seven-ounce boy born at 2:35 P.M. in Metropolitan Hospital.
MONTCLAIR, N.J., May 22 --Mrs. Mary C. King of 107 Chestnut Street, widow of Robert W. King, died yesterday at Mountainside Hospital, Glen Ridge. Her age was 97.
WASHINGTON, May 22-- The Government will soon begin to move about $50,000,000 worth of grain out of storage facilities controlled by Billie Sol Estes.

The New York Music Critics' Circle Citations have been voted to four new works heard this season: Robert Ward's opera "The Crucible," Benjamin Britten's opera "The Turn of the Screw," Elliott Carter's Double Concerto and Arthur Berger's Quartet.
PHILADELPHIA, May 22-- State Supreme Court Justice W. Curtis Bok died today at his home in suburban Radnor after an illness of several months. He was 64 years old.
Lester R. Giegerich, New York realty investor, has completed a sale-leaseback transaction with Albertson's, Inc., a chain of supermarkets in the West.

PHILADELPHIA, May 22-- The Rev. Andrew W. Gottschall, director of the southeastern Pennsylvania district of the National Conference of Christians and Jews, died yesterday at his home in Roslyn. He was 70 years old.

WASHINGTON, May 22 (AP)--A Southern Representative denounced Elizabeth Taylor and Richard Burton today for their conduct in Rome while making a motion picture and questioned whether they should be allowed to return to the United States.
LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, May 22--President Moise Tshombe of Katanga Province met with Premier Cyrille Adoula today for the first time since Mr. Tshombe's arrival from Elisabethville last Friday.

WHITE PLAINS, May 22-- Representative Edwin B. Dooley, seeking the Republican renomination for Congress, charged today that County Executive Edwin G. Michaelian, the Republican county chairman, had made a "political payoff" to get Republican leaders to endorse Ogden R. Reid for the nomination.
PHILADELPHIA, May 22-- Civil defense planners were accused today of ignoring fire as one of the deadliest hazards in a nuclear attack.
Walter Lippmann will return for his fourth appearance on Columbia Broadcasting System television next month.
ALGIERS, May 22--Responsible European authorities disArmy had found the bodies of closed today that the French fifteen Europeans buried in lime on a farm near Maison Carree, seven miles from Algiers.

WELLESLEY, Mass., May 22 --Dr. F. Mowbray Velte, a retired Presbyterian educational missionary, died of a heart attack yesterday while taking a test for an automobile driver's license. He was 68 years old.
Guests at the Travelers Aid Society of New York benefit yesterday had to do a little traveling--from the fashionable precincts of East End Avenue and Sutton Place South to the International Airport.

"Art In Orbit," the eighth annual art show by the city's public school pupils, may be seen in the lobby of Lever House, Park Avenue and Fifty-fourth Street. More than 1,000 paintings, sculptures and ceramics are on view. Admission free.
WASHINGTON, May 22-- The House Judiciary Committee approved today a constitutional amendment to ban the poll tax as a prerequisite to voting in Federal elections.

WASHINGTON, May 22-- The Senate Foreign Relations Committee approved legislation today authorizing a $4,662,000,000 program of economic and military aid to friendly nations in the fiscal year beginning July 1.

Middle South Utilities, Inc., and subsidiaries reported yesterday a gain of 8.4 per cent in total operating revenues for the first four months of 1962. Elec tric operating revenues for the period rose 8.5 per cent.
TUXEDO PARK N.Y., May 22--Mrs. Frank Humphrey Jr. and Mrs. Howland P. Rogers are co-chairmen for the benefit dance to be held at the Tuxedo Club Saturday for the Tuxedo Memorial Hospital.
BUENOS AIRES, May 22-- Federal policemen fired tear gas at recently elected Peronist Deputies today in an attempt to keep them out of the Argentine Congress building.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, May 22--President Tito turned out to be a space buff today. The Yugoslav chief of state, who will be 70 years old Friday, clambered over the space capsule in which Lieut. Col. John H. Glenn Jr. orbited the earth.

Lawbreakers in Lambertville, N.J., have the unusual opportunity of being arrested by a policeman who also is one of the East's foremost professional handlers of field trial dogs. They've got to be there in the winter, though, because the rest of the year the handler-policeman, George Stymiest, is busy
A team of Cornell scientists appears to have discovered what it calls "an entirely new means of controlling diseases."

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., May 23--A railroad and a power company staged an inspection tour today of an area that their development promoters believe has great promise as an industrial-residential center--the Mid-Hudson region.

No man, according to a Bartlett-certified quotation, is a hero to his valet. Although Richard H. Rovere, The New Yorker's Washington man, is obviously no valet, no man is a hero to him either. Not very many, anyhow. Read through his latest collection of dispatches, taken from The New

Voluntary contributions from 250 lawyers have been received to build up the Clients' Security Fund of the New York State Association of Trial Lawyers, the association's president, Joseph Kelner, reported yesterday.
BERKELEY, Calif., May 23 --Dr. Hartland S. Snyder, a theoretical physicist on leave from the Brookhaven (L.I.) National Laboratory, died last night in Alta Bates Hospital here. He was 49 years old.
For helping to promote a better understanding of the American way of life sixty individuals, schools and organizations in the New York area received awards yesterday from the Freedoms Founadtion.
Stewart L. Udall, Secretary of the Interior, said yesterday that the United States must increase imports as well as exports.

The American Stores Company, one of the nation's largest food chains, reported yesterday that sales and earnings for the fiscal year ended on March 31 were the highest in its history. Paul J. Cupp, president, also announced plans to change the company's name to Acme Markets, Inc.
Mayor Wagner said yesterday that he would like to see tuition fees abolished in the city's community colleges.
COCOA BEACH, Fla., May 23--A new school of funnymen --space comics--are enjoying great popularity up and down the neon-lit motel strip in this honky-tonk town that Mort Sahl calls "Disneyland East."
BERLIN, May 23--Soviet guards attempted today to block passage of a United States convoy on the Berlin autobahn, asserting that the Army should have notified them beforehand of the troop move.

THE flotsam of our age, prematurely embalmed in some drip-dry plaster, is one of the themes of a moderately successful show of sculpture at the Stephen Radich Gallery, 818 Madison Avenue. Another main theme is, of all things, clouds and the wind that moves them. Peter Agostini's work is interesting in its subject-matter and technique, but has little sculptural value.
WASHINGTON, May 23-- Senator Jacob K. Javits today became the first prominent Republican political leader to propose Governor Rockefeller as the party's Presidential nominee in 1964.

YONKERS, May 23--Martin Tananbaum, the president of Yonkers Raceway, said tonight that the track would no longer pay the Yonkers policemen who handled traffic to and from the track on their off hours, "let alone give them an increase."

HONG KONG, May 23 (Reuters)--Witnesses reported today the first recent Chinese Communist moves to halt the refugees flooding into this British colony. The number returned to China this month rose above 5O,000.

VIENTIANE, Laos, May 23-- The Laotian Right-wing forces routed--by pro-Communist artillery at Nam Tha early this month will have to show proof of increased fighting ability before the United States will assist in replacing the equipment the routed units lost, a United States Embassy spokesman said here today.
July 7 was announced yesterday as the closing date for "My Fair Lady," which has been entertaining theatregoers here since March 15, 1956.

WASHINGTON, May 23 (UPI)--The space agency plans soon to award small contracts to study the feasibility of sending men on a year's flight past Mars and Venus in the early Seventies.
MOC HOA, Vietnam, May 23 --A son of Gen. Lucius D. Clay was among four United States officers who were wounded today during an attempt to block the escape of a force of proCommunist guerrillas.

Q.--Mr. President, assuming that the King- . Anderson Bill passes, as you have predicted, do you then envision--in perhaps next year or the year after--going to Congress again and asking for a plan which would provide similar coverage to pay doctor bills?

COMPLICATED end-plays are just as likely to occur at low contracts as at high ones. The end position in the deal shown today, which may be so unusual as to baffle students of bridge nomenclature, resulted from bidding and play that occur frequently in the best games, but might never get into the textbooks.

Mrs. Hazel B. Sands, acting Queens County Republican leader, announced yesterday that the party's slate in the Nov. 6 election would be headed by Municipal Court Justice Angelo Graci as candidate for Surrogate.
BALTIMORE, May 23 (AP) --The Maryland Racing Commission postponed today a decision on giving Manuel Ycaza an additional twenty-day suspension for unfair riding tactics in the Preakness last Saturday.
Cotton futures were unchanged to 50 cents a bale off yesterday.
A thousand New Yorkers paid $25 each last night to attend a Parisian carnival in Washington Mews. The festivities included street dancing, strolling troubadors and gaily decorated boutiques.
CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., May 23--The most potent facility for studying and predicting solar flares has given Lieut. Comdr. M. Scott Carpenter the "go" sign for his scheduled orbital trip tomorrow.
RIO DE JANEIRO, May 23-- The Brazilian political Left is veering toward an aggressive anti-United States position for the campaign to be waged for October's Congressional election.

THERE are almost as many methods for restoring over permanented or over-bleached hair as there are beauty salons in New York. The latest theory among hair stylists seems to be that protein is the magic in gredient for restoring lifeless hair.
COLLEGIANS who consider chess usually do one of two things about it: either they leave it strictly alone or, if they play it, they play it extremely well.
WASHINGTON, May 23 (AP) --Patent Commissioner David L. Ladd opposed today a suggestion that drug manufacturers be denied an exclusive patent on their new products after three years.
Rod Serling and the Columbia Broadcasting System have reached an agreement under which Mr. Serling will produce a new series of thirteen hourlong dramas for "Twilight Zone."
PARIS, May 23--The four Independent ministers, whose resignations were demanded yesterday by the Deputies of their party, decided today to stay at their posts.
SCARSDALE, N.Y., May 23 --A field of 162 seniors, ranging in age from 55 to 82, indicated today that golf was still their favorite game.
HONG KONG, May 23 (AP) --Poon Soo is one of the lucky ones.

The mail received by the White House and members of Congress, not to mention the news papers, reveals many misapprehensions about the Federal Government's proposal for income tax withholding at source from dividend and interest income.

WASHINGTON, May 23-- Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. said today he--and not the Government--initiated the suit in Tax Court to settle whether $18,615 he received from production of the play "Sunrise at Campobello' constituted taxable income.
LOS ANGELES, May 23-- The Mets, from their remote position in ninth place, made a heroic effort tonight to make their presence felt in the National League pennant race-- to no avail.
ALGIERS, May 23--European terrorists killed a special security policeman and wounded four others today in a gun battle in the center of Algiers.

WASHINGTON, May 23-- Senate stockpile investigators produced a memorandum today indicating that Sinclair Weeks, while Secretary of Commerce in 1956, and two other officials had decided to let a company "buy out" of a copper contract.
Joan Sutherland will sing at Lewisohn Stadium for the first time on Monday, July 23. Three days later she will appear at Ravinia in Chicago, and on August 2 at the Hollywood Bowl.

WASHINGTON, May 23-- Secretary of State Dean Rusk will visit Bonn late in June, officials said today. They added that Mr. Rusk's visit would be simply a "keep-in-touch" and not a "patch-it-up" mission.
MADRID, May 23--The Most Rev. Gregorio Modrego y Casaus, Archbishop of Barcelona,

That old phrase "Darkest Africa" seems as far removed from today's reality as the ancient description in the Book of Kings : "Once in three years came the navy of Tharshish, bringing, gold, and silver, ivory, and apes, and peacocks."
Jerome Rosenberg, the last of three Brooklyn hoodlums sought in the slaying of two detectives last Friday, was taken into custody last night after he had arranged his own surrender.

LONDON, May 23--The Bank of England is quite satisfied with the nightly protection it gets from a seventeen-man military guard.

The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (World Bank) announced yesterday a loan of $50,000,000 to a Colombian utility to help finance several electric power projects in and around the capital city of Bogota.

Five corporations and fifteen individuals, including twelve Orientals, were indicted here yesterday on charges of having defrauded the Government of $60,000 in duties on the importation of children's dresses from Hong Kong.
CHICAGO, May 23 (AP)Z Grain prices continued to fall despite somewhat improved demand today on the Board of Trade.

The National Labor Relations Board was urged by MooreMcCormack Lines yesterday to decide speedily which of two rival unions would represent unlicensed seamen on the line's thirty-four Atlantic and Gulf Coast ships.

It would be unfortunate if public concern over the possible implications of Senator Yarborough's and Representative Rutherford's receipt of funds from Billie Sol Estes were limited to these particular incidents.
A stubborn three-alarm fire in two buildings yesterday caused injuries to five firemen and delayed 3,000 homebound commuters on the Third Avenue elevated line in the Bronx.
WASHINGTON, May 23-- The House Committee on Education and Labor approved today a new and direct approach to desegregation of certain public schools and colleges.
Do punch-drunk prizefighters exist only in the addled minds of unprincipled sensation mongers?
FRANKLIN, Tex., May 23 (AP)--The county grand jury searching for a motive in a mysterious death linked to the Billie Sol Estes case asked today for United States Department of Agriculture records.
WASHINGTON, May 23-- The nation's railroads and the five operating rail unions agreed today to resume negotiations with the assistance of the National Mediation Board.

Events today: Junior high schools' "Salute to Music," Sam Levenson, guest speaker, Carnegie Hall, 8 P.M.; Manhattan Consort, LaNoue Davenport, conductor, Carnegie Recital Hall, 8:30; West Side Symphony Orchestra, Joseph Eger,

A University of Michigan epidemiologist yesterday reported that the incidence of rheumatoid arthritis was more or less equal between men and women, rather than two to three times more prevalent in women, as had long been believed.
PARIS, May 23--Raoul Salan, former chief of the terrorist Secret Army Organization, was sentenced tonight to life imprisonment by a high military tribunal.
Prices of United States Treasury bonds yesterday continued the upward move that began Tuesday.
WASHINGTON, May 23 (AP) --The House of Representatives voted today a record budget for space exploration.

PARIS, May 23 (UPI)-- Whitney Reed of Alameda, Calif., the top-ranking United States singles player, had to rally to beat Patrizio Rodriguez of Chile, 4-6, 6-2, 8-6, 6-4, in the second round of the French tennis championships today.

Plans of Doubleday Co., Inc., to acquire a major interest in Curtis Publishing Company have been delayed by the death on Tuesday of Pennsylvania Supreme Court Jus tice W. Curtis Bok, reliable sources said yesterday.
STAMFORD, Conn., May 23-- Mental health problems in the suburbs will be tackled in two new out-patient clinics opening here next fall to serve southwestern Fairfield County.

The stockholders of the Swan-Finch Oil Corporation met here yesterday for the first time since the company went into reorganization four years ago. The company al legedly was looted of millions of dollars by Lowell M. Birrell, its former president, now a fugitive from justice and living in Brazil.

SAIGON, May 23 (AP)--Government forces said they scored a smashing victory over a Communist guerrilla band today near the jungle hamlet of Jao My, forty-five miles southwest of Saigon in the Mekong Delta.

The stock market acted yesterday like a diver going off a springboard. It went down, up, down, up and then plunged. The results: The third 5,000,000-share day this month and year, lows for The New York Times combined and industrial averages since Jan. 4, 1961, and the largest number of declines --1,005--since Oct. 21, 1957.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 23--A $1,000,000 program by American Quakers to help repatriate about 300,000 Algerian refugees in Morocco and Tunisia was reported here today by Bronson P. Clark, the director of the work.
BRASILIA, May 23--The Council of Ministers approved today a decree enabling the state to nationalize all major public services in Brazil.
BAY HEAD, N.J., May 23-- Paul Franklin Hay, a general partner in the New York investment banking firm of W.C. Langley Co., died yesterday in his home here. His age was 73.
