DUNKIRK, N.Y., May 23 (AP)--This western city of nearly 20,000, with 17 per cent of its working force unemployed, is on the verge of having that situation worsened.
GREAT NECK, L.I., May 23 --Frank D. O'Connor, the Queens District Attorney, declared here tonight that he was a candidate for the Democratic nomination for Governor.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., May 23--The Rutgers tomato, a leading variety in the nation for fifteen years, "has outlived its usefulness," a vegetable expert at Rutgers University that developed it, admitted today.
Richard M. Jackson, president of Seaboard World Airlines, yesterday assailed the prevailing airline system for arriving at international cargo rates.
Nonprofessional employes of Beth-El Hospital in Brooklyn struck yesterday for union recognition, a union contract and higher wages.

PHILADELPHIA, May 23 (AP)--Harold Johnson, the light-heavyweight boxing champion, and his manager, Pat Olivieri, said today they had settled their differences and would go to Berlin for a title bout with Gustav Scholz of Germany on June 23.
LONDON, May 23--"There are risks as well as opportunities" for Britain in the Common Market, Prime Minister Macmillan said today.
SAN FRANCISCO, May 23-- Enrique Jorda made public today major items he will offer San Francisco Symphony Orchestra patrons in his final season as conductor and musical director.

WASHINGTON, May 23--The recent crop of critical books and articles on covert operations of the Central Intelligence Agency, principally with respect to the U-2 flight, which was downed in Soviet Russia, and the invasion of Cuba, which was repulsed by Premier Castro, has nourished Proposals for a Congres

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., May 23--Governor Rockefeller, beginning a three-day tour of the capital district today, conferred with business men and educators, set the foundation stone for a housing project for the aged and touched a button putting a $1,500,000 computer system into operation.

MACAROONS, which usually stick to a baking sheet, can be removed easily when vegetable parchment is used to line the sheet. Meringues baked on a sheet covered with vegetable parchment remain white on the bottom and can be lifted off easily without damage.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., May 23--Borough Council President Joseph F. Ziemba of Sayreville and the owner of a West Orange excavating company were indicted today in the theft of fill dirt from public lands.

Market research has had a rather piecemeal development in this country. Whenever a company has wanted to check the results of a specific campaign or solve a specific marketing problem, it has begun a short-term research program for that purpose.
DeWitt Clinton won its seventh straight Bronx Public Schools Athletic League track title yesterday at Van Cortlandt Park Stadium in the Bronx.

WASHINGTON, May 23 (AP) --Higher standards and more stringent examinations for those entering the securities business were urged today by the National Association of Security Dealers. The group lists 4,850 member firms.

BROOKLINE, Mass., May 23 --Boston won the Griscom Cup today for the first time since 1956. Playing over the Country Club of Brookline 6,075-yard, par-74 course, Boston's women golfers defeated Philadelphia, 12 --8 , and New York, 12-9, for 24 points.

DENVER, May 23--The possibility that the Rev. Dr. Stuart Hamilton Merriam might regain his pulpit at the Broadway Presbyterian Church in New York City appeared remote here today in view of two judicial decisions made last night by the General Assembly of the United Presbyterian Church.
The Protestant Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest announced yesterday that it had called Canon J. Burton Thomas, rector of the Bishop Cronyn Memorial Church, London, Ont., to its rectorship.

BUENOS AIRES, May 23 (AP)--Two Senators and five Deputies resigned today in protest against President Jose Maria Guido's recent decree recessing Congress for at least a year while Argentina's political parties are reorganized.

"A reformer," says Richard S. Childs, "is one who sets forth cheerfully toward sure defeat." For when his movement becomes respectable, the statesman takes it over; when it wins, the politician comes along. And the reformer is then off on a new crusade.
WASHINGTON, May 23-- President Kennedy promised reporters today to give them an answer next week on the Government's attitude toward studies linking cigarette smoking with cancer and heart disease.

WASHINGTON, May 23-- President Kennedy said today that he recognized that it would be hard to withdraw United States troops from Thailand now that they have been committed there. However, he distinguished between this commitment and United States obligations in Western Europe.

Sol W. Cantor, president of Interstate Department Stores, Inc., took the occasion of his company's annual meeting yesterday to deliver a vigorous defense of the role of discount stores in the American economy.

ONE of the more disquieting and disappointing as pects of the Monday evening telecast of the Academy of Television Arts and Sciences was the participation of high government officials in the awkward and banal ritual.
Mailers are accidentally or deliberately putting trading stamps instead of postage stamps on letters, and postal authorities wish they would think before they stamp.
The Philadelphia Warriors' franchise in the National Basketball Association was sold yesterday for a record $850,000 and was transferred to San Francisco.
GENEVA, May 23--The disarmament conference inched toward a compromise today for breaking a six-week-old deadlock that has stalled discussion on measures to reduce international tension.
Orders for machine tools from abroad gained in April, but not enough to wipe out a sharp drop in domestic orders, so that the total went down by 2.2 per cent from the March figure.
Governor Rockefeller asserted last night that New York led all other states in medical assistance to the aged and in finding jobs for workers over the age of 45.

WASHINGTON, May 23--The House Foreign Affairs Committee ordered today a 20 per cent cut in the $3,000,000,000 asked by President Kennedy for economic aid to Latin America through the Alliance for Progress.

Sales of the Grand Union Company for the fiscal year ending next March 4 will reach a record of $700,000,000. Thomas C. Butler, president of the Eastern food chain told shareholders at the annual meeting yesterday at Paramus, N.J.

WOODBRIDGE, N.J., May 23--Police Magistrate Benjamin I. Kantor today found Representative Seymour Halpern of Queens guilty of speeding at eighty-five miles an hour on the New Jersey Turnpike and acting in a disorderly manner when stopped by a state trooper.

CONAKRY, Guinea, May 16 --Month after month in this little West African port the sun blazes down on two giant machines. They have been pushed aside and are now either forgotten or ignored by the Africans who work here. The Guineans call them snowplows. The Russians, who sent them, call them earth movers.
A researcher from Bell Telephone Laboratories described yesterday tests that he said, showed that "voiceprints" may prove to be almost as effective, for identification, as fingerprints.
The Maritime Administration will study turbulent labor-management relations within the shipping industry, Donald W. Alexander, administrator of the Federal agency, announced yesterday.

NEW ORLEANS, May 23 (UPI)--United States District Judge Frank Ellis ruled today that the Orleans Parish (county) School Board need not integrate six elementary grades next September as ordered by his predecessor.

LOS ANGELES, May 23(AP) --A Federal Court jury ruled today that United Air Lines and the Government were liable for damages in an air collision that killed forty-seven persons over Las Vegas on April 21, 1958.
HOLLANDIA, Netherlands New Guinea, May 23 (UPI)-- Dutch military forces moved today to isolate Indonesian invaders prior to the start of "mopping up" operations.

PORT OF SPAIN, Trinidad, May 23--The leaders of Trinidad's ruling and Opposition parties will meet with Colonial Office officials in London next week to argue the issue of independence and the form it will take.

WASHINGTON, May 23--The United States will admit several thousand of the most eligible Chinese refugees in Hong Kong by invoking emergency powers to waive the immigration laws. Officials expect to start the process of admitting the Chinese in two weeks.
EL PASO, Tex., May 23-- Billie Sol Estes faced his creditors today, but declined even to tell his occupation on the ground that it might tend to incriminate him.
Mayor Wagner said yesterday that President Kennedy's message of support for Charles A. Buckley, the Bronx Democratic leader, had "confined itself to his work in Congress."

CANANDAIGUA, N.Y., May 23--A spanking new separation center for the army of lost souls, those doughty bettors who stand in eternal formation at the $2 windows, was activated today. They call it Finger Lakes Race Track.

Nearly a year ago we observed here that conditions for wayward adolescent girls (16 to 21 years old) who are in deep trouble with the law were a disgrace to the city. In recent months the situation has worsened. The plight of these girls, including many first offenders, inside theso-called House of Detention for Women is probably the city's greatest shame.

NOW is the time for all good men to take to the woods. And they will do so, usually with families, now and through the summer and fall. This year camping as a recreational activity will reach a new high, with new facilities and areas opening across the country.
A group of twenty-five young American rabbis left New York International Airport last night for Israel for Talmudic study at the Israel Torah Research Institute in Jerusalem.

The nation's inventories of gasoline declined by 2,683,000 barrels last week, while stocks of light fuel oil rose by 3,238,000 barrels, the American Petroleum Institute reported yesterday. Refinery operations increased sharply, although crude oil production showed a modest increase over the week before.

KIAMESHA LAKE, N.Y., May 23--Leaders of Conservative Judaism urged the American Jewish community today to make available unused facilities in synagogues and community centers to increase the number of Jewish all-day schools.
Still another questionnaire has been sent to brokers by the Securities and Exchange Commission as part of its investigation of the nation's securities markets.
The city announced plans yesterday for revising surface transportation to, from and between some of the major airports in the Metropolitan area.
WASHINGTON, May 23--The Kennedy Administration has developed its own style of approaching labor-management problems.
LONDON, May 23--Prime Minister Macmillan vigorously defended today his Government's wage restraint policy.
WASHINGTON, May 23-- President Kennedy said today that the Administration did not plan to ask Congress in a year or two to extend medical care coverage through Social Security to doctors' bills.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 23-- Dr. Harry N. Pratt, director of New York Hospital, warned today that government control of the nation's voluntary hospital system was inevitable unles he voluntary health services cooperated to provide comprehensive and high-quality service to all segments of the population.

LONDON, May 23--The slide in equities continued on the stock market today. Nearly all prices fell at the beginning. Investors were made cautious by unfavorable company reports and the weakness of Wall Street. Slow sales depressed prices further.

Mrs. Millicent C. McIntosh, retiring president of Barnard College, declared yesterday that it was time to stop wailing about the waste of woman power and make sure that educated women took advantage of their multitude of opportunities.

WASHINGTON, May 23-- The Federal Reserve Board reported today that the condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in leading cities showed the following principal changes for the week ended May 16:

Robert Epps, who acted as his own lawyer and questioned himself on the witness stand, was convicted yesterday of having passed $500 in bad checks. A General Sessions jury acted after twenty-eight minutes of deliberation.
PARIS, May 23--Raoul Albin Louis Salan, who was sentenced tonight to life imprisonment for rising up against the French state, was once the most honored of French generals.

WASHINGTON, May 23--The House Ways and Means Committee voted today to repeal the 10 per cent Federal tax on rail and bus passenger fares and to reduce the levy on air travel to 5 per cent. The committee wrote the provisions into an Administration bill for a one-year extension of corporation and excise (sales) taxes that are scheduled for automatic reduction July 1 under present law.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 23--Some time soon an automobile mechanic will be getting special training on Taiwan, a Mali farmer's rice crop will be greater, Israel may be storing water deep underground in geological formations and Central America will know what has to be done to establish a regional communications network.

LONDON, May 23--The Labor party's leaders decided today to have personal talks with Bertrand Russell, Lord Chorley, and Canon J.L. Collins, three prominent members, about their sponsorship of the World Congress for General Disarmament and Peace, which will be held in Moscow in July.

A Government witness who said he tried to bribe a judge to keep from going to jail for fraud testified yesterday in Federal court that before he made the alleged attempt he could have escaped with a sentence of six months.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 23--A Nigerian journalist has been named the first Dag Hammarskjold scholar by the United Nations Correspondence Association.
Forty-six seniors and graduate students received the Bachelor of Sacred Theology degree yesterday at the commencement exercises of General Theological Seminary here.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 23--Acting Secretary General U Thant appealed tonight to Indonesia and the Netherlands to resume negotiations to avoid further conflict over Netherlands New Guinea. He urged that the two countries again use Ellsworth Bunker, a former United States Ambassador, as an intermediary.

World sugar futures prices fell 5 to 10 points (hundredths of a cent a pound) on a volume of 16,100 tons in the fourth most active session of the year on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange yesterday. In other trading on other markets, cocoa futures rallied; copper
James R. Hoffa won agreement yesterday from leaders of 57,000 teamsters in this city and New Jersey to support his efforts to establish a uniform wage pattern for 600,000 truck drivers in the nation.
WASHINGTON, May 22--A second Democratic member of Congress from Texas acknowledged today that he had received a financial contribution from Billie Sol Estes.
MANILA, May 23--The former Philippine Ambassador to Washington, Brig. Gen. Carlos P. Romulo, arrived today from Europe to assume the presidency of the University of the Philippines.

Dr. Fred Schwarz told an audience of about 200 persons in Manhattan Center last night that one of the obstacles to peace was "the insincerity of many professed Christians" who refuse to recognize that communism was flourishing and dangerous.

A series of books on important issues of United States foreign policy was inaugurated yesterday by the Council of Foreign Relations. Called "Policy Books" and ranging from 75 to 125 pages, the volumes are being published by Harper in both hardbound and paperbound editions.
LOS ANGELES, May 23-- Richard M. Nixon cannot win the governorship of California, his rival in the Republican primary, Joseph C. Shell, declared tonight.
CHICAGO, May 23--The eightieth annual meeting today of the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) was marked by a prolonged and heated debate on the company's philanthropic efforts.
BONN, Germany, May 23-- Chancellor Adenauer was re ported today to have promised Under Secretary of State George W. Ball to do all he could to ease Britain's entry into the Common Market.

Three executives of the Dodge division of Chrysler Corporation, six superintendents of the Michigan Wisconsin Pipeline Pipeline Company and a New York lingerie manufacturer were among the forty-five persons killed late Tuesday night in the crash of a Continental Airlines jet near Unionville, Mo.

WASHINGTON, May 23-- President Kennedy called attention today to the efforts of Ellsworth D. Bunker, a retired United States diplomat, to mediate the dispute between Indonesia and the Netherlands over Netherlands New Guinea.
Dr. John J. Theobald notified the Board of Education yesterday that he would retire as Superintendent of Schools to join a company that makes teaching machines.
The downward trend in the nation's steel operations may not run its course before midAugust, industry leaders agreed yesterday.

A study of New York State's 80,000 regular and seasonal hired farm workers indicated yesterday that they could be brought into the state unemployment insurance system at an annual cost of $3,600,000 in benefits.
Physician, Lynn A. Boice's winner of the Santa Anita Handicap, gave an interesting demonstration of stretch-running as he took the feature purse, called the Cravat Handicap, at Aqueduct yesterday.

CANNES, France, May 23-- Anselmo Duarte's "O Pagador de Promessas" ("The Given Word"), a film that few persons here had seen, became tonight the first Brazilian feature to win the Cannes Film Festival's Golden Palm.

SEOUL, Korea, May 23--Gen. James A. Van Fleet, head of a twenty-eight-man United States business mission to Korea, predicted today that the United States Government would "fully endorse and support" industrial projects agreed upon by Korean and United States business men.
ALBANY, May 23--State Senator Austin W. Erwin of Geneseo, chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, announced today he would not be a candidate for re-election this year.

CAPETOWN, South Africa, May 23--The Government of Prime Minister Hendrik F. Verwoerd came under bitter attack in Parliament tonight by opposition parties who charged it with trying to set up a police state.

WASHINGTON, May 23 (AP) --Senator Barry Goldwater today challenged George Meany president of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations, on his contention that a rise in profits might not mean more jobs.
Rival seamen's unions clashed in a brawl yesterday in a jurisdictional dispute involving the Moore-McCormack Lines.
LONDON, May 23--A publishing venture designed to provide low-cost technical textbooks, for use especially in Commonwealth countries, was launched today in Oxford.

UNIONVILLE, Mo., May 23 (AP)--The Continental Airlines jet that crashed in pieces last night, killing all forty-five persons aboard, may have been torn apart by thunderstorm currents, Federal Aviation Administration officials speculated today.

COCOA BEACH, Fla., Thursday, May 24--The final countdown for the triple orbit of the earth by Lieut. Comdr. M. Scott Carpenter began early today. The launching time is set for 7 A.M. barring weather delays or technical difficulties.

Maybe it was the sight of Mickey Mantle. Maybe it was Kansas City pitching. Maybe it was just about time. Attribute it to what you may, the Yankees snapped out of their scoring lethargy yesterday with a resounding boom at the Stadium.
CHICAGO, May 23 (AP)-- The Chicago office manager of the Commercial Solvents Corporation was found dead today. The police said that he had killed himself.
ATLANTIC CITY, May 23-- David Dubinsky, one of labor's stanchest supporters of the Kennedy Administration, called today for a national thirty-fivehour work week.
The construction of key projects in the greatest roadbuilding program in the history of the metropolitan area will have its heaviest impact on motorists this summer.
WASHINGTON, May 23 (AP) --The House by voice vote passed a bill today authorizing the San Juan-Chama and Navajo reclamation projects in New Mexico.

MINEOLA, L.I., May 23-- Harry E. Hanners, a former narcotics addict who started a school for inmates at the Nassau County Jail, received a suspended sentence in First District Court today after having been convicted of obtaining narcotics by illegal means.
Mayor Wagner received a city key yesterday--and here's how it happened:

New York State raised $57,330,000 on housing bonds maturing from 1964 to 2012 yesterday at an interest cost of 3.21978 per cent. Chase Manhattan Bank and associates bought the issue and reoffered the bonds at yields of 1.70 to 3.75 per cent. A spokesman for Chase said that over $50,000,000 of the bonds were sold.
ROME, May 23--Conservatives accused the Government today of pushing Italy into state socialism.

WHITE PLAINS, May 23-- Dr. Charles Burton Gulick, a classical philologist and Eliot Professor Emeritus of Greek Literature at Harvard University, died here today in a nursing home. He was 93 years old.
PARIS, May 23--The six countries of the Common Market are close to agreement on two principles that Britain will have to accept to enter the trade organization.

BONN, Germany, May 23-- The Cabinet is believed to have agreed today on Karl Heinrich Knappstein as the new West German Ambassador to the United States. He is at present Bonn's observer at the United Nations.
Garry Moore testified yesterday that the "blacklisting" of entertainers was "a little like fighting six men in a closet with the lights out--you can't tell who's hitting you."
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, May 23--A Yugoslav Parliamentary delegation will pay an official visit to the Soviet Union next month, it was announced here today.
Floyd Patterson said yesterday he would defend his heavyweight championship against Sonny Liston in Chicago sometime in September.
CHICAGO, May 23 (AP)-- Midwestern trucking companies have agreed to pay the Teamsters union $5 for each trailer hauled by railroad flatcar.
If the Dutch-Indonesian fighting over Netherlands New Guinea continues to build up as it has in recent weeks, the world will soon have hostilities of major proportions on its hands.

SEATTLE, May 23--The newest functioning cul tural center in America has been in operation here for several weeks. It is the Seattle Center, the actual construction of which began only a little more than a year ago and was finished just in time for the World's Fair.

TAMPA, Fla., May 23 (AP)A Federal judge refused today to dismiss a mail fraud indictment against James R. Hoffa, president of the Teamsters Union, and a Detroit banker. He ordered them to stand trial in September.
WASHINGTON, May 23-- The Administration is looking for the key to Europe's economic growth as a possible guide in improving the rate of growth in this country.

MINNEAPOLIS, May 23 (UPI)--The Minneapolis Star and Tribune, shut for six weeks by a strike, proposed arbitration today in a key dispute over mailroom work procedures. The mailers' union rejected the proposal.
SAN FRANCISCO, May 23 (AP)--The Philadelphia Phillies hammered out a 10-7 victor over San Francisco's slumping National League leaders tonight.
The National Football League increased the salary of its commissioner, Pete Rozelle, by $10,000 to $60,000 a year yesterday and also announced the method of elections for the Football Hall of Fame.

GENEVA, May 24 Arthur H. Dean, chief United States delegate at the seventeen-nation disarmament conference, said today that the United States and the Soviet Union planned to present a joint declaration condemning war propaganda.
WASHINGTON, May 24 Cuba has turned to the Soviet Union for emergency aid and is encouraging free enterprise by small farmers in moves designed to solve her food crisis.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, May 24 (AP)--Foreign Minister Subandrio said today that the appeal of U Thant, Acting Secretary General of the United Nations, for resumption of negotiations on Netherlands New Guinea should be directed to the Dutch.
The second orbital flight by an American astronaut, while more scientifically oriented than the first, has not resolved the basic medical problems affecting prolonged space journeys.
A strong plea to all Government and business interests here to help combat the continuing decline in the port's foreign waterborne trade was made here yesterday by the Port of New York Authority.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, May 24 Robert K.A. Gardiner, chief of the United Nations Congo operation said today "it is too early to be sure or optimistic" about the outcome of the talks here on ending the secession of Katanga Province.
ALEXANDRIA, Va., May 24 Mrs. John Paton Davies, a missionary in China for more than forty years and the mother of two foreign service officers, died here today. She was 84 years old.
The discount store came to Fifth Avenue yesterday as E.J. Korvette, Inc., opened for business in a richly appointed eightstory building at Forty-seventh Street.
WASHINGTON, May 24 (UPI) The Senate Housing subcommittee voted today to expand the Administration's proposed half billion dollar transit aid program by authorizing $300,000,000 for loans.

GRAND TURK, B.W.I., May 24 Lieut. Comdr. M. Scott Carpenter returned to dry earth tonight to an emotional reunion with two fellow-astronauts who for several agonizing moments today had wondered if they would ever see him alive again.
CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., May 24 An astronaut in a Mercury capsule can do nothing to change the direction of his travels through space except fire his retro rockets and come down to earth.

ALBANY, May 24 The Public Service Commission today authorized the New Haven Railroad to discontinue on Sunday the sale of sixty-ride unrestricted monthly commutation tickets and ten-ride weekly tickets for travel within the state.

The calm of an afternoon devoted to the appreciation and reward for creative endeavors was shattered yesterday when Alan Dugan, Brooklyn-born poet, accepted a fellowship to the American Academy in Rome, and then dressed down the honor societies that awarded it. Mr. Dugan, 1962 Pulitzer Prize winner, felt that someone else should have received the fellowship.
BUENOS AIRES, May 24 President Jose Maria Guido was under attack today both in a Federal appellate court and by the large Popular Radical party.
WASHINGTON, May 26 The United States has severely rebuked the Right-wing Laotian Government for its political and military conduct in recent weeks, State Department officials reported today.

The Sonnenblick-Goldman Company, mortgage brokers, have leased about half a floor in 100 East Forty-second Street through Peter H. Korn, assistant vice president of Cushman Wakefield, Inc., agent for the building. building.
As Lieut. Comdr. Scott Carpenter was orbiting the earth yesterday, a handful of scientists some twenty feet below ground on the East Side were working out problems in simulated space conditions.
Major Canadian nickel producers have lowered the price of their metal 2 cents a pound to 79 cents, the first cut for this product since 1948.
More than 500 persons attended the dedication yesterday of a new $3,500,000 Rehabilitation Research and Professional Education building of the Institute for the Crippled and Disabled.
WASHINGTON, May 24 The House Ways and Means Committee will meet next Thursday to take a final vote on the Administration's trade expansion bill.
A 3-day-old boy showed "marked improvement" at Metropolitan Hospital yesterday after receiving a second transfusion of a rare type of blood.

WASHINGTON, May 25 The Association of American Railroads and the American Trucking Associations reported increases in revenue freight for the week ended May 19, compared with the corresponding week of 1961.

BANGKOK, Fiday, May 25 (Reuters) A squadron of su personic British Hawker Hunter jet fighters began arriving here today to support United States military forces in Thailand.

WASHINGTON, May 24 The president of the National Guard Association charged today that Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara had been "poorly advised" in moving to reorganize and reduce the Army reserve forces.

Two builders and the corporation they control were indicted yesterday by a Kings County grand jury on charges of grand larceny and fraudulent representation growing out of the sale of new homes in the Mill Basin section of Brooklyn.
A $25,000 study of the effect of urban renewal on small businesses in a twelve-block area downtown was authorized yesterday by the Board of Estimate.

BALTIMORE, May 24 (AP) Charlie Lau missed one of Hoyt Wilhelm's knuckleballs for a passed ball in the eleventh inning tonight and Dick McAuliffe raced home with the run that gave the Detroit Tigers a 5-4 victory over the Baltimore Orioles.
Richard S. Childs, for more than fifty years a leader in civic causes throughout the nation, received more than 200 messages yesterday on his eightieth birthday.

NAHA, Okinawa, May 17 The landing of a United States Marine "floating battalion" last week in Thailand has left no gap in the United States'. ability to deal with other local crises in the Far East, a Third Division spokesman said here yesterday.

A sigh of relief went up across the nation yesterday following the news that Lieut. Comdr. M. Scott Carpenter had been found in a life raft in the Atlantic after his triple orbit of the earth. Until it became known that radio contact with Commander Carpenter's space capsule had been lost, the flight had aroused less interest than that of Lieut. Col. John H. Glenn Jr. last February.

ROME, May 24 The former Papal Nuncios to Spain and Portugal respectively, Ildebrando Cardinal Antoniutti and Giovanni Cardinal Panico received their wide-brimmed, tasseled red hats from Pope John XXIII in a private ceremony in the Vatican today.
LONDON, May 24 The United States will defend Europe as it would America, a British Government spokesman asserted today.
WILLEMSTAD, Curacao, May 24-All four games of the thirteenth-round of the Candidates' Chess Tournament were adjourned yesterday.

IBADAN, Nigeria, May 22 Samuel L. Akintola has stubbornly refused to accept his dismissal as Premier of Nigeria's Western Region. However, tension is easing in the country's constitutional and ideological crisis.

Now that Lieut. Comdr. M. Scott Carpenter has duplicated the success of Lieut. Col. John H. Glenn Jr. on a three-orbit Mercury flight, project officials are expected to press on immediately to more ambitious things.
PITTSBURGH, May 24 The National Labor Relations Board is seeking a Federal court injunction against a Teamster Union local on the ground of unfair labor practices against the H.J. Heinz Company.

The Commercial Solvents Corporation, 260 Madison Avenue, sent a letter to each of its 17,917 stockholders yesterday regarding its relations with Billie Sol Estes, the Texas business man who is under Federal indictment for fraud in building his financial empire.
Sugar futures showed gains in heavy trading and led activity on the New York markets yesterday. Cocoa and copper futures weakened and cottonseed oil futures advanced. Other Commodities were mixed.
Attention in the bond market yesterday was turned to taxexempt municipal and state bonds, which gained strength in active trading.
DICK HOWSER, the freshman shortstop of the Kansas City Athletics, was at bat against the Red Sox last year and Joe Ginsberg, a rather amiable whack, was the Boston catcher.

MADRID, May 24 (Reuters) The Spanish Government published today increased coal prices designed to meet miners' pay claims, but men in the Asturias region were reported to have reservations about ending their illegal five-week-old strike.

KIAMESHA LAKE, N.Y., May 24 The newly elected president of the Rabbinical Assembly, the international association of Conservative rabbis, outlined his program today to strengthen every phase of Jewish life.
DENVER, May 24 (UPI) Mrs. Helen Maurer Nielsen, a close friend of former President Dwight D. Eisenhower and Mrs. Eisenhower, died today. She was 61 years old.

The New York City Center of Drama and Music yesterday reported a loss of $12,401 for the fiscal year ending April 28. The actual loss, however, was $407,869, but grants and contributions totaling $395,468 reduced the deficit.

The Bonn Government has now submitted its own counter-proposals on the issue of Berlin. It accepts the principle of continued talks with Soviet Russia and of the American plan for a working agreement on Berlin to stabilize the status quo, but it also asks substantial modifications of this plan.
BOSTON, May 24 (UPI) Ed Bressoud's two-run fifth-inning double gave the Boston Red Sox a 7-5 victory today over the Minnesota Twins.
YONKERS, May 24-Thunder, lightning, rain, a sloppy track and four other hardy pacers failed to stop Lehigh Hanover tonight at Yorkers Raceway.
CHICO, Calif., May 24 (AP) An explosion destroyed a Titan missile and wrecked its launching silo today during a fueling test at the newly constructed Chico missile complex.

The first private American commercial loans to private Greek institutions in more than twenty years amounting to $14,000,000 were announced here yesterday by Demetrius Galanis, Deputy Governor of the Bank of Greece.
ROME, May 24 The number of Roman Catholic priests is declining in areas with strong population increases, according to the First International Congress for Ecclesiastic Vocations.

Conference on the unauthorized practice of law under the auspices of the American Bar Association with the cooperation of the Joint Bar Associations Committee, Association of the Bar of the City of New York, 42 West Forty fourth Street, 9:30 A.M. Afternoon session, 2 P.M. Continues tomorrow morning.
RIO DE JANEIRO, May 24 President Kennedy has approved July 30 as the date for the start of his official visit to Brazil, informed sources said today.
ALBANY, May 24 The State Board of Regents was expected tomorrow to cancel the licenses of about twenty-five physicians authorized to practice in the state.
BOSTON, May 24--Gov. John A. Volpe of Massachusetts said today he planned to suggest Federal legislation to stem the "Freedom Ride North" movement.
ALGIERS, May 24 The sentence of life imprisonment for Raoul Salan in Paris last night was greeted here today with shocked surprise by the Moslem population.

The quick dispatch of American troops to Thailand last week was a useful display of strength and decisiveness in answer to Communist advances in Laos. In Bangkok the move has been psychologically reassuring, but the American force, it now seems evident, will not, in the foreseeable future, be called on to help withstand a Communist military invasion of Thailand.

DUESSELDORF, Germany, May 24 (AP) Dr. Erich Mende was re-elected today as chairman of the conservative Free Democratic party, which he has led to new political strength and participation in West Germany's coalition Government.
A clinic on housing rehabilitation was warned yesterday that unless the "stubborn, ostrich-like attitude" of planners was reviewed, New York would become a city of "only highrise, massive bulk."
Ground-breaking ceremonies for the $1,110,000 Barnard College student center will be held today at 2 P.M. at the site on Broadway between 116th and 117th Streets.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., May 24 Operating income of the Tennessee Valley Authority power system was $44,315,000 in the nine months ended March 31, according to the quarterly report issued today. The income was 10 per cent higher than in the period a year earlier.
SAIGON, Vietnam, May 24 The South Vietnamese Seventh Division continued today to inflict heavy casualties on a Communist guerrilla force trapped on the southern edge of the marshy Plain of Reeds.
TOKYO, May 24 (AP) Hsinhua, the Communist Chinese Press agency, charged today that five Indian soldiers had crossed the Tibetan border in the Longju sector May 18.
CHICAGO, May 24 Donald D. Van Slyke of Port Jefferson, L.I., clinical chemist was named the winner today of the American Medical Association's first Scientific Achievement Award.
HOUSTON, May 24 (AP) The Cincinnati Reds halted the Houston Colts' three-game winning string, 5 0, tonight behind Joe Jay's six-hit pitching and the hitting of Leo Cardenas and Don Blasingame.
WASHINGTON, May 24, (UPI) Two committees of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York split today over Federal wiretap legislation.
RIVER VALE, N.J., May 24 For the third year in a row, Apawamis won the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association interclub championship today.

ALBANY, May 24 Governor Rockefeller suggested today the possibility of using state financing, similar to that now available for middle-income housing, for the construction of nursing homes under private auspices.

WASHINGTON, May 24 (UPI) The White House announced today that Malcolm M. Kilduff, a career public affairs officials at the State Department, will become an assistant White House press secretary in June.

IN the current issue of Horizon, John Mason Brown records three significant episodes in the intellectual life of the late Robert E. Sherwood. They show the paradox by which a disintegrating world added stature to a man of principle.

BANGKOK, Thailand, May 24 (AP) United States infantrymen were issued cartridges today for the rifles they have been carrying empty in their assignment to help thwart any Communist infiltration from Laos.

LONDON, May 25 (Reuters) A Soviet scientist today congratulated Lieut. Comdr. M. Scott Carpenter and said the second American orbital space flight underlined the need for Soviet-United States space cooperation.

After many years in the service of the city as an educator and public official, Dr. John J. Theobald will retire from active duty as Superintendent of Schools on Sept. 1, four years after he took that office. He will enter private business appropriate to his experience in education.

An unemployed plumber went around and around in a bank's revolving door three times yesterday before deciding to enter and try a robbery, the police said.

WASHINGTON, May 24 (AP)--Terming racial discrimination in Washington housing an insult to America and its foreign guests, a State Department officer appealed today for a law to eliminate such practices.

BRIELLE, N.J., May 24 Roland Moore, a former antiques dealer in New York who specialized in Chinese art, died yesterday in Fitkin Memorial Hospital, Neptune. He was 74 years old and lived on Ocean View Avenue.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, May 24 President Tito celebrates his 70th birthday tomorrow. The occasion also marks the twenty-fifth anniversary of his elevation to the leadership of the Yugoslav Communist party.

Daily average borrowings by member banks of the Federal Reserve System declined $17,000,000 to $47,000,000 in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.

Joseph Eger and his West Side Symphony Orchestra marked a first birthday last night with a concert in the Clark Center of the West Side Young Men's Christian Association. Since the stage of that ex-ballroom is a trifle small, the orchestra, played on the floor, with seats arranged "in the round." Warnings of approaching severe storms and possible tornadoes have become increasingly accurate through the far-seeing radar scanners that the Weather Bureau has been operating from atop the R.C.A. Building since March of last year, the bureau said yesterday.
FREETOWN, Sierra Leone, May 25 (Reuters) The people of this new nation went to the polls today in the first general election here since the country became independent of Britain in April, 1961.

WASHINGTON, May 25 (UPI) Government auditors charged today that the Air Force spent $63,000,000 developing and producing a new type of helicopter when the Army already had one that would have done just as well.
WASHINGTON, May 25 (AP) Following is the roll-call vote by which the Senate passed today a farm bill carrying most of the Administration's request for crop controls:

WASHINGTON, May 25 (UPI) Another research rocket was fired into the upper atmosphere from the Government's station in Wallops Island, Va., today as part of the investigation of what future space travelers will face.

ATLANTA, May 25 Dr. and Mrs. Allen Candler Smith have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Virginia Eron Smith, to Thomas Edwin Taylor. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Fielding Taylor of Newnan.
The Rev. Dr. Julius Mark, senior rabbi of Temple EmanuEl, will be honored today at a special service marking the fortieth anniversary of his ordination.
A Government witness testified in Federal Court yesterday that one of three defendants on trial for bribery was innocent of the charge.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 25 After two coups and a countercoup, within nine months, the Syrian Government is again in difficulties.
RICHMOND, Va., May 25 (AP) Clifford Ann Creed rallied on the last two holes today and defeated Mrs. Judy Eller Street, 1 up, in the semi-finals of the Southern women's amateur golf tournament.

GLEN COVE, L.I., May 25 Mrs. Walter Cooperstein of Lake Success, L.I., scored a 39, 40 79 and led the field of fifty-one in the Women's Cross County Golf Association's tournament at the Nassau Country Club today.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, May 25--An international convention establishing the absolute liability of the operator of a nuclear powered ship was approved here today by the International Diplomatic Conference on Maritime Law.
WACO, Tex., May 25 (UPI) Abb Curtis, the chief of Southwest Conference basketball referees, said today he is sure that two officials, Bill Johnson and Odell Preston, participated in point-shaving.

HARTFORD, May 25 A. Searle Pinney of Brookfield, Republican state chariman, announced today his personal support for a state party ticket to be headed by John Alsop of Avon for Governor and John Davis Lodge of Westport for the United States Senate.

CHICAGO, May 25 (UPI) A Federal District Judge today accused the Department of Justice of "strong-arm tactics" in seeking to shut off telephone and telegraph service to two agencies that specialize in racing news.
Sales of the Todd Shipyards Corporation for its fiscal year ended on March 31 rose to $125,232,339 from $107,951,896 the preceding year. The company, however, showed a net ...

SELDOM has the mind of a writer been so tenaciously explored as it is in Herschel Baker's "William Hazlitt" Since Mr. Baker can make the clash of ideas as stirring as a naval duel on the high seas, his book has the sustained interest of a narrative chronicle.

NORWALK, Conn., May 25 Mr. and Mrs. William H. Harrar have made known the engagement of Mr. Harrar's daughter, Miss Leslie Aitken Harrar, to David Treadway Carr. He is the son of the Rev. and Mrs. Henry L. Carr of Long Beach, Calif.
Southwestern Bell Telephone Company announced plans yesterday to offer $100,000,000 in debentures on about Aug. 7. Part of the proceeds would be used by the company to repay ...

OLD GREENWICH, Conn., May 25 W. Vaughn Ischie, executive vice president and director of manufacturing of the Sinclair Refining Company, died of a heart attack in Greenwich Hospital today. He was 60 years old and lived at 7 Old Wagon Road.
If the prices of canvas are bullish these days, three theatre-struck as well as business-wise young Philadelphians may be held partly responsible.
Proceeds of the premiere preview of "Advise and Consent" on June 5 at the Criterion Theatre will be shared by the National Association for Mental Health and the National Multiple Sclerosis Society.
PARIS, May 25 The execution of former Gen. Edmond Jouhaud, condemned to death last month for his role in organizing violent opposition to the French state, was stayed tonight.
City Investigation Commissioner Louis I. Kaplan withdrew last night from a new insurance company whose incorporators include a number of political figures.

Mrs. Helen M. Day Harris, runner-up in the women's amateur national singles tennis championships in 1889 and 1892, died Thursday in St. Barnabas Hospital for Chronic Diseases, the Bronx, after a long illness.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., May 25 A choral evesong, commemorating the golden jubilee of the Protestant Episcopal Church of St. John the Divine here, will be held in the church on South Columbus Avenue at 4 P.M. Sunday.
BOSTON, May 25 A 12year-old boy whose severed right arm was sewn back into place two days ago continued to improve here today.

PARIS, May 25 Whitney Reed, America's top-ranked tennis player, was knocked out of the French tournament at Roland-Garros Stadium today by Guiseppe Merlo, an unranked, unseeded Italian. The scores were 6 4, 6 4, 6 0.
A capacity crowd of 18,929 saw Buddy (Nature Boy) Rogers of Camden, N.J., wrestle to a draw with Cowboy Bob Ellis in the feature exhibition match at Madison Square Garden last night.

MADRID, May 25 (AP) Strikes appeared to be spreading today in Barcelona, Spain's second largest city and chief industrial center. Military and civilian authorities conferred there on measures to prevent an outbreak of violence in the labor unrest that has gripped parts of the nation for six weeks.

EL PASO, Tex., May 25 (AP) Creditors of Billie Sol Estes lodged claims totaling $23,799,651.39 against him here today. The claims were filed with the clerk of the United States District Court because Mr. Estes' affairs have been placed in receivership.

BALTIMORE, May 25 (UPI) Manuel Yeaza's suspension was lightened by the Maryland State Racing Commission today after Johnny Rotz had testified that Ycaza "didn't bother my riding one little bit" in last Saturday's Preakness Stakes.
WASHINGTON, May 25 Conservation looks to the future, but the urgency is immediate, President Kennedy told the White House Conference on Conservation today.

TLEMCEN, Algeria, May 25 About 8,400 Algerian refugees have crossed the Moroccan-Algerian frontier in the last twelve days, after having been separated from their native land and isolated from the horrors of war since 1955.
It appeared yesterday that summer had come to the bond market prematurely, for the day was like a typical Friday of that season dull.
GENEVA, May 25 The United States and the Soviet Union announced today one of their first major agreements in the ten-week-old disarmament conference.
ATLANTIC CITY, May 25 George Meany said today that the merged labor movement would soon undertake a nationwide campaign to cut the standard work week from forty to thirty-five hours.

Baltusrol, the winner of Series II in the Women's Metroterclub team play, challenged the last team in Series I, Hollywood, yesterday and won, 9 5 , at the Green Brook Country Club in North Caldwell, N.J. Baltusrol thus returned to Series I after more than five years.
INGLEWOOD, Calif., May 25 (AP) The stakes-winning entry of Olden Times and Prove. It is expected to be favored in the Californian Handicap at Hollywood Park tomorrow.

A six-room model apartment is now open at Tower East, Third Avenue at Seventy-second Street. John Gerald of W J Sloane has designed the interiors, using a blend of Empire and Directoire antiques with reproductions. The apartment is open daily from 10 A.M. to 5:30 P.M.
VIENTIANE, Laos, May 25 (AP) Prince Souvanna Phouma, the neutralist leader, returned to Laos today for another attempt to form a coalition Government.
Many home owners are unaware that they can modernize their houses with help from the Government.
RYE, N.Y., May 25 Mrs. Ann Brevoort Eddy Walden, an author who used the name Ann Devoore, died yesterday in her home at 66 Milton Road here.
ALBANY, May 25 A laxity in teacher training was given today as one answer to the perennial question why children can't read as well as many adults think they should.
Mayor Wagner received an oral anti-polio inoculation yesterday when he took part in a public demonstration in City Hall Plaza.
LONDON, May 25 Most shares in the stock market resumed their downward trend today despite some early bargain hunting.
DALLAS, May 25 (AP) Mary Lena Faulk today pulled five strokes ahead at the halfway point of the $10,000 Civitan open.

WASHINGTON, May 25 (UPI) The Air Force said today that some sites selected for underground deployment of the Minuteman intercontinental ballistic missile probably would be relocated to meet new safety requirements.
COCOA BEACH, Fla., May 25 Evidence piled up today that much of the anxiety experienced by millions about the fate of Lieut. Comdr. M. Scott Carpenter yesterday could have been avoided.
Traffic Commissioner Henry A. Barnes, his propensity for making speeches and his disagreements with Robert Moses were lampooned yesterday by the Circus Saints and Sinners.

YONKERS, May 25 Lehigh Hanover's easy two-length victory in last night's mile-and-asixteenth Cane Prep at Yonkers Raceway stamped the Stanley Dancer-handled colt as the one to beat in next Thursday night's $110,965 William H. Cane Pace here.

NEWARK, May 25 Grace Protestant Episcopal Church will mark its 125th anniversary in a week's series of services beginning on Rogation Sunday, May 27, and closing with a parish corporate communion Sunday, June 3.
CHICAGO, May 25 (UPI) Al Smith hit two run-scoring triples and Joe Horlen survived a rocky third inning tonight to register his fourth victory as the Chicago White Sox beat the Minnesota Twins, 5 4.

Most elbow space at the railing of the New York Stock Exchange visitors' gallery was occupied yesterday by somewhat glum watchers. "These are exciting days," said one young insurance executive, with no animation in his voice.

Twenty-two winners in the annual Avery and Jule Hopwood creative-writing contest at the University of Michigan were announced yesterday. The awards, for fiction, drama, poetry and essays, totaled $14,500. The largest single award, $1,400 for poetry, went to Philip D. Church, a graduate student from Girard, Ohio, for a volume entitled "The Season's Snare."

A fair-haired miss of 13 stood, self-possessed, before a jury a few days ago and talked engagingly about Japanese dolls. Not once did she falter over the tongue-twisting Japanese names for the intricate doll family.
PORTLAND, Ore., May 25 (UPI) Col. Homer B. Millard, who founded two military preparatory schools, died here on Wednesday at the age of 64.

WASHINGTON, May 25 Keith Funston, president of the New York Stock Exchange, defended his organization's policing activities today in the concluding public session of the Securities and Exchange Commission's special inquiry into the securities market.
WASHINGTON, May 25 The Defense Department said today that three Soviet ships were stationed near the United States nuclear testing area in the Pacific, apparently on an intelligence mission.
The nation's basic engineering needs on urban congestion, traffic, smog, housing, water pollution and noise control are being neglected, an Engineers Joint Council committee reported yesterday.
ROME, May 25 A 1,100year-old Vatican wall tower that Pope John XXIII ordered renovated will be ready for him by mid-June, a Vatican spokesman said today.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), May 25 Dr. Nahum Goldmann, president of the World Zionist Organization, said today that he believed Premier David Ben-Gurion deliberately wanted to damage his position by criticizing him for representations Dr. Goldmann had made on Israel's behalf.

ITHACA, N.Y., May 25 Pennsylvania and a considerably changed Cornell crew will row here tomorrow in a race that should establish the East's leading varsity contender in the intercollegiate association regatta in June.
PARIS, May 25 Robert Ricci, head of the Nina Ricci dressmaking house, was elected president today of the Chambre Syndicate de la Couture Parisienne, the French high fashion syndicate.
Leonard Sasso's Staretta brought back recollections of her retired stable-mate, Globemaster, by the manner in which, she raced to victory in the feature race at Aqueduct yesterday.

SAIGON, Vietnam, May 25 An American professor said tonight that the South Vietnamese security police were refusing to let him leave the country unless he signed a statement answering allegations that he and an American clergyman were involved in a propaganda plot against the regime of President Ngo Dinh Diem.
CHICAGO, May 25 The president of the American Medical Association charged today that President Kennedy had given "incorrect information" about the organization at his news conference Wednesday.

The world's largest air pollution control equipment has been ordered for the one-million-kilowatt power generator being built at the East River station of Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Charles E. Eble, president, announced yesterday.
WESTFIELD, N.J., May 25 Wes Ellis of Mountain Ridge shot a two-under-par 34, 36-70 at the Echo Lake Golf Club today and won the individual pro prize by two strokes in a proamateur tournament.

SAIGON, Vietnam, May 25 The Canadian and Indian members of the International Control Commission have found Communist North Vietnam guilty of subversion and covert aggression against South Vietnam, reliable sources said today.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., May 25 Dr. William H. Childs, Professor of Accounting at Hofstra College, died at Brooklyn Hospital yesterday after a heart operation. He was 59 years old and lived at 338A Jackson Street here.
New York's observance of Memorial Day, which falls next Wednesday, will begin today.

William Zeckendorf, New York real estate developer and investor, announced last night that he had purchased the Savoy Hilton Hotel on Fifth Avenue at Fifty-ninth Street from the Hilton Hotel Corporation.
FRANKLIN, Tex., May 25 The mysterious death of Henry H. Marshall has shaken this sleepy town in central Texas and has made amateur detectives of many of its 1,200 citizens.

Not long ago the Government and Moore-McCormack Lines in a joint effort built the luxurious liner Argentina. It cost $24,500,000, and the Government paid for about half, under Federal subsidy law. This week pickets and a strike forced withdrawal of the Argentina from her scheduled sailing; and nearly 245 passengers were notified within only a few hours of departure time that the cruise was off.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, May 25 (Reuters) Twenty-five women staged a protest against the Government's new "sabotage bill" outside the Johannesburg Stock Exchange today.
WASHINGTON, May 25 The Consumer Price Index has risen as much in the last three months as it did in the preceding twelve months.
NEW CANAAN, Conn., May 25 The little red schoolhouse on Carter Street, which flourished from 1865 until it was closed in 1957, will take a new lease on life tomorrow.
LONDON, May 25 Jo Grimond carried the Liberal party's attack on the Government north of the border tonight, with a plea for more nationalism and individualism for Scotland.

Mr. and Mrs. John Francis Melvin of 249 East Forty-eighth Street have announced the marriage of their daughter, Miss Andrea Somers deBraekeleer Melvin, to Peter Spelman Prentice. The bridegroom, a greatgrandson of the late John D. Rockefeller, is the son of Mrs. Ryan Prentice of New York and Paris and Spelman Prentice of Southampton, L.I., and San Francisco.

CHESTNUT HILL., Mass., May 25 Announcement has been made by Mrs. Herman A. Katz of the engagement of her daughter, Miss Elizabeth Katz, to Julian Daly. He is the son of Mrs. David Daly of New York and the late Mr. Daly.

APPLAUSE was showered on Jacques Tiffeau after the showing of a lightning collection of coats, suits and first-time sportswear for the concern of Tiffeau Busch. Buyers' pencils kept the fast pace of the models who wore fleet, lowheeled shoes.
HERKIMER, N.Y., May 25 (AP) Abram Zoller, former State Supreme Court Justice and a Mayor of Little Falls, died today at his home after an illness of several months. He was 79 years old.

COVENTRY, England, May 25 A new and boldly designed Coventry Cathedral, built to replace the one wrecked by Nazi incendiary bombs twenty-two years ago, was consecrated here today in an ancient and majestic ceremony.

The offices of the Child Study Association at 9 East Eightyninth Street have been turned into a temporary art gallery where a silent auction for fifty paintings and drawings will be held from Monday to June 4.
LENOX, Mass., May 25 Mrs. Caroline Mitchell Stokes, widow of the Rev. Dr. Anson Phelps Stokes, educator, minister and author, died today in her home here after a long illness. She was 87 years old.
WASHINGTON, May 25 (UPI) The Defense Department acknowledged today it had wasted millions of dollars under cost-plus-fixed-fee contracts for the development and purchaseing of military hardware.

WASHINGTON, May 25 (UPI)--Three Senate Republicans attacked the Agriculture Department today for what they called "atrocious," "inexcusable" and "unconscionable" delay in removing Government grain from storage elevators formerly controlled by Billie Sol Estes.
LARCHMONT, N.Y., May 25 A record of 119 yachts fled to the eastward late today in the seventeenth Block Island race of the Storm Trysail Club.
A hilly and rocky tract of land can cause many difficulties for a home community, but builders sometimes find that such terrain helps them to create a more attractive colony of houses.

A WELL-MADE, well-chilled soup is one of the most de lightful ways to start lunch or dinner on a hot day. Cooks discovered that fact long ago as indicated by such traditional chilled soups as the Spanish gazpacho, Scandinavian fruit soups and Russian borsch.
SEATTLE, May 25 The Philadelhpia Orchestra, on a cross-country tour, played the first of two concerts last night at the new Opera House.

With stock prices heading downstairs clippety-clop this last week, worried Wall Street market men were wondering if the Federal Reserve Board would be coming to their aid with a cut in margin requirements the amount of cash needed to support credit purchases of stock.

ONE piece of antique silver won't fill a hope chest, but it will make an unusual gift for a bride. A large collection of sterling and silver-plated furnishings and table accessories that recently arrived from England might be viewed with this in mind.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 25 (UPI) Billy Pierce, aided by home runs by Willie Mays and Orlando Cepeda, scored his seventh victory without a loss tonight as the first-place San Francisco Giants beat the Philadelphia Phillies, 10 7.
Seven races, four over obstacles and three on the turf, are programmed for the annual oneday meeting of the Adjacent Hunts Racing Association at the Blind Brook Club course in Purchase, N.Y., today.
WASHINGTON, May 25 (AP) Chuck Essegian's eighth-inning home run, his twelfth of the season, gave the Cleveland Indians a 2-1 victory tonight over the Washington Senators.
GRAND TURK, B.W.I., May 26 The Project Mercury medical team pronounced M. Scott Carpenter today to have come through five hours in space with no significant physiological effects.

The cold-blooded murder of two detectives during a Brooklyn hold-up last week was followed by fine police work in the rapid apprehension of the major suspects. But our congratulations to the Police Department for its efficiency in this especially shocking crime are tempered by our concern over the evident violation of the civil rights of some of the persons arrested.
PLATTSBURGH, N.Y., May 25 (AP) David Rubinoff, the violinist, made his final appearance on a concert stage tonight.

WASHINGTON, May 25 An automatic scanner patented this week is capable of continuously judging the fat content of bacon and guiding a slicing knife accordingly. The resulting packages will have the same number of slices and the same weight.
DANVILLE, Va., May 25 Dr. Edmund Jennings Lee, for twenty-one years rector of Chatham Hall, died Thursday. He was 85 years old.
VILLANOVA, Pa., May 26 The eighty-sixth annual outdoor track and field championships of the Intercollegiate Association of Amateur Athletes of America opened today on a record note.
ROME, May 25 The Golden Colosseum, a Roman tourism trophy, was awarded tonight to President Kennedy.
WASHINGTON, May 25 Walter Lippmann, the columnist, said tonight that he thought the "world balance of forces" had "become rather more favorable to the West" in the last year.
PARIS, May 25--During the last U. S. Presidential elections perhaps the most profound if least defined issue was that of American prestige and the American image abroad.
Some small stores in the city, chiefly independently owned groceries, are bypassing trading stamps.

The Rev. Dr. Stuart Hamilton Merriam yesterday attacked a presbytery commission's request that he remove his belongings from the Broadway Presbyterian Church. He called it "just a pirates' act an act of pirates coming on a ship and attempting to scuttle it."
The threat of a network of coal slurry pipelines has the railroads concerned.

ALBANY, May 25 The State Board of Regents today canceled the licenses of twenty-four physicians, including the son of one Regent, because their grades on licensing examinations had been altered from failing to passing.
The world has seldom, if ever, experienced a situation quite like that which developed with the recent massive flow of people from continental China into the tiny colony of Hong Kong.

The author, director, producer and temporary carpenter, set designer and electrician of "Night Life" conferred yesterday in an office at 881 Seventh Avenue. It was a one-man conference. Sidney Kingsley was at work on his new play.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 25 A Security Council meeting on the Indian-Pakistani dispute over Kashmir, scheduled for next Monday, was definitely postponed today.
HOLLWYOOD, Calif., May 25 Three key movie unions will open a long-threatened picketing war tomorrow night against American film stars who refuse to make movies in the United States.

The White House conference on conservation this week was the first such meeting since Theodore Roosevelt's historic congress of governors in 1908. It was, quite evidently, part of the Adpublic interest in the preservation of America's ministration's continuing effort to stimulate natural resources.

The impact of Lieut. Comdr. M. Scott Carpenter's space flight upon the emerging countries of Africa was suggested yesterday by the President of the Ivory Coast. He called it "a great victory for peace."
HONG KONG, May 25--The flow of refugees from Communist China fell abruptly to a trickle today after four weeks in which about 70,000 persons crossed the border into this British colony.
BONN, Germany, May 25 The Cabinet will consider communist East Germany's move for large trade credits from West Germany next week, a Government spokesman said today.

WASHINGTON, May 25 (AP) Disability pay of a retired Navy captain who was wounded at Pearl Harbor has been stopped while the Controller General decides on the officer's protest to the Pentagon over application of conflict-of-interest regulations.

ABOARD THE CARRIER INTREPID, at Sea, May 24 (Delayed) M. Scott Carpenter offered his own bottled water and special space food to two parachuting rescuers as they bobbed in separate liferafts in the Atlantic today.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 25--The Netherlands has presented a detailed complaint against Indonesian attacks in Netherlands New Guinea to U Thant, the Atcing Secretary General, without asking specific action.

OTTAWA, May 25--U Thant, Acting Secretary General of the United Nations, said today that the policies of the United States and the Soviet Union were shaped by an "obsession with the past" rather than a realistic appraisal of the present.

WILLEMSTAD, Curacao, May 25 Tigran Petrosian of the Soviet Union tied for the lead in the Candidates' Chess Tournament by defeating Miroslav Filip of Czechoslovakia in a Queen's Gambit Declined lasting twenty-eight moves.

We go on the proposition that no matter how able (and how likely to win) the Republican candidates for state office and United States Senator may be, the people are entitled to expect from the Democratic party a ticket that offers a reasonable and attractive alternative.
MOSCOW, May 25 Premier Khrushchev said today that the United States action in landing troops in Thailand "seriously hinders a settlement of the Laotian problem."

BEHIND the "Do Not Remove" tag appearing on all upholstery and bedding sold in New York State stands a small but vigilant army of inspectors, the New York Department of State, a testing laboratory and the courts.
YORK, Pa., May 25 (AP) Mayor John F. Snyder of this south central Pennsylvania city opposed today the resettlement of Cuban refugees here.
WASHINGTON, May 25 (AP) The Senate confirmed by voice vote today President Kennedy's nomination of Mrs. Eugenie Moore Anderson of Red Wing, Minn., to be minister to Bulgaria.

Delinquent deportment afield does not automatically disqualify a chap from membership in the Association of Bonafide Baseball Heroes if he performs a good deed with his bat. Hence, Chico Fernandez earned admission last night at the Stadium despite three blunders with his throwing arm and glove.
A Moore-McCormack Lines official told the National Labor Relations Board yesterday that the ship line used its thirtyfour Atlantic and Gulf Coast vessels interchangeably on all of its trade routes.

The Society of Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center has re-elected Mrs. Donald Perkins president. Other officers elected were Mrs. Harold L. Behlke and Nicholas Benton, vice presidents; Mrs. Elliot H. Goodwin, secretary; David W. Devens, treasurer, and Carl W. Timpson Jr. assistant treasurer.
A gift of $500,000 was made yesterday to Barnard College in honor of Mrs. Millicent C. McIntosh, who is retiring as president at the end of June.
GRAND TURK, B.W.I., May 25 M. Scott Carpenter apologized today because his space flight had turned into a "cliff-hanger" that kept so many people, including his family, worried about his safety.

SALISBURY, Southern Rhodesia, May 25 The Government of Southern Rhodesia refused passports today to four officials of the territory's Zimbabwe African People's Union. They had been scheduled to attend a Pan African conference in Accra, Ghana, early next month.

RICHMOND, Va., May 25 Clifton A. Wishart, executive vice president of Reynolds International, Inc., subsidiary of the Reynolds Metals Company, died here yesterday in a hospital. He was 60 years old and had lived for the last two and a half years in Hamilton, Bermuda, headquarters of the subsidiary.
PARIS, May 25 A new form of investment a mutual fund that will invest in other, mutual funds in the leading nations of the free world has been formed in Geneva.

The National Council of Churches has named Mrs. Theodore O. Wedel, a leader in the Protestant cooperative church movement, as assistant general secretary for program. The appointment was announced yesterday by the Rev. Dr. Roy G. Ross, the council's general secretary.

WASHINGTON, May 25 (UPI) The United States was reported today to have apologized to Japan for a "breach of etiquette" in having failed to give advance notice on the movement of United States military planes from Japan to Thailand.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 25 The Speedway Golf Course again proved a fast track for the field in the $50,000 Indianapolis open tourney today as Joe Campbell and Dave Ragan tied for the lead with elevenunder-par totals of 131 for thirty-six holes. The leaders eclipsed the record 132 for this distance that was set by Jerry Barber two years ago when the tournament was first held.
KAMPALA, Uganda, May 25 (Reuters) British troops killed sixty tribesmen in a night clash with 1,000 men returning from a tribal raid in northeast Uganda, it was announced today.
ROME, May 25 Italy endorsed today a plan for a nuclear force for the North Atlantic Treaty Organization as a means to curb French and possibly West German nuclear ambitions.

Phil Moyer of Portland, Ore., who weighed 210 pounds four months ago, will be down to 160 when he steps into the Madison Square Garden ring tonight to face Ted Wright of Detroit in their scheduled tenround middleweight fight.

RIO DE JANIERO, May 25 The Brazilian Congress gave final approval today to a bill raising military and civilian wages by 40 per cent. The passage was a serious blow to the Administration's anti-inflation program.
WASHINGTON, May 25 The Senate passed today a complex and controversial farm bill carrying many of the stiff production controls and penalties asked by President Kennedy. The vote was 42 to 38.
JERSEY CITY, May 25 This city's Housing Authority was accused today of de facto racial segregation in its eight low-cost housing projects.

WASHINGTON, May 25 (AP) The White House announced today that President Kennedy has accepted with regret the resignation of Grant Stockdale of Miami, Fla., as Ambassador to Ireland. The resignation will become effective on July 6.

International Nickel Company of Canada, Ltd., is holding to its earlier estimate that it would sell as much or more nickel from its own mines and plant in 1962 as in 1961, Henry S. Wingate, chairman, said yesterday.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 25 West Germany has granted a total of $2,900,000 to 792 victims of Nazi "scientific" experiments, the Economic and Social Council announced today.

IBADAN, Nigeria, May 25 (Reuters) Tear gas was used to quell fighting by rival factions of the ruling party in the West Nigerian Parliament today over dismissal of Chief Samuel Akintola as Regional Premier last week.
WASHINGTON, May 25 Two Negro youths told today of having been held seventyeight days in a seven-by-sevenfoot jail cell at Baton Rouge, La., for having protested racial discrimination.

A number of Seventh Avenue manufacturers have found they can keep their factories and workrooms humming during the slack April-June period by offering lower prices to retailers who place early orders for furtrimmed winter coats.

THE annual Eastern States regional tournament be gan yesterday at the StatlerHilton Hotel with 210 men's pairs and 182 women's pairs entered in the opening twosession contests.
ROBERT RUARK'S AFRICA" went with gun, camera and strong opinions, on a vivid filmed tour of the Dark Continent over Channel 4 last night.
State Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz said yesterday that he would establish a bureau to combat "an alarming increase," in the number of persons illegally practicing law in the state.
GENEVA, May 25 (Reuters) Following is the text of the Declaration Against War Propaganda submitted by the United States and the Soviet Union to the disarmament conference here today.
BUDAPEST, Hungary, May 25 (UPI) Premier Janos Kadar appealed today to leading Western and Eastern diplomats for their support to help Hungary achieve good relations with all countries.
LISBON, Portugal, May 25 (AP) Dr. Julio Dantas, a former president of the Portuguese Academy of Science and one of Portugal's greatest poets and playwrights, died today in his home at the age of 86.
Nearly half the owners of a new middle-income cooperative apartment project to be built under the state's Mitchell-Lama program are Civil Service employes, a recent survey has disclosed.

CINCINNATI, May 25 (UPI) Moe Drabowsky of the Cincinnati Reds tonight scored his first victory since Aug. 14, 1960, by defeating his former teammates, the Chicago Cubs, 2 1. The game was marred by an injury to Ernie Banks.
SEATTLE, May 25 (AP) Secretary of State Dean Rusk urged today that space activities be brought under international regulation at once, lest space is turned into a military arena.
ATLANTA, May 25 A threejudge Federal court held today that urban residents must be granted equal representation in at least one house of Georgia's General Assembly.
"WE tell our children to 'grow up' but we don't tell them how," according to Carolyn D. Goodman, acting director of community services of The Guidance Center of New Rochelle.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., May 25 The engagement of Miss Cynthia Ann Lowe, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Wallace Robert Lowe, to John Dwight Leggett 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leggett Jr. of New Canaan, Conn., has been announced by the future bride's parents.

Competition in the market for office space has placed the owners of older buildings in a squeeze. They face the prospect of having either to modernize their structures or to lower rents in order to avoid losing tenants to new buildings.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., May 25 (UPI) The segregationist Capital Citizens Council today sent three more Negroes to Hyannis, Mass., and promised that three more would be on the way soon.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., May 25 (AP) Two administrative regions of the Methodist Church will be merged into a single unit as a result of a vote today by the New York Conference. The delegates voted 193 to 86 to merge with the New York East Conference.

WILMINGTON, Del., May 25 (AP) The two top officers of the General Motors Corporation predicted today increases in business for 1962 and several years ahead for the nation's biggest industrial enterprise.

MELBORNE, Australia, May 27 (Reuters) Australian research equipment will be launched into space by a United States rocket, it was announced tonight.
A proposal that unions selfinsure their welfare plans by setting up a central reserve pool has been made in an official labor publication.
CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., May 27 Lieut. Comdr. M. Scott Carpenter returned to the starting point of his space journey today and was honored as a national hero.
The Jewish People's Philharmonic Chorus, Maurice Rauch, conductor, gave its second concert of the season Saturday night at Town Hall.
A smal1 order of Roman Catholic Negro nuns that has a novitiate in a secluded section of Staten Island had about a thousand dinner guests yesterday.
Obies their name drawn from Off Broadway's initials were distributed on Saturday at the Village Gate, 185 Thompson Street.

PITTSBURGH, May 27 Liquidation of steel inventories seemed to be picking up speed last week. Orders of the largest mills indicated users would reduce stocks by 1,000,000 tons in June. This would be double the estimated May reduction.
RIO DE JANEIRO, May 27 Brazil's foreign policy will come up for a vote of confidence Tuesday in the Chamber of Deputies.

A major change of one-way street patterns to speed traffic and increase safety on the lower West Side will be put into effect next Sunday. The basic changes were announced last February by Traffic Commissioner Henry A.

NUERBURGRING, Germany, May 27 (UPI) Phil Hill, the world champion from Santa Monica, Calif., and Olivier Gendebien of Belgium won the Nuerburgring 1,000-kilometer sports car race today in a factory Ferrari. They covered the distance in 7 hours 33 minutes 27.2 seconds, an average speed of 82.4 miles an hour. The time was slower than last year's winning average.

He sat shirtless and relaxed as he sipped a cup of coffee in the Yankee clubhouse before the start of yesterday's double-header with the Detroit Tigers at the Stadium. PARIS; May 27 (Reuters)-- Rod Laver of Australia, who is bidding for all four of the world's major lawn-tennis titles this year, was injured in the French championships today. He recovered, however, and beat Sergid Jacobini of Italy, 4--6, 6--3, 7--5, 6--1.

CAIRO, May 27 President Gamal Abdel Nasser declared tonight that in the future the United Arab Republic must have a President who can be removed if he deviates from the national interest or seeks personal gain.

Anti-Communist pickets turned out at two points in the midtown area at 2 P.M. yesterday. They expressed support for the Government of Guatemala and protested the imprisonment of the Yugoslav author, Milovan Djilas.
MOSCOW, May 27 The Soviet Union's Prosecutor General said today the country now had "reliable guarantees" that the terroristic practices of the Stalin era "will never again be repeated."

The New York Zoological Society reported yesterday it had received a $266,400 grant from the John A. Hartford Foundation for a three-year program of research in marine biochemistry at the New York Aquarium, Coney Island.
CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., May 26 There is perhaps no painter today whose art is more warmly received but less durable than that of a 30-yearold blonde named Cecilia Bibby.
METTET, Belgium, May 27 (Reuters) Heinz Starke, a German racing driver, died after a crash today with another German driver during a Furmula 2 race.

Deere Co., producers of farm machinery had lower sales in the second quarter and for the half-year ended April 30, compared with those of the preceding year, according to the report released today. THE wonder of Moscow housing-project expansion, as personified by a big, genial construction leader who tenderly courts a young unwed mother and befriends her little brother this is "Apartment In Moscow," which opened Saturday at the Cameo.
HONG KONG, May 27 (AP) An American immigration official said today several thousand refugees from Communist China might be on their way to the United States "within two weeks."

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., May 27 The third annual antiques fair reconstructing the famous flea market of Paris and the Caledonian market of London will be held here on June 9 on the horse-show grounds of the Piping Rock Club. The Family Service Association of Nassau County will receive the proceeds.

An attack on the referee in the first game and fist-fights among fans provided a wild setting for the International Soccer League double-header yesterday at Downing Stadium, Randalls Island, as a crowd of 11,112 watchesd.
