A bank that favors the withholding of income taxes from interest payments plans to offer instant refunds to eligible depositors.

WASHINGTON, May 25 Following are the votes of Senators from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on major roll-calls in the week ended yesterday. There were no major roll-calls in the House of Representatives.

In what is hailed as its first major achievement, the seventeen-nation disarmament conference at Geneva has tentatively approved a declaration worked out between Soviet Russia and the United States calling again on all nations to refrain from war or the threat of war and to ban all war propaganda in order to facilitate total disarmament.

LONDON, May 27 Twelve pictures, including two Picasso drawings, paintings by Renoir and Mastisse and prints by Degas, have been stolen from the Lefevre Gallery here. The theft was discovered this afternoon.
The president of the National Conference on Social Welfare urged last night that Social Security be extended to provide health care for the aged.

A leasehold for eighty years on the property at the southwest corner of Second Avenue and Fiftieth Street has been purchased by 50 Associates, Inc., representing investors. William O. Land and Harry Lefton were the brokers. Jules Perlman was the lawyer for the sellers, who are clients of Walter Scott Co. Benjamin Pulier was the lawyer for the buyers.

MARTINSBURG, Iowa, May 27 (AP) A young man ambushed and killed his aunt and uncle in their lonely farm-house last night, then drove four cousins home from a dance and killed three of them, Sheriff John Wallerich said today.

The white people of South Africa fought bravely a long time ago to win their independence. For many years they have had it. For about a year they have been a republic and are not even a part of the British Commonwealth of Nations.

Alco Products, Inc., Schenectady, N.Y., a major supplier of Diesel-electric locomotives to countries around the world, is using a new method of protecting the locomotives from the damage of sun, wind and salt water during long ocean voyages on the deck of a freighter.
MILWAUKEE, May 27 (AP) The American Newspaper Guild struck. The Milwaukee sentinel today. The management of the city's only morning newspaper announced it would not publish editions for Monday.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 27--Two subcommittees of the United Nations Committee on the Peaceful Uses of Outer Space, one scientific and technical, the other legal, are to begin work in Geneva tomorrow.

Secretary of State Rusk has made an eloquent plea for an international system of law to keep space from being turned into a military arena. His plea, coming so soon after Commander Carpenter's orbital flight, indicates that the Administration would do well to take another look at its plans to explode several hydrogen bombs in space.

The medieval, agrarian rite of Rogation was re-enacted yesterday in the formal garden of St. John's in the Village Episcopal Church, 218 West Eleventh Street. The Rev. Charles Howard Graf officiated. The rites of Rogation were developed in sixth-century Gaul

WASHINGTON, May 27 The public-hearing phase of the confused and confusing Billie Sol Estes case opens tomorrow with Republicans hoping to place a major scandal on the Kennedy Administration's doorstep.

WASHINGTON, May 27 (UPI) The United States detonated today the fourteenth in its new nuclear-test series in the Christmas Island area of the Pacific. The atomic device, exploded in the atmosphere, was dropped from an airplane.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 27 Casey Stengel's Mets lost both ends of a double header to the Giants today, but at the same time managed to regale a gathering of 39,551 with an uproarious afternoon. In the opener, marked by a seventh-inning free-for-all, the Mets bowed to the team they...

RYE, N.Y., May 27 On an afternoon of flukey breezes calculated to make skippers wish they had remained ashore, Joseph G. Burbeck's Cyrano won the annual Eye-Opener series for Star Class boats today. Burbeck, who won last year with Capster, carried off top

CENTERVILLE, Iowa, May 27 (UPI) The Civil Aeronautics Board said tonight the blast that ripped apart a Continental jetliner Tuesday night, killing forty-five persons, occurred in the lavatory on the right side of the plane.

Four walks in the eighth inning against the pitching of Paul Foytack of Detroit represented the greatest concentration of Yankee power in the second game of a double-header at the Stadium yesterday. Little wonder, then, that the champions, who had won the opener, 4 1, on Moose Skowron's ninthinning homer, concluded their home stand with a 5 1 setback.

AMSTERDAM, May 27 The market here moved lower all last week on lack of demand, which reflected the weakness on Wall Street and other foreign bourses. The only encouraging feature was that the decline took place in diminished activity.

Adlai E. Stevenson, United States Representative at the United Nations, said yesterday he intended to press for changes that would increase the United Nations' ability to enforce decisions aimed at keeping the peace.
ROME, May 28 (AP)-- Elizabeth Taylor did her death scene as Cleopatra today, and the long-worried stockholders of Twentieth Century-Fox couldn't be happier.

James Richard Hurst, tenor, made his New York debut at Carnegie Recital Hall last night. His program was arranged in the conventional way, according to language. The groups were in Italian, French, German and English, with Mozart's "Il Mio tesoro inatanto," also in Italian, preceding the last group.
WASHINGTON, May 28--The Supreme Court took the following actions today:

MINNEAPOLIS, May 27-- Hundreds of high school valei dictorians in Minnesota, the Dakotas and western Wisconsin have been looking forward to an event almost as important as graduation--seeing their pictures in The Minneapolis Tribune.
DOVER, Del., May 28 (UPI) --Two empty life rafts were found today in the area where an Air Force C-133 Carbomaster disappeared yesterday with six men aboard.

Sales and earnings of three major department store chains reported yesterday increases over the corresponding periods a year ago. A smaller chain, however, had a larger deficit and lower sales volume than last Year.

WASHINGTON, May 28 (AP)--The Supreme Court refused today to reconsider its April 23 decision that the Michigan. Supreme Court should take another look at the fairness of that state's legislative districts.
DETROIT, May 28 (AP)-- Jim Bunning held the Baltimore Orioles to three hits tonight in a 5-1 victory by the Detroit Tigers.
LONDON, May 28--John A. C. Robertson, Under Secretary of the British Treasury, died yesterday in his home. His age was 49.
MIAMI May 28--The Alliance for Progress has got off to an "excellent start," deLesseps S. Morrison, United States delegate to the Organization of American States, said here today.
WASHINGTON, May 28-- United States-Soviet talks on Berlin are to resume here this week in the midst of continuing efforts to restore a united front in the Western Alliance.
WHITE PLAINS, May 28-- Mayor Stanley W. Church of New Rochelle was recommended tonight as the Democratic nominee for Representative from the Twenty-sixth Congressional District.

SHORT HILLS, N.J., May 28--J. Herbert Woolley of 75 Oakview Terrace, co-owner of the Woolley Fuel Company here and a former Police Commissioner of Millburn Township, died today in Istanbul, Turkey, while on vacation. He was 62 years old.

SINCE the Irish have a great gift for gab, the proceedings at the Martinique Teatre, where the stage version of James Joyce's "A Portrait of the Artist as a Young Man" and Joseph Carroll's curtain raiser, "The Barroom Monks," opened last night, were not a complete, loss.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, May 28--The Yugoslav Government announced today that President Tito has been invited to visit the Soviet Union this summer. No date or other details have yet been decided.
PURCHASE, N.Y., May 28-- The Rev. Robert I. Gannon, former President of Fordham University, defended liberal arts colleges today as "one of the most vital forces in our national culture."

Joseph Cotten will return to Broadway in "A Calculated Risk" on Oct. 31. He will portray an industrial leader in Joseph Hayes' play. It will be staged by Robert Montgomery and presented under the auspices of Howard Erskine and Mr. Hayes.
"I NEVER saw a purple bee, I never hope to see one," might have been the paraphrased musing of some serious trout fishermen on Eastern streams over the week-end.

District Attorney Frank D. O'Connor of Queens, a declared candidate for the Democratic nomination for Governor, accused Governor Rockefeller last night of allowing New York to become a "second-class" state.
VIENNA, May 28--Restored at considerable cost, the 162year-old Theater an der Wien was solemnly rededicated this evening to music and drama.
Catullus, the little bay colt purchased for $16,000 by the Greentree Stable at the Saratoga Sales last August, earned more than his selling price with a magnificent effort at Aqueduct yesterday.
CENTERVILLE, Iowa, May 28 (UPI)--Federal investigators said today a suicide-bent passenger might have planted a fused dynamite-type of explosive that shattered a Continental Airlines jet last week.
Agents of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company went on 'strike yesterday in the greater New York area.

WASHINGTON, May 28 (AP)--The Supreme Court denied a hearing today to Levi S. McDonald, who was convicted in two trials in two Oregon counties for dynamiting trucks used by The Portland Oregonian-Oregon Journal during a stereotypers strike.

An exhibition and sale of American, English and French furnishings made before 1770 is now being held at Old Westbury Gardens, Old Westbury, L.I., under the auspices of the New York Antiques and Art Dealers Association.
The stock market ticker tape yesterday resembled an automobile-clogged highway on the eve of a big holiday. There was far more traffic than it could handle.

WASHINGTON, May 28 (AP)--The Supreme Court ruled today that employes who walked out of a Baltimore shop to protest excessive cold had engaged in a "concerted activity" protected by the National Labor Relations Act.

BUENOS AIRES, Tuesday, May 29--The first of almost 2,000,000 workers began a twenty-four-hour nation-wide general strike at midnight. The walkout threatened to paralyze many industries and the national railway system.

"A great, great wave of selling" brought on choppy seas, yesterday for La Branche wood Co. member of the New York Stock Exchange and specialist in the storm-tossed stock of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company.

Announcement has been made here by Mr. and Mrs. Henry Ives Cobb Jr. of Mount Kisco, N.Y., of the marriage of their daughter, Miss Sheila Cobb, to Michael de Shee Clarke. His parents are Mr. and Mrs. Richard Warner Clarke of Katonah, N. Y. The Rev. John Shields performed the ceremony Saturday at St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church in Katonah.

Gary Gubner, who has enjoyed a great year as a record-shattering shot-putter received the New York University Alumni Trophy at the Violets' annual Sports Awards Dinner last night at University Heights.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 29 (AP)--All except one of the thirty-three starters roared around Indianapolis Speedway today in the final shakedown for the 500-mile Memorial Day race. The yellow caution light flashed twice, but a 462-foot broadside skid by Gene Hartley as his engine blew was the only mishap during the three-hour carburetion test.

GREENWICH, Conn., May 28--An August wedding is planned by Miss Lynne Averill Warner, whose parents, Mr. and Mrs. Beverly Walden Warner, have made known her engagement to Rhys Evans. His parents are Mr. and Mrs. Albert E. Evans of Dorset, Vt.
CLEVELAND, May 28 (AP) --Early Wynn, Chicago's 42year-old pitching marvel, hurled a three-hit shutout tonight for his 295th career victory as the White Sox beat the Indians, 2--0.
PIERMONT, N.Y., May 28-- St. John's Roman Catholic Church, a 100-year-old historic structure on River Road, was destroyed this afternoon in a fire visible for miles up and down the Hudson Valley.
The Commerce and Industry Association of New York suggested that minimum crews of longshoremen work at night on steamship piers to receive and discharge truck cargoes.
HYANNIS, Mass., May 28 (UPI)--Four more Southern Negroes arrived in this Cape Cod resort today. A man who came yesterday left for New York City.

An automatic field separation complex capable of handling up to 28,000 barrels of oil daily is being shipped from Tulsa, Okla., to South America to help speed the flow of crude oil from the jungles of Colombia.

Net earnings of Sears, Roebuck Co. for the first quarter of fiscal 1962 were a record of $31,899,874, the giant retailer reported yesterday. This represented an increase of 37.4 per cent from the $23,217,974 cleared in the quarter ended on April 30, 1961.

St. Louis, Mo., borrowed $4,500,000 on the bond market yesterday for sewer improvements at an interest cost of 3.6233 per cent. Lehman Brothers and Phelps, Fenn Co. bought the issue of serial bonds maturing from 1964 to 1992 and reoffered the obligations to yield from 2 to 3.75 per cent.
CHICAGO, May 28--Volume on the Midwest Stock Exchange was 235,000 shares today. A normal day's trading would be between 150,000 to 200,000 shares.

CAPETOWN, South Africa, May 28--Prime Minister Hendrik F. Verwoerd's controversial sabotage bill passed its first parliamentary hurdle tonight amid growing indications that its passage into law within a few weeks was assured.
PHILADELPHIA, May 28-- Mrs. Flora Morris Vare, the first woman to serve in the Pennsylvania Senate, died yester day in Lankenau Hospital. She was 88 years old and lived in near-by Ardmore.
Roland Hayes will mark his seventy-fifth birthday Sunday with an afternoon recital at Carnegie Hall.

THOSE jewels of consistency, the New York Mets, groped their way back home at dawn yesterday like sleep walkers. This is not too far-fetched an analogy. Ever since they left on a disastrous excursion of the wild and woolly West they have been shy on two commodities--sleep and victory. Ballplayers thrive on each. The Mets obviously have not been thriving.

Does principle take precedence over party loyalty? Will conscience get the upper hand over political regularity? The "reform" Democrats answer "no" if they wind up supporting Representative Charles A. Buckley of the Bronx for re-election to his House seat.
JOHN O'HARA's "The Big Laugh"* ig a searching historical novel of Hollywood's medieval era, when sound was coming in and the earliest pioneers were fading into Sunset Boulevard,
While Wall Street doctors were groping for a means of controlling the selling epidemic on the stock market, it became obvious yesterday that the disease had spread to areas of the bond market.

WANT to learn some of the secrets of good bowling? Then listen to a conversation between a couple of fine bowlers who discuss their problems on the lanes. Such eavesdropping recently disclosed that a bowler should try to roll his regular style of hook most of the time and that the best way to keep from getting hurt is to keep the bowling hand in good shape.
OCEANPORT, N.J., May 28 --Lloyd N. Sickles, a former Borough Councilman and a member of the Board of Education here, died yesterday at Monmouth Medical Center in Long Branch. His age was 72.

KAMPALA, Uganda, May 2$ (Reuthers) ---- Pian tribesmen murdered 107 men, women and children of the neighboring Suk tribe in northeast Uganda last week, Internal Affairs minister William Nadiope told Parliament today.
Southern Airways officials said yesterday they would appeal a tentative Civil Aeronautics Board ruling against the carrier in its two-year dispute with the pilots' union.

A syndicate of New Jersey investors headed by Mortimer L. Schultz of Plainfield has bought the Park Central Apartments, a seven-story biulding at 490 Park Avenue, southeast corner of Thirty-first Street, Paterson, N.J. The price was more than $1,400,000.

A prediction that earnings this year will rise to 75 cents a share was made yesterday by Sherman Simon, chairman of Floyd Bennett Stores, Inc. The company's net income was 35 cents a share in 1961 and 3 cents a share the year before.
An Eastern Airlines plane with a jammed nose wheel circled ninety minutes last night before skidding to a safe landing on a foam-decked runway at New York International Airport.

STANTON, Del., May 28 (AP)--Jack Welch's Weatherton became the first stakes winner of the fifty-four-day thoroughbred racing meeting that opened today at Delaware Park. Weatherton beat the favorite, Rose Net, by two and a quarter lengths in the $11,200 Wilmington Handicap.
NEW ORLEANS, May 28 (AP)--A panel of three state judges reversed today the conviction of George Lincoln Rockwell and nine of his followers on charges of disturbing the peace.

CHICAGO, May 28--The Continental Casualty Company will offer persons 65 and older health insurance plans providing coverage for in and out-ofhospital expenses and prescription drugs, Roy Tuchbreiter, its chairman, said today.

A housewife who lives on Montgomery Avenue in the Bronx opened her door recently and was greeted by an unfamiliar but smiling milk delivery man who appeared to be about to hand her a free quart of milk.

While most women are concentrating on their summer wardrobes, America's designers are busy showing fall clothes. These collections, this country's equivalent of the Paris operatings in July will continue through the middle of June. They attract store executives and buyers from all over the country to Seventh Avenue, New York's garment center. Reports on trends from significant designers will be... given here. The clothes will be in stores beginning in late July.
WASHINGTON, May 28--The Post Office Department announced today that it was rescinding all bulk-mail transporting contracts with companies operated by Thomas W. Doran, a Buffalo trucker.

WASHINGTON, May 28 (AP)--The Supreme Court refused today to hear an appeal by a Philadelphia teacher who was dismissed by the city school board on the grounds of incompetence after he had been accused of refusing to cooperate in a loyalty inquiry.
WASHINGTON, May 28 (UPI)--American Airlines said today it would cut fares if the proposed 5-per-cent cut in the Federal air transportation tax was approved.

The Curtis Publishing Company and its domestic subsidiaries had a net loss of $4,727,337 in the first quarter this year on gross revenues of $55,575,091, the report disclosed yesterday. In the first three months last year the publishing company's loss was $1,863,168, after deducting a deficit of $261,657 from the sale of securities. Gross revenues were $60,900,506.
Severe traffic bottlenecks because of construction are expected in the following areas marked on the map over Memorial Day, according to a survey by the Automobile Club of New York:
WASHINGTON, May 28 (AP)--The Supreme Court threw out today a California jury's award of damages under the Sherman Antitrust Law against Sunkist Growers, Inc., and two affiliated organizations.
Senator Jacob K. Javits called yesterday for an $8,000,000 increase in the annual budget of the United States Travel Service in a bid to attract more tourists to this country.
WASHINGTON, May 28 (UPI)--The United States will open a series of three or four high-altitude nuclear blasts over Johnston Island in the Pacific in about four days, the Government said today.
An issue of $15,000,000 of Copenhagen Telephone Company, Inc., debentures was marketed yesterday at a price to yield 5.95 per cent.
William H. McKeon, the new Democratic state chairman, proposed some sweeping changes in the state election law last night and in methods of financing campaigns.
WASHINGTON, May 28--Authorities here regard the decline in the stock market as primarily a reaction to the fact that stock prices were too high in relation to existing and prospective economic
LOS ANGELES, May 28 (AP)--Archie Moore chased Willie Pastrano throughout their ten-round fight tonight, but had to settle for a draw before a crowd of about 3,000 in the Sports Arena.

MARBLEHEAD, Mass., May 28--The Boston Yacht Club's 12-Meter sloop Nefertiti went under sail for the first time today off this port, and the impression she left on her afterguard and critics was most favorable.
The non-Communist world is growing in strength and unity, Harlan Cleveland, Assistant of State for Internatinal Organization Affairs, said last night.
The weakness in the stock markets affected the commodity markets yesterday as most contracts traded on the New York exchanges fell.
BONN, Germany, May 28-- Leaders for nearly a million civil servants and workers employed by the Government threatened authorities today with a work stoppage unless the unions pay demands were met.

The marriage of Miss Barbara Tunmore to Harrison Whittingham Conrad Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Conrad of New York and Fair Haven, N. J., took place yesterday in the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. John J. Tunmore of 430 East Fifty-seventh Street.

DENVER, May 28 (UPI)Lieut. Comdr. M. Scott Carpenter came home to Colorado as a hero today. He was greeted by 500 cheering fellow Coloradans as he started two and a half days of acclaim in Boulder and Denver.

WASHINGTON, May 28 (AP)--The Supreme Court refused today for the second time to review the trial of a group of men serving life sentences for the $1,219,000 Brink's armoredcar service robbery in Boston.
Alberto Severgnini, senior partner in the Buenos Aires law firm of Severgnini Robiola, died yesterday in his home at 165 East Seventy-second Street. He was 69 years old.
